40287900.review:
I'm not a fan of frustration for the sake of frustration. This game is all about it. First, it's a clunky interface. You have to select and confirm every action at least twice. I can forgive the lack of tutorial. It's supposed to be a survival game. But it should be a little more intuitive on how actions work; this is especially true with the crafting system. The interface is similar to old fallout games but without the feedback on whether or not actions may lead to a certain result. Too many menus within menus. Too much RNG grind in the hopes that you might find enough gear before getting eaten by random dogs; or killed by a stranger who is always faster than you, and for some reason, is really fond of your hospital gown because that's the only thing of value on your character. I say random dogs because stray dogs are apparent. Random dogs just show up on top of you.

There's really no variety to the gameplay other than the few story choices that only lead to one result. The randomness that does exist is clearly skewed against the player. I have to replay the same starting sequence of events for 15 minutes each time I have to restart. Just let me skip it. Or put in a reloadable save state. So glad I got it on sale.

Graphics: 3/10 - pixel art is ok. Gameplay: 2/10 - clunky, not intuitive, RNG hell, linear story with veil of real choices. You won't survive long even with good gameplay because RNG says screw you.

40204028.review:
OldSchool immersive post apoc sim with a huge learning curve and extremely detailed MUD-Like text system. It's a game that's so complex and unforgiving that at times it can seem buggy but it was actually the game punishing you. Think a metal cooking pot makes a handy weapon? It DOES!!! You can also store things in it and use it to boil water. Ok combat time... did you remember to empty it before the encounter? OH NOES now the game won't let you attack or pull out the objects because your opponent closed to range too quickly. Worst of all... THE GAME DOESNT TELL YOU ANY OF THIS WHILE IT IS HAPPENING so it feels like you're glitched and simply can't attack.

You can save your progess on exit but only have 1 character going at a time. With Perma-Death turned on you have to be extra thoughtful as to plan out every turn and it is VERY possible to create broken characters that are too feeble to advance beyond the first few minutes before freezing to death or getting mauled by a dog. Some skills are extremely intricate and detailed while others are more passively blah but the appeal is "just one more turn" in a solid setting and mildly interesting story-arc. Neo-Scav is a rogue like blend of Civ and Fallout 2 that is well worth the price on sale.

40146168.review:
This game is Brutal. To the Nth degree. At first it feels like your standard character-based isometric RPG- there's even a lot of emotion despite the lowrent unanimated graphics, brings me back to 1998. 

Then it slugs you right in the chest. 

My first run, things were going well. I'd found a crowbar and killed several dozen dogs. This was sustaining me nicely. 

As if to tell me to get off my ass and find a quest, the game spawned in a WRAITH. A literal demon from Hell. I ran. It killed me in one hit. 

The next two runs I died from hypothermia, but then I got the mechanics down. 

Okay, so let's go out, explore. Once I had the basics of the game down, I went cross country. Killed men by the dozens. Literally slaughtered about forty people. I had a military rifle, two scopes, a meat cleaver, water for days, plenty of armor, no danger of hypothermia- I was the man. Unfortunately, survival had turned me into a remorseless cannibal. Felt bad. So, when I saw a stranger on the road, I decided to leave her alone. Then she approached me. I tried saying hello. 

She shot me with a 12-GA slug. It collapsed my ribcage and I died before anything else happened. 

I really dig how the combat functions on a basis of injury, not HP. It's possible to kill in one hit with your fists, or get stunlocked by a dog and mauled to death. It's also possible to take on entire platoons alone if you get a little lucky and know how to rock their asses. Fun as hell, if slightly frustrating. 

It was like three bucks.
Buy this game.

40109171.review:
EDIT: Ironic that the day after I buy this game it goes on sale. $12 I could have saved. L E L

True gritty post-apocalyptic survival games (that do it right) are hard to come by. That's why I was excited after seeing NEO Scavenger's intricate gameplay, despite its underwhelming aesthetic presentation. Unfortunately, after about 7 hours of gameplay, I can say for sure that NEO Scavenger is wasted potential.

To break down the flaws of this game - and there are many - let's address the largest of the bunch: the UI. I'm not doubting the dev's intelligence, but I can't wrap my head around how someone could push through a UI as clunky and confusing as NEO Scavenger's. Everything about it is plain awful. And this is not a generality - the ENTIRE UI is a nightmare to navigate. Crafting. Combat. Exploring. Making in-game decisions. All of it is unbelievably tedious due to the UI. Its difficult to get more specific when everything about it is so poorly implemented. All I can recommend is to gut the UI completely. There's no saving it. Its THAT bad.

Next up is the audio. NEO Scavenger from first glance seems like it has good atmosphere, and you'd think a gritty post-apoc survival game would benefit greatly from good audio, but NEO Scavenger fails to impress. Items have stock sounds when you click them. Players make footsteps only when you move a tile. There's music... occasionally. But other than that, the majority of the game seems to have no sound or ambiance whatsoever. Combat has no sound effects, so that coupled with the UI makes for an underwhelming experience, as is most of the rest of the game in this regard.

There's a growing trend with indie games to make stupidly difficult, rogue-like, Dark Souls-esque games for the sake of "challenge". NEO Scavenger tries to jump on this trend as well, but does it even more poorly than the rest. The game's learning curve, first and foremost, is a 90-degree incline upwards. You have to waste at least a few hours dying and restarting, along with consulting the wiki, to figure the game out. Learning the game was a small bit of fun for me, but was easily eclipsed by the tedium of dying of hypothermia, reselecting my character traits, fighting the dogman, rinse and repeat. A huge problem with the game's formula is that each death sets you back far more than what's reasonable. Its similar to Getting Over It by Bennet Foddy, except each time you fall (death), you go back to the beginning of the game. Having to start at step one again and again is the definition of tedium, and entirely ruins the experience - I'm not kidding. The game gives you zero incentive to want to rescavenge the world, collect a trove of items, suit yourself up, and set off into the wilderness, because death can quite literally be random. You could accidentally drink tainted water. A dogman could kill you in your sleep (even with half a dozen noise traps lying around). In-combat RNG could just hate you at that particular moment. Several events can even kill you in a Choose Your Own Adventure Book fashion, which in a game like Scavenger, is uncalled for. You may as well spoil the story for yourself on the wiki too, because the story in-game is anything but compelling or intriguing, and not worth pursuing by itself. Overall, crafting/item collecting and permadeath together is akin to a peanut butter and anchovy sandwhich - the two do NOT mix. Its just bad game design, plain and simple, and its tragic that NEO Scavenger went this direction. It would be so much better otherwise.

I previously mentioned dying of hypothermia. This is what all new players will face when starting the game. You wake up in a hospital gown (not a preferred outfit to survive the post-apoc) and you quickly become hypothermic. If you can't find warm clothing in the first 6 to 8 in-game hours, you die, and go back to square one. No competent game does this for its early-game. You at least let the player experience a meaningful tidbit of the game before shoving them into the meat grinder. What Scavenger should have done is offered the player warm but low-quality clothing that will quickly degrade, as to at least give them a fighting chance to scavenge for more clothes and give a more consistent early-game experience (no, being forced to choose the Trapping skill to get the Dogman fur coat doesn't cut it). Consistency is another issue - the world map is, for the most part, randomly generated, and this means that not all new games will allow you to find clothes in time. You just have to die and start over because you got a bad roll - sorry bucko. The game tries to show how brutal and unforgiving it is, but instead flops on its back, twitching and making spit bubbles.

Not necessarily part of the NEO Scavenger experience, but I did notice that the game advertises another Steam game, Project Zomboid. I was hugely disappointed the dev chose to do this. Project Zomboid is a game stuck in Early Access hell, where the developers have overpromised and underperformed for years, and do a weekly monday blog blathering about nonsense instead of delivering the product people paid for. What's worse is that anyone who criticizes the dev team or their moderators are quickly banned for "bad behavior". They are also known to demonize and strawman critics if banning isn't enough. I'd pick NEO Scavenger's flawed game any day over a more-refined-by-comparison game like Zomboid soley due to Zomboid's disingenuous developer team. Its very disappointing that Blue Bottle Games would advert for them, and they've done so for years at this point.

There are more minor grievances I have with Scavenger, like how sterilized water shouldn't include other sterilized water in its recipe, the "no moves left to craft" UI nuisance, combat chance % never given despite life or death depending on it, but that would take much longer to write up. Overall, with what I've put forward here, people will get the jist of the huge flaws with the game, and will make more informed decisions as to whether or not a purchase is warranted. Its been years since the last update (which is unfortunate), but I do hope Blue Bottle Games revisits NEO Scavenger and makes meaningful changes and updates to the game, because it really did have a lot of potential, and would be worth its $15 price tag rather than $10 or less.

For now, though, its about as rickety and run down as the buildings you loot from.

40055941.review:
Is this game good? Well it depends what you are looking for..

This game feels pretty much cobbled together, a lot of quests are not working properly and you pretty much need to look up everything in an wiki to actually progress..

When you follow the quest you are given a few options to handle things, if you chose the wrong option - you are dead. Easy as that. Then you can grind all your gear again and start over.

The map is not really procedurally generated, it has the feel to it but the landmarks are at the same spot all the time.

I encountered many quests that I just didn't get (and didn't work properly due to bad scripting), it did not explain anything to me and if you do a single mistake your save is garbage. 

This game doesn't hold your hand, it will throw you into a world without even telling you how to survive temperature. There are a lot of random stuff you would never figure out like to use the "trapping" skill with the "dogmans" body will make a coat? This is not only silly but who would even try that?

After about dying ~10 Times you will get the hang of the basic system of the game - use everything at your disposal to stay away from the dogmans. After this the game is pretty much done if you are careful enough.



I can't really recommend it, it's not pretty, its very niche and it's novelty wears down after some time.. I spent a lot of time with it because I just wanted to figure out if there is more to it (which there is not sadly). Is it worth the steep price-tag?  No.. I played better games for less money.

Though you notice this is a labor of love, so many details, nice thought-out systems and small things that make you smile. But be prepared to lose everything over and over again and not like in Dark souls where a narrative is driving you - or at least there is something of meaning behind it, no.. It will just kill you and you have to start over and hope for good loot.. Otherwise you can start again. This is a typcial wiki game.

39830085.review:
An absolutely superb game. There are some balance issues, but it really all adds back to the experience. I have yet to have another game deliver the feeling I have playing this game other than S.T.A.L.K.E.R, in which I actually constantly feel in danger while also being stunned by all that the game world has to offer me. The game is also aesthetically pleasing in the same way S.T.A.L.K.E.R. is in the sense that everything is very rustic/post-apocalyptic, similiar to other titles such as Rust where there is a true sense of a civilization that has once collapsed, rather than just a few abandoned structures placed willy nilly there are actual houses/cities in a tile-based environment with lengthy descriptions attached to them that are an absolute treat to read into.

The game also hosts an excessive amount of content, so much so that you could play hours upon hours of the game and still be enthralled by it. Every piece of content you discover serves it's own purpose as well. Even the most redundant looking of things can be used in their own fashion. Being chased? Just throw rocks at whatever is chasing you. I guess what I'm trying to say is that no content is just there to be there. Nearly everything serves it's own purpose, be it sinister or not.

Speaking of sinister, the game's lore/backstory is probably one of the most interesting to read into. Within ten minutes of launching the game and starting your first run the first few thoughts you will be having is "Just how did the world end up like this?". The best part of it all is that this question is never really specifically answered, (at least it hasn't been for me yet) but there are multiple pieces of information scattered around the world such as old newspapers, the conversations you have with people and the creatures you come across that allow the player to make their own conclusions on the subject. 

One thing that must be said about Neo: Scavenger, however, is that the game is not for the fient of heart. Those who have a hard time wrapping their heads around a plethora of game mechanics will quickly find themselves dying unfairly from a rather large amount of things simply because they do not know how to approach the subject. One of the game mechanics I got stuck on for a while is the combat. I was dying from some of the easiest foes rather quickly because I did not know how to properly fight at all. I had the proper equipment, but I just was simply pulling it off all wrong. This was especially annoying because of the fact that Neo: Scavenger has a rather punishing perma-death mechanic, but in the end it all became clear and soon I was dispatching those same enemies with ease.

While I was having a relatively easy time with those enemies, they certainly weren't underestimatable. A swift blow to the head by one of them could land you concussed or stunned and make the fight unexpectedly more harder for you. Certain enemies also exhibit pack-like behaviour, (not just dogs!) which could land you in some sticky situations. Every fight I've ever gotten into in this game feels like a real fight for my life, and the outcome is never truly understood untill the fight is finished. Sometimes it isn't even the fight that kills you, but the wounds or other effects afterwards that can send you to your grave, such as the Blue Frog cult, a dangerous cult that intentionally infects people with a disease they worship.

Overall the game is very pleasureable (in a masochistic way) to play and extremely punishing yet rewarding. The blend of mechanics in the game is superb, the combat is superb, the lore is superb, the feel of the game is superb, just everything about it is fucking superb. I highly reccomend this game to anyone who is even a slight fan of rogue-likes, survival games or just a fan of a fun challenge.

39718019.review:
***MINOR SPOILERS AHEAD***  This game should be renamed "Survival 101" as most of the things you learn in this game are legitimate tactics of survival. Some seem obvious, like boiling your drinking water. Others far less so. Anyway...the game starts with you waking up in a cryo chamber with no memory whatsoever. Worse? Something is coming, and you don't have much time to react. Quickly now...

Like many rouge-element games, this one has you managing the usual suspects regarding your character: hunger, thirst, sleep, etc.  It also contains some character customization parts that you select at the game's start and generally easy to learn mechanics (like you need Botany to scavenge and identify which plants are safe vs. poisonous and someone with Trapping makes more use of animal carcasses, etc.).

Anyway, I measured my progress as a player not in how many enemies I killed/avoided, or how much I explored, but in how much of the story I uncovered and how long I had survived in-game.  Seems kinda silly, but when you first start playing surviving an in-game week is nearly impossible. Even seasoned players still find it challenging sometimes. The random events were a neat touch too, adding another flavor of tension to the game of survival.

So take a crack at it, die a few times and then come up with a seemingly genius plan....find all the right stuff you need....and then die anyway because you forgot to cover your tracks and a thug found you while you were sleeping and blasted your head off (been there). Then realize you don't know jack, and that until late game you'll be flying by the seat of your pants the whole way. No plan is perfect, and this game proves that very well. So prep your character and your buttocks, because NEO Scavenger is a ride you won't soon forget.

39645706.review:
There's something maddening about death. Perhaps the whole 'dying' aspect has a part in that. But something truly rewarding comes along with the sour taste of a bullet tearing through your fur coat and hospital gown. This game has no true direct path, But many smaller ones that you, The player decide. Every little move could be your last, It could be deciding to leave those bullets behind, Only for a good seven weeks later, You run out of ammo for your handgun or rifle, And really regret not dropping your scraps of cloth for those rounds. Or it could be deciding to not prepare a suitable camp for the night, and a 9 foot beast come tearing through your camp, and you. It could even be greed, Going for that guy with the cozy looking coat, Only to be on the recieving end of a crowbar from his buddy. This game truly is not for the faint of heart, But I'd be lying if I said it wasn't fun to die in the most horrible ways. This game is perma death, And you can die in an instant, But it's fun to close a door and open another. I'd give this game a solid 9/10. Of course, No game is perfect, There's some tedious menus that could be fixed, A lot less clicking to craft or switch turns, But that's one of my few and more notable complains. Here's a more simplistic list.

Pros:
Immersive descriptions of post apocolyptic Detroit, or modern day depending on which side of the city you're on.

In depth medical system. You can get the runs from drinking dirty water, Or slowly die of infection from a stab wound.

Combat is rather good, A lot of variety on what to do, Including talking, Taunting, Tripping, Hiding, Shooting, Poking with a sharp object, and more.

Massive map. I have played my fair share, And have yet to see the whole world. Not to mention it is randomly generated with a wide variety of events.

Loot. You can find everything. From ketchup packets to high caliber sniper rifles, To CDs and laptops. (That actually work!)

Animals and enemies. While there are a basic set of enemies, There's enough variety to give unique encounters and risk, From wild dogs to armored soldiers with machine guns.

Armor system. You can wear masks to protect from disease such as mold or airborne viruses. You can wear coats to protect from the cold, Shirt, Pants/shorts too. You can sling your crowbar or rifle onto your back for carrying. You can put binoculars around your neck for easy access, Even left and right shoes, And so much more. Not to mention some of the amazing mods that add gloves and scarves and misc items into the game.

Vehicles. While, Understandably, There are no cars or trucks in the game without mods at the least, There are shopping carts, sleds, box carts, and such to carry even more valuables. This does however, Give you major speed debuffs. So haul carefully.

Crafting. This game has a rather large array of crafting, From trapping to herbalism, To ranged weapons, to sharpening a spear or making a glass shank.

Story. While the story is a bit basic, It gives that New Vegas vibe. There's an end goal, But it's not something you need to focus on. Of course, If you want to win you have to, But you're going to want to drink and eat a wee bit before you go on a crusade.

Cons:

Menus. The menu system can be a bit finnicky, It involves a lot of tabs you have to manage to open things as you go. Thankfully, You kind of get used to it, And it's a turn based game so you don't have to worry for time.

Punishment. While this may not seem like a negative to most, Not even to me, It is understandable that this game can be rather angering. One wrong move and you can lose hours of progress and have to start over. Make sure you know what you are getting yourself into before you buy. It's no casual game.

Encounters. While some encounters are brilliantly crafted, There are a few that can be end game scenarios. Such as one, Which I will not give specifics, Where you must go investigate something or you can leave. If you investigate, it is an instant death, With no chance to save yourself. These events occur often, Even into late game, so do be careful for those as they can be the most punishing out of all aspects of the game.

Balance. While I do believe this game has done amazingly well for the survival feel, I can't help but point out that it is extremely difficult to do without specific perks. Such as botany which allows you to forage for berries. I've always had a lot more difficulty not choosing botany, As you can go many turns without seeing so much as a can of soup or stale crackers. This isn't really a major issue though, As it's not game breaking.

That is all I have to say about this game, It's very very fun, I certainly suggest buying it if these pros and cons sound fair. If you disagree with anything I have to say, Feel free to comment. If you have questions, Feel free as well. Though I won't go responding to negative things, So please be a bit gentle with the shunning.

39582945.review:
dont be too easily put off by what you see in the screenshots or videos. sure, neo scavenger isnt the prettiest game out there, and the ui is a bit clunky. but underneath all that, is a very good example of how a survival game should be.

there's so much learn, and so much to do, in every playthrough in this post apocalyptic world. and there WILL be a LOT of playthroughs, because you will die ... a lot. you will learn what skills are important to your playstyle. you will learn to be picky about what you want to bring along. you will learn there are times to fight, and there are also times to run. and more importantly you will learn that death could potentially lie behind every corner. from eating the wrong berries because of the lack of a botany skill, or engaging in what seems like an easy fight, only to slip and fall at the wrong moment.

yet somehow, the game keeps pulling you back for more, as you continuously torture yourself ... all in all, it's a really good rogue-like survival game, and you wont find too many that are better than neo scavenger.

39469632.review:
I have been playing neo scavanger for years now and got it when it was first on steam and boy has the game changed since then
This is one of the rare cases of early acess games actually releasing with all there promises and being a truely full game and it shows. But this game has a large ammount of flaws

Pros: 
The game has a lot of content and you can tell. Whether it be events, Uniqe locations and items there feels like a lot in the game and unlike most rouge likes it will take many playthroughs to really understand the mechanics. 22 hours in and i still feel like a beguiner when it comes down to things

The combat is brutal and fair and fast. Its simple and works really well but does take some imagination.

The medical system works wonders. Instead of looking at some health bar you need to manage everything from your imune system to blood loss and pain and more. Around half your deaths will just be from infections and water based dieses. 

Replayability is something ill bring up again but the game is quite replayable. The map is randomly generated to an extent (Uniqe locations spawn in the same spots but the map layout itself is random) 

The game is pretty fair. Unlike some games you dont really have these rng dice role events. When you die it feels like it was your fault and your fuckup and you will find yourself saying "well i wont do that nextime" 
You get infected, learn to purify water
You get shot in the chest and bleed out, Dont attack the DMC guards with a sauce pan
You starve to death, Resort to canibilism
Your character starts to become a maniac and fears he will run out of human meat to eat, Just go back to normal food

Theres plenty of mechanics to also keep things detailed. Spying and hiding to body heat and plenty of skills
The game is relativly balanced and it is quite adicting to gear up and have fun
The game will also not hold your hand and your basicly free the entire game


Cons:
Death sucks in this game. Unlike many other rouge likes theres not much of a progression system exept for personal knowlage and a few random skills. But the bigest killer is restarting
You will die tons of times and the game doesnt diffreneciate itself enough to render you really dont much diffrent run to run. Sure you will learn but it will turn to you going through the exact same motions many times of loot, fight, die over and over. You will almost always head to detroit then do whatever quest the hatter gives you and you will do this many times as you learn from experience what to do and not to do. It can make playing this game for long periods of time very frustrating.

NPC's are a disapointment to me. Back in early access it was fine to have the "Conversations" be basicly a "fuck off" from every npc willing to talk and a crowbar to the face from the rest. There is basicly no interaction to be had with random npcs in the world. You can either
Kill them
Surrender
Make them surrender
Cease fire
Run away
Or talk. And talking usually is nothing but them saying "i dont want to talk" and walking off. There are no real conversations to be had and the few that you do have usually are very short and formulaic with no real branch off's and as you replay this game over and over again you will read the same things over and over again. Its just disapointing

The game may be fair but its also brutally hard. This is a pro and a con depending on the person but there are many times you will just die for shit that is almost unavoidable. You get infected with Blue rot because you accidently went 4 tiles in range on some random npc then see ya. Unless you know exactly how to get the one cure in the game through an event then your as good as dead.

The UI can just feel cluncy and weird at times. Like scavanging mutliple buildings sometimes requires you to go through 3-4 menus and sometimes will boot you out if you find nothing. It gets pretty annoying over time.

Detroit is a disapointment in a lot of aspects. Its basicly 5 little buildings inside with little to do and a couple of shops and shit outside. Theres not much to do and not much to even talk about

Quests and events are very scarce. You will usually just do the hatters quests but if you choose to go in some other direction the game is basicly just run around and survive till you go to detroit




conclusion: the game is fun for 1-2 hour segments every few days or so but gets frustrating in long play throughs and can feel pointless at times. its a great airplane or trip game on a laptop and it is fun but dont expect some amazing rpg. This is basicly a combat symulator with some rng loot thrown in.

39255934.review:
Neo Scavenger, it's one of those more than meets the eye, suprisingly in-depth games, sort of deal.

Is it super high-res ultra 4k HD graphics? No. Does it need to be? No.

What you get is an in-depth survival game set in a post-apocalytic Michigan, with added mythical/urban legends and light supernatural touches. It's a sandbox that you can play until your character dies, or you delete the save to start over, but it does indeed have an actual storyline that comes to a conclusion. It's rather difficult to complete the story as you need to balance survival as you do it, but it's there.

The game isn't easy, you can easily die within your first handful of turns if you don't know what your doing. The game starts you off in an encounter with one of the game's most dangerous enemies. You will have at least one (albeit very poor choice) option on how to handle this encounter, but picking certain traits before starting will open up new and better options for this and future encounters. However this feeds into the difficulty, taking combat orientated traits will make fights easier, but it probably won't help much with finding food, warm clothing and doesn't give much help with the storyline. Of course the opposite is true as well, some traits offer better survival aids, or open up easier routes through the storyline, they all offer an advantage, just not always the best one.

Oh and you're no longer going to die from hypothermia by turn four 90% of the time anymore. That was patched out with a one-time freebie event that will save your ass, yay.

38361940.review:
[h1]1[/h1]

The night was dark. 

It was not the normal darkness that resulted from the lack of light to illuminate the shadows,  it was the dark that suggested that the very concept for light had never existed before it. The kind of darkness that hid all manner of terrible creatures that the mind could only imagine, and even some beyond that. It was the darkness of the void that came before the light and the firmament. 

Damascus wore it as a cloak around him. 

Where other creatures hardly strayed far from the the light, his kind lived and even thrived without its warm touch. The light was as much of a stranger to him as the Yuctou Sea was to the lesser beasts of the Endless Desert. But he did not need the light to ‘see’. He observed all around him as he made his way through the forest by sound alone. He could hear ever chirp, every chitter, every rustle as the breeze blew through the trees. He could hear all manners of nocturnal creatures hunting their prey, just as he was.  

He moved his feet deftly as he made his way through the forest, his feet avoiding any branch to break and leaves to rustle as he silently made his way closer towards the road that cut through the woods, and towards his quarry. 

Odd, Damascus thought to himself as he caught sight of his prey. 

The carriage had stopped in the road, surrounded by men with torches. From here he could hear their voices, geering and snickering. 

“It’s a simple matter, gentlemen.” said one of men, “Pay the toll, and we let you walk away with all your innards staying where they belong, otherwise...” He was talking to the driver of the carriage who sat atop it, holding the reins of his horses , doing his best to keep them from panicking. The driver simply looked at the man, saying nothing. Brigands most likely Damascus thought. 

“Maybe your ears don’t work,” he growled and began to speak louder, “I sai-” he was cut off as an arrow hit him in his chest. He sputtered and groaned as he fell to the ground. The other brigands around him didn’t have time to panic before they too were taken out by more arrows flying through the air. Not one missed their mark. Not one arrow didn’t result in a dead man. 

Several men dressed all in black, wearing bows and quivers on their backs, approached the carriage and knocked on the side. Damascus was surprised he hadn’t noticed them before, but he knew his quarry wasn’t going to travel alone. He was content as they hadn’t noticed him either. 

He was going to have to do this next part carefully, he thought to himself. He readied a stone into his sling, and starting to swing it, slowing picking up speed to make sure the sound didn’t travel far.

A portly man dressed in opulent clothes opened the door of the carriage and leaned out the side. “Is that all of them?” he asked one of the men in black. He nodded. “Good work. I’ll make sure your men receive a bonus once we reach Middlerei-” He stopped for a moment when he noticed one of the men in black turn towards the woods. 

“Is something the matter?” he asked. One of the men had noticed Damascus, staring right at him in the darkness as he swung the sling. There was an attempt to scramble for a bow, but it was too late. He sent the rock flying at tremendous speed, hitting the portly man between the eyes. He slumped forward and hit the ground with a loud thud. 

Damascus didn’t have time to celebrate his kill, though, as the men in black started to fire arrows at him. They were well trained, and perhaps could see well in the dark, but the forest was too dark to keep track of his moving form for long as he weaved through trees and brambles with deftness no human could manage. Many arrows came close though, some too close. He had to dodge one at the last second after hearing it whistling through the air towards him. 

He had ran a mile through the trees before he could no longer hear the men chasing after him, safe once again in the comforting darkness, for now...

Ihr erwacht aus dem Cryoschlaf in einem Labor ohne zu wissen wer ihr seid oder was eure Aufgabe ist. Das erübrigt sich aber recht schnell, denn zunächst einmal müsst ihr überleben! Auf einer Großen, und bei jedem Spielstart generierten Karte bestehend aus Hexagonfeldern bewegt ihr euch zug um zug, untersucht zerfallene Gebäude, sucht nach essen und versorgt eure Wunden und Lädierungen. Ziemlich schnell wird klar das die Zivilisation wie wir sie kennen nicht mehr existiert und durch eine Katastrophe dahin gerafft wurde.

Euch erwartet eine tolle Atmosphäre, ein Postapokalyptischer Soundtrack und viele schmerzhafte Erfahrungen.

Gnadenlos gut!

(NUR FÜR PIXELFETISCHISTEN!)

37968665.review:
Put 4 hours into the game giving it a good try.  The short description is - Hard and Unforgiving!  This is a perma-death, loose all your progress, everything is different on new game... kinda game.  I tried several different builds and died constantly.  I was fell upon by dogs more times then I could count with out a weapon.  After the second death it seemed like every place I searched for items, was empty.  So ya, this game is brutal.  Get ready to spend a lot of time getting good. 

Don't get me wrong though.  I love the design of the game.  The idea of it and game play is great.  While I think a easier mode would be nicer or something to make it more enjoyable for us filthy casuals.  It is still a solid game worth playing.  I will probably continue to play it at a later date.

Though if you are not a fan of hard, unforgiving, perma-death games.  Then you might want to steer way from this one.  There are some other great suvival games with just as much strategy and a bit easier.  Though if you want a challenge.  Then get this game.

37804517.review:
This game might be good if you stick with it, but the combination of a very steep learning curve, low accessibility, and scarcity of useful items made me pass on this game. It's a punishing game, make no mistake. You will die, and often. You'll die because you got wounded during the initial encounter (no spoilers) and couldn't find any bandages, you'll die because RNGesus didn't favor you and you haven't been able to find any decent loot and now you're dying of hypothermia quite a lot because you start with only a hospital gown... and you can't take one from someone because they'll most likely have better stats and a cleaver when you only have a piece of broken glass and a handful of dirty rags. 

The lack of a tutorial or even any tips on how to navigate the convoluted UI had me spending most of the time I have on record figuring out how to even play the game- I believe I spent about ten minutes looking for an 'attack' button during my first fight before I realized the game didn't tell me or make any indication that I was apparently too far away from my target. It's not a very intuitive system and you might have to turn to user guides to figure out how to even cook meat, because nothing is obvious and this game holds its mechanics like Gollum would the One Ring... the only difference being that this game isn't the one to rule them all. 

I don't mean to rag on the game. I'm impressed that there are people that can not only survive, but thrive- and enjoy themselves while they do so. Finding loot and actually surviving for a bit is a very nice experience, but these moments are too spread out over a whole lot of dying. In my personal opinion, NEO Scavenger is just too difficult, too tedious, and too unfair to be enjoyable.

37795460.review: Since a long time I've seen a lot of developers publish a variety of games under the "[i]Rogue-like[/i]" flag, now that we have plenty of choices on the genre we have lost track of the origins of the concept, I've seen a lot of people reject the idea of [i]Rogue-Like[/i] as a classification as it is based on a single title (like metroidvanias) and I can understand why, since there are too many titles that replicates aspects of the genre without bringing too much of the original substance to the gameplay. How I understand it, a Rogue-like is a [b]Tabletop-like RPG experience[/b] with [b]high replayability value[/b], and this, is where [b]NEO Scavenger[/b] shines the most. It's difficult to know what the secret ingredient to make a Rogue-like is, surely it goes beyond the system and mechanics. Maybe it is the [b]complexity and depth of the choices spectrum offered to you[/b], maybe it is the [b]knowledge curve and experience that the game demands to explore it[/b], maybe it's the [b]cruelty and the random shitstorm that makes every run special[/b] and a hard-earned experience, [b]NEO Scavenger[/b] has them all, but brings a lot more to the table and makes justice to the genre. I love the ambience of the text-based Points of interest with a simple but effective narrative prowess, I love the map navigation system with tracks and hiding places making the map a very influyent aspect of the game (much more than a shop, a stair up and a stair down), I love all the lore, crazy factions, and characters I've met, I love the eastereggs and crazy small features that enriches the game, but my favorite feature of this game is the brutal combat system, here you can see a wide variety of relevant commands and status that refracts the tide of the battle in their own special way. Forget about hacking and slashing every turn or you'll get your skull crushed onto the floor pretty soon.

37083401.review:
Frustrating... but in a good way!

Apocalyptic survival games are a dime a dozen these days, but very few of them seem to do the genre justice. NEO Scavenger is a good one. It provides a complex survival experience in a simple and clear format, almost emulating a text-adventure feel.

Most importantly, the game is challenging. It doesn't hold your hand and simply drops you into the apocalypse. If you like games that let you figure out the best way for you to play, you may enjoy this. So far, I've died of hypothermia, infection, acute bleeding in the lungs, and more, but every time I find myself immediately pressing New Game to try again.

The permadeath function can be a bit of a ball-ache, having to restart from the beginning does get old, but it certainly adds to the experience, punishing the careless.

Минигайд, если собрались играть в этот шедевр.
1. Для удобства качайте руссификатор. (Если вы из Энглии, пропускайте этот пункт)
2. Посмотрите рецепты крафтов. В Steam Руководствах найдёте.
3. При создании рекомендую всегда выбирать "Ловушки". Для ближников "Ближний бой и Сильный", а "Дальний бой" и "Атлетика" для дальников соответственно. Остальное подбираете по желанию. (Мне нравится Хакерство,Ботаника)
4. Через 10 смертей вы уже поймёте, что строить из себя Хэнкока ненужно. Умереть можно от бомжа с палкой.
5. Чаще смотрите на часы. За окном уже может быть рассвет.

36650496.review:
По сравнению с другими онлайн-ололоками, этот проект можно назвать Сталкером от мира выживалок. Образно, по атмосфере, по кривоватости, не особом удобстве в управлении и скорости. Очень, очень цепляет реалистичностью без впадения в совсем маразм. 
Год назад потратил на NEOS время, осилил где 75% событий и оборудования. На этой недельке зашел и поглядел, что мод Extended NeoScav все еще развивается (v5.2a), поставил и снова залип. Он реально покручивает логику действий и использования вещей и мест, как и их разообразие.
Ах да, музыка и звук хороши, но я играю без них. Слишком много времени съедается, проще что-то послушать, подкасты там, параллельно.

35644279.review:
Neo Scavenger is an incredibly demanding and incredibly hard game.
But in a good way.
Waking up in post apocalyptic Michigan, your main concerns will be to stay fed, hydrated, clothed, rested, and on and on and on. Usually, when games are this descriptive, they're hard as hell and either feel disappointingly bad or absurdly good.
Neo Scav is the latter. Not for everyone, this devious mix of a Survival game and a Roguelike is incredibly brutal but it makes you feel GOOD when you manage to survive for more than two turns.
It makes you be constantly on the lookout- both at your own stats, for better equipment, and for enemies that can spell your doom but can also spell your next lunch.

Overall, It's incredibly immersive, what little story exists is incredibly well-written, and I've never been so arelieved at  finding good shoes.
8/10 would make a coat out of a dogman again.

35641165.review:
NEO Scavenger definitely attracts a wide range of people, and that's one of its most charming aspects. First and foremost, the ultimate genre is survival, so people who like survival games such as Don't Starve or even This War of Mine, a less well-known title, will enjoy NEO greatly because it doesn't fall off this path at any point. There's a storyline no doubt, but it isn't the key focus of the game and I easily played it without paying attention to what my character's goals actually were. 

It's a text-based game which, I must say, is well-scripted. There are few typos or grammatical errors that I've noted, and, although white text on a black background is bound to wear the eyes out after a long enough session, the words themselves are very readable and humorous at times.

The gameplay is easy, but you won't start the game with much success. You begin by choosing the skills of your character, from benefits like 'Medic' to flaws like 'Feeble'. By adding more flaws, you can choose more skills. This is often where you'll fall at the first hurdle. It takes a bit of trial and error to find your perfect set-up, which gives you a bit more value for your money, though I must say the amount of scenarios one can find is limited, or at least from my experience. Certain instances reoccur quite a lot, and it can be hard to overcome that skill curve. The game doesn't tell you how to play it. You really are trying to survive.

In summary, NEO Scavenger is a decent game. It offers a nostalgic layout with a challenging premise with many interesting concepts and mysteries to delve into (or not). If you want to play it well, an element of strategy is required. There are also battle sequences for Pokemon fans, which is average in nature, and depends wholly on the skills and 'luck' of your current character. NEO is repeatable, but there is a limit on how many hours you can put into it. For £11, this is understandable, and it's an acceptable price, although waiting for a sale isn't a bad idea. 

If you dislike losing, reading, repeating processes until perfection, playing a game without guidance, games without a lot of sound or mouse-based gameplay, it might be worth looking into another survival game, but, if not, NEO Scavenger is a solid purchase which you can play again and again without internet or a gaming computer.

35097684.review:
Short version:

Don't be fooled. The demo is heavily front-loaded, and comes from an earlier version of the game. I was intrigued by the demo's promise - the Choose Your Own Adventure-style mechanics, the sneaking around crumbling ruins looking for supplies, the scary combat that made encounters tense and meaningful.

However, this "final" version is a hot mess of a game that feels cheap and lazy in nearly all aspects of its design. It's flawed at the very core of its concept, and I can't recommend it at all. Bad/10, don't buy unless you like random coin tosses wiping your saves and making you start over.

Long version (includes playable demo):

In fact, we can play the game right now, for free, in the space of this review. That's how shallow it is. Are you ready? Okay. I'm flipping a coin. Heads? Tails? Good choice, let's see: oh, you lose. Here we go. Heads? Tails? Interesting tactics. Okay - oh, you lose again. Heads? Tails? Oh, neat, have some random loot. But you also hurt yourself getting the loot. Also, dogs. 20 dogs. They eat you. Oh, well, actually, you can flip a coin to see if you can get away. You want to do that? Okay... oh. Darn. You lose after all.

I'm not exaggerating. The game is almost entirely based on a flip of a virtual coin. Everything you do comes down to absolute random chance. Forget any notion of augmenting the luck of the draw with your virtual skillset - your skills themselves are nothing more than cards in a deck. You've got "Strong." You're good at melee, right? "Strong and Melee." Oh, too bad, your enemy drew "Strong" *and* "Tough." Whoops. You're dead. Delete your, say, 20 hour save file and start over from scratch.

That's really the depth of this game's design. Make the wrong choice in a CYOA event? Dead, save file deleted. And some of this stuff is out-there random, too. It would be amusing if, like in the real thing (good old paper-back CYOA books), you could bookmark at least some of your progress and fix your mistake eventually, but nope - the whole game is based on stupid, abject luck killing you and forcing you to start over. Over and over and over again. In a game this flimsy-floozy, ironman needs to be an *option.* "Hardcore" is a distinction you earn by being good enough to rate as a consequence-based experience. This is not that. This is a dozen feral dogs appearing one after another at the whims of RNJesus to arbitrarily kill you for laughs.

Combat is a death sentence if you don't take very specific traits. That is stupid. Even if you do take the token, all-but-required traits, it's still just a toss of a coin whether or not you get killed. There's no strategy. No planning. No real player input. It's all just stupid, basic numbers. It's the laziest type of junk non-game you can imagine. Think you're a maverick and you don't want to play as a Herculean beefcake? You want to try to get by on stealth, cunning, and guile? Maybe get some hits in with finesse? Forget it. Sneak up on a guy with Tough and the best you'll do with your crowbar is tickle his funny bone. He'll then Chris Redfield you, exploding your head with a single punch. If you try to use melee weapons, and you don't have the right traits, you're dead. The enemy will bump you, and you will fall apart. Combat against an enemy with Tough is functionally impossible if you are not similarly equipped - you could catch him completely by surprise, and it doesn't matter a whit.

The actions you can take are rarely based on logic or the flow of a fight, as you'd perceive it - instead, the game makes no bones about it, and literally tells you that they're randomly available to you. Sometimes you can attempt to dodge. Sometimes you can't. Sometimes you can attempt to kick a downed enemy. Sometimes you can't. And of course, any given action has a chance of failure, even after passing the "can I even try it" dice roll. It's just random chance on top of random chance. It's mindless.

There's nothing wrong with making combat meaningful and deadly - I'd love to see more games give the player reason to actually avoid looking at enemies like loot-and-XP-pinatas - but this isn't that. Enemy encounters are ridiculously random, and the player has scarce few tools to avoid it. More often than not, its Olympian sprinter dogs dodging a million attacks, causing your character to whine, cry, and generally give up on life the instant he's bitten or scratched.

I'm reminded of Unreal World, another "survival" game I was fixated on for a long time. After going through hours upon hours of painstaking hunting, building, and gathering, arming and armoring myself against the elements and my enemies, I fell victim to a wretched combat system that just shrugged and said, "meh, you lose." My character in that game was supposedly possessed of excellent skill with a blade. Despite this, I found myself staring in disbelief as my character flubbed every single strike, missed every attack, and ate every swing of a clumsy bandit's rusty handaxe as my only input as the player was "try to attack again, or just give up on life." That's this game in a nutshell, only this game has added "choices" that can wipe your progress instantly. Naturally, that means this game is "better," right?

It's a shame. People have been clamoring for real survival games for years, and this lazy schlocky junk is what we get. Amateurish garbage whose apparent mission in life is to cure us of that desire. It's nipping the genre at the bud, and that sucks.

I pirated this game a very long time ago (no shame), and loved it to bits. I saw it randomly on Steam, a couple of years since the last time I played it, and was excited to support the game I had loved and have a nice pretty up to date and legitimate copy.

(Minor spoilers ahead)

The missions are the same every playthrough, and the map only changes slightly with each new save, but it doesn't get old. You'll develop your own playstyle over time, have your favorite skills and such. Some people like to rough it in wilderness, others like to chill with the Enclave, some like to head to Detroit and make a living off of selling scavenged goods to the marketplace. There are countless little details and different ways to approach situations using special items and skills in this game. Don't let the graphics (or the dozens of newbie deaths) fool you, this is an amazing game if you dig the realistic survival thing.

Only cons I can really think of is that combat could be made a little bit less repetitive. Perhaps add some different verbage and some new kinds of wounds. But that's a very nitpicky thing.

34900436.review:
This game had an uphill battle to get me to like it. I am not a fan of roguelikes, but the setting and the promise of a good story drew me in. What's worse than an RNG-powered permadeath game is an RNG-powered permadeath game with a faulty save system that randomly deletes your progress if you don't run the program every few hours. I hunted down the save folder, made copious backups, and had the so-thoughtfully-provided game wiki open in the background. I discovered through trial and error that the crowbar and lighter are your best friends. And when I accidentally beat the story of this game... it was underwhelming. The 18 hours spent swearing at both the game and my machine did not add up to a wall of text and an abrupt smash to credits. It required no skill to get to, just a pair of items easily obtainable/craftable anywhere in the world. My advice: just replay Fallout. Undoubtedly, this game is one of the best turn-based survival strategy games I have played. Old school with plenty of wonderful ideas wrapped in an intriguing storyline. Would highly recommend this game!

Pros:
    -Post apocalyptic survival
    -Interesting storyline
    -Not as pricey as some of the other survival games
    -Many MANY different style of play with different character traits (my personal favourite is [i]melee[/i] with [i]trapping[/i])
    -Well thought, very realistic (includes day-night cycle, hunger/thirst, temperature, diseases, sicknesses and infections...etc.)
    -Feel free to [u]consume[/u] your fallen foes! (when you ARE desperate, of course)
    -You are not invincible :D encourages thinking before any action is taken

Cons:

    -Controls might be confusing in the begining
    -Turn-based game so really need to be aware of energy and time
    -You are not invincible D: [spoiler]It is perma-death[/spoiler]

34745444.review:
I'm a casual gamer typically (unless there are zombies involved - then it's anything goes).  This is the game I go to after I've been eaten for the fourteenth time in one of the few games I'm very intense about.  It's calming, interesting, and I really like the storyline.  I like that I don't have to go insane during the fight sequences.  This game is by no means easy, but it doesn't induce the same stress levels that a first-person kill-fest does.  And for when I just need to bug out for a while, I don't have to pay attention to the story-line.  I can involve myself in it if I want to, or ignore it and just concentrate on not dying of pneumonia.  

The one negative I have about it is that it feels unfinished.  I keep looking to see if there are updates, and there are, but usually they're minor bug fixes or else they're updates about the game going mobile.  I feel like there's a lot missing here that could be expanded upon.

Overall, I recommend this game and hope everyone who plays it enjoys it.

34185288.review:
TL;DR GAME GOOD, ME LIKE, BUY!!



GENERAL


i 100% recommend this game to anyone interested in survival games or even turn based strategy games.


seeing as theres a demo i wont talk about the mechanics or how to physically play the game and maneuver the interfaces, you could get all that pretty easily just trying it for yourself but i will say dont let how simple it appears fool you, there is an amazing amount of depth to this game once you get into it.


now i have heard complaints about the RNG, and i'll admit it can be harsh but honestly i've never personally felt it was unfair since you can heavily reduce the chances of a lot of things. sure i might die in one shot before i ever see my enemy (pretty rare) but how many times have i done that same thing to my own enemies? everything RNG throws at you it throws just as hard at the npcs, which to me makes the combat system one of the best i've ever played but more about that down below.



REALISM


Some of my favourite moments in all my years of gaming have come from this game, and for one simple reason. 
This game is hard, and i dont mean hard like most games i mean its hard in a very realistic fashion. 


i've died from simple food poisoning because i ate raw meat and couldnt keep hydrated,
 from cholera because i didnt boil my water,
 hypothermia because i braved the elements in nothing but a hospital gown,
blood loss because i didnt wrap my cuts,
infection because i didnt clean my wraps
Heart attack because i overworked myself
and starvation/dehydration because i knew better than to eat the raw meat or unboiled water
and dont even get me started on combat related deaths


but you'll notice with every new death i learned something, i learned the why of what was killing me and slowly figured out how to craft everything i needed to fix those situations, 


spears for hunting,
fire to cook and boil food and water
makeshift clothing from rags and hides to keep from freezing


little by little, with every death and every new run, you learn better builds for your skills,
 how to build a better campsite,
 what fights to get into and when to run away
 and eventually before you even realize it youve gone from scavegning to scrape by to scavenging for comfort.


COMBAT


with a combat system that exemplifies the desperate nature of every conflict and the risk that comes with that, you'll find yourself envisioning some of the most impressive fight sequences.

imagine being awoken to a stranger in your camp wielding a cleaver. you have nothing but a stone to defend yourself with and hes charging you stopping only to demand your surrender before running again to close the gap, you steel yourself as he gets closer and at the last moment you jump and tackle him to the ground, scrambling to get up before he does you seize the moment to kick at his head while hes down but he rolls away at the last moment, you lash out a flurry of blows with your rock hoping to end it before he can get up, but he manages to get to his feet with only minor injuries and slices your gut whle you try to catch your breath.

squared off and on even terms now you ready a defensive stance hoping to avoid the razor edge of his cleaver, dodging one swing you see your moment and headutt him stunning him for just a moment, but it was enough you bear everything you have crashing the hard stone into his chest over and over before he can get his bearings.

as he starts to cough blood hope starts to cling to you, you demand he surrender his gear and you'll let him live. he responds by savaging your arm crippling it and causing you to drop your stone. Pain obscuring your focus exhaustion setting in from blood loss and exersion you take a step back your only thoughts on the blade set to take your life you prepare to dodge knowing another hit like that and your done for.

your enemy seeking to close the gap dives towards you eyes widening as you sidestep and he falls vulnerable to the ground, you kick him, and you kick him, over and over, his ribs cracking underneath you. you grab your stone with your good hand and finish him taking your new cleaver and whatever else he had as your prize. 
 



WHY ARE YOU STILL HERE?

if your still reading this then you have more then enough time to download the demo either here or on the mobile app and see what im talking about.

34161225.review:
I'm a bit disappointed with this game because my issue, as many have already pointed out in longer and more detailed reviews, is entirely with the first-impression a game like this gives. I had actually followed this game for a while and finally got to play it today. I played for about an hour straight and my whole experience was the following : Make character, explore surrounding hexes of beginning campsite area, fail to find any items for 90% of scavenging explored hexes, attract unwanted attention indefinitely, proceed to either get mauled by feral dogs or have to surrender to some random jackass that, from what I understand, removes *at least* one item(including containers which actually takes the container plus all items inside it counting it as a single item) from your inventory(which, to add insult to injury, meant I lost my starting gown and was literally naked - no items at all). Rinse and repeat. No fun at all.

In fact, it's all because of RNG and the issue is the chance of success when performing actions. You start the game with essentially nothing. Following the first-time tutorial messages, you'll always scavenge the starting area to get a gown and, seemingly useless, shards of glass. Virtually every single start had me next to a small town with storage sheds and abandoned houses/mobile homes but the loot chance bar is at ~5% without any items to help you scavenge. The stealth bar was usually at around ~50% or ~75% without the hiding skill but was still constantly alerting enemies to my location(which then proceeded with me dying). Using the hiding skill reduces loot chance but increases stealth chance(even though I did alert enemies to position using the skill with it increasing it to ~90%). See the issue? Either stick with a very very low chance to get indefinitely useless loot in a spot I kept on spawning next to and alert enemies OR lower that alert chance but get no loot at all. I had *one* single "lucky" run in the 1 hour I played and it involved me getting a crowbar, which increases loot chance but lowers stealth. Well, guess, what, completely useless for me in that run because the areas I scavenged with the crowbar consistently resulted in injuries, no loot, and alerting various enemies, which is what ended that run because I quickly got beaten down by 3 dogs. This experience was the whole the 1-hour in, what, 10 runs? 

It's not even like I'm bad at these types of games. I could do literally nothing about the starting of each run since gathering loot is initially very low, entirely run by RNG, and you start with nothing while also having odds of getting loot against you tenfold. I didn't even understand most of the menus because without certain starting-perks, certain stats are hidden against you(which I assume this includes combat too because I didn't see any combat stats like hit chance or item stats such as weapon damage, range, etc.).

To cut a long story short, it was a disappointing experience because it's yet another game(a rogue-like, too) that depends almost entirely on RNG while giving you no long-term benefits beyond death, meaning you're almost entirely playing against luck itself(and everyone already knows RNG/random number generator mechanics are bullshit. See : Darkest Dungeon) sort of like a gambling game where it's a win-lose 50-50 respectively. You go as far as you want risking it every single instance(e.g. every draw of a card or every individual action in this game), except in this game you get literally nothing if you die.

I would've like it more if it didn't come off as so threatening and hardcore because, yes, a lot of roguelikes suffer from this issue. I still haven't gotten much out of FTL for exact reason, because the game starts off as very overwhelming and hardcore, and I got scared off by it. Same thing happened here.

Also, as a random aside since it doesn't fit into any of my ranting... Aside from the first couple tutorial messages, the game explained *nothing*. Even crafting was just weird, especially since the game presumably has crafting recipes that you have to find via scavenging. Oh boy... fun.

If anyone disagrees then I *dare* you to try and create a starting-the-game guide that doesn't essentially tell someone how to play the game, because if you can't then my thoughts will be pointed towards how linear the game would be in the end in terms of progression.

If you like watching hours of game play suddenly and arbitrarily end, wiping away all progress you've made, this is the game for you!
Game play can be fun. Scavage, explore, survive, fight.
The issue I have is being suddenly one hit killed several hours into a run. There are no persistent rewards, so game play does not change or evolve. Failure is not a process, it is random and has little to do with the player. Death is frequently simply an uncontrolled roll of the dice. Some might like that, but I enjoy a game where there is an element of skill in the play. In this game REPEATED AND FREQUENT failure is simply due to random events rather than player skill. 
If you enjoyed this game I HIGHLY recommend cataclysm: dark days ahead.
it is free, open source, a bit old at this point I will admit, but DDA is a much better survival rouge-like than this game.

34026442.review:
[u]What I liked: [/u]
[list]
    [*]Inventory management
    [*]A true survival style game
[/list]
[u]What You Need to Know: [/u]
[list]
    [*]This game always sounded so good to me, making me want to play it but I never would buy it. I finally did and was ultimately disappointed

    [*]The game is turned based which isn’t where the game went wrong. Being turned based lets you think about actions and plan ahead while also giving lots of options in combat.

    [*]This game is not meant to be what most people expect a survival game to be, where combat or mining resources is not the main gameplay loop. This again is not bad; it focuses more scavenging supplies and staying away from dangers, sounds good right?

    [*]The game starts to fall apart when you play the beginning over and over not really learning from mistakes as it’s really the RNG that will hurt you. Combat is stupid in the sense that a lot of the time you just encounter an enemy, no warning or true way to avoid enemies. You try to run, but it fails a lot. So you get hit and bleed to death. This isn’t fun. I don’t want to fight random enemies if I stay hidden and cover my tracks and won’t let me run away even when I’m athletic carrying nothing

    [*]There are some games in this genre that do focus on a story(War of Mine) and some that don’t(Zomboid). Neo Scavenger said it has a story. I didn’t feel like it did. I didn’t find much in the game. I do know looking it up that it’s found through playing and not spoon fed to you. Some might like this, I didn’t as looking on the wiki anyway seemed like the story was short, sparse and barely even enough to keep me playing. I just didn’t find any reason to care about this world sense it felt so empty.

    [*]Also having no real end to the game means that you real just play till you get bored, as you have no closure of escaping, sustainability, or actually surviving. I know it can be hard to do with the survival aspect as that might hurt replayability, but I think that is false. If the game is fun, you’ll want to play it again and try something new

    [*]Overall having a hardcore survival game experience dependent on the RNG nature can mean that no matter how good you are at the game, a bad roll can mean you die and have to start the same 30 minutes over getting boring fast. The story is so bare that it does nothing to give you a reason to continue playing and with no ending to the game and I have more games to play that will hook me; I’ll pass for games with better survival mechanics.
 [/list]

[h1]My Score: [/h1]
[b]D[/b]

[b]Paid: $4[/b]
[b]Main reason for dislike:  replaying the beginning so much, no real end goal and RNG that hurts the vibe [/b]

Better games that are similar I recommend: 
[list]
[*]This War of Mine (has an end, story and no zombies)
[*]Project Zomboid(no story, zombies, no end atm)
 [*]Darkwood ( story, has an end)
[*]Sunless Sea ( great world, and story, weak combat, no zombiest, has an end)
[*]State of Decay 2 (might be cool)

[/list]

33960437.review:
TL;DR; Review; It's a rogue like. You will die a lot, and you will die to pure randomness sometimes. Is the game bad? Hell no, it's a lot of fun. But if you're not prepared to put up with rogue-like bullshit-RNG at times, it will piss you off. 

Ignore [most of] the negative reviews that complain about dying or repetition and all that. These are people that either A) Got very mad and wrote it in the heat of the moment or B) Are just bad at understanding the concept of rogue-likes (Particularly that they are games where you die and you star over, and over and over, with many random elements). 

I realize calling negative reviewers 'upset' is in poor taste, and I don't mean to say the game is without flaws. But steams default "Most helpful" sorting shows almost half the reviews as being negative, and most are complaining about how 'hard' the game is. (Despite the overall score being 90% and, the recent score as of writing this is also 90% with 40 reviews). 

The game is hard. No dobut. And you will be upset sometimes about dying. As the tldr says, there is a lot of RNG at times. Take a drink of water out of a weird lake? Well, you might die, you might be fine. Sometimes its your only option because loot RNG fucked you and you have no other potable drinking source. 

It's definitely not for everyone, but the same can be said for any rogue-like. I mean imagine FTL, one of the most loved modern rogue-likes. Most of the criticism thrown at NEO Scavenger can be thrown at it as well. It's repetitive (especially after playing several hours in a row), it punishing at times, and the RNG can screw you hard at times. 

One criticism I can sympathize with is that the beginning is repetitive. You start the game out the same way each time. In FTL you can have a wildly different playthrough from each start, but in here, it's the same location and series of events each time. To me, it's not a big deal, I don't find it boring, and it's at most 5-10 minutes before you already have a radically different playthrough. But when you first start playing, you'll probably play through the beginning a fair few times. (Although it's not as bad as it seems, as the beginning can play out a few different times, which will keep you entertained the first couple of deaths). 

There are clunky parts to the game, and for one the art style isn't my favorite. It's pretty, but it looks like it's 10 years out of date to me. It looks like a point and click CRPG from several years ago. Maybe that's intentional, and it's mostly a personal niggle. The quality of the art is fine, but it's the style I am not overly fond of. 

Beyond that, there is a surprisng amount of depth here. There are tons of incredibly rare items, and you will fear for your life during most encounters. 

It simulates a post apocalyptic scavenger situation fairly well (in the sci-fi sense, not some preppers training fantasy). 

I'm just disappointed by the amount of "helpful" reviews that are essentially the same negative reviews over and over. While they have good points, if you know and like what you're getting into, they're not negatives. 

But be aware, it is punishing. The RNG in this one can be especially brutal. 

If you like rogue-likes, especially challenging ones, this is the one for you. 

If you're the kind of person to throw your controller at the wall when you lose at a game, you should probably stay away from this. 

Try the demo if you're apprehensive.

33937910.review:
[h1] Brief introduction [/h1]

I usually don't write reviews. To be honest, I don't at all. But this game, this marvelous fucking piece of game deserves 15 minutes of my non-precious time.

[h1] Pros	[/h1]

 - Realistic crafting: this game takes it to a whole new level. Want to craft a noise trap but you don't have pebbles? Don't worry, you can use lighters, AA batteries or anything that is small and heavy. Want to cook meat in a fire but you don't a stick? No problem, you can do it with a fucking crowbar, HECK, even with a fucking shotgun. The choices are infinite. You don't need the exact items to craft a recipe, you can always find a substitute that suits best your situation

- Realistic diseases/poison/bleeding/freezing system: I won't discourse much on this one, since it's auto-explanatory.

- Inventory management: This games takes it really serious too, whereas different types of items ocupy different sizes on your bag, but still taking account their weight, encumbering you even if your bag is not full.

- The environment IS harsh: Even if you have rifles and shotguns, there's a big chance you can die if caught off guard, you will never find yourself in peace in this game

- The skills/flaws system is so fucking good: Different skills have different impact on your choices through the game. SEVERELY.

- Your choices DO matter: Never choose an option without thinking first, otherwise the world will punish you pretty bad.

- The world is not centered on you: A lot of stuff happens on Neo Scavenger world, and much of it don't care about the player, pretty much like in a real dystopian world.

- There's A LOT to discover in the game, there's A LOT of random encounters and A LOT of lore to unravel.

- There's a lot of liberty on this game. You can join factions, act evil, act good, help people, kill people, be neutral. Your choice.

[h1] The only con	[/h1]

[spoiler] Camp Grayling endings will make you mad as fuck [/spoiler]

OVERALL, this games deserves a whooping 9.8/10, the best survival game I ever played in my entire fucking life.

33916528.review:
This game is something quite special to me. It is a true survivor game, that succeeds in making you feel accomplished by just surviving. You don't just find water or food that is ready to consume. You have to boil water to make it safe to drink, and cook food to prevent it from making you sick. You have to be extremely mindful of the weather and what you're wearing, as you can quickly die from freezing to death, or being wet. Even combat is extremely dangerous, where every threat can bring you down in the blink of an eye. Get shot in the head or heart by a pot shot? Doesn't matter if you're a pro soldier, you're dead. And then, even if you survive a battle, you can die from the infections of your wounds, internal hemorraging, etc. 

I should make this clear in that you're not taught anything for this game. There is no tutorial. Experimentation, common sense, and a bit of knowledge about the world can take you a long ways. For example, you're not told to clean bandages prior to dressing wounds to avoid infections. Fire can be used to harden sharpened wood to make them effective weapons. As well as the variety of methods needed to treat sicknesses you can incur on your journies, which are just as dangerous as the guys with guns. 

Make no mistake, you will die, many, horrible, deaths. This is not a game for those without patience and dedication. However, if you can deal with the pain of losing quite often, you will find that this game is quite fun. You are not a super soldier. You are not a prodigee of any kind. You're just some dude wearing nothing but a piece of cloth with an arm band. You're just as strong, or weak as anyone, or thing you can find in the wild. 

Good luck, and good hunting. You'll need it.

33554381.review:
Neo Scavenger is a quite unwieldy post-apocalyptic turn based survival RPG-roguelike. What sounds complex ultimately ends up being just as complex as it sounds, meaning that more often than not, the player character will ultimately die very soon due to quite ridiculous RNG. Either you'll simply find no food while scavenging. Or you'll get an infection while scavenging. Or you'll get ambushed while scavenging. Or you'll get shot by another NPC survivor from several hundred meters away while being armed with as little as a multitool / knife. You'll die to starvation, you'll die to bleeding, you'll die to infection, you'll die to dehydration, you'll die in combat and even more often after successful combat due to injuries taken, you'll die to electrocution, you'll die falling down somewhere .... the list goes on and on.

NEO Scavenger is absolutely brutal, lethal and frustrating, which makes it one of the most deadly roguelikes I have played recently. It does a lot of things right, but it is lacking in two key elements: Accessibility and fun. Sadly, NEO Scavenger is neither. Not due to a lack of presentation, but due to a lack of intuitive controls as well as descriptive tooltips. Every battle is massively lacking in information about status effects or success & failure of actions taken and even taking the actions themselves is resolved in an extremely unwieldy and bothersome manner by picking an action not from a list but from icons which resemlbe items within your squarish inventory, which have confusing icons and no descriptive tooltips whatsoever. NEO scavenger is not only a lot of trial and error, it also leaves the player completely in the dark regarding mechanics and the result of actions taken. More often than not my character died to injuries I wasn't even aware I had taken due to a lack of information during combat or during random events while scavenging.

NEO Scavenger had a lot of potential, but the way it currently is and the way it will most likely remain indefinitely, I am unable to recommend it to anyone, not even die-hard roguelike fans.

The only reason that I'm giving this a thumbs up for is the fact that it has the potential to be enjoyed deeply by any tryhard who wants a really deep game. However, for me, I don't like this game at all because of the great depth being choked by the great confusion that stayed around until my fifteenth game. This game isn't my type of game, but it might be yours, person who is wondering if they should buy this game. The developer(s) did a fantastic job making a solid game.

P.S. If you like this game, also try Project Zomboid (I didn't like that one either)
