33296132.review:
I like NEO Scavenger.  I like the randomness of the world, the scavenging, the "mystery", and the ability to do anything you want for as long as you want.  But out of the 5 times I played, I was killed 5 times by a random encounter out of the blue; no warning, no options.  I understand this is realistic and highly probable IRL, but in a game, it just isn't fun.  This may be a "Rage Quit Negative Review", but the fact remains: I am p****d off.

PROS

+ True open world gameplay
+ Scavenging, crafting and exploring is fun
+ Tons of items to find and experiment with
+ Interface, while confusing at first, is actually excellent

CONS

- No way to customize game world options or difficulty
- Frequent, non-preventable instant deaths ruin experience
- Vague story isn't terribly engaging
- High learning curve may annoy some

33291120.review:
Best Roguelike I've played since I was a kid. It is very difficult and I dove into it purposely knowing nothing about features, capabilities, etc. I had no knowledge of what is important to collect, what horrible diseases or ailments I could die from, and how mutant wolf beasts will tear your face off. I died constantly in the beginning but literally with EACH playthrough, I live longer, do better, and as far as random encounters (RPG/decision making elements) go, I have yet to have the game repeat itself.

This game is a blast and I live in paranoia because I died of sepsis or dysentery (I don't remember exactly which) but it gave me a grumbly tummy for 2 days, then killed me in my sleep. I'm sure there's a cure, but I haven't found it. I love testing mechanics, experimenting, crafting, etc. to live just 20 minutes longer than last time.

Here are some memorable moments:

Attacked by wolf beast, tackled and beat him to death with fists, ripped off its skin with broken glass, enjoyed my new hat. Near death, wandered into a derelict building, wanted to sleep, found woman and child on second floor, they scream for help, I want to help, I have 1 bullet and I've lost a lot of blood, I bandage up and sleep while they are still trapped upstairs, I wake up and eat some steak, manage to free the woman and child, kill woman and child, sleep like baby, wake up get attacked by a bandit, use 1 bullet and body slam bandit, kill bandit, eat bandit, get surrounded by mutants, eat broken glass, die a hero.

10/10 Would wear manskin coat, brandish a monkey wrench, and die with crippling depression again.

[h1]《末日拾荒者》评测：开局就裤衩，装备全靠打；辛辛苦苦捡垃圾，一朝太浪命归西[/h1]
关键词：独立游戏 回合制 末世 生存 Rogue Like   [b][u]英文[/u][/b]

上手需要的英文程度：高中水平；
读懂剧情需要的英文程度：CET-6水平。

中文资料：[url=tieba.baidu.com/f?kw=末日拾荒者] 末日拾荒者贴吧[/url]，看精华区索引帖足够了；
英文维基：[url=neoscavenger.wikia.com/wiki/NEO_Scavenger_Wiki]NEO Scavenger Wiki[/url]，英文一手资料比较详尽，也含有少量中文页面。

离线玩了至少几百小时吧，是时候补一篇评测了。很难想象，本作是一位独立游戏人，历时4年，反复打磨的良心作品。如果说一定有不足的话，...我这个纯英文玩家也不得不说，因为语言障碍，国内有多少玩家错过了这款神作啊！

[h1]剧情[/h1]
[quote=吧友，1026784376]游戏背景是在未来的地球，那时候地球因为外星人入侵，核辐射泄漏，战争频繁而变成末日世界。
我们扮演的主人公-小菲（菲利普-狄克philip kindred）在一个人体冷冻机构醒来并且失忆了和狗人战斗过后逃出了冷冻机构，发现这个世界已经变了……就是这样为了在这个末日世界生存下来并且去找回自己遗忘的记忆而在被军法封闭且充满危险的密歇根州流浪着，并在各个城市的废墟中搜索着有用的食物材料和工具而成为一个末日拾荒者。随着他跟着残留的印象前往底特律，经历怪林，zamzam角斗场，到阿勒根游乐场找到印第安部落的所在，遭遇蓝蛙邪教并勇闯蓝蛙总部萨吉诺精神病院……帮助底特律神秘商人帽酱的各种委托，隐蔽湖尖阁楼的骨灰盒等等，并再北进到了格雷灵营地慢慢的一些真像逐渐清晰……[/quote]

[h1]乐趣[/h1]
[olist]
    [*]Rouge Like游戏嘛，天生的欧皇与非酋鉴定器：
开局虽然就一条裤衩，但人的命运啊，也要看历史的进程；
欧皇走不出三步，推车衣服食物饮水药品武器样样搜刮完毕，在发愁丢掉哪件好呢；
非酋浪了小半个地图了，饥寒交迫瑟瑟发抖遍体鳞伤。

    [*]Rouge Like游戏嘛，玩的就是各种花式作死：
没饭吃，饿死；没水喝，渴死；
吃了毒蘑菇毒果子腐肉，喝了毒水生水，上吐下泻死；
吸了毒气、摸了病人、伤口感染、吃错了药，各种惨死；
天冷下雨不穿衣服被冻死、天热穿两件秋衣加一件夹克加一件大氅加狗皮大衣被活活热死；
被枪打、被平底锅砸、被长矛捅 [spoiler]同为非洲人，相煎何太急！[/spoiler] 、被物理学圣剑拍、被狗咬、被怪物按住了摩擦...总之壮烈战死；
半夜睡觉，莫名被土匪野狗变异怪物等等摸哨，稀里糊涂死；
自以为是人形起重机，手提两大包、拖着推车、背一大包、脖套一中包、肩上扛枪、衣服裤子口袋里塞满零碎...这个倒累不死，不过没事您走两步试试？ <--- 如果诸位Steam账号里各游戏都变成实体游戏，这就是诸位的写照。

适当备份存盘文件吧骚年，不要浪了：[spoiler] C:\Documents and Settings\你的用户名\Application Data\Macromedia\Flash Player\#SharedObjects\一串随机字符\localhost\Steam\steamapps\common\NEO Scavenger\NEOScavenger.exe\nsSGv1.sol[/spoiler]
 
    [*]Rouge Like游戏嘛，擅长用大量文字和场景体现恶趣味：
鞋子分左右，穿顺拐了脚会起泡，穿女生粉色拖鞋随机鞋会掉；
物品每回合都会自然磨损，使用后磨损更多，因为物品大多是自制山寨货的缘故，所以经常会走着走着，背包散架了，衣服破成抹布了，弓烂成树棍了；
饥渴中，捡了一大包薯片，大喜，打开一看，只有区区两片薯片，食之，聊胜于无，但口渴程度急剧加重； <--- 作者满满的对膨化食品的恶意啊。

33055730.review:
This game is outstanding! It's brutally difficult, makes you have to think tactically and strategically. The devs have really put their heart and soul into this game, and you can tell by the in-depth gameplay. From wearing the same rags on your face you used to stop your bleeding, to wearing mismatched shoes on the wrong feet. There was a lot of time and research put into it, so undoubtedly the quality is there. 

No AAA 3D game has been able to capture the helpess, lonesome, sometimes fearful feeling and atmosphere this game provides with the exception of FO3. You will die from black mold inhalation, starvation and dehydration, mauling, having your cranium caved in with a looter's boot and many other miserable deaths before you start to get a grip on the game. No matter how well you're doing for yourself it WILL throw you a curveball that 7/10 times you might not be able to hit. 

The game consists of quite a bit of reading, but I assure you, when you do come across those scenarios, the writers for the game have a gift of making you feel like you ARE the character. Whether you're coming across ZomZom's and feel the sheer terror of the situation you're in, or coming across an eerie bumpkin living in an isotope mine, the written out scenarios are extremely captivating and engaging. And not to mention, EVERY choice you make will have a tremendous impact on how the playthrough pans out.

Onto the combat, it's EPIC, and plays back into what I commented on above, the quality of writing. It will feel like you're battling for an eternity, constantly tripping on the poor terrain and having to choose whether to take a chance on getting up, or roll around dodging your attacker's next move. Chasing down scavengers through the woods as they desperately try to flee your relentless attacks. Or my personal favorite, fighting a evenly matched opponent when you both have nothing but your bare hands for lethal weapons. You will fight, you will fall, you WILL cough up blood, and sometimes you will yet again, get your head caved in after a long and tedious fight. 

Anyone, and I mean ANYONE who's a fan of post-apocalyptic games must add this to their collection. NEO Scavenger is living proof that you don't need good graphics to have a fun game. The things you can do in this game are practically endless. There is so much to do, and you have such little time. I'm STILL trying to survive longer than 6 days per playthrough. But the good thing is, you learn something new each playthrough. Whether that be how to play, or a new strategy that works.

There is no room for mistake, there is no room for impulsive decisions or recklessness. This game is everything a survival game should consist of, and then some!

My only complain is I've saved a few games to end off for the night, only to return to no saved game. Fullscreen mode is a lie once you unconciously hit escape to leave a screen like we're used to, and there were a few times I had to exit out and reload my save to fix a scavenging glitch (I would press 'E' to scavenge and nothing would happen even though I still had sufficient points left over for my turn).

9/10 - Would hopelessly flee from a Merga Wraith only to run into a Dogman pack again.

32808698.review:
Love this game. The survival aspect is challenging at first and the plot is spread out so you have an incentive to cross the landscape. The only unfair thing about this game is the menu events(imo) because it's pretty punishing to choose a seamless option and instantly die from it. I just created a permeate save to remedy that issue during the final part, although permadeath DOES add to the excitement.

NEO Scavenger's strength lies in worldbuilding and it's game mechanics. The combat gives you a plethora of options like kick, drag, roll etc. Nature can assist and endanger you but it mostly endangers you :D

If you enjoy learning to live off a barren earth and exploring, Neoscavenger is your game.

Cons:
The AI interaction in random encounters lacks depth unless it's combat. Complex diplomacy is not this game's strong suit. This game makes sure to keep you alone in this world. You also can't attack the societies.

Even though lots of the locations are randomized, the same ones appear on every map, so replay value comes more in experimenting with the menu interface than trekking unknown lands. I think this makes the second replay weaker than the first.

32374252.review:
TL:DR;
I cannot recommend it due to few fatal flaws. 
This is a flash game of armorgames quality, sale material not worth more than 6$. 
Worse it is aimed only at a certain group of people with masochistic tendencies. Read on to find why.

Review:
NEO Scavenger, an odd name for a title that claims to be post-apocalyptic survival game. 
It hardly achieves what it promises and unfortunately uses few tricks to hide its flaws from the player for the first few hours.

Graphics: 5/10
No excuses for uninspired graphics. Sure, it's not the most important part of the game, but the choice of tiles, buildings, etc. is waaaaaaaay to poor.

Sounds: 8/10
Actually pretty good. Keeps atmosphere. Ambient, dark elements accompany the game pretty good.

Gameplay: 5/10
Well... good for the first few hours. 
Rogue-like random map and loot, random encounters etc.
The problem is that it is yet another game which uses brutal RNG and player's death as an excuse for lack of any in depth mechanics and content.
Once you get a grasp of this title, you will realise that there is nothing to aim at, except for maybe very difficult base infiltration mission which is also an end game.

You see, this game has totally nothing to offer. 
- no skill progression
- no character progression
- no camp building
- no real crafting
- no loot variety
- no enemies variety
- no real missions and NPCs
- no factions you can actually join in a meaningful way
- not possible to start a gang of friendly NPCs and roam the land

There is simply nothing in terms of gameplay that after few initial deaths can hold you to this title. 
It's all the same - walk around, kill mobs, loot corpses, scavenge, return to camp (now probably ransacked by NPCs.
Fetch wood, boil water, cook meat, repeat till you die of diarrhea or other plagues. 

You can't, for example, raid some bunker or a military base and bar the entrance from the inside, thus being shielded from harm. You can't really upgrade it (there is room 17 in starting location, but I got a bug and it vanished, taking all the stuff with it). You can't start a farm or hydroponics at the camp. Can't make bullets.

With crafting limited as it is, with no solar panels to recharge all those laptops and batteries and stuff, you are either forced to buy technology from remaining megacity or live like a tribal. 

Only you can't have a tribe because you cannot befriend any of the numberless horde of nameless NPCs.

Therefore this game is only recommended either on sale or to a group of people who enjoy dying and starting over against whatever devilry RNG has conjured against a player this time.

32347378.review:
You wake up in a cryo-freezing facilty with no memory of who you are or why you're there. There's no time to gather your thoughts as you hear something big moving through the hallway toward your room. What happens next depends on what skills you have.

From the moment you wake up, you're fighting for survival. In NEO Scavenger, winning the fight doesn't get you xp or even good loot at times. Sometimes winning the fight just means you've opened the door to dying from infection later on. In NEO Scavenger, the little things kill you just as often as the big things.

I've been playing since alpha and have managed to find a skill combo that really helps me get past the basic 3 needs, but there have been countless games where a bad choice has ended my career as a scavenger. Sometimes it's not even your choice and its just bad luck. In a recent game, i woke up to a bandit bashing me in the head. I didn't even get a turn because it was already over for me.

I will admit that every now and then the RNG loot can completely screw you or that sometimes things feel unfair. It makes the sting of death even worse when you've finally made your way deeper into the game and a dogman is on your tail, you're tired, you're out of ammo, and you're dying of thirst.

Like i said, i've been playing since alpha and i've never made it into the deeper parts of the game. I have been playing for a few years at least and theres still parts of the game that are unexplored to me.


If you are looking for a low-end high replayablity game that is tough yet rewarding, this is your game.

Only in NEO Scavenger waste 3 minutes inspecting whether the new club that you found is better than the one you already have in your hand, and then get shot with a bolt action rifle by a guy wearing only a hoodie and a single flip flop and holding a broken bottle in the other hand.

7.8/10, not sponsored by pepsi.

The real issue, though, is no multiplayer, hotseat or otherwise.

I hope the dev adds more content and tweaks the balance a bit more, but otherwise it's a great game and I highly recommend it. I'd give it a 9/10.

It sort of pains me a little to recommend this game - I may have just rage quit it myself - but it is good. I did really well the first time I tried, and then not nearly as well all the subsequent times. 

I really appreciate that this game isn't afraid to have complexity, but yet the complexity can be grasped just by playing the game and using 'common sense' style reasoning.

What I really *don't* appreciate is story-based roguelikes - first Sunless Sea, and now this. I feel the world/story-discovery element really clashes with the "haha, random stuff happened, now do it over, and with the same story stuff" element. 

At least Sunless Sea had a mode for "this is now what *we* intended, but we guess we'll let you play it like a more normal RPG".

31205880.review:
Premessa: Neo Scavenger è un'avventura di sopravvivenza in 2D + testuale (inglese) ambientata in un mondo post apocalittico.
Oggi se nomini un gioco 2D gia' molte persone pregiudicano l'esito, in piu' se è testuale e non nella lingua madre del giocatore magari è ancora peggio.

Traduttore Google alla mano per le parole che non so mi immergo nel gioco (ci ho giocato molte piu ore di quelle segnate da steam per il semplice fatto che prima lo giocavo su un altro account):

""
Giorno 0: mi risveglio all'improvviso, rumori, mi sento male, capisco essendo un medico (skill che si puo scegliere alla creazione) che sono stato scongelato da una capsula di criostasi... intorno a me solo un vecchio laboratorio ... cerco infomazioni , poche e frammentate, cerco di capire cosa succede, dove sono... niente, l unica cosa che trovo è un kit di pronto soccorso e un foglietto nascosto dietro una botola d'arezione con scritto come fare un contenitore a sacca scritto da chissachi... Esco , la luce... davanti a me un mondo distrutto, vedo in lontananza delle macerie , ci vado e cerco di trovare qualcosa per coprirmi, ho freddo, la temperatura sta scendendo e la mia fame aumenta ora in ora dopo la criostasi, arrabatto quello che posso, creo delle specie di pantofole con degli stracci legati assieme e mi rintano nel primo casermone mezzo distrutto per passare la notte... molto freddo... troppo freddo... vorrei accendere un fuoco, ma con cosa?...
Giorno 1: mi sono mosso all'alba, non ho dormito molto, traoppo freddo, troppi rumori, sono ancora scosso dalla criostasi e sono sicuro di iniziare ad avere principi di panico dopo che ho sentito qualcosa muoversi al piano di sotto di dove stavo... ho il battito alterato e un principio di congelamento...
Decido di correre verso un altro cumulo di macerie, trovo degli indumenti, un paio di pantaloni usurati, un sacchetto di plastica e una chiave inglese, niente di che ma è gia qualcosa rispetto a niente... in lontananza ho visto un tizio forse mi aiuterà, quindi decido di avvicinarmi... appena mi vede inizia a correre verso di me, impugnando una bottiglia rotta e nell altra mano ha una sorta di sacca, tento di parlargli, nessuna risposta, tento di avvertirlo minacciando, niente, si lancia verso me , accecato dalla brama di derubarmi? di uccidermi? di.... mangiarmi? 
Nella lotta tento di schivarlo, pararlo, buttarlo a terra come posso... diamine sono un medico non un soldato, lo colpisco di fortuna con la chiave inglese, scappa...
Diagnosi, una gamba lacerata dalla bottiglia, s'infetterà se non la curo a dovere... bende, ma devono essere pulite non stracci... antibiotici, magari li avessi... solo cosi sarei sicuro di non morire per infezione... ho freddo... domani dovrò cercare da bere qualcosa di potabile, la corsa, lo scontro mi hanno affaticato e assetato. 
Dio se sei ancora in questa terra dimenticata, aiutami a resistere.
""

Ecco questo appena descritto è solo la punta dell'iceberg del coinvolgimento che ho trovato nel giocare a questa avventura survival, come tutti i giochi ho dovuto imparare la logica che ci sta dietro e capire come sopravvivere al meglio, carpire informazioni, affinare le tecniche, sapere quando potrei farcela o quando non potrei, questo gioco non ha un settaggio di difficoltà, ma alcontempo ha una difficoltà quasi reale e naturale degli eventi, alchè crea una sorta di "magia" che ti coivolge davvero da dire "C**** sto morendo di fame se non trovo qualcosa ... sono spacciato" , in piu il fatto che è un gioco settato Hardcore, ovvero hai solo "1 vita" , come dovrebbe essere , rende ancora tutto piu interessante.



Pro:  
-Gioco molto leggero in Flash player non so se ce una versione tablet ma secondo me potrebbe girarci tranquillamente.
-Meccaniche intuitive anche se non ho trovato un vero tutorial (esiste una wiki in inglese che aiuta molto però)
-Coivolgimento sonoro / ambientazione a livelli inaspettati rispetto al gioco
-Longevità elevata grazie alla creazione del personaggio differente che ne aumenta o differisce la difficoltà
-Ogni partita è differente dalla precedente e può sembrare migliore, ma esser la peggiore della vostra vita o vice versa.


Contro:
-La grafica pur essendo settata volutamente in un certo modo forse poteva essere un po piu dettagliata 
-Non ci sono tantissime quest o punti di interesse (ma non credo sia nemmeno lo scopo dei programmatori riempire questo gioco di quest)
-Ovvie limitazioni da piattaforma e da indi software game portano a pochi aggironamenti e sempre piu radi man a mano che il tempo passa (peccato) Non ho trovato mod o implementazioni esterne, ne traduzioni in italiano per via appunto del Flash che da quanto hanno detto i programmatori in una discussione è limitante.

Appunto:
Credo che il fatto che non si possa salvare e ripartire dalla mossa precedente sia una scelta voluta e giusta, ma creare un flag per lascirare decidere al giocatore che tipo di esperienza vuole giocare o RI giocare o semplicemente cercare di andare avanti il piu possibile ricalcolando mosse potrebbe essere divertente (esiste in realtà un modo di salvare, basta copiare ogni tanto un file flash del salvo da un altra parte e rimetterlo quando muori per "riprovare" )


Concludendo :
Neo Scavenger è un gioco al pc, un libro da leggere e un film nelle vostre menti che scatena il coivolgimento.
inaspettati esiti , loot casuali e scelte creano un caos ordinato che concluderà la vostra storia sempre alla morte, ma ad ogni esito potrete dire "ho osato troppo, sono stato sfortunato, oppure semplicemente ho fatto il meglio che ho potuto"

玩之前感觉这游戏虽然画风不好，但是各种设定还挺带感的嘛
但玩过几次之后，就发现它的简陋不是停留在画面

用技能的选择来代替难度选择，即使不考虑剧情问题，也显得十分鸡肋：单局玩法单一，技能的意义大多限于初期，有些玩法太过依赖运气（竟然不是让人想多试试别的开局？是的，因为游戏本身的简陋）

剧情文本一般，可互动内容特别少，剧情选择以及随机事件愚蠢至极！！！ 
我不知道那些剧情杀的选项的意义何在？
要么你先看攻略，被剧透之后，未卜先知，选择最好的选项
要么就赌运气，选错了就没有任何办法地被一段文字杀死，然后删档重来
很多选项都不是依靠推理能解决的，因为这是设定好的
没有特定技能，某些剧情根本无法触发，或者是必死的

单局流程很短，后期极度无聊，当你拿到打火机，撬棍，一件厚衣服，这个游戏基本上就“通关了”，进入“不作死就不会死”的阶段
但这个游戏没有任何操作空间，作也没什么乐趣（难不成去正面刚一队守卫？或者主动染上蓝腐病，靠自愈换抗体？），剧情又是那副样子，以我这种半吊子水平，半个小时就毕业了
绝对是我玩过的最不耐玩的生存游戏

感觉这更像是一个为玩家制作的生存游戏编辑器，框架很好，内容少的可怜

30498339.review:
I have been thinking for a while whether this game should get a thumbs up or a thumbs down from me. In the end, I'm going with a reluctant thumbs up, though I'd recommend waiting for a sale.

NEO Scavenger is a post-apocalyptic roguelike survivalist game that is also often dubbed a hobo simulator. For good reason: you start the game waking up in a facility with nothing but a hospital gown, a wrist strap and a strange talisman. Once you start playing and get to look at your inventory screen, you will notice that you do not actually have any inventory space. This game does not give you an abstract bag to store your items in. You can carry whatever you carry around in your hand - if you want more, you will need to scavenge a cardboard box or a plastic shopping bag to carry your stuff in (the former you have to carry in your hand, the latter can be used as a backpack). If you are good enough at scavenging, you may eventually be able to find something better, such as a children's backpack - a legit travelling backpack is a luxury you'll have to search a lot for, and either way, even these backpacks will be extremely limiting, so you do have to carefully pick and choose what to carry with you. Eventually, you can get a much bigger inventory by finding an abandoned shopping cart or other similar vehicle you can lug your items around in, but that makes it harder to run away if you get into trouble (unless you ditch the cart and just run for your life).

Anyway, there are strict inventory constraints and you also have to deal with rapid wear and tear on your equipment - some shoddy stuff (hand-crafted weapons, sandals) might fall apart after just a short period of use. You also have to deal with finding food and water - and beyond that, you have to make sure the food is edible, the water is not contaminated, and beyond that, to find a same place to sleep, to find a pair of shoes (that don't give you blisters when you walk in them), and to survive all the encounters out there. All this makes for a very gritty and tough survivalist game and this is actually the strong point of NEO Scavenger. The 'feel' is really good and the challenges of this game are rather unique - not many games have you struggle for basic necessities like this one. Death is permanent - no reloads.

There are three major weak points, though, which you should be aware of. One of them would not be enough to spoil the game, but the three of them together do, or at least get close to doing so... it is up to you to decide if they are big enough red flags for you.

First: NEO Scavenger's survivalism is based around an extensive crafting system. You need to craft in order to ensure your water is not infected (drinking all the water you find makes things much harder, though it's actually possible to survive with the constant diarrhea and other illnesses you get from doing so if you are lucky enough), to light fires for warmth and cooking, to craft primitive weapons and more. The crafting system is quite cumbersome, though, which is a major problem when it is so necessary to use it. It is hard to get into at first, hard to understand all the different options you have, and the interface is a bit unwieldy in general.

Second: The developers originally started programming this game in Flash, which (according to their own admission, even) turned out to be a pretty bad idea, but they never rebuilt it in a more suitable environment. This means that the game has a few quirks and a few very nasty bugs. Saves seem to have a tendency to get corrupted every now and then, and while there is an autosave option, that introduces other problems in turn (I had my minimap data get wiped while autosave was on).

[Note: apparently some autosave bugs were just recently fixed a few days after writing this review. So there's that.]

Third: despite being a roguelike, this game lacks something most roguelikes have, which is extensive replayability. Unlike in most RLs, there is no leveling or character development - your guy doesn't get any stronger or weaker throughout the game (aside from illnesses/injuries and other temporary buffs/debuffs), so the progression in the game stems solely from you exploring newer areas and finding stronger enemies. There is also only one start (no races/classes, no different starting scenarios) so if you've completed the game once, you've seen it all... aside from any optional areas you might have missed the first time around. Further, quite a few of the challenges in the game don't even stem from poor scavenging strategy or combat - sometimes you just get a brief "choose your own adventure" segment where you have to click on various options and hope that you aren't instakilled. Common sense and caution can generally get you through these encounters, but still, this doesn't help replayability. Further, though it takes a while to learn how to survive early on, the game is not actually that hard later on once you're set and since it is easy to just run away from the majority of foes (plus there's little reason to fight them when you can't get XP or essential loot from them - you can get everything you need from just scavenging), you just need to learn what options to click (or not to click) in the choose-your-own-adventure segments and you know how to win.

Well, NEO Scavenger is a good hobo simulator, but not a very good roguelike. So I guess that whether you should buy the game depends on whether you're looking for the former or the latter. It's a fun little game with an interesting story (and you'll have some interesting stories of your own to tell on the forum after you play), but it just isn't something that will keep you occupied for hundreds of hours, replaying it again and again. Its hobo simulator aspect is good enough for me to barely justify a recommendation, however.

30154416.review:
GAWD DAM IT!!!!!!!!!!
FUC!!!!!!!
STUPID GAMEE!!!!!

Finally got my feet under me.

Took 3 arrows but won the fight...i don't take them out cause I figure it'll make the wound worse. Limped back to base. Fought off a dog on the way. Boil up some clean rags, notice that my wounds have stopped bleeding. Shit this is going to hurt.

Takes out an arrow, bandages (wow, I'll survive this!)
Takes out another arrow, bandages (Damn right!)
Takes out third arrow, everything goes fine! I'm going to live! Arrow in 'hand,' move cursor to place arrow on ground, click, not enough room to place. Game decides "oops, gotta put this arrow somewhere, but there's no room on the ground..."

Game inserts arrow back into my gushing chest, slicing the pulmonary, kills me instantly.

Fucing...hell....

All because the game designers fucked up the item movement system. (FIX THIS!!!)

So yeah.


Otherwise, it's a pretty fun game, just lacks on content. I know, shocking...but I believe this. The big problem is how do you survive? Once you figure this out...not much left to do. The main storyline is pretty short all things considered (and not really deep or logical when you really try to make sense of it) and there's not terribly many 'random'/'lesser' encounters to keep you busy along the way. None of the guys that walks around ever talks to you, they just try to kill you or run away. 

Overall the impression you are left with is that you are fighting a wave of death. This is really cool. But shallow after about 5 hours because everything is so in depth that you are left wondering, "why isn't the human side of things as complex?"

There should be people who are traders. There should be non-combat entities walking around on the map, trying to accomplish their own goals (secure a campsite like you...hunt deer or creatures for their faction). Desperates who are sort of lost, running away that you can interact with. You should be able to form a band of followers, be able to discuss their roles in your little band of survivors and start relationships etc... I feel like other games already do this but that people developing a game pick one main theme to go after then stop, instead of diversifying and branching out and growing.

At the moment there are some 'encounters' that happen randomly when you enter a square...and these are great!...but there aren't enough. This is sort of like a 'first step' towards humanizing the game.

There should be an alliance 'system,' so that if a guy with the 'trapper' skill settles down 20 hexes from you and makes that his base, you can go approach him, offer to trade, and develop a relationship. Now you can approach more freely etc...

Here's another idea: Instead of adding human-centric 'content' in the form of side quests and dialogue trees, try and think of some ways you can mix it up. Be innovative. If you can add something that completely shocks people because they don't expect it from a video game, they'll love you forever and your game will be remembered.

What I think is funny is that the devs tried to hook a story onto the game without any of the above 'humanization'. You get a thrill from uncovering the story but the SECOND you know what happens, you stop caring. The devs should hire some literacy major who just graduated and is working at BK (this would cost next to nothing) to take a look at their game and write some story in for them. Might even do it for free for the resume.

So my advice: 
1) Add some more 'systems' (like the allegience, like seriously expanded dialogue, like other NOT-PLAYER CENTERED characters etc.). Every system you add on top of what you've got will expand the scope, audience, and profit of the game geometrically.
2) Hire someone who knows how to write a story and populate a world with characters. If you're going to end the story like you did (and hint at a sequel like you did), you need to have a reason for us to follow the guy we play as. For the audience to care, you need a good characterization and some intriguing humanization. Try engendering endearment with non-life threatening consequences (severing of relationships, loss of 'honor' or something else your guy values).
3) Don't give up. You've made something really great here, but it seems like you've stopped. Don't do that.
4) With every step you take, ask if someone has done it before. If you can, try to make your solution unique.

good luck

29720798.review:
[h1]Player has begun transformation into a Wendingo.[/h1]

[b]NEO Scavenger[/b] is a turn based isometric roguelite survival sandbox role-playing game. 

In the at first bare feet of Philip Kindred, dazing panicked out of a cryogenic facility, the plotline tasks the player, in addition to surviving, with finding their forgotten past and any background on the Michigan wasteland. The menus are unintuitive and a bit of a mess to navigate effectively, but eventually it becomes more or less second nature. 

Remarkably detailed sprites represent everything in the game world, including your "paper doll" character avatar. There's really not much else to say about the graphics: it's not a super high tech 3D game. The screenshots should give an idea of how it will look like.

On the sound front, the effects are equally simple: crunchy footsteps when moving on the map, cracking and popping firewood when you get a campfire going. The little slurp sound when consuming water is especially satisfying when you're heavily dehydrated, even if it may only buy you some time in the end. Music is ominous when it does trigger.

You start the game by choosing your character's desired positive skills and negative traits - aside from Unstoppable and Elusive reputations and one surgery, you gain no more skills or traits throughout the game, so choose wisely what you'll stick with on your playthrough. Your character then wakes from a cryo pod, with an imposing and lethal dogman approaching his location. Your abilities and any found items can provide additional responses to encounters and combat, even some which may not be immediately apparent.

Once having escaped from or dealt with the dogman, you're pressured into finding means of regulating your temperature, quenching your hunger and thirst, and any other bodily ailments. Scavenging is a big part of the game, but even bigger is [b]smart[/b] scavenging. Moving on the map leaves trails, which get more intense if you decide to run, if you're suffering from certain ailments or if you're pure and simply bleeding. Searching for loot in promissing places is always a tradeoff between the chance of winning something, the risk of being stuck or hurt by collapsing structures, and of making a big enough racket that you get spotted.

Combat is a difficult affair; it's less about striking with the biggest stick than it is about dancing around your enemy and exploiting any vulnerable states while covering your own flank, and exploiting the environment whenever possible. In general, fallen combat entities are at the greatest risk, as they can't do anything but crawl, roll dodge and get up. For a pleasant change from the norm, melee weapons have their own ranges: a crowbar will reach further than your own two fists. Firearms, of course, are even deadlier, but they use hard to find, expensive munition, and are cumbersome to store.

Once combat is resolved, the surviving party needs to tend to their wounds. A fairly in-depth medical system presents itself with bruises and cuts, which may bleed, and demand different types of care. Pain accumulates from multiple wounds or a couple severe ones, like crippled limbs, and too much pain will interfere negatively with all of your activities, culminating in passing out (usually a death sentence in combat). Blood loss remains a concern both in and outside of combat, as penalties to your physical prowess and temperature regulation pile up if you run low, but using dirty rags to bandage wounds is generally a bad idea. In the longer term, immune system strength determines how easily you're able to fight back against things like cholera and infected wounds. The standard survival needs appear too, and they, too, negatively affect your actions if you go too hungry, thirsty, tired, carry too much load, and are too hot/cold.

The game does seem to have an unintrusive overarching plotline, with the first player nudge appearing in the first night: the distant lights, promise and opportunities of the Detroit Mega City. Trudging through marshes and ruined suburbs and high rises, popping pills to keep the pain of fighting under control, setting noise makers when camping to stand a chance at catching trespassers before they do you in, going cannibalistic, random encounters with unfavourable actions and outcomes, are all just some of the things you'll face on your journey to survive in Michigan.

While permadeath remains a staple of modern, indie survival games, it is a bit of a shame to lose the progress of a highly developed plotline to seemingly random deaths. I guess that's what makes this game that little bit more special than the droves of survival sandbox games coming out in recent years: a sense of purpose.

It is a good game with great replayability. Definitely recommended with a small sale.

29465122.review:
Great game, if you like bullshit. I was in perfect condition, no wounds, full health, everything. Out of nowhere, I get "Poison stage 2" "Sepsis" "Severe Abdominal Pain". So I go to the hospital. Get "Treatment for all sicknesses and Poisons"(fucking nanorobots!). Painkillers. Anitbiotics.
It does nothing. 
All of a sudden I get "Blood loss" (without wounds btw). "You are getting colder" AND "you are suffering from heat exhaustion"(at the same time lol). Bam, dead. Btw, this is WITH a trait that says: "You have a strong immune system".

In the Forum, I find a bunch of posts a la: "Sepsis uncurable" etc.

So yeah, lots of bullshit RNG. Like enemies RIGHT NEXT to you being able to escape, etc.

Let's get into it.

Right off the bat, this is a really amatureish game. It runs in Abobe FLASH PLAYER (lol). You can't take screenshots. If you click "New game", it doesn't even ask whether you want to delete your old save. It just deletes it instantly. So one misclick, and you're fucked.

The inventory system is really bad; just your basic grid inventory. There is an auto arrange function. But that's it. No logic. Can't flip items. Can't put items in your hoodie's pockets, if you have a coat over it. Got some wire? You can hang a crowbar over your shoulder! But not a spear.
Crafting is stupidly tedious. You have to drag items into the screen, to even see what you can make. WHY? How about you just show us what we can make from all our items? Nope.
Recipes are nothing but written instructions. Have fun scrolling through pages of text. Intuitiveness = 0.

Also, it's got the most basic quest system I have EVER seen in a game. IF you can get someone to talk to you, they give you one sentence, end of conversation. I say IF, because even if you hold someone at gunpoint, they won't talk to you. BUT you waste a turn, so now they can hit you in the face. And then escape. Seems legit.

Also, just a little PSA to all wannabe game desingers out there: Items do not BREAK so quickly in real life. This is a survival game TROPE, and it needs to die. It's stupid.

Survival Games "survive" on REALISM and LOGIC, and this game is just sub par in those regards.

The fact that there is no help/tutorial whatsoever doesn't help either... Dying of some bullshit is NOT "experiencing" or "learning". It just sucks. I refuse to play another mediocre survival game, while having to read the FUCKING wiki...
That's another fucking survival game trope. Gtfo!

That being said, the game CAN be fun at times, in the usual survival game fashion. But seeing as this BS is making me consider just stopping this game already, I think it warrants a "thumbs down"
If this was the first survival game ever, it would be ok. But survival games come a dime a dozen, since over a decade, so you should have the genre figured out by now. And being an "Indie", is not an excuse.

VERDICT: Low production value survival game with BS RNG mechanics, lack of logic, and -occasionally- fun.

Buy at your own risk. Don't expect a great game.

UPDATE: Just died in a fight. I had a knife. It "Scratched" him. Guy hit my arm with the blunt end of a pistol. I passed out from "unbearable pain" (hahaha). Guy kept hitting me. Died from brain injury.

Fuck this game.

29301228.review:
Neo Scavenger is a challenging rougue-like that pushes you to survive with whatever chance throws your way. Every step forward could mean a miracle of a find or certain death. A good, solid play that requires strategy and good old fashioned luck.

~

Neo Scavenger uses a turn-based RPG system of gameplay that sees you move your character over a tabletop of hexagons, each tile representing something from ragged abndoned cities, wide open fields, and whatever else lay dormant in the wasteland.

The gameplay is challenging and is almost purely startegy and luck. You need to make do with whatever you can find, even when it's practically nothing. The skill comes in knowing what to do with what you have. Though the game doesn't neccesarily take it upon itself to point a few things out that could potentially save your life, you're going to need to experiment some with what options you have on screen. The user interface itself is a bit confusing at first but isn't terrible once you get the hang of it.

The visuals used are excellent and the pixel art for things like objects, enemies, and landmarks are all easily discernible from their sprites alone. Even your own player character will eventually start to look like a real bonafide survivor after not too long, the rag tag mashup of loot, weapons, and accesories included. Cut scenes use their own original art for each one.

The soundtrack adds a brooding atmosphere to the game, one fitting a world where everything is in tatters and nothing is new. Other than the soundtrack, sound effects mainly come from moving or using items. Not much else makes noise and their is no audible dialogue.

All in all, this is a great, solid game that anyone with a taste for survivng, scavenging, and strategising could get into.

29213171.review:
I know I will get flamed for this, but this game is just too hard. Period. End of story.

I do not understand the modern trend of making these rogue-type games with no difficulty slider. (Teleglitch, I am looking at you.) I mean, you make a game to garner profits, then make that game so hard that only die-hards will even bother to buy it, and that is somehow the new model? Why not make the game approachable to a lot more people by having a difficulty slider, and then special achievements for those brave enough to try the hardest settings?

Far Cry Primal, for example: It has an easy setting that a 3-year-old can play, but it also has a very very very difficult survivor expert mode that 99.9% of players will never even play, let alone beat. Often, with games like Far Cry and Metro and Fallout, I beat it on an easy setting first, then go back for punishment later. I get a lot of hours out of these games, and the key: they are FUN. I mean, I am not necessarily asking for excessive hand-holding like the quest indicators in Skyrim, but just asking for a decent save system and a difficulty slider.

Games like Teleglitch and NEO Scavenger are absolutely terrible for the elitist attitudes they promote. Those games have nothing to do with FUN and everything to do with hollow acomplishments few people can even relate to. So why am I angry or even bothering? I am bothering because other than the difficulty levels, these games are interesting and COULD BE a lot of fun.

Consider the absurdity of Teleglitch. That game advertises hundreds of custom guns, but guess what? 99% of those guns you will never find or even get to shoot on this side of 1000 hours of play due solely to the difficulty of the game. I just do not think that is cool. For this nightmare, NEO Scavenger, I have put in quite a few hours, and I have never even found a gun. Ever. Never won a fight. Ever. I fixed the HVAC heater, fixed the electricity, found sleeping and mummy bags, found shopping carts, and really that is about it, and I always always always died for stupid reasons that in real life would never happen. 

So sad that the difference between a no-star review and a 5-star review is the simple addition of a difficulty slider and custom achievements.

29076753.review:
Few games manage to create an atmosphere that's as creepy and demoralizingly nerve-racking as Neo-Scavenger. This is a scary game at bottom, but not "thrill-horror"; things don't jump out at you. No, it has that horror of, "Oh god... I know what's coming for me... I can see it a few miles off in the distance... and I can't do anything about it... I might as well keep pushing along and hope I can hide when it catches up." That kind of horror.

The music does a great job of adding to this atmosphere as well. Good music is hard to come by in games these days. Usually you find bland formless soundtracks, or stuff that just "gets the job done", but in Neo-Scavenger the music is an essential part of the experience.

This is a very good adventure game with unique gameplay and a very original setting.

29059215.review:
Let me just say this at the outset: even though I've put more than 50 hours into NEO Scavenger, I still haven't beaten the game. Not because it's dense (it is), not because it requires you to wrestle with brutal RNG (it does), and not because it can kill you whenever it darn well pleases even after hours of scavenging and gearing up (it can--and it will). I haven't beaten this game simply because I haven't felt the need.

There is a story here: after picking your traits (ranging from combat and technical expertise to wilderness lore) and weaknesses (like nearsightedness and physical fragility) you wake up in a cryogenic facility in a world struck by a mysterious apocalypse. At first you have nothing but your name, a hospital gown, and a mysterious amulet. But with a lot of scavenging and a lot more luck, you can find and craft the gear necessary to fend off the raiders, disease-ridden cultists, and horrifying creatures that roam the wilds as you search for your identity and uncover the secrets of the world.

The game is broken up into two sections: the hex-based overworld and text-based encounters. On the overworld, you move from hex to hex to get from Point A to Point B, stopping at urban hexes to scavenge for items and wilderness hexes to scavenge/hunt for food. When you enter the same hex as an NPC, you initiate an encounter in which you can choose to offer a ceasefire and go your separate ways, or engage in combat (the more likely event). Scavenging, combat, and most story events are presented in a choose-your-own-adventure-style: the situation is explained to you in detail and you can decide from a number of options (others being open or closed to you depending on your traits and equipment). Most choices you make are basically dice rolls. In combat, for example, dodging and attacking requires you to roll your luck against your opponent. Actions that are unlocked by specific traits or items (for example, luring an enemy into a trap with your trapping skill) are always successful. 

But because of the nature of the game, it doesn't always matter how careful and prepared you are: you can and will be one-shotted by powerful enemies. Even average enemies can kill you if they sneak up on you in your sleep, or get lucky with a good strike, or if you fall during combat and can't manage to get up. And if you die, that's it. You have to start from the beginning.

So with that said, if you get this game and want to beat it, prepare to be frustrated. Prepare to lose a lot of important rolls. Prepare to get a game over based on trial and error in which a single choice leads to your death without any warning or indication beforehand. And if none of these things bother you, then prepare for a lot of reading and a lot of experimentation just to find out how to craft a decent starting weapon or light a fire.

If, however, you're like me and don't care about finishing the game, then you will find a surprisingly satisfying survival simulation with brutal combat and a crafting system that will make you feel like a genius. It's perfectly possible to ignore the main quest, set up camp somewhere, and live day by day off the land and your luck. In fact, I'd suggest you do this for your first few playthroughs--even if you ultimately want to beat the game--because you'll learn what works and what doesn't.

Here's the bottom line: NEO Scavenger is a dense game that doesn't have much in the way of flash. But it's got a lot of depth and surprising complexity. It's a game that relies a lot on luck; you can fight and kill a giant man-wolf-beast with a spear, then die the next day because of some bad water. But this can be mitigated to some extent by knowledge, which you will only gain from playing--and dying--a lot.

28905428.review:
What a cracking little gem this game is. Brutal and unforgiving though it is is does manage that rarest of feats in providing an emergent story. The moment you get cocky you're toast. Complaints against the RNG element are not without basis, but then survival is like that. I'm not a massive rogue-like fan and would usually prefer the ability to save, but I realised this game had something special when I died after a 6 hour solid playthrough and smiled rather than rage-quit. The graphics are abysmal, the menus somewhat clunky and I come from an era that had to live through low res graphics and don't find them charming and rretro. But never has a game drawn so heavily on the imagination, and never have I experienced a game that manages to bring a crappy low res hex to life.

The combat is what sets it apart from Project Zomboid, apart from the deep joy of not having to deal with ***king zombies. Whilst somewhat barebones it does make you very careful about how you go about it. In addition there doesn't come a time when easy mobs are trivial bore to swat away. That feral dog can still trouble an unfortunate or over-confident veteran. Every encounter has the potential to send you into a downward spiral if not handled with care.

The luck cuts both ways, I had a very fortunate shot with a sling that set me up nicely with very useful loot, which I lost because I thought it made me king of the hill. 

In short if you really want a zombie free realistic survival experience and you have the imagination to paint the picture in your mind rather than have it rendered in technicolor for yo,u then this game is a must buy. The dev deserves high praise for this little cracker and whilst it is by no means perfect and regularly kicks you in the nads there's something special about this one that spectacularly succeeds in  being greater than the sum of its parts.

28846311.review:
Fallout 2+.

Si vous aimez les jeux en tour-par-tour, basés sur du texte, au RP assez fort, aux caractéristiques déterminantes, avec chaque contre-partie possible (la vision d'aigle, c'est cool, mais la myopie, ça s'échange bien contre un talent pour savoir ce qui est comestible ou non !), et une histoire aux choix variés, ce jeu est fait pour vous !

Il assez rustique au premier abord : graphismes basiques, textes omniprésents, interface simpliste.
Il se laisse dompter avec un-peu d'effort : très punitif et souvent imprévisible (un escalier de trop suffit pour perdre son personnage), il est pourtant très riche en contenu et pas avare en événements.

80h plus tard, vous aussi, devenez PGM :
[spoiler]Petit guide de choix de stats "craqués" : [list]
[*] Combats : [b]Strong[/b] + [b]Melee[/b]
[*] Survie : [b]Medic[/b] + [b]Botany[/b] + [b]Trapping[/b]
[*] Avec des points en rab' : [b]Hiding[/b]
[*] Négatifs : [b]Metabolism[/b] + [b]Myopia[/b] + [b]Fragile[/b] (+ [b]Insomniac[/b])
[/list]
Détail du choix :[list]
[*] [b]Lockpincking[/b] ne sert presque à rien quand on transporte au-moins un pied de biche
[*] [b]Hacking[/b] ne permet que d'obtenir des données à revendre (§§ cher §§)
[*] [b]Mechanic[/b]/[b]Electrincian[/b] servent surtout à crafter des trucs qui peuvent être lootés gratuitement
[*] [b]Ranged[/b] sert à distance (promis !)
[*] [b]Hiding[/b] *peut* servir à se protéger contre une arme à distance
[*] [b]Tracking[/b] ne sert (pour moi) à rien hors multi-joueurs
[*] [b]Botany[/b] peut facilement être remplacé par [b]Athletic[/b] ([b]Myopia[/b] devient alors inutile, ou à garder pour [b]Hiding[/b] avec [b]Insomniac[/b])
[/list]
Petits trucs de jeu :[list]
[*] Les sacs, c'est le bien ; tous les sacs, aussi gros que possibles, partout où c'est possible (dos, mains, hanches, jambes) ; pour vivre heureux(es), vivons saqués
[*] Un sac plastique vide (en boule) ne prend qu'un emplacement, à toujours conserver au cas où l'usure aurait raison d'un de vos autres sacs
[*] Tuer la bête de départ permet d'obtenir son corps, qui se découpe en fourrure ([b]Trapping[/b]) + viandes
[*] [b]Medic[/b] permet de scavenger la zone de départ pour trouver une trousse de soins (le premier "sac" assuré du jeu)
[*] Les boîtes de médicaments prennent 2 emplacements, et stockent 2 tas de médicaments, elles ne servent donc à rien ; +> les bouteilles (vides) prennent 3 emplacements et peuvent stocker chacune 6 tas de médicaments, c'est donc largement rentable
[*] L'eau potable et l'eau insalubre ne se mélangent pas, il suffit donc d'obtenir une unité (goutte) d'eau potable (par loot ou cuisson) pour la superposer avec une autre unité d'eau inconnue : si les 2 fusionnent, ce sont de l'eau potable toutes les 2, il ne reste plus qu'à les séparer (avec shift) pour récupérer l'eau (potable) inconnue, puis essayer sur une autre unité inconnue voir si elles fusionnent
[*] Les points d'actions se comptent en entier, sauf pour le craft ; c'est donc possible d'utiliser 0,9 points en craft, et de consommer le 0,1 restant en faisant autre-chose que du craft
[*] Rentrer dans une forêt ou sur une colline consomme normalement 2 points d'action ; pour économiser, il vaut mieux le faire en toute fin de tour pour "finir" le reste de ses actions (0,1 points suffisent largement à ça)
[*] La viande d'humain(oïde) n'a pas de contrepartie, si ce n'est d'être interdite à la revente au marché noir
[*] L'électricité se stocke très bien dans une batterie de smartphone, qui emcombre 1 à 3 emplacements d'inventaire pour stocker jusqu'à une douzaine de réserves
[/list][/spoiler]
Voilà, sur-ce, et pour ne pas être hors-sujet : ce jeu est vraiment bon, il est juste.. spécial.

28795554.review:
For a game like this, you have to compare it to the other games in its genre, survival. I can think of Don't Starve and This War of Mine. Both games are probably superior to Neo Scavanger in both polish, balance and depth. The story/rpg elements in Neo Scavanger are very light so not worth mentioning. The main thing Neo scavanger has going for it compared to these two titles is it is turn-based.

Don't starve has the most depth and polish.
This War of Mine offers the most control (least randomness).
Neo Scavanger offers turn-based experience and is probably more random.

So do I recommend it? Well, I really like my games to be turn-based. If you are like me, consider getting this on a sale. Otherwise, the other two games are probably superior.

Edit: Aaand I just got hit by a playthrough ruining bug involving my shopping cart bursting and the game not calculating my encumberance correctly.

28786121.review: This game is way more complex, detailed, and downright fun than I expected it to be. Some of the negative reviews I read complained about how the random nature of some of the game elements can screw you over, regardless of how well you've prepared-- while I have had this happen to me (more than once), I think that it's just a reality of this style of game, and careful planning can lessen the risk. I think my biggest complaint would be that there do still seem to be some kinks in the system: for instance, I just lost my most recent game because I got locked in the combat screen until I died, AFTER I had already killed the enemy. That said, this game is overall interesting and really well conceived; if you like tile-based adventure games, this one is definitely for you.

28679233.review:
Hands down one of the best games out there.

It's like a single-player Rust roguelike set in a Fallout style post-apocalyptic wasteland with a dash of dwarf fortress adventure mode.

Outstanding but not overbearing or mandatory story. You can just ignore it and survive, or you can persue it and enjoy the eerie and compelling narrative.

Incredible, constantly changing and progressing combat. Tons of variables including fatigue, damage type, range, and even intimidation make sure that the combat stays complex, deep into the game. 

The graphics might look off-putting at first, but they're exactly where they need to be. After five minutes of play, you're completely immersed.

Salvaging is wonderful. Do I explore the crumbling apartment building? It might collapse. I could use a torch so I can see better and maybe not hurt myself, but then it's more likely that something angry will see the light and come for me.

I can't give it enough praise. I don't play single players games, but I LOVE playing this and comparing stories with my friends.

The only bad thing I can say about this game is that the crafting system is a bit clunky, and a lot of things aren't explained as well as they could be. This is however quickly remedied with the wiki.

9 out of 10.

28664532.review: I followed this game since its early stages and it has surely come a long way. Definitely RNG based, which can be a hassle some of the time, but overall brings the point across that it's supposed to be hard. It's a survival game for a reason after all. It's like the dark souls of hex games in that regard; one moment you're living life to your fullest potential and then you'll get mauled by a pack of dogs. It is just how the game is and not knowing what's around the corner is what makes it enjoyable. Plus there are lots of different ways to go about playing which makes replayability higher.

28664058.review:
You REALLY SHOULD play NEO Scavenger. (If you enjoy survival and rouge-like games especially.)

If the price is too much for you, wishlist it and grab it on sale, but it's well worth the full price. I bought it at full price for myself and have grabbed several copies at various prices for friends.  (PS: There's a free demo so you can try it without buying it.)

[b][u]The Short:[/u][/b] [list]
[*] Incredibly addictive and fun ... you may be surprised at how easily it sucks you in
[*] File save is bit of a con, but there are steps you can take to prevent game loss
[*] Learn from experience and past mistakes
[*] RNG hates everyone sometimes
[/list]

[b][u]Quick Tips:[/u][/b] [list]
[*] Reading is important ... be sure you do that.
[*] Using your brain is important ... be sure you do that too.
[*] Your first character WILL die ... and so will many more. Expect it and enjoy the ride.
[*] Until you get some experience with the game, I recommend stacking your skills to how you want to play then branch off and try other skills later.
[i]i.e. If you prefer to avoid combat, take hiding, athletics (running away) and tracking (seeing where others are/have been).[/i]
[/list]

[b][u]The Long:[/u][/b]
I wanted to first address some of the issues presented in the couple negative reviews I saw in the hopes that it presents some additional perspective.
[olist]
[*] "It's too hard" -> Grow up. You can't (and shouldn't) expect to win a game on your first time out. There's a learning curve. It's a fantastic addition to the game.
[*] "The Interface" -> It is different, yes. It can be difficult sometimes, yes. But every game out there has a different UI from one another. Just takes some getting used to.
[*] "Too random" -> Honestly, I think this makes each time you play so wonderfully different than the last ... But for a large amount of the random items you get an indication of how things will go. What items will you get? What enemies? Will you find food or starve?  There's dice rolls involved, and sometimes it sucks. A lot. (After saving to buy a really expensive item, only to die just outside the city to a creature type I had defeated several times in the past... I was so angry. It even managed to stop me from playing ... for like a day. Then it was a 'how can I do this better' situation.) Sometimes sh*t happens, we just have to pick up and keep going.
[*] "Permadeath" -> ?? ... It's a SURVIVAL game ... If there was no permadeath, then there would be no survival! If dying means nothing, then surviving means nothing...
[*] "Save game system" -> Yep, it's flash. Yes, it can get wiped if you clear your web files. Yes, it can't save if you have flash blocked. It's not perfect, but it's how this particular game was made. Over 100 hours played (plus 10 or so on the demo before I purchased it), and I have not had any issue with losing a saved game.
[*] "Poor graphics" -> Ok. Yes, it's not the out-of-this-world 3D modeled everything that make for pretty cutscenes, but I don't think the graphics detract from the gameplay experience. Look at it one of two ways: It's charmingly retro, OR It's a post-apocalyptic game where civilization has collapsed and tech is very limited so this was what could be produced ;)
[*] Some info lacking -> Not in the reviews I saw, but definitely an issue I had with the game. Additional info about certain items should be available from NPCs at least. I can understand the character not instantly knowing all the information about a particular item (weapon for instance), but a guard probably should or a shopkeep. Why can't I ask them so I don't have to guess it's effective range or drawbacks?
[/olist]
I think those were the main things that caught my eye. Now on to the good stuff!

I wish under "Do you recommend this game?" there was an option for "Abso-freaking-lutely!"
I love this game. I'm not even sure I could explain exactly why. But I do.
It's single player only, but my friends and I have mused at how this could work multi-player. (We have no clue.) But for now, it's entertaining to narrate little stories about our adventures while we play. (One friend [spoiler]turned to cannibalism[/spoiler]... oh the stories with those playthroughs...)
[list]
[*] There is lots of... -> There's lots of items. There's lots of ways to use items. There's lots of status effects. There's lots of ways to die. There's lots of ways to live. There's lots of area to explore. There's lots of places to scavenge. There's lots of pockets and bags. There's lots of ways to interact.
[*] Common sense is useful... -> Drinking dirty water might make you sick. Eating rotten food will very probably make you sick. A sling's effective range isn't as far as a rifle's. A meat cleaver will hurt more than a fist. Freezing is bad. [spoiler]Wearing a left shoe on my right foot will give me blisters[/spoiler]. [spoiler]A tree provides a better hiding spot than bare, open ground[/spoiler]. Etc...  
[*] Living is hard... -> This is no piece of cake. Nor should it be. Surviving in a post-apocalyptic world on your own with nothing but a hospital gown would be VERY difficult, if not impossible, for most. NEO Scavenger brings this reality to us with rng, some punishing encounters and permadeath. The better suited you are for battle, the better you will do, but victory is never guaranteed. 
[*] That's not how it went last time... -> Ah, good old RNG. Always remembered for being infuriating and not for the times you should have died, but didn't. Just as places, items, scavenge results, etc... are random, so are the creatures/NPCs. Their stats can vary from one to another even if they are the same type (although the same types will have a range for stats). It keeps the game varied as you really don't know if that creature will attack viciously or run after a few wounds.
[*] What happens next... -> The story and writing are quite enjoyable. Drawing you in and making you want to keep coming back and progress to find out what's going to happen. There's the occassional, "wtf did that just say?" But overall, it's a definite pro. Like I said, reading is important.
[/list]

If you made it through all that, congrats. And thank you. Hopefully this helped you out in some way, shape or form to enjoy NEO Scavenger.

28427993.review:
As a game, this is an admirable failure.  As an artistic experience, it succeeds, but not in a way that makes for a playable video game.  The bottom line, however, is that you almost certainly should not play it.

The writing is excellent, and not just by video game standards.  The dev could write good sci-fi fiction.

The game has permadeath.  The core game loop is good, but clunky.  Progress is punishing.  It takes 10 real life minutes to make a bunch of arrows, which aren't particularly effective, but they're what you get.  I recommend the sling.  Even taking all precautions, you can die instantly because a dogman or blue frog pops up at close proximity or in your sleep and kills you in one round.  You realize that there's nothing you could have done, and often there's nothing you can learn from to prevent it in the future.  

Because getting a character into survival state, which allows exploring the story, takes several hours, the clunkiness becomes an insane ping-pong of clicks (left screen, right screen, ten ping-pong clicks to sleep; seven to scavenge a single building; repeat until you die or quit, then repeat some more).  I view this as an artistic statement about life that, like the sudden and unpreventable deaths, cannot be understood until wearily experienced.

The problem is that the game breaks into choose-your-own-adventure encounters that are both the reason to play the game and what breaks it.  A majority of the options in these encounters will instantly end your game.  Single encounters will have branching choices, the majority of which will end your game.  They cannot be predicted.  Because of their branching nature and the immense real life time to get to the point where you see them, you cannot realistically finish the game.  Further, the game hard-limits your exploration; you get X number of choices, then time's up.  The internet is full of gnashing and wailing, true believers who spent over 100 hours on the game begging the dev to release the text files of the end-game, which he basically did by telling people what to search for in the XML files.

If you do buy it, some guy made a batch file that acts as a save-game manager.  Get it.

28208676.review:
NEO Scavenger is a great roguelike survival RPG. Playing it, you really get the impression that the experience of surviving (or not surviving, probably) in a post-apocalyptic future would be this difficult. I recommend it with a few warnings:

- It's a Flash game. That fact annoyed me for some reason when I learned it. Probably because there's no animation and it feels kind of "cheap." It creates the impression of a big, hex-based board game. Also, I'm not sure if it's because of the Flash-based game engine, but I lost all of my "map" progress when the game failed to save properly once.

- The pixelated, retro-style graphics work, but they don't cover up the fact that the game is rather ugly--and not because of the apocalyptic setting.

- There is some groan-inducing writing. Most of the writing is nice, though. It's not anything that detracts from the experience.

- The game is random to a fault sometimes. You're going to come across things that can instantly kill you. Or they'll come across you while you're sleeping. It's not fun to lose hours of progress when a thug caves in your head with a monkey wrench because you picked a poor campsite...or RNGesus didn't give you his blessing.

- Despite the game's randnomness, certain events never change. When you die, you're going to have to redo certain key events to be able to have a decent chance of advancing to the real progression. This can become monotonous after a few new games.

- There are no save slots. This is unconditionally an ironman-mode game. That wouldn't be a problem if there wasn't the occasional corrupted save file.

If you're interested in the genre and you understand that this is a game you might never complete because it's just so damned unforgiving, you can get a lot of fulfilling hours out of this.

28192739.review:
I don't think this is a bad a game per se, I think it is a game that suffers from poor design choices that make it a lot less fun than it could be with just a little more thought and understanding of what makes a game fun. The basic premise is promising - post-apocalyptic survivor wakes up with nothing and is left to fend for themselves.

Unfortunately, you are totally at the mercy of the RNG in this game, meaning that one bad result = game over. Given how almost all mechanics apart from crafting in the game are RNG-based, that means a lot of die rolls and a lot of potential for that one unlucky roll to come up. This is particularly evident in combat, where one lucky roll/critical hit means game over. You can mitigate this somewhat by trying to avoid combat. But you will not be entirely able to avoid combat and retreating is, you guessed it, RNG-based. 

Now of course, RNG-based games always feature bad luck - it's what the R stands for after all. What separates the wheat from the chaff (and where NEO Scavenger desperately falls short) is whether you can recover from "bad luck", i.e. to what extent you are at the mercy of factors outside of your control. Good games always give the player a sense of control over their own destiny – even if the RNG is brutal. When I play something like nethack and die, I normally think, "had I done XYZ differently, I might have survived ". 

NEO Scavenger is far too unforgiving in this respect. A single hit can one-shot you. An unlucky stumble in combat can mean game over. However much you can hedge your bets, the nature of a RNG means that at some point you [i]will[/i] be unlucky. When I die in NEO Scavenger I think, “had the RNG been kinder, I might have survived”. That's a bad sign.

This is a real shame, because the combat in itself is interesting and tactical enough to be engaging initially. But a few games in, and combat no longer interests me. Why not just throw a die at the start and see if I get one-shotted and save me the hassle of trying to be tactical/retreat? This sums up my core problem with NEO Scavenger: it feels like the game is a single dice throw that simply determines how and when you will die; not whether you will die. And that's why it’s not fun.

Other ways to die include dying of hypothermia (= the RNG didn’t spawn enough clothes in the first ~10 turns), infected wounds (=the RNG didn’t spawn a fire-proof canister for boiling water; or alcohol) etc. It’s essentially a glorified version of Snakes & Ladders or Ludo, games determined purely by luck of the dice. 

There are a number of other obvious flaws that would be forgivable if the game itself was fun: Flash is a terrible choice of platform, there are several bugs still in the game (e.g. the act of changing, not wearing, footwear gives you blisters; visual glitches) and the interface (particularly crafting) is clunky to say the least. But none of this would matter if the core game was actually fun.

Großartiges Survival-Indie-RPG Spiel. Es verzeiht einem nichts, man muss seine Schritte gut planen und vorausschauend agieren. Dazu zählt auch sich nicht in jeden Kampf zu stürzen sondern lieber mal zu flüchten. Das Auftreiben von sauberen Wasser, neuem Loot und die Nahrungssuche sind dein täglich Brot.
Bis man den Dreh raus hat, wird man oft von Vorne anfangen müssen!

27745417.review: Detta spelet är en av dom bästa klassiskt inspirerade post apocalyptiska spelen jag någonsin spelat. Att överleva i detta oerhört svåra spel är en dygd, men med träning så blir man bättre. Jag tycker att detta spelet förtjänar priset "skurk i störst behov av en kram" för det är en skam för spelvärlden om detta faller mellan stolarna. Så jag vill ge detta mästervärk alla de kramar det förtjänar <3

27713339.review:
+
1. Absolutely original mix of futuristic post-apocalypse enemies (no zombies thank god)
2. Great mix of sci-fi and fantasy
3. Permadeth is punishing but you will start to care for your life and progress!
4. Great  crafting system.
5. Brutally realistic chose-you own adventure.

Buy it for fullprice, this guy deserves it (even better, goto his web and buy it there, you will have the option to play it in browser everywhere ...even at work ehm ehm)

27683268.review:
How can a game be this deep? There's so much to discover in this world! It may be a survival game, but it sure does feel like an exploration game from time to time. The theme is fantastic with an apocalyptic and lovecraftian vibe!

Like an iceberg in the ocean, you only ever see so little of it if you don't wxplore it fully. It adds to the theme of the game. Makes this game even more mysterious than it already is...

I've also never seen a game like this before! It's a one-of-a-kind hidden gem that keeps on surprising me in all kinds of ways! It's also pretty dificult! 

(It's also incredebly polished!) 

There is one con for me, though: 
Some loadout are far superior than others. It takes away the feeling of multiple choices when creating your character. Some actions are impossible without the right skills, though. This makes it even more unbeliveably replayable.

27652071.review:
Great survival and crafting game.

Turn based, inventory management, skill management, survival management, Rogue Like with storry hooks.

Cons:
The storry bits could have been longer.

27583226.review:
I love this game so much, I own two copies and I plan to get the mobile version when it's released. It's immersive with an extremely interesting story, it has fun mechanics, and it's one of the most frustrating games I've ever played. I was ecstatic when I found 500$ worth of antibiotics, knowing I was safe from infection and I could sell some of the pills for food and other necessities if need be. Happily I made my way through forests and marshes across the map, secure in my wealth and odds of surviving. This and that happened and eventually I needed one of those sacred pills. I reached into my backpack with a smile on my face - only to find out my backpack had fallen apart somewhere in the middle of fucking nowhere and I hadn't noticed (the game told me, I'm just an idiot). ALL of my antibiotics were gone, along with my clean cloths and everything else I was keeping in there. Then I died.

That was a year ago. I'm still raging about it and I'm still playing this game, because I can't fucking beat it, yet it's really a blast. Seriously one of my favorite games.

27571380.review: Fun little isometric survival simulator located in michican.

27443121.review:
Never has being jumped by a werewolf in the middle of the night been more fun.

NEO Scavenger is intense and has a steep learning curve. But each new playthrough teaches you things about the game and how to better survive the wastes: when you're toting your prized shotgun, dressed up to the nines, and the enemies that harrassed you at the beginning of the game now run in fear of you - there is no better feeling.

My only con would be the lack of late-game missions that keep me from playing longer.

27420640.review:
Best worst game of all time!

Stumble into the world like a doe eyed baby.
Die.
Stumble into the world with resolve you will do better.
Die.
Stumble into the world with the keen wit of the hobo code.
Live.
Kill men for their shoes.
Kill forest creatures for their skin.
Beg the gods for a pot.
Drink tea and thank christ for your pot.
You are wounded.
Use what clean rags you have.
One dirty rag cant hurt.
Wonder what to do with a broken cell phone, save it forever.
Your plastic shopping bags are your life now.
That old plastic sled saved you from having to abandon all that old broken glass and string.
Your last two bullets mised their mark.
You re hypothermic and that dirty rag led to an infection.
You stab anoter dogman to death with a crudely made spear.
Text scrolls by and you watch your life fading.
You survive and hide in the woods trying anything to live.
Your two left shoes are killing you.
You don't want to die, you arent ready yet.
You light the biggest fire this forest has ever seen.
The melonheads are coming.
You run but they are gaining.
Your wounds will not heal.
Your trash is not good enough.
Your hobo training has not prepared you for death.
You trip and cannot get up.
Dead.
You enter the world with a cold sense of dread and no will to live.
You begin murdering and eating humans.
Your shopping cart is filled with human flesh.
You are an abomination.
You have no pot.
You have the troubles from dirty water.
Dead.
You enter this world with a new resolve, you will become its master.
You venture far and wide, your skills keeping you alive.
Your trash is second only to the trash of a god.
You buy amazing new eyes.
You are friends with all civilization that remains.
You are slayer of beast, mutant, and mellonhead alike.
You sleep amongst a mountain of tin cans and wear two matching goddamn flip flops.
You are master of the wastes.
You enter the black swamp.
Dead.
You look around yourself and realize everyone who ever loved you has left.
You have been evicted.
You have lost your job.
You push your shopping cart from tile to tile in real life.
You fight men for cigarette lighters and for socks.
You are the master of the hobo way.
You are wearing two left shoes.
You are already dead.

27315598.review:
Любопытная Survival-песочница, с типичным для жанра лутом и крафтом. Основной целью, как ни странно, является выживание в пост-апокалиптическом мире. Игра обладает довольно сложной механикой и отсутствием какой-либо локализации. Сюжетные повороты игры довольно атмосферны, напоминают текстовые квесты из космических рейнджеров.
Игра с режимом пермасмерти, а умереть здесь очень легко: недооценить противника, умереть от кровотечения, отравления едой и водой, от сюжетных поворотов... что заставляет пытаться пройти ее снова и снова, а система перков разнообразит варианты развития событий каждого прохождения.

Если вы не дружите с английским языком, брать не рекомендуется.

27249835.review:
First of all, go ahead and play the demo, it is very representative of the game and if you like it, you are going to like the game.

The tension this game puts you through is remarkable, you will find yourself analyzing the tiniest details, making sure you won't wake up in the night being slaughtered by a wolfman.

There are, however, a couple of things I personally would've liked to know before I played the game. I'll put these in spoilers in case you want to find everything out by yourself:
[spoiler] If a weapon has a strap, you can carry it by pointing at the shoulder of the character in the menu. Also, some bags can be carried over the left shoulder. [/spoiler]

The biggest problem this game has is bugs. Unfortunately, they can be truly devastating. Once, I loaded my game and the progress on the map was completely gone, so I could not see what I have seen in the past.

[b] If you take anything away from this review, let it be this:[/b]
The game, despite my hours played, is actually really short. Once you have managed to master the mechanics (which will take at least 30 hours I would say), you can finish the game in a couple of hours.
I was very disappointed when the ending screen appeared, because I thought now that I mastered the game I could use all my skills to explore the world and getting stronger.

Anyway, the game was worth playing and I hold it in high regard.

This gem is a really great survival game. The world is truly crude and unforgivable. Each decision may cost you everything and there is no place for making mistakes. You will probably start all over dozens of times, but it will not be frustrating.
