27029481.review:
neo scavenger is a game that comes out of the blue in the steam indie market. Some games are good, because you remember the time you met that NPC that you felt engaged, and connected too, and of how believable they were, and because of the epic landscape that makes you feel like you were living an alternate reality then a program installed onto your computer. And then there are some that have unecesary and game breaking mechanics that is more of a nusciance and a story that fells like it was put together with no thought and imagination making the experience into an endurance test. so where does Neo scavenger come in, it is a role playing, post apocalyptic survival game with a top down perspective on a map that closly resembles to a board game. The game in my opinion is one of the most emmersive games i have played for awhile and i have considerably played enough to know the positives and negatives and heres why:

[u]positives[/u]
if you watched the trailer of the game, you would have noticed that it has still images and is text based, thats because it is. It is a turn based game simmilar to the rpg genre but unlike most turn based rpgs, your actions are in sync with the npcs. whenever you talk to someone in a confrontation you could be at risk at being shot with a range weapon because, when were about to talk, that person blasted your head off because it was their intention. you can sneak up to npcs and kill them but the problem is that you dont know who your sneaking up to. you could end up killing a harmless scavenger then a raider makeing confrontations even harder. the game does a great job at making confrontations meaningful and difficult to handle without felling cheap and half fasted.

you woundering what the story is about like what most games have, well NEO scavenger has a story which is unique and enagaging. The world has many factions that has changed the world in their own ways, but it more happens in the background and what you do have little to no affect on them. Because you cant be a force of nature saviour or villian, it is because you are human. You do not have any special superhuman skills that games secretly slip into your character and instead make random events and point of locations intense. you instead have to think through things because if you don't your going to die, alot. Did i mention that when you die, you die for good and that you have to restart the game. This is the level of detail simmilar to darksouls, only more soulcrushing as the world is belevable and you are quickly reminded your human because you tried to play hero against a healthy dogman.

The survival mechanic has been thrown around recently in alot of indie games because game developers impiment this, but end up copy pasting and being bland because they forgot what makes survival fun. The developers have managed to make the survival genre good in their game as it makes you feel like your recovering from wounds and actually hunting and cooking food. Whenever you attempt to patch yourself up or feed yourself you have to do it manually and organically, you have to think whats right and wrong theres no indicator except for the multiple bars on the right that can be summed up as your health bar. Even fighting feels visceral and brutal. The game uses text to explain what part of the body you hit on an npc and that npc can be   also knocked out through pain (the same can happen to you).

[u]negatives[/u]
The game has its annoying nitpics that i have witnessed throughout the game like, why do i have an imaginary pocket for my cash and, why can i reload my gun and patch myself up in ONE TURN like im the flash (whenever you acsess your inventory the npc can now have a prolonged turn because you were busy BUT ONLY THIS as you can manage your inventory for as long as you want and the npc can't do anything about it). There are the problems with the limitations of the flash engine as sometimes your save file could be deleted (this only happened to me twice).

skills can be a mixed bag. You can be a tough, melee botanist but end up dying because you didnt have the athletic attribute that can help you outrun the dogman or a feble, frail survivor thats good at hacking, electronics, mechanics with eagle eye and tracking but died to a good punch to the face from a raider skilled in melee. I managed to stop this with a mod called big bad cheater which give you a defect called mega human that gives you all the traits and still make you feel human without turning you into a god. Go to the blue bottle site and search it up, instaling is dificult so go to youtube to get help.

[u]conclusion[/u]
I remeber having fond moments with i fight i had with a crazed, infected man with a loaded bow, got shot, pulled the arrows out which caused him to beg for mercy after what he witnessed, and killing him with multiple hatchet blows because he would have killed someone or infected them with a disease simmilar to the plague (the hatchet is not in the game it is a mod called Mighty Mini Mod of Doom which adds more equipment and an extended story line. It also works with Big bad cheater, i highly reccomend it). Neo scavenger is a game that may not be for everyone so in summary do you want:

*be emmersed in a believable world

*feel more of a human than a walking tank

*get into fights with bloody detail, simmilar to manhunt

*organicly complete tasks and naturally survive with a permadeath system

*actually care about your actions

if this interests you, buy it you will never experience anything like this. The developers have done a great job at making a game true to their genre and i hope that they make games in the future with this much thought and imagination put into them like this simply made but absorbing game.

The game is flash-tier but still pretty good. It's innawoods simulator, minus the slavshit.

Brutal survivalism and inventory management - I like how it takes cold, sleep, pain, and disease in ways that most so-called survival games overlook. This makes for a realistic and engaging but utterly merciless game. There is no save scumming in this game. Ironmode only. Too hard? Just give up, casual, and go back to Minecraft.

If you want to play it on easy mode, get Strong, Melee, Botany, and Trapper. Get Myopia and Fast Metabolism as negative traits. Make a cloak out of the Dogman and get to Detroit, then make tannin tea from the forests near the sprawl and sell it until you can get into DMC, get eye implants, then as much equipment as you think you need to get going; this will compensate for your disadvantages. Still, never get cocky - one false step and it's over; I've died multiple times from being careless even when I had a full set of nanomachine healing thingies and plentiful supplies.

26504423.review:
NEO scavenger is a tough as nails survival game that will make you hate it so much you'll either kick it off a window or end up loving it.

It's a turn based tabletop-RPG-of-sorts that starts you waking up in a cryo facility in the middle of the post apocalyptic ruins of Detroit. It is sorta RPG because despite having almost no character progression to it you'll pick up a bunch of traits at the start and both skill checks and inventory management will be paramount to your survival, and sorta tabletop because you'll move across hexes using said abilities and items to gather, fight and resolve the situations you'll find yourself in.

The graphics are reminiscent of the DOS games of the early 90s and the sound design is minimalistic but effective.The player model will reflect equipment changes and every item has it's own art, and hexes have varied art that will let you know what to expect from each. Everything is functional, but the real star of NEO scavenger is it's gameplay and game design, and its biggest make or break factor.

The most important part of the game is undoubtedly the RNG, since it dictates how successful you'll be when scavenging, what you'll get, how combat will go, or whether you'll catch one of the many incredibly deadly diseases that plague the wasteland. There are some things that the player can do to nudge said rng one side or the other trough their abilities and gear, but make no mistake: take a whiff of blue rot or drink from the wrong water and you're pretty much done for, without being able to do much else about it.

The beginning of the game is the toughest and most frustrating part of it, because you'll start out virtually naked and extremely vulnerable, to the point that an idiot with a frying pan will be able to do you in. Avoiding confrontation is without a doubt the most effective way to play the game, but the implacable entropy will eventually force you into taking risks be it food or gear. Combat can be equally frustrating since being in the wrong place at the wrong time can earn you being 1 shotted by a hick with a rifle, although I gotta admit when that happens to you killing an enemy with just one bullet feels badass and satisfying as hell.

When you finally reach Detroit Megacity things get substantially easier. You'll be able to scavenge the surrounding areas and sell the loot for money, and you'll basically be doing scavenging trips while way better equipped and with better fallbacks. You'll be given missions regularly that will take you to stupidly dangerous places so you'll have to still stay on your toes. But having access to DMC is a far cry from scuttling around in a hospital garb praying to make it without shitting yourself to death due to cholera or freezing to death inside an abandoned building. You'll likely have to retry the first weeks over and over again, but once you manage to get a character rolling it gives you a great sense of accomplishment. Of course the game includes a full compliment of biological needs to take care of, but ironically those are one of the easiest parts of the game with the right perk or once you get some of the very early gear.

In closing NEO scavenger is a very long, hard and replayable game that you'll either hate until you love it or just plain hate it. Regardless, it's cheap and if you like survival and a challenge you shouldn't be afraid to pick it up. 7/10.

26240170.review:
Attend the tale of Phillip Kindred, who died as he lived: partially clothed, dragging a sled, and fighting off an infection.

NEO Scavenger is mean. It's unfair. It's cruel. It's grisly. The odds are stacked against you and odds are you won't make it a week. It's also one of the most fun procedural RPGs I've ever played.

It's certainly not perfect. The UI is clunky at best and deeply confusing at worst (remind me to tell you about the time I accidentally ate spoiled human flesh) and the story, while it starts strong, peters out to an ending that hints at a design cycle that ended with exhaustion rather than completion.

Still, NEO Scavenger is otherwise a remarkable and very well thought-out foray into a mythical, post-collapse Michigan with tons of interesting worldbuilding details and enough entertainment value to last you for a long, long time.

I would have like to see some system in place for modding, and a steam workshop

overall I think Neo Scavenger for the little game it is, is great

26180576.review:
Two eyes flickered open and heavy breaths followed as she awoke from the nightmare. Her body shot upward from the sleeping bag. She felt her grip on it loosen as she began to calm down. Her eyes adjusted to the dim lighting of the shed.  She listened to her racing heart and the rain on the shed’s metal roof.
For a moment, a mere moment, the girl felt relaxed by the noise. Rain was soothing. The unbroken rhythm of each drop.
But the ease was lost when she heard a grumbling noise from the pit of her stomach. Her eyes traveled to her stomach. She placed her hands on her stomach, and tried to remember a time where she felt full. As proof, she wore a protruding ribcage.
Her attention was then drawn to the door of the shed. She could go out and search for food, risk death for food. Or stay here safe from the outside world and risk starvation.
Another grumble from her stomach made up her mind. The young girl found the dagger behind her dirty pillow. She gazed at it’s worn appearance for a moment. A dagger was not much but she had not much else.
With as must courage as she could muster, she slid out of the sleeping bag and crept slowly out of the shed. With one last look at the place she considered home, a dusty area with only one hole for light to penetrate through and a small space, she turned away from the shed.
Her eyes looked around the forest and felt goosebumps as rain tickled her skin.
        The air was coated in a thick fog and the air was stale. What little left of trees stood, but various scraps decorated the ground.
        At the age of fifteen, she had been on her own since she was five. Well that what she could remember at least. Whatever happened to the world, she could not recall. The only thing she could recall was her name, or what she had been called at the time. Merida.
    Merida shivered feeling the rain soak into her clothes, or what little there was of her clothes.
    The scrawny young girl moved away from the shed. She crept through the forest, feeling her muscles tense. A few snarls, growls and footsteps reminded her that she was not alone in the woods. It was dangerous here.
      A few moments of walking and she heard something. A bush rustled. Her eyes darted to the bush and she stopped suddenly. She moved quickly behind a log across from the bush. A small rabbit wandered out of the bush. It's ears twitched for a moment. Luckily, it seemed to not have noticed Merida's presence. The rabbit sniffed at the ground for a moment and turned it's back to the log.
      Hunger outranked patience, and Merida suddenly leaped forward towards the rabbit. She aimed her dagger for the creature, but missed. The rabbit, startled, begin to ran. Merida eagerly chased the rabbit farther. Her legs ached as she forced herself to continue.
  It wasn't until a while, when Merida managed to chase it to the outskirts of the forest. Caught up in the chase, she had not noticed where she was until she tripped on a tin can. She fell down the hill and into the heaps of scraps.
      The dagger in her hand had slipped from her grasp. It fell along with her.
      With a sudden stop downward, she caught a glimpse of the rabbit running through the scrapyard. Her eyes wandered around, and she felt fear gnaw at her. She had never been here before. She had never left the forest before.
      Merida tried to catch her breath. Her small body was not strong enough for the run. Pain engulfed her right leg. She noticed a red liquid spilling from her leg. A large cut rested on her knee. Various scratches decorated her body as well.
      She guessed the fall into the scraps had managed to give her the mark, along with the blade of the dagger. Tears threatened to seep out her eyes but she dare not cry.
      The girl struggled to stand. But her leg was badly injured and the weight of body was too much.
      So she crawled forward. After a few attempts, the girl gave up. The pain in her leg was unbearable.
      There she lay, amongst the scraps, with a still empty belly, a damaged body and lost hopes.
      'There's no one, no one here to help me..', she thought to herself in despair.
      With that, she shut her eyes, and awaited death. She knew she was not dying at the moment; but without shelter, food, and with her wound, she didn't think she'd last a night.
***
      Night was present when she heard the noise of the beasts. Creatures of all variety were known to come out at night time. Her eyes tried to make out her surroundings in the darkness.
      The night brought cold air to her. She shivered, and wished for her shed. At least it was shelter there.
      Merida heard something rustle near the scraps. She shook in a terrified motion as the sound came closer. Clomp. Clomp. It almost sounded like footsteps. Merida tried to move her legs, but they felt numb.
    She struggled to move, anything to avoid what ever it was.
    The noise drew closer. All she could manage to do was hold her breath. A light as well, a red glow, was now close to her. She tried to avoid looking towards whatever it was, in fear that it would see her glancing.
    The noise was now there near her. And the glow surrounded her. She close her eyes in fear. Suddenly, something cold and metallic touched her. She opened her eyes slowly, and saw two glowing eyes looking at her. The glow showed a mechanical being made of metal, gears and scraps.
      And that was when she drifted into darkness.

26119535.review:
"...solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short."

Such is life in the "state of nature" described in [i]Leviathan[/i] by Thomas Hobbes. NEO Scavenger illustrates this state more accurately than most single-player survival games. Here you are not completely alone with wildlife in a sandbox like in The Long Dark; but you're also not stranded on an island with mutant cannibals like in The Forest. Instead, you find yourself competing for resources with other survivors, some of them in desperate conditions like you are at first, and others thriving in the desolation and lawlessness. Once you manage to grasp the basics of survival, after several "nasty, brutish, short" attempts resulting in horrible deaths, you will also thrive in this chaos.

This is a game built upon brutal trial and error, and the errors will often cost you all the progress you've made, with all the cool loot you've scavenged. But each death makes you stronger, smarter, more adapted: you live, you die, you live again. And it's this very brutality that makes it so rewarding. Even when you are several days in, thriving in the chaos like a badass, you can still get seriously sick and die abruptly, no matter how much you try to avoid the inevitable. But you soldier on. I did, and somehow I made it to the ending, which, according to this [url=http://www.reddit.com/r/NeoScavenger/comments/2w9xvz/camp_grayling_is_awful_game_design_spoilers/]Reddit post[/url], is very hard to reach even after several tries. [url=http://dumptext.com/0fa6HjYE/raw/]Here[/url] (MASSIVE SPOILERS) is my ending log, just in case anyone wants to check or compare.

It also stands apart as an RPG as much as a survival game. Openly influenced by classic tabletop RPGs with creative problem solving through skills, it feels somewhat like playing the original Fallout for the first time once again (and that also means dealing with clunky UI and mechanics). The encounters with characters and factions often have branching storylines and different, sometimes irreversible outcomes. The writing is a bit too purple sometimes, but that's a genre thing, and considering that it's a one-man development team, it's still better than the writing in many AAA games.

The UI can be irritating, and I can only advise that you pick up on the hotkeys ASAP and get used to them, it'll make life easier and counterbalance the addictivity of the scavenging mechanic, the real rough core of the game, which manages to keep you busy for hours and hours while you search for that one left boot in good condition or whatever. Realism isn't a defining factor exactly, but it's well-balanced so that it plays like a challenge, but also not complete scarcity. There is loot aplenty once you learn how to optimise the scavenging.

I've put 110 hours into it according to Steam, but since it is a game that you can just leave in the background while you browse, I didn't spend every hour playing it in a frenzy. This is a game that walks the fine line between casual and hardcore in a fascinating way. It's a background game that can hook your attention for hours in between other things that might hook your attention. And I believe it has immense replay value beyond the seemingly endless cycle of scavenging and dying. I intend to try another character build at some point and see how the story will develop.

The worldbuilding has potential to develop into a franchise and evolve into bigger, more complex gameplay mechanics, and I don't mean necessarily in first-person, though that could be interesting. As a launching effort, NEO Scav is a brilliant little game, a real diamond in the rough of clunky UI.

My first death happened almost 10 minutes later. I had a good backpack, a rifle, a crowbar, perhaps I even had a few hundred kills to my name. How did I die? A looter with a monkey wrench... Yup.

Anyhow, about a year and a month or so later we could starting modding, and oh boy did people mod it fast. I loved the game, and I love the mods.

25953042.review:
The game looked intriguing and certainly has a number of positive reviews, so I gave it a try. Ultimately however, this game just wasn’t for me.
My main issue was that the game requires Adobe Flash Player, which (for me) frequently popped up during game play due to security settings, and ultimately crashed the game. And this was a huge annoyance, because every time I attempted to bring up the task manager to ‘end task’, the crash-screen interceded. It did present a quit or send error option, however neither responded to my input, ultimately I had to restart my computer.

The other issue, which I admit is simply a stylist preference, was the color depth and color pallet, this game is definitely retro, like C64 retro. This included the user interface, which was very challenging (for me) to navigate, and in the short time I played this game I was never quite sure that what I intended to do was actually completed successfully (in a word: feedback).

Unfortunately I was unable to play long enough to experience the story and atmosphere, which have been repeatedly praised for this game.

25482491.review:
NEO Scavenger is something of an oddity among survival games, in that it is extremely good. It's an intriguing mashup of genres - take The Road crossed with The Mist with a little dash of Blade Runner and throw in a sprinkling of cryptozoology and Unsolved Mysteries and you've got NEO Scavenger in a nutshell. It works extremely well despite this hodgepodge of influences, and the world at no point feels contrived or artificial.

In any case, I'm getting ahead of myself: at the beginning of the game, none of this concerns you. Waking up in a deserted cryo-facility three-quarters naked and knowing nothing but your name, your most immediate priority is survival. You have several routes to achieve this, but all of them involve the same basic points: eat, drink, sleep, stay warm, don't get sick and don't get wounded, and if you do get wounded, take care of yourself promptly. 

You accomplish this basic survival through two main methods. The first is scavenging, which involves travelling across the hex-based overworld map, choosing a tile to scavenge, and then choosing a specific location within that tile to scour, and at last choosing what abilities and items you'll use in the process. The yields are seldom all that great, but this is the game where you will feel exuberantly grateful for plastic shopping bags, worn flip flops, plastic bottles and old pots - where an intact shopping cart by comparison is an unimaginable score. Most of these things you use in crafting, in which you turn things you find into marginally more useful things.

If it sounds easy, believe me when I say it's not. Comestibles are scarce, and there's only so much nutrition you can get out of 50-year-old bags of chips and snack cakes. The pressing threat of starvation can lower you to the point where you're wandering across the land eating every little thing that seems the least bit edible to buy a few more hours of life, a threatening prospect when your character lacks the botanical skill to identify poisonous foodstuffs.

What to do when you run into a stray feral dog thus becomes a no-brainer. When pressed enough, you might even contemplate the unthinkable. Encounters with both animals, people and [i]other things[/i] are both somewhat rare and appropriately tense. You most often can't judge a person's intentions by sight alone, and trying to talk things out can leave you extremely vulnerable if they turn out hostile. In some cases, if you stumble onto a face-to-face encounter with someone, you may not even try to talk, given that even that moment of hesitation would be enough for them to stick a meat cleaver in your skull.

The combat in this game is a little bit of an odd duck. It's a bit similar to the original Wasteland, turn based, highly abstracted and without a tactical map - every enemy has a number representing their distance from you, and you have a number of options - advance or fall back, charge or run away. If your target is within range of your weapon, you can attack, and you can pull various special maneuvers or defensive moves depending on the circumstances. It can get a bit mechanical if you know what you're doing and are fairly well kitted, but when you're more down on your luck it can be fairly exciting in an 'oh god please let me live through this' sort of way, as playing it safe can become less justified if it means prolonging an encounter where every moment threatens death. Altogether though, the combat lacks dilemmas, in that there is almost always an objectively optimal action to take in each given situation. Not that it doesn't still have interesting situations - enemies with guns are an interesting example, as you have to weigh the possibility that they're bluffing with that of them actually having bullets and plan accordingly, and this is after all a game where you can win the fight but die slowly and painfully in your camp of an infected cut, huddled up in a sweaty sleeping bag and shivering with fever.

Death, I should mention, comes easy and takes many forms, if that wasn't already clear. If a scavenger stumbled onto your camp while you sleep, there's little you can do. Even if you manage to wake in time, you might be better off running blindly rather than risking a fight in the dark. But you don't need to fight to die. Cholera, food poisoning, diarrhea, infection, hypothermia, exposure to chemicals, yet more exotic diseases - there's plenty of ways to die and none of them are pleasant. One of my bigger problems with the game plays into this - there's certain encounters where you're given choices that can kill you instantly. On one hand, this makes every choice feel grave. On the other, it's kind of a cheap shot, and you can suffer immense penalties from consequences you had no way of foreseeing.

One of the things that I found immensely interesting as a possible consequence of the above is how the wasteland comes to warp your sense of morality. Whereas in other games you might be inclined to do good because you think you're a good person, here, the stress of constantly looming starvation, predation by other humans and the ease with which death comes can make you rather disinclined to stick your neck out for others. Even if you throw a good deed or two out now and then, putting yourself in harm's way for someone else's benefit is not something that the world encourages. If you find yourself in a state of pressing enough need, you might even find reason to screw an innocent over for your own benefit. Once you're put in that situation, you kind of start to sympathize with all the people trying to kill you for your stuff. At the very least, you can't really blame them any more, not when they're in the same shitty situation as you. In that way, the game is an excellent illustration of how irrelevant morality becomes when survival is at stake, and the horror that results from that.

The game does have story, I should mention, and even a vague sort of plot. The writing is very good, the world building is great and the atmosphere is amazing. I should warn you that this game is incredibly bleak - it's not the sort of wacky post-apocalyptic amusement park of the more recent Fallout games, or even the relative optimism of the originals and FONV - it is a world of misery, starvation, murder, cannibalism, despair, negligence, scarcity and extinction. It isn't actively malicious, the depiction of suffering is not gratuitous - the world is callously indifferent, and this comes across in the writing marvelously. The world doesn't center around the protagonist, and for most purposes you're just another wasteland ragman whom nobody gives a hoot about. Some locations and encounters could have used a little more fleshing out - in one particular instance I imagined that my character could have the opportunity to finally get some answers about the state of things in the world, but to my disappointment I couldn't even ask about even the littlest point of interest. Incidentally, I found that the odd bits of old newspaper offering scattered details about the world's backstory far more interesting than the plot involving the protagonist's past.

In that vein, one of my bigger problems was a relative lack of content. There's plenty for the price, but a few more locations, conversations, quests, NPCs, cryptids to encounter and supernatural horrors would have done wonders for a relatively small investment. In the course of my first successful playthrough, I've seen just about everything there is from one point of view. There's still time to start new playthroughs and see how things turn out for different choices and to explore bits of missed content, but overall there's still less than I'd have liked, in an ideal world.

Ultimately though, NEO Scavenger was one of my favourite video game experiences of recent memory. It's engaging and atmospheric, and weaves gameplay and narrative seamlessly together. More games should try to be like NEO Scavenger.

25058336.review:
Ever play a game that made you want to throw your computer out the window, and then 5 minutes later want to play another round?

...that's NEO Scavenger.

If you frustrate too easily, if you don't like random difficulty spikes, if you can't have fun when the game isn't "fair" all the time, if you don't like to lose... this might not be the game for you.

You'll have the deck stacked against you right from the start most of the time. Just making it a day or two might seem impossible. Then you'll have that run of luck and manage to gather a small fortune, and even come to think of yourself as neigh invincible, only to succumb to some kind of horrible infection because you forgot to wear an air filter and accidentally inhaled some spores.

This game is not fair. It wasn't meant to be fair. That's part of the beauty.

There's a small but awesome modding community for this game, as well... and they've managed to add quite a bit of additional content to the game. Definitely worth checking out after you've played the base game for a while and want an expanded experience.

Roguelike permadeath meets somewhere between Zork Zero and Return to Zork.  Only there doesn't seem to be a set storyline.  Therefore, expect alot of roaming around in the dark until something interesting happens.  Also expect to die alot including rerolling a new character each time.

You start out as a survivor of a disaster, you wake up basically naked and unarmed with no items.  Now go wander around scavenging so that you don't die.  You will find lots of good loot that will go to waste because you just don't have anywhere to put it so you leave it on the ground and hope you can find your way back later if you find a use for it.  It can be  a real bummer sometimes.

If you don't find clothing right away you basically are gonna have to start again until you do.  Finding clothing is totally randomized.

It has the feel of sifting through trash can after trash can looking for something you can use while hiding from monsters in the dark.  Hence, the name NEO Scavenger.

I have yet to live past day 2.  Difficult game it is, but if you give it a little time, you might have a different experience than most hack and slash survival games.

Not for the cry babies or wimps.  If you are a cry baby or a wimp, buy something else.

Me being both a cry baby and a wimp, I probably shouldn't own this game either having given games like WazHack a bad review for using permadeath coupled with randomly generated deathloops as a bad gaming experience.  However, I have given this a thumbs up because I feel that the text based playfield gives the player the illusion of a fighting chance where as the graphics based games are basically just deathloops without strategy.  If you don't shoot fast enough you die coupled with the fact that randomized loot against randomized monsters is usually bad for the player which if I was honest is probably true here too but the game is called neo scavenger, not dungeon explorer.  

Scavenging vs. Adventuring, is there a difference? Play this and find out.

Pros:
+Unique, although simple, graphics
+Satisfying narrative
+Immersive and well-thought out atmosphere
+Interesting and innovative game mechanics
+Nice UI
+In-depth interaction and self-interaction mechanics
+Very interesting health system
+Easy to learn, hard to master

Cons:
-Lack of items (which is especially discouraging for an open-world survival game)
-Lack of enemies
-Narrative and discovery dwindles as the game progresses
-Single storyline with little variation

Overall:

24235827.review:
I think there are only slightly more redeeming qualities to this game than there are bad ones, so this is only a "recommend" because "meh" wasn't really a choice.

The game is very tedious. One thing that survival games tend to forget is that survival is a very tedious business, and they compress the timeframe a bit for emphasis of that particular aspect, but that just tends to make it even more tedious. This tends to detract from exploration or story-telling: you can't care about those things if the only priority you can possibly have is just making it to the next day. NEO Scavenger seems like it has a very rich and detailed story behind it and a setting that has the potential to be deeply immersive, but none of that matters if you simply die within the first week most of the time. 

It doesn't help that the game is somewhat obtuse about a lot of extremely important mechanics, such as the combat system, or health, or that drinking unfiltered water pretty much guarantees that you get cholera or are poisoned. Sure, that last one is pretty obvious in retrospect, but what that implies is that a decent portion of the time you have is going to be spent sterilizing all your water, and hoarding water, etc., which is just about as fun as it sounds. 

Item durability is also a terrible system. I don't think it was ever fun or strictly necessary in any game in which it was ever implemented. Yes, on some level, it intuitively makes sense, but it's overly simplistic in its implementation and just keeps forcing you to obsessively hunt for more junk.

The skill system is interesting at face value, but your choices are limited from the start, and since they're fixed this drastically limits the options available to you (particularly at the start of the game) and you are always made painfully aware of it whenever you craft or interact with anything. It doesn't help that some are incredibly useless or situational.

Permadeath is a good thing, I guess, but it also discourages the player from taking risks. There is always an element of risk in everything, but if you're dealing with an unknown and don't know how to assess the risk, you will eventually come to the conclusion that chancing it isn't worth it in most situations, which, again, runs counter to the player's natural drive for exploration. If you're gonna have permadeath in a game, that's great and all, but you gotta throw the player a bit more of a bone here.

I think this game certainly has potential so I'm not gonna trash it utterly. But it is a very very lukewarm recommend at best, at least for now.

24139027.review:
NEO Scavenger is a hard-core survival game that takes place in a dystopian post-apocolyptic future.  The interface is simple and the graphics are basic but this masks a game that is flush with choices and possibility.  

You awaken with nothing on you and no knowledge of what has happened to the world.  From the moment you are revived at the beginning of the game until you die due to exposure (or starve to death...or get torn limb-from-limb...or...) you are constantly pressured by the environment and your characters own survival needs to move ahead.  Death is far more likely than survival and the options to keep yourself going can get pretty deep and dark (for example, eating the flesh of other humans is a perfectly acceptable way to go...if you don't mind a growing ravenous hunger for the flesh of the living).  To be completely honest, I've yet to get anywhere close to the end of this game but  never stop revisiting it because the sheer diversity of options always leaves me feeling like there were other choices and that any of those other variations might have led to a profoundly different outcome (IE - death by some new lurking horror or contraction of an unexpected disease).

24111337.review:
I personally really enjoy this game! Its very remenesent of original fallout titles, but I feel like this game expands on Turn based actions and combat. (for example, the tough ability, since it gives you the ability to headbutt someone.)

I find that the abilities and flaws you can choose from give the game a lot of replay ability, and can be either incredibly angering, or extremely useful. 
The difficultly makes you really try to find good ways out of a situation, and plan ahead, but even if you plan you could freeze, dehydrate just a hex before a river, or find a pack of feral dogs/Looters. IT makes you actually panic when you see your character in danger, since you know that if you take one small step in the wrong direction, you have to restart.

the random situations in the cities make you feel as though you really are helpless at times, becuase sometimes no matter what you do you wont be helpful, It paints a grim picture on how far humanity had fallen, and really helps set the scene.
I've gotten to the DMC around 4 times, though its hard to last long after that for me! After finding out that strong + trapping the wolfman in the beginning of the game gives you a warm coat, Dehydration has been the worst for me. 

The only issues I've found with the game is that the "New game" and "save and quit" button are the same, so if you don't pay attention, you'll press new game by reflex, and I've lost 2 DMC saves to that. 
Another is that there's no setting to turn off permadeath, I know some people who would love to play this game, but the difficulty and permadeath keep them away(like a lot of people with dark souls, haha)

A large glitch I've found is where you will be able to see the "scavenge" button, but it refuses to activate scavenging, though its available in the area (you are notified of scavengeable area's with a glass icon) and you have to turn your game off and on again to fix this. People have talked about this glitch for a long time now, but it hasn't been resolved. 

In short, the game is one I'll be recommending to a lot of people, Since I really enjoy it. (at the time of this review i've had the game for 2 days, and played 28.4 hours) 
If you like challenges, survivals, permadeath and looting, this is a game for you!

24069550.review:
I really, really wanted to like this game.  I enjoy roguelikes (I love Nethack) and survival games as a genre, but I can't recommend this one.


In the end, it's too easy to die without any foreknowledge, making the game feel a lot like playing roulette.  In my most recent game, I walked into a hex that appeared unoccupied, but in fact hid a dogman who killed me before I even spotted him.  I'm used to dying frequently playing games like Nethack, but I always feel like it's my fault, or that there was something I could have done to prevent my most recent death.  I do not have this feeling when playing Neo Scavenger.

The UI is also very cumbersome (e.g., trying to navigate the craft menus, or trying to move things around in your inventory between vehicles and a box, etc.), coupled with tons of annoying fiddling in order to play even near-optimally (like always making/lighting torches when you scavenge, or trying to put on the 3 best shirts you have found), means that most of the time you're fighting the UI instead of making interesting decisions.  The simple fact that you can't tell whether water in a bottle is purified or not without dumping it out exemplifies what I mean.  Instead of looking for a bottle [water (purified)], you just have to dump out all your bottles until you find one containing purified water, take a drink, then put all the water back in the bottles.  It's madness.

24022109.review:
Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!

This is a Text turned based game.


[h1]Interface/Menu/Settings[/h1]

You can play the game on Fullscreen and windowed mode.
You are able to change the GUI (Screen ratio).
There is a Master Volume and you can change the Volume every 10%.
There is a Sound Volume and you can change the Volume every 10%.
There is a Music Volume and you can change hte Volume every 10%.
You are able to set a FPS Limit.
You can mute the sound entirely.
Toggling the Auto save button.

[h1]About the game.[/h1]

You start off in a Perk selection menu, Each bar has their own ammount of Points and you only start with 15 Points.
Flaws are there to make your game harder but they wil give you points to spend on your perks again.
When you are at Map Grid. You will a Grid Field and at your left some clickable things and status.  On Top left, you see your movement. Then below that your hunger meter, Then Thirst, Then Rest, Then Weight limit, Then comfortable, Temperature and Hurt. Below that you will see some Colored Bars. Like End turn, Run, Scavenge, Hide, track and others. You are most likely hit from the encounter so Click on the ground that u are currently standing on, Then Scavenge and search around for medkit supplies, Then right click on it *or drag it to ur hands). Then use sheet on the wounds and you are good to go for now. If you are Scavenging and you found items, Click on the Character portrait under CONFIRM to see the items. Then CLICK on the items left and see if you can bring it with you. The LEFT SCREEN FIELD ARE ITEMS ON THE GROUND, THIS IS NOT YOUR INVENTORY. That is on the right side.  If you see Red Footprints, this could be yours or from a nearby unit. You are able to hide your Footprints aswell. Sleeping bags are a useful tool to increase "Hyporthemia", Sleep to increase your temperature.

Might look confusing at the start.
Game is Post Spamming.
Music is weird.
Basic Sound quality.
Hard game to understand at the beginning.
Requires patience and willing to understand the game.
Random Generated worlds and items.
Day and Night Cyclus.
Game could be REALLY unpunishing or has some "unfair" moments.
It's filled with enemies from time to time and sometimes you can't do anything about it. With a chance of dying.

[h1]Other things.[/h1]

Pressing Escape bar button will change your size to window mode.
Use Sleeping bags to increase your temperature and you won't freeze to death.

-------------------

I Give this game a 6/10

Zusammenfassung: Das Spiel hat Potential, aber es fühlt sich nicht fertig an.

 Die Motivation ist hoch man legt los. "Oh man startet nackt und mittellos irgendwo im nirgendwo." Der Entdeckergeist ist geweckt. 
NEO Scavenger haut einen voll in die Fresse. Man überlebt kaum die ersten Tage, hat keine Ahnung, was man tun soll und startet immer wieder neu, weil man erfriert, verhungert oder dir jemand n Topf auf den Schädel haut. Das beste Gesicht des Spiels. Hilflos wie beim Würfelspiel.

Eine Herausforderung. Man wird immer besser. Weiß, welche Skills nützlich sind, welche Items nützlich sind. Man beginnt den Würfel für sich zu manipulieren. Seine Chancen zu verbessern. Man will mehr entdecken.

Und dann erreicht man "the glow" und es fühlt sich wie ein Ende an. Man fragt sich: wars das schon? Man zieht los, hortet, aber irgendwie ohne Ziel. Das Spiel wird ab da an langweilig, wenn man voll ausgerüstet in der Welt herumirrt. Macht man einen kleinen Fehler oder fällt der Würfel ungünstigt, ist alles verloren und man muss wieder neu anfangen. 

Aber wofür? Hat man am Anfang noch die Aufgabe schnell zu lernen, möchte man nach einigen erfolgreichen Durchgängne nicht wieder Stunden verbringen die nötigen Gegenstände zu finden, nur um wieder ziellos rumzuirren. Ein Spiel, dessen Prinzip es ist immer wieder neu zu starten, brauch auch einen Sinn, warum man immer wieder neu startet. Don't Starve schafft es mit einer Abwechselungsreichen Welt und viel Inhalt. Neo Scavenger hat aber aus noch mehr Gründen versagt:

- das Crafting-Menü ist horror, die anderen Schaltflächen auch eher ungünstig angebracht
- zu wenig Auswahl an Gegenständen 
- immer der gleiche Kartenaufbau
- keine Abwechselung bei der Gebäudeauswahl zum looten
- das looten zu klickintensiv
- Verschieben von Gegenständen erschwert (z.B. automatisches Drehen der Items, auffüllen von Slots, usw. wäre sinnvoll)
- Charackter kann sich während des Spiels nicht weiterentwickeln
- zu wenig Aufgaben, bzw. Entscheidungen sorgen dafür das einige Aufgaben verwehrt bleiben, sodass ein Neuanfang nötig ist

Positiv ist:
- Kampfsystem erlaubt viele Strategien, drängt einen jedoch zur Vorsicht
- Musik und Design stimmig
- Zufall und Unwissenheit als besonderer Reiz

Schade, dass ein Spiel wieder mal an der Konsequenz scheitert, eine Sache zu Ende zu bringen, denn die Ansätze sind wirklich interessant.

BTW:
Ich kann mir NEO Scavenger sehr gut auf Tablet oder Smartphone vorstellen, da es rundenbasiert ist.

23975154.review:
Fun and completely unforgiving.

I've died of food poisoning, beaten to death with various blunt objects, been torn apart by feral dogs, shot in the head by a hunting rifle, frozen to death, and eaten by mutants; and all in usually less than a week. And yet every time I happily start a new game and try again.

NEO Scavenger might turn some off with its simplistic graphics (you'll rarely be looking at more than the game grid and a few lines of text) but what it lacks in visuals, it makes up for ten fold in an incredibly deep survival and crafting system. 

If you love survival-type games and want to be challenged by a game, then NEO is a surprisingly good choice. Just be warned that at any minute your wonderful safehouse filled with all the great loot you've found, savanged, and killed for can be taken away because one damn surviver got a lucky shot with their hunting rifle.

23834173.review:
Grafiskt och spelmekaniskt är detta ett väldigt enkelt spel vilket kanske inte är så konstigt eftersom det verkar vara kodat i Adobe Flash. Men man ska inte låta detta avskräcka. NEO Scavenger är smått beroendeframkallande på samma sätt som spel som Colonization och Civilization.

Jag är den typ av spelare som brukar vilja ta det lugnt, fega och bygga upp ett ordentligt lager med bra vapen, prylar och mat innan jag ger mig ut på några farligheter. Om något ska dödas gör jag det helst på avstånd med ett prickskyttegevär. Jag gick in i NEO Scavenger med just den inställningen - sakta med säkert. Men det visade sig [i]inte[/i] vara en framgångsrik strategi i detta spel. 

För att lyckas i NEO Scavenger måste man vara villig att ta risker, men inte till den grad att man blir dumdristig. Man ska hela tiden ligga på en hårfin balans mellan att välja det säkra och ta risker. Man måste också vara beredd att prioritera. Allra tydligast blir det när man ska släpa runt på prylar. Man hittar en grym vänsterkänga av militärmodell men ingen högerkänga. Antingen behåller man den och hoppas på att hitta en som matchar eller så slänger man den. Om man behåller den så får man kanske inte plats med den där extra vattenflaskan som man behöver för att överleva och så dör man av törst men med en väldans fin känga i ryggsäcken. Eller ryggsäck och ryggsäck - det är inte alls säkert att man hittar en sådan. För det mesta får man nöja sig med att släpa runt på sina saker i en plastpåse.

Precis som i gamla tiders rollspel så får man i början av spelet möjlighet att påverka sin karaktär genom att spendera ett antal färdighetspoäng på olika färdigheter. Det kan vara kunskaper i botanik, mekanik, elektronik, jakt osv. Beroende på vilka färdigheter man ger sin karaktär så blir spelandet annorlunda. Du får annorlunda valmöjligheter i olika situationer och det kommer även att påverka dina möjligheter att gömma dig, försvara dig eller hitta användbara saker eller mat.

Jag rekommenderar NEO Scavenger om man vill ha en riktig utmatning, gillar turbaserade strategispel, gillar överlevnad och har tröttnat på spel där man blir bortskämd med saker. I NEO Scavenger får man vara glad om man har en sten eller en glasskärva om man hamnar i strid och en näve blåbär är en festmåltid.

23804845.review:
When I originally bought this game several years ago, it was on a random whim during a sale.  I played it for about 15 minutes, and was so turned off by the way it looks and the unintuitive interface that I pretty much immediately uninstalled it.  This was a big mistake.

I recently re-installed it, determined to give it another shot, and what I discovered, underneath the (genuinely off-putting) flash game look and feel, is a game of truly staggering complexity and compelling depth.

NEO Scavenger is a game in which you can wrap a rag around your face when exploring buildings to avoid inhaling toxic mold, pry open the lock on a storage shed with your crowbar, find an empty soup can and a left shoe, and pump your fists into the air in triumph IRL because now you won't have to worry about getting blistered feet, and you can boil the water you've been finding to make it safe for consumption.  Now, if only you had some pants...

Similarly, no other game has ever filled me with such joy and sheer relief at finding an adult-sized backpack.  Such an item enables you to carry enough wood and water that you don't have to keep stopping every few spaces to make camp, and you can make much better time on foot towards that mysterious glow in the East!

One game, I was attacked by a feral dog, who I beat to death with my bare hands, falling down into the mud and becoming exhausted.  Using a shard of glass, I skinned the beast after it died from internal hemmorhaging brought on by my pummeling.  I took its meat and cooked it over a fire, overjoyed that I'd figured out how to do so.  Delicious, life-giving dog meat.  I used its hide to wrap around the glass shards and make a crude shiv, not knowing what else to do with it.  I was then set upon by a bandit who'd heard my struggles with the dog, to whom I surrendered, knowing I stood no chance.  He left me naked and near death from hypothermia.  I ran into the woods and quickly built a fire as night fell, plotting my revenge, sleeping fitfully on the ground.  When dawn broke, I went to the nearest building and by sheer chance, found some clothing and a crowbar.  I went in search of the bandit who took my dog meat, only to find him dead near some other buildings.  The wastes are cruel indeed.

If you miss Wasteland 1, if you think Fallout 2 really badly needed detailed wound dressing and immune system mechanics, this is the game for you.  It would be really nice if you could choose to play as a woman, but privately I suspect that the creator didn't want to deal with modeling pregnancy or the menstrual cycle.  Can't say as I blame him.

23427349.review:
Could not stop playing Neo Scavenger for weeks after picking it up. Can't recommend it highly enough. Aside from having solid gameplay/balance, it also checks off some of these important boxes for a survival game:

-frequent painful death (took me a dozen playthroughs to survive past a few days)
-lots of clutter to collect, most of which has use based on your strategy
-meaningful loadout variety (very different strategies/experience based on initial skill choices)
-compelling story progression; you'll get a bit further each time before dying or making an irreversible poor choice
-does a good job of setting an ominous dystopian post-apocalyptic wasteland cyperpunk tone

In terms of critique, I have to admit it does feel a bit sparse in terms of core content. Not only does the excellent foundation beg for an expansion of material (you could say that about any quality game), but certain items, mechanics, and gameplay elements clearly feel unfinished. The main story line is short as well, but feels much longer than it is because of how hard it is to progess through it without dying. Luckily there is a small but active modding community that has done some impressive things to expand the game in terms of content as well as mechanics. 

Anyway, Neo Scavenger isn’t perfect but as one of the few games I’ve ever purchased at full price, I’m comfortable saying its worth it.

23422149.review: Very challenging, about as realistic as survival games get. It's a very unique game, you never see your character except for on the overview map and in the inventory screen, and even then it's really just a human form with no details. The game is one huge balancing act between keeping your stomache full, not getting mauled by giant bear-like creatures or murdered by other people, not getting sick, and finding good loot. If you don't like a challenge, you will not like this game. 10/10 It certainly accomplishes its goals admirably, but I don't recommend playing without some sort of guide or without being helped by someone who's played before. Now, don't just look up everything you encounter in the wiki because that kinda spoils the fun, but certainly don't go in blind or you'll die within a week.

23416520.review:
TL/DR at end
Game is hard, but good.

Until you find out the game is using 2-5GB of temporary internet files as your "save data" and cleaning your computer wipes your save, every time. Devs started with an internet flash game, and ended with an internet flash game. they can't even code the save files into real save files so that long-run gameplay (about a month or two in in-game 'time') doesn't start lagging. seriously, a game that is not server based and has low quality graphics lagging because devs can't code a proper save file. sad too, it had potential.

EDIT:The fact that it is a flash save file IS the issue.
the file being deleted upon cleaning your computer is just one of the problems that arise from the issue.

If you clean your temporary internet files, even through chrome, firefox, or IE, like any halfway tech savy computer user from time to time, your save file WILL be deleted, as the files are stored in your temporary internet files, which is what gets wiped. This is something the devs SHOULD have anticipated, unless they are idiots who never maintain their computers

There is also the fact that the save file for one game gets HUGE because flash is not meant to save long term memory. While I have over 7TB hard drive space on my computer, so a 6GB save file goes practically unnoticed, this is not the case for everyone, and this also creates bigger problems that are not related to how much space you have

The biggest issue is that the more you play the more the game lags because of this saving method, as flash games are not meant to continuously read and update a save file that big. The lag isn't apparent at first, but play and survive in the game for a few ingame months. you will start to notice stuttering and lag no matter what kind of computer you are running it on, beacuse the issue is with the game itself and flash player. A 2GB plus flash save file is unacceptable and just bad foresight by the devs, not to mention 6GB+ when you've been playing the game for a while.

So yes, you could blame google chrome, firefox, CCCleaner, whatever for the save file deletion. But you have to blame the devs for using such a stupid system. For not knowing how or wanting to code a good save system. THEY are the ones who chose to put a decent sized persistant universe into a flash save file. THEY are the ones who decided to give their game a save system that will eventually make your saves unplayable.

You can argue all you want, but the devs are the ones who made the decisions that gave thier game a crippling handicap. Maybe the game was never meant to be anything more than an online flash game, and for that game, that would be ok. But to package it as a game on steam when the game has that kind of major flaw? That is entirely dev screwup

EDIT 2:
To show that this is not the only issue with the game, but the one that overshadows everything else into making me write a negative review, here's some critiques i gave to an idiot who has his head to far in the sand:

"The fact that I cannot rely on my save game's integrity, either due to the way the game saves or the lag in a single player game that is a result of that flaw, is a HUGE deal breaker for me, the rest of the game notwithstanding. The fact that it's a rogue-like game amplifies that, as all of my progress is that much harder to replicate. 

And as for "lots and lots" of content, no offense to the devs on this one, but there just isn't. The creatures and NPCs are pretty basic, storyline is minimal, and "completing" this game is both unsatisfactory, and ends the game without the option of continuing, There are also many events in the game that can happen either randomly or from you entering an area that can either kill you no matter what, no matter how geared or skilled you are, just because you chose the wrong option, or even better you chose the right option and it still has a chance of instantly killing you, or can kill you due to you not having one specific item that is absolutely useless under any other curcumstances and normally just takes up space in your pack.

There's also an event that only happens when you character is asleep and is basically unblockable that [spoiler]leaves your character permanently blind ( a creature literally steals your eyes) and you have to move one hex at a time to the main city (which takes forever, even if you are close), while every creature and most NPCs that see you trying to murder you, and EVEN IF you make it to the city, you have to pay an ungodly amount of money for cybernetic eyes[/spoiler], JUST to resume your normal play.

The thing is, I can look past all that, the other shortcomings of the game, and can still get enjoyment from it. If it weren't for the issues with the save files. Which is why I wrote a negative review citing the save files, because as I said, everything else I could look past as part of the challenge, dealing with a buggy and vengeful game that hates you. But the fact that on top of everything else, one of the main things you expect to have no issues with, your save file, has major issues, is a huge irritation to me."

TL/DR: The game has great potential and is fun if you don't intend to play it for long. But if you play to long the game lags, your save file gets deleted when you clean your temp internet files, and the game hates you more than dark souls

One of the best roguelike experiences I've encountered, everything about this game is lovable and enjoyable, though in the beginning it can be very unforgiving. After you start you (or at least I did) will die many times from freezing without knowing what to do about it. Later you realise what you should do (or google it) and you get into the game a lot. There is quite a lot to explore, although the game could have a lot more content than it's having. However considering that it's not a big project and not many people are working on it, it's understandable.

Still, the price is quite high for what you get. It has a lot of replayability to a certain point, but after you reach that point and explore it all, there is nothing more to do. Updates bring something new quite often, but it's not really enough to keep you playing. I would advise buying it on at least 70% sale, or in a bundle or something. 

8/10 Would join blue frogs

I wake up in a cryogenic facility, Instantly approached by a hulking monster. Remembering my knowledge and previous work in a garden, I decide to smash plants against my skin to scare the monster away. It works. I proceede to leave, Gathering pebbles and bark for my future domination of the world.
Day two.
I find out that bark does not protect me from hypothermia, And decide to scavange for clothes instead. Finding a shoe and a t-shirt, I dress. From rags to riches, They always say.
Day three. I am approached by a random man wearing a hoodie with a glass bottle. Thinking he is bringing me a gift, I attempt to speak with him, Only to have my head wildly bashed in with said bottle, The last words going through my head being; "I wonder if my shoe fell apart."
----

The complexity of the game itself is astounding, Considering that it's a flash. All in all, Worth the money.

You're close to hypothermic, but just need to survive until the next day so you can focus the sunlight to start a fire to warm yourself.  As dawn approaches, you slip into oblivion...


You wake up in a cryo facility... Good luck!

NEO Scavenger is a brutal game where you'll die often, and in horrible ways - even once you understand all of the mechanics, the random number generator will seal your fate if you're not very very careful (and sometimes even if you are).  There's surprising depth in the crafting, combat, and survival aspects for a game without any animation.  You need a tin can, a lighter, and some twigs to make sterile water to drink.  You need the same things plus a dirty rag to make a clean rag.  If you get hurt and are bleeding, you need to wash the wound with sterile water (or another antiseptic) and then bandage it with a clean rag.  I died of massive infections twice by the time I realized how to properly care for myself after a fight.  I died several times in combat before I realized how to play defensively and wait for openings.  I still die just through bad luck, but I'm getting further and further into the game each time.

中文名：末日拾荒者
实际时间其实也有上百个小时了....

为了吸引更多人关注这游戏，我特此删除了旧评论，重写一篇更为详细的。
2013就入的这款游戏可以说是百玩不厌，一款目前为止最让人感到真实的生存文字冒险游戏。简单概括也可以把它看做是2D版DAYZ。但却没有如此多需要让人操心的BUG，虽然没有僵尸但是也有狼人，木瓜人（什么鬼...）狗、掠夺者、蓝色邪教等敌人。

主角从一个一无所知的冷冻仓醒来，接着踏出世界的第一步就已经是世界末日。没错就一件病服的主角从此开始了废土的冒险之旅。在旅途中你将会完全遇到各种不可预知的事件。你需要食物、水、睡觉、休息、衣服、交通工具、武器等等一系列重要的必须品。然而这些只能完全靠你去“拾荒”来。或者你运气不好的则可以直接靠武力打劫你遇到的陌生人，前提是你要保住自己的小命。在这款游戏生火是必不可少。烧过水的水喝起来才比较安全。而且也些大城市你可以交易，以及你可以遇到各种任务NPC。甚至还有最终BOSS等着你。整个游戏的秘密无穷无尽，给生存系玩家是一个个千钧一发的命运选择。让你知道什么叫走错一步路，则小命不保。当然主角光环在这游戏不适用....

目前唯一的缺点就是 没有汉化，当然民间汉化还是有的。而优点很明显。游戏可以配合任何玩家的天马星空的MOD，而且没有任何什么不和谐的感觉。甚至你自己就可以亲手更改图片文字来制作或者完善MOD.

为了不做剧透我只能介绍到此！

22479886.review:
If you're looking for an intense, unforgiving turn-based isometric strategy surivival game with perma-death I recommend you give this a try, although I do recommend picking it up when it's on sale, $15,- seems a bit of a steep price in my opinion.

You start off the game by creating your character, selecting strenghts and weaknesses, after which the proverbial shit immediately hits the fan.

You find yourself just awoken from cryo-sleep in a facility when you notice a strange-looking beast approaching you. You can deal with this using strenghts you've previously selected, after taking care of the wolf-like creature you start to wonder where you are, or who you are, you remember next to nothing, and as you set foot outside the facility you notice everything has changed, buildings are in poor condition, and there are no signs of life to be found.

You must scavenge for survival, your first order of business is protecting yourself from the elements, finding clothes is your #1 priority. After getting yourself warmed up and safe from hypothermia, you should probably find a way of protecting yourself, and scavenging for weapons can be a tedious task, but the excitement you get from finding a mint-condition rifle or shotgun is more than worth it, I won't spoil any more of the game, but I will say this: it's extremely unforgiving and I myself have never survived for more than 25 days, unraveling quite a portion of the story, but not close to all of it.

TL;DR
NEO Scavenger is an unforgiving and exciting survival game, and I'd definitely recommend it if you're a fan of the genre, but you will die. A LOT.

Happy scavenging ;D

This is basically "The Road" as a videogame. You drag a shopping cart filled with junk through a desolate wasteland, desperately scrounge for a meal, and the apex of your day is finding a shoe in working condition for the correct foot. Try it out. I don't like survival games, generally, but this one took a hold of me.

Played the demo for a long time and finally decided to buy this game.

Pros:
-Learning curve is very fun and challenging
-No level progression, so if you die, all you are really losing are items. No need to re-grind back up to level 200
-Very atmospheric
-Character customization is decent

Cons:
-Very empty characters, only defining traits are those chosen at the start of the game. No real room for roleplaying.
-Story is very difficult to uncover without multiple runs, and when you do uncover it, its also very empty and disappointing.
-Music is so nonexistent that sometimes i forget its there
-Dying is a bit unbalanced, explained more below

If i have a fur coat, with a backpack jammed with goodies, and im wielding a crowbar, i should NOT get killed by a half naked man with his bare fists just because he had the "Strong" trait. Also getting OHK'd by a dogman when im in top shape because he just so happened to swing at my upper chest and got a good hit in, causing me to go into cardiac arrest. This may be a roguelike but that doesnt excuse poor game balance by the developers.
Ill play this game from time to time when im bored but im definitely not jumping on this everyday when i wake up in the morning because im so excited to make ANOTHER empty character who i kill with alcohol poisoning because ive survived for about 5 years. (because thats how simple this game is once you master it)

Game review aside, you should try Cataclysm DDA, its a free OpenGL game, and its wickedly addictive.

Rating: 5/10
Verdict: Buy it on sale if you have nothing more important on your wishlist.

22202024.review:
A challenging, clunky, and surprisingly deep survival sim.

Best: 
Atmospheric, procedural game world interspersed with story events and areas
Brutal but fair survival sim keeps you coming back, learning new tricks each time
Perks grant new info about the sim mechanics (eg playing Medical allows you to see your health bars)
Modding to allow saves or grant more perks adds greatly to already high replayability

Worst: 
Not a lot of explaining done, only partial visibility of what's happening under the hood, mechanically. If you're the kind of optimizing player who needs to know how many units of hunger a gummibear diminishes, you'll be stuck spending some time on a poorly-maintained wiki looking for clues.
Awkward UI for a modern game
Unpredictable responses from game engine (ie autosort ground inventory when away from camp) discourages late-game experimentation
Inefficiency makes for a time-suck

My strong recommendation for NEO hinges on the opinion that the simple mechanics support a compelling emergent narrative. Repeatedly clicking the "kick when down" option in combat, each time seeing your fallen opponent gain increasingly grisly status conditions, packed a surprising emotional punch. And that's what this game is going for: drawing engaging story moments of wilderness and post-apocalyptic survival from austere gameplay elements. Never in a game have you been so happy to find a plastic bag, so afraid of a lone dog, so desperate for a drink of clean water. The very central crafting system, while inefficient, is fairly intuitive and visually interesting. After I'd played for a while, a central occupation became setting up camps decorated with the bones of my enemies. The story was interesting, though you'll have to play hard or get lucky to see all of it. Modding to allow saves broke the game in that it destroyed the haggard, roguelike grind for survival. How quickly, failing to plan ahead, you'll find yourself surrounded by a pack of dogs or caught out in the open at night makes every decision important, and the longer you survive the more is at stake. Without saves, however, I wasn't able to gather the resources necessary to explore the hacking and electronics mechanics, or to wholeheartedly play the story encounters, which are often deadly, without being afraid of losing my entire enterprise to a single bad decision. Then again, that's exactly what NEO is all about.

C'est un vrai jeu de survie dans un monde post-apocalyptique avec une touche de fantastique, mélange de RPG, de tactique tour-par-tour, de crafting (avec un très, très grand nombres d'items à récupérer un peu partout), sur une carte du monde divisée en hexagones. This is a good game let me tell you why as I recall the last moments of my last life:

I had kept this character alive and well for a good 15ish days when suddenly in the middle of nowhere he began vomiting. I was worried but I had some Antacids on me so I swallowed them and kept going unknowing of what was happening. about a day later I saw I had a disease called 'blue rot' it was stage three. Having no clue of what this was and fearing for my characters life I looked it up on the wiki. Turns out naturally I only had a 30% change to survive it but If I found a certain NPC in a certain place (I wont tell you here) Then I could be cured and immunized. the problem was that in 72 hours there was a 70% chance I would be dead. Panicked by this I began to search the map frantically to the point where I was running through a forest at night when something approached me... I searched and searched but couldn't find anything due to the low light conditions I was stuck in. Then suddenly I was slashed in the stomach by what was revealed to be a dogman (think of a werewolf with no human form.) Startled I took my equipped crowbar and smacked it in the face stunning him. This didn't come without a cost however as the dogman swung again causing my leg to start bleeding profusely. I saw that the beast was stunned took my opportunity and ran while I could through sheer luck I lost it.  Wearily I continued my search for this illusive NPC well into my second sleepless night when I saw them. My dogman problem had tripled. Three dogmen 20m away. I didn't want to use it but I saw no other option. I took out the only item of value I had (a pistol with a full mag) from my bag and began to shoot knowing that running was out of the question due to their speed. 6/7 of the shots hit the pack but they were starting to close the distance. I took my bow from by back dropping the pistol and began to unload all five of my arrows into them. One of the dogmen had collapsed due to the pain I had inflicted but that still left two. There was now only 5m between me and them, my two sleepless night had left me on the verge of collapsing and even if I somehow survived this the blue rot would likely kill me. I wanted to die a hero at least. I dropped everything but my trusty crowbar. I braced for impact then swung with all my might at their leader. I was immediately slashed, battered and bruised but I had nearly got the leader at least. It was then that my sleepless nights  combined with effectively a marathon got the better of me. My battered body unable to continue collapsed of sleep deprivation and there unconscious I was torn to pieces and devoured by dogmen.

This was only of of the epic moments of this life. From this game I have so many stories I could tell from wandering out of the cryo chamber for the first time to reveal the ruined world I was surrounded in to hunting a deer for an entire day with a single spear to turn its skin into a bag of which I hauled around the best cuts of meat I could get from it. This game is an experience and I recommend trying unless you don't like to read because to become really immersed then you need to read all the text they present to you.

21735970.review:
네오 스케빈저 모든 공략(초보 + 특성공략 + 중수공략 포함)

*초보 필수 특성

1.힘+밀리(긍정적)

맨처음 시작시 이 두가지 특성을 넣어서 도그맨을 잡을경우 다치지 않고 잡을 뿐더러  보안키를 줍니다.
보안키를 가지고 큰도시의 헥터한테 갈경우 키를 주변 3000원에해당하는 도시 입장권으로 바꿔줍니다.
밀리랑 힘의 조합은 근접 최강으로써 힘은 근접공격력 50프로상승 밀리는 근접 공격확률을 대폭 올려줍니다.


밀리는  큰 나무막대기+유리조각+작은 끈+밀리가 있으면 창을 조합할수 있어서 도시에서 끈만 바로 구할수 있거나 입고 있는 옷 찟어서 바로 숲 에 가셔서 조합하시면 됩니다. 도그맨이 온다해도 두세방 찌르면 맛있는 고기 덩어리가 됩니다.


힘은 루팅할때 건물이 무너지는등의 위험요소가 증가하지만 폐허가 아닌이상 다칠일은 많이  없으니 후반까지도 잘씁니다.



2.근시(부정적) 

근시는 안좋은 특성에 있습니다만 이 특성은 유일하게 치료 가능한 특성입니다. 
그러기 때문에 누구나 필수로 찍으셔야합니다.

메가시티 병원가셔서 2층에 올라가시면 1000원짜리 치료 하시면  바로 이글아이로 바꿀수 있으며  5000원이 넘는 치료는 인공눈이며 인공눈으로 바꿔도 이글아이랑 같습니다만 인공눈은 업그레이드가 가능하여 망원경 업그레이드와 나이트 비전가 가능합니다 
병원에서 모든 업그레이드를 마치면 이글아이+망원경+나이트 비전이 될수있습니다.


---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

*추천 특성


1.원거리+운동+트랩핑(긍정적)

이조합은 원거리 능력과 달리기로 도망가면서 쏘는 조합입니다.
가까이 오면 트랩핑능력으로 적에게 심각한 데미지를 주는 함정 능력을 쓰면서 적에게 멀어질수 있습니다.
그리고 밀리+힘의 조합에서 나왔던 보안키를 굳이 얻지 않아도 트랩핑 능력으로 헥터에게 낚시해서 입장권을 뜯어낼수 있습니다.


 원거리는 밀리 능력 조합인 창을 조합할수 있으며 활(기본사거리 15)(원거리 30)과 슬링거(기본사거리 짱돌10,조약돌12)(원거리 짱돌20 조약돌25)의 사정거리가 두배입니다.

창:큰나무막대기+날카로운물건(유리)+짧은끈+원거리 특성
활 조합: 큰나무+종이3+긴끈(작은끈3개 조합)+ 날카로운 물건(유리,칼)+원거리 능력
슬링거 조합: 긴끈 2+천(옷,더러운천,꺠끗한 천)
총또한 사거리 두배이므로 후반에 총쓰실때 좋습니다.
총알 구별도 해낼수 있습니다.


운동은 런을 5까지 켜놓을수 있으며 체감상 두배이상 지치지 않는거 같습니다. 전투시에는 특수한 능력으로  도망치기가 가능해서 더 멀리 도망칠수 있습니다.


트래핑은 만능 능력으로써 시작시에 도그맨을 잡았을경우 도그맨+유리조각+트랩핑 능력으로 바로 도그맨가죽옷을 입을수 있습니다. 이 늑대가죽옷은 매우 비싸므로 후반에 도그맨 씨가 마르도록 사냥하시면 돈을 많이 버실수 있습니다.
또한 다른 동물 가죽도 동물사체+트래핑+날카로운 물건을 이용하시면 가죽이 많이 나옵니다.
가죽옷 조합 가죽10+작은끈20+날카로운 물건을 이용하셔서 가죽옷 만들어 파셔도 됩니다.

초반에 옷이 없어서 추우시면 숲에 가셔서 작은 나무가지+ 나무껍질로 불 몇개씩 만들어도 되고  그 불로 고기 구우셔도  됩니다.또한 훈제고기가 가능한데 훈제고기는 갈증이 증가하지만 고기의 유통기한이 증가합니다. 훈제고기는 재만 구하면 되는데 캠프파이어가 꺼지거나 따로 캠프파이어만 조합창에서 넣으셔서 일부러 끄셔도 됩니다.

훈제고기 조합법: 고기+재(ash)+불+아무 막대기+트랩핑

거기에 트랩능력은 나무가지+끈 조합으로 작은 동물 사냥이 가능한 트랩을 만들수 있으며 트랩으로  숲에 탐색하시면 다람쥐 두마리씩은 잡힙니다.

건물의 알람도 또한 확인 가능합니다.

2.빠른 신진대사(부정적)

이능력은 부정적 능력입니다.배고픔과 갈증이 많이 증가하는대신 치유 능력이 증가합니다.
전투 특성이 있을경우 닥치는 대로 죽창을 찔러대기 떄문에 배고픔은 거의 없습니다.후반에는 먹을걱정이 없고 물도 펄펄 끓여서 한가득 싦고 다니기 때문에 전혀 문제없습니다. 그리고 식물학과의 조합이 좋습니다. 워낙 널린게 숲과 평지여서 식물학으로 과일을 골라 드시면 배고픔과 갈증이 한번에 해결됩니다.



-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

*다른 능력들

메딕: 하얀 알약 파란알약으로 보이는 알약들이 무엇인지 구별해 낼수 있습니다.
이걸 알아낼수 있다면 파실때 가격이 증가합니다. 하지만 통의 이름을 위키에 쓰셔서 그 통이 무언인지만 알아내면 내용물도 유추해낼수 있습니다.
아니면 상점이나 병원에서 알약을 구입후에 합쳐지는지 보면 합쳐질경우 같은계열의 약입니다.
캠핑시 캠핑하는곳의 힐링량을 알아낼수 있고 치료창에 가시면 혈액량,면역체계,고통수치 등을 알아낼수 있습니다.

하얀색빨간색 캡슐: 진통제
하얀알약: 항생제 또는 제산제
파란알약: 수면제 또는 혈액 희석제
주황알약: 강력한 진통제 또는 L-티록신
핑크색 알약: 물정화제

진통제: 통증을 줄입니다. 중복사용효과가 없습니다.
항생제: 면역체계를 치료합니다. 질병이 있을경우 치료됩니다.
제산제: 구토를 치료합니다.
수면제: 불면증이 있을경우 유용하며 잠이 실패할경우가 적습니다.
혈액 희석제: 치료제가 아닙니다. 피를 흘리고 있을때 출혈이 증가합니다.
강력한 진통제: 통증을 많이 줄입니다. 매우 비쌉니다.
L-티록신: 치료제가 아닙니다.갑상선 호르몬 약입니다.구토를 유발합니다.
물정화제: 물정화제 + 물 조합하실경우 소독한물이 나옵니다.

은신: 은신은 플레어어의 은신확률을 올려주며  캠핑시 각건물의 은폐도를 볼수 있게해줍니다.

이글아이: 주간에 시야가 증가.위에서 언급했듯이 돈으로 이글아이를 올릴수 있다. 찍으면 안됩니다.

트래킹: 적이 이동한 발자국을 볼수 있으며 자신의  발자국을 빠르게 지울수 있다. 도그맨같은 추적자들은 발자국으로 기습하곤 합니다.

느린 신진대사: 밥과 물을 적게 먹는다. 그리고 치유능력이 조금 떨어집니다.

해킹: 전자 기기들을 해킹해서 안에 있는 정보들을 상점에 팔수있게 합니다.
작성자는 한번의 해킹성과로 어떤 노트북안에서 5000이 넘는 가치의 정보를 발견했습니다.
 이것은 약간 설명이 복잡한다 설명을 좀 길게 하겠습니다.
일단 각 기기마다 다른종류의 배터리가 필요하며 배터리안에 전기를 넣어야합니다.
전기는 배터리에 없을때가 많으며 충전은 5시 방향 끝에 있는 메가시티에서 하얀색 타일의 집에서 받을수 있습니다.
타일에 가셔서 인벤토리를 보시면 전기코드가 있습니다.
전기 코드를 오른쪽 클릭해서 use를 사용할경우 안에 전기가 차며 empty out하면 전기가 전기코드 밖으로 튀어나옵니다.

글이 길어져서 카페의 글을 보시길 추천드립니다.
카페에는 스크릿샷으로 직관적이게 설명되있습니다. 
동영상도 있으니 제 글에서 찾아보시면 쉽게 공략가능합니다.
http://cafe.naver.com/indiss/18511

21706043.review:
英語読まない＆全て遊びつくしたわけではないので、間違った記載があるかもしれませんので悪しからず

まず言語が英語のみ、かつ日本語化が技術的にほぼ不可能な点（出来なくはないらしいが、異常なほど手間）
生き抜くだけなら、個人のブログや動画などを見て、実プレイで生き死にを繰り返せばそう難しくはないです。
イベントの翻訳も、少しならブログや動画などで訳されたりしています。

世界観は、ポストアポカリプス物ですが、マップの大部分が平地、山、湖、森、アイテムを漁るためだけの廃墟、
簡単に殺しにかかってくる人間と、化け物じみた生物がウロウロしている点を除くと、
ほぼ未開地のジャングルに点々と廃墟を置いただけのように感じ、終末観を感じさせるほどではない。
新聞やイベントの内容を読めれば終末観を感じられるかもしれませんが、英語力がないなら感じないかもしれません。

アイテム周りに関しては、アイテムの説明文や、制作要素について
説明文も当然英語ですが、簡単に訳せる非常に簡素な英文しかありません。
英語が母国語の人でも、このアイテムはWiki見ないと理解できないのでは？という物がかなり多いです。

制作に関しては、微妙におざなりに感じます。
アイテムが多いとアイテム制作画面を開くだけに少々時間がかかり、ややストレス
制作アイテムのレシピは必要最低限の物だけで、簡略的で良いが、
頻繁に使う水の煮沸と、煮沸に必要な焚火を制作するのが中途半端に手間がかかる。

マップは広いが、イベントがあるエリアはそこまでなく遠く、
金銭のシステムがあるのに交換出来るのがマップの一番隅（他にもエリアはあるかもしれないが）、
死ぬとセーブが消えるのに英語読めても選びそうな選択肢を選ぶと簡単に死ぬ（セーブのバックアップは一応可能）


等々散文駄文が目立つ内容となってしまいましたが、
英語を母国語のように扱える方でないなら、あまり購入はお勧めしません。

21682547.review:
This game is one that won't leave you unsatisfied as it is brutally hard, and when you die you rarely get upset and think; "I could have done that instead" or "maybe that wasn't a good idea, I should avoid doing it again" (only time I've gotten upset is when I die fighting a bad medusa gang member, almost dieing, then getting killed by a stray dog)
1. The game is terrible when it comes to forgiving mistakes, which makes it brutally fun as you either get punished or punish others for making a bad move like attacking you without weapons while you have a large knife and the strong skill. It can also destroy you if you make a bad move and give you no chance to save yourself
2. The npcs seem player like, some either hunting you down and causing trouble just because they can, others thanking you for not trying to stab them while on their way to go do something. Some ignore you too. Great realism to how some people see, like they would act in an event like this
3. It's a hard game, both to learn and play when you at least think you have the ropes down, a pocketknife, and a yellow canary lighter in your jean pockets since your grocery bag is full of more grocery bags and food. And don't think "oh it must be the bad kind of hard because you need to learn stuff yourself and everything is brutal" since it's a fun game and the only time the game isn't hard is maybe the first few moves when absolutely nothing can move yet and get you. It's a good kind of hard that makes you feel warm with the feels for your characters health and well being as he try's to figure out what the fuck happened and why he can't remember shit.
4. Even when you think you got things going well it can still go bad. The run I was the most equipped on was ended by a dogman who was hungry for human flesh, mine to be specific after he killed an npc and ditched the body. This keeps you on your toes as you sneak from building to building hopping to find a crowbar or bow or at least a lighter while the building doesn't give away under your feet and you fall to your doom or fall down some stairs and hit your head, breaking your neck and dieing right away.
I live the game, also a great tip is don't take your necklace off, no gear, no matter how strong, is worth taking it off. If you need it that badly then make room for it. 
Keep your yellow canary lighter close by and what ever odd tool turned melee weapon and named "mr head basher" or "stabby stabby craby" or "I dunno what the hell to name this" ready to bash/Stab what ever wanders close enough at night, even a deer or bunny

So I was fighting this one Mutha and we both reduced each other to near death. I ended up blacking out and waking up to find my gun stolen as well as other stuff on me. Also, there's mods!
