21359789.review:
Краткая история моего игрового опыта в NEO Scavenger
Споткнулся, упал , очнулся , ...
Оказался в криво-камере в пригородах Детройта в 2000 каком-то (неизвестно каком) году, с амулетом на шее и выбранными заранее способностями
Как опытный бомж прятался и маскировался, кипятил воду, чтоб не отравиться, обследовал разрушенные здания.
Сделал себе копьё в лесу, а потом убил пару уродов и по счастию своему получил пистолет с патронами от людоеда bad mutha.
Весело бродя по лесу и убивая своим копьем собак( их мясо нужно жарить и есть как в шаверме), наткнулся на хорошего человека ATN Warrior, который указал путь в Анклав и наследил.
В анклаве пожрал на холяву и купил у них лук со стрелами и хорошую дубинку)
В каком-то доме валялась карта Детройта и я решил отправиться к тому месту, где раньше был его центр.

Scavenging a few derelict houses, realizing that plastic bags and chip packets are more usefull than mobile phones,
Sleeping in a forest under a makeshift tarp tent in the rain, getting hypothermia,
Eating nondescript mushrooms and having a nervous system breakdown,
Being hunted down by a pack of wild dogs,

Trying to cover up your tracks as you move between areas,

21194383.review:
The best word for this game is 'harsh', I reckon. It just doesn't care about you if you screw up. 
This makes it incredibly satisfying to succeed in. 
Gameplay wise scavenging is gritty and engaging, combat is incredibly serious, and crafting is pretty satisfying. 
The UI is pretty weak, especially in crafting and managment, but it all works fine once you suss it out. 
The story has been pretty compelling so far. I was blown away by how they executed Detroit, I haven't seen anything quite like it before. That said I have only managed to get to it once, and it seems a sort of first stop for the plot to really start rolling. 
If you like survival games give it a crack!

21192163.review: This game is way, way too hard. You cant even beat a normal person armed with stones when you're at full health and have weapons. As soon as you leave the starting area you're suddenly afflicted with hypothermia and tracked and attacked by dogs that you also have no chance of beating. Then, each time you start a new game you have to pick your traits all over again for the 5 minutes that you're going to live. You'll often die a day or two after leaving the starting area from hypothermia even if you do everything you can to not freeze to death. The first few turns, if you aren't lucky enough to find yourself some clothing and a rudimentary weapon, you can bet you're going to die in your sleep or as some dog (or Dogman)'s lunch. I love the concept and the style. A turn based survival that works off of hexes? Pretty clever. But the execution is far too brutal and with not even the most simple of tutorials to learn basic survival from, it's even more unforgiving... and not in a fun way. Buy this if you feel like being helpless and frustrated, otherwise I'd recommend passing this up until there are some major changes that put you, instead of RNG, in control of your fate.

Character creation needs some work still, but it's fine. Some of the permadeath aspects can really suck, like how in certain encounters 2 out of the 4 choices will kill you. However this is compensated for with beautiful writing and detail. Combat is one of the best aspects of the game, it feels fresh, rewarding, and pretty realistic. Your first playthrough and your later playthroughs will have such a big difference, it's crazy. If you can't afford the kind of big price tag, I recommend the demo at the least. That has the combat.

21152208.review:
[url=http://www.le-serpent-retrogamer.org/test-neo-retro-neo-scavenger-la-galere-dont-vous-etes-le-heros]> Retrouvez cette critique en images sur le Serpent Retrogamer  <[/url]

[b]Le genre du survival a de nouveau le vent en poupe. Après un Day Z plutôt orienté shooter, et un Lone Survivor plus old school, un ancien de chez Bioware décide de mettre son grain de sel en présentant un jeu un peu particulier. Sous le nom Neo Scavenger, préparez vous à un jeu de rôle, tour par tour de survie post apocalyptique. Plaira t-il au joueurs?[/b]

[h1]THE WALKING (8bit) DEAD[/h1]

Neo Scavenger se veut être un survival au tour par tour, et nous le fait comprendre dès le début. Notre héros est enfermé dans un laboratoire abandonné, se réveillant totalement perdu et sans souvenirs de son passé. Nous choisissons d’abord ses capacités parmi un nombre donné. Si l’on choisit la compétence “Strong”, le personnage sera plus fort physiquement et aura tendance à choisir la manière forte en toute situation. A l’inverse la compétence “Mechanics” donne au héros la possibilité d’utiliser les équipements électroniques pour échapper aux dangers qui arrivent sur lui. Un dernier exemple intéressant est la compétence “Botanics”. Grâce à elle on peut concocter de quoi se soigner avec les objets ramassés à Terre, mais de manière plus générale, tester toutes les manières de faire de sa vie la moins misérable possible.  L’action est modifiée en permanence de ce fait, et les embranchements seront semblables a un livre dont vous êtes le héros. Mais qui dit survival, dit personnage faible et désœuvré, et avec les compétences arrivent les faiblesses.  Serons nous faibles? insomniaques? ou myopes? toujours est il qu’à l’inverse d’un jeu de rôle, on ne joue pas un héros mais un homme affaibli. Cela se sent également par le fait que nous commençons l’aventure sans affaires et sans vêtements si ce n’est un habit d’hôpital. Un grognement se fait entendre au loin, et nous devons vite nous en sortir. On sent une influence post apocalyptique à ce point qui sera confirmée par la suite, et le début de Neo Scavenger fait grandement penser à “The Walking Dead”. Mais assez divagué, rentrons plus en détail dans le jeu.

[h1]SEUL CONTRE TOUS[/h1]

Nous sommes donc dans le laboratoire, et devons nous décider, ce qui prend la forme d’un texte avec plusieurs choix. Comment couper l’accès à la bête rôdant dehors? En fonçant ( Strong) sur la porte pour la bloquer avec les moyens du bord bien sur! Seul problème, on s’épuise plus que de nature.  On se dit alors qu’il y a moyen de pirater les portes pour empêcher l’arrivée de l’inévitable, et ça marche! On en profite pour soigner notre amnésie grâce aux carnets de bord probablement laissés par les scientifiques. Une fois le silence revenu, le héros que nous sommes réussit à sortir et voit un environnement totalement dévasté. Le jeu prend alors la forme d’une immense carte divisée en hexagones.  On se déplace sur celle ci par à coups, en fouillant chaque case. Parfois c’est juste la plaine qui s’offre à nous, ou des forêts voire même des villes abandonnées. Par le biais d’actions, on peut se cacher, fouiller, dormir ou encore fabriquer des objets. Mais pour avoir des objets, vu que l’on est quasi nu, il faut trouver les endroits ou chercher. C’est surtout dans les villes que ce sera le cas, et là où un bout de chaussure et un verre de whisky vont nous aider à passer la nuit, des journaux parsemés vont donner des infos sur ce qui est réellement passé. L’aventure prend donc une tournure à la fois survivaliste et historique, car on apprendra à la fois des choses sur le monde qui nous entoure, sur nous même et sur les événements  qui se sont déroulés. La découverte sera de courte durée, car une menace extérieure sera présente sur notre chemin, sous la forme d’une entité extra terrestre. Le jeu se rajoute également une composante “chat et la souris”, ou la guerre de la moindre goutte d’eau se heurte aux affrontements contre les bestioles. Et il ne vaut mieux pas les affronter justement, à moindre d’avoir des armes dédiées…mais c’est une autre histoire. Toutes ces composantes donnent un jeu plutôt complet et prenant. Seuls quelques petits détails viennent gêner l’expérience.

[h1]DES OMBRES AU TABLEAU SOMBRE[/h1]

Neo Scavenger est à la fois un jeu dont nous sommes les héros et également un jeu de déplacement par hexagones. C’est un hommage voulu par les développeurs, mais également un inconvénient à cause de l’interface. Tout flaire les années 80, avec des combats se terminant en 34 clicks, les menus où l’on se perd rien que pour sauvegarder et les objets récupérables par 3 clicks, le joueur le moins téméraire peut perdre vite le fil. La qualité technique du titre se veut simple et réussit son pari, avec seulement le nécessaire pour distinguer l’action. On aurait voulu un peu plus de détails pour s’y retrouver, surtout avec l’interface, mais le parti pris est bien visible. Enfin, une grosse barrière se monte devant vous si vous avez la faculté de ne parler que le langage de Molière: toute l’interface est en Anglais. On peut s’accommoder dans les menus, mais le jeu en lui même déborde de textes, allant même jusqu’à couvrir la moitié de l’écran. Pour les gens souhaitant tenter leur chance prenez un dictionnaire. Des choses un peu gênantes mais qui pourront être surmontées par tout joueur courageux.

[h1]A retenir[/h1]

[b]Vous aimez la survie? Et bien vous aurez de la survie! Neo Scavenger ne laisse que très peu de marge de manœuvre au joueur. On doit survivre, en étant quasi nu, sans armes, et avec des caractéristiques et faiblesses particulières. On progresse en surveillant chaque pas, et construisons notre aventure en apprenant plus sur ce qui est arrivé dans ce monde dévasté, dans une aventure complexe. Par contre, l’interface est très austère, en Anglais, et seulement les plus courageux vont aller jusqu’au bout. A essayer pour soutenir le développeur, mais en étant prêt à souffrir pour être fort.[/b]

21119791.review:
Wasted potential. A neat idea made unbearable by an inexcusably horrendous interface, glitches and things that don't make sense and completely break any immersion. More chore than challenge; would not recommend.

- - - - - - The interface is absolutely horrible for no reason other than bad design. You're going to be clicking on things at least five times more than you have any right to. What's worse, once you explore the map a bit, the game begins to be unreasonably slow and unresponsive.
- - - - Game suffers from bugs that have no right to be in the final product. For example, if you get exiled from the city, get a different tracking bracelet and try to get it again, the game will treat the new bracelet as the old one and won't let you back in. What's worse, the only way to get back is to literally wait (!!!) for an entire year of game-time (8760 turns).
- - - - Unimmersive; for a survival game, surviving stops being any challenge whatsoever as soon as you reach the city outskirts and stay there. You can live safely and comfortably indefinitely while earning a shootload of money, and the only reason to leave safety is to push the story forward. Also, the character is supposed to be someone who got dropped into this post-apocalyptic world out of the blue, yet in the extremely limited NPC interactions he somehow already knows about things he hasn't even come close to seeing. The "crafting recipes found on random pieces of paper scattered all over the place" thing not only makes no sense, but is also largely useless as they more often than not show obvious things like "heat source + kindling = fire", or "binoculars + strap = binoculars with strap".
- - - It's a wiki game; the game itself fails to give you even the most basic information about things for no good reason; for example, weapon reach, not to mention things like weapon damage, etc. The player has to look things up that he really shouldn't need to, and even then, the wiki itself doesn't bother listing a lot of useful information about a lot of things, which shows a lack of any real player interest.
- Minimum in-game sounds, almost no music.
~ Game might seem "unfair" to a lot of people who dislike dicerolling and are used to streamlined games. Some situation can simply kill you, and there's nothing you can do about it. Permadeath.
+ A challenging and exciting early-game. Caution and risk management are needed, and running for it is often the correct choice.
+ An interesting, strategic and tactical battle system, once you get the hang of it.
+ Character creation is also interesting, which lets you choose traits and disadvantages (which let you choose more traits)

20966221.review:
Raw, Challenging, Unforgiving and ultimately a test of will. You must survive in a harsh environment against realistic conditions and wounds in what appears to be a post apocolyptic world. Every wound could become your last as you struggle to find equipment to help push you forward. Balance your traits to your advantage and use them as your life depends on it.
This seemingly simple game will prove a true challenge as even the most seasoned veteren can find himself in an untimely end as the environment and its stalkers barrage you with attacks from bitter cold, poisoned food to cannibalistic warriors hell bent on your life. Every night could be your last as survival is truly of the fittest.
This game pushes you to your limits as you use your wits to make every choice from what you carry, to how you fight, and how you treat that gashed leg and shattered ribs.

Can you survive?

As someone who truly loves a true raw environment where the details count in the mechanics of the game, I have to give this a high score. It's truly one of the few of its kind out there and it does it excellently. I highly recommend this game!

20874694.review:
Vorweg ein wichtiger HINWEIS, welcher auch der Hauptgrund für mein Review ist: Informiert euch unbedingt vor dem Spielen auf der Homepage des Entwicklers Blue Bottle Games über die Probleme beim Speichern des Spielstandes (wegen Permadeath, gibt es nur einen). Da das Spiel Flashbasiert ist wird der Spielstand von diversen Browser- und Anti-Cookie Programmen gelöscht! Man kann ihn aber relativ leicht sichern wenn man weiß wo er zu finden ist!. 

Mit Blasen an den Füßen renne ich, immer noch im Krankenhaushemd, und mit nur einem Schuh, vor dem streunendem Hund weg, nachdem ich 2x gestolpert bin bringe ich ihn endlich außer Sichtweite und fliehe aus diesen Ruinen. Im nahegelegenen Wald ruhe ich mich etwas aus und finde zu meinem Glück ein paar Pilze, gut, dass ich botanische Kenntnisse besitze, denn sie sind giftig...oh, und da liegt ein totes Eichhörnchen! Hätte ich nur die Scherben mitgenommen, dann könnte ich es jetzt zerlegen, aber vielleicht sollte ich erstmal meine Spuren verwischen, da ist dieser Typ unweit meines letzten Lagers vorbeigekommen...sehen konnte ich ihn nur dank des halb kaputten Fernglases, dass ich fand und mir mit ein paar Schnüren um den Hals gehängt habe, Kurzsichtigkeit ist auch kein Spaß...Jetzt erstmal die Schrammen von den Stürzen verbinden, ganz schön schmerzhaft, ah, nur ekelhaft dreckige Stofffetzen, und kein Antibiotikum, aber vielleicht kann ich sie mit dem Schnaps säubern...

Nur ein kleiner Auszug dem was sich bei Neo Scavenger vorallem im Kopf des Spielers abspielt, nämlich ein echter Überlebenskampf. Zumal am Anfang ist das Spiel äußerst tödlich, vorallem wenn man Pech hat und nicht schnell wichtige Gegenstände findet/bastelt, und/oder zu schnell in einen Kampf verwickelt wird. Es sei denn man spielt einen toughen Schläger, der kostet allerdings und lässt dadruch weniger Optionen für andere Fähigkeiten zu. Es sei denn man packt sich noch ein paar Nachteile drauf, z.B. kurzsichtigkeit, oder einen sehr schnellen Stoffwechsel. 

Ich denke, die bestehenden Kritiken fassen es schon gut zusammen, deshalb möchte ich als Kritikpunkt nur die etwas sehr umständliche Inventarverwaltung anführen, wobei ich damit nicht das Mikromanagement per se meine, das hier nicht lästige Pflicht sondern überlebenswichtig ist! Das Spiel ist insgesamt in Sachen Menüführung und verwaltung auch in den Kämpfen ein wenig kleinteilig geraten, rundenbasiert halt, was aber wiederum zur Atmosspähre des Spiels passt in der jede noch so kleine Entscheidung wichtig sein kann, und jeder weitere Schritt wohlüberlegt sein sollte. 

Positiv herausheben möchte ich noch den sehr atmosphärischen Soundtrack, die einfache, aber wirkungsvolle Chakraktergenerierung, und das interessante, wenn auch eher unübersichtliche Crafting (passt aber auch wieder zum Spiel...). Zur Story kann ich noch nicht viel sagen, ist erstmal nicht sehr originell, aber motivierend.

Insgesamt eine klare Kaufempfehlung für alle die Spiele mögen bei denen die beste Grafik und die beste Story im Kopf entsteht.

20817043.review:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie 

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

Basically, this is the kind of difficulty and immersiveness you will find in this game.

The first thing you have to know about NEO Scavenger:

20684733.review:
I have discovered my true calling as a hobo, fighting off feral dogs to scavenge post-apocalyptic ruins for anything remotely valuable.

This game is quite good. It's actually very short, which is probably a good thing because it's so difficult. However, despite the amount of random bullshit that seems to kill you in this game, I never had a death where that I couldn't see why it was my fault. The world is extremely harsh, but you'll mostly find out about the stuff that kills you early in the game, or it's common sense, so you won't get to the endgame only to be insta-killed unless YOU do something stupid. Just be aware that the minute you DO do anything stupid, you will probably die. This, together with the core gameplay around surviving, is what kept me coming back to the game, even after ragequitting in frustration and deciding to never play it again. The different systems around survival -health, scavenging, combat, crafting, character creation, bartering, and inventory - work together extremely well. I have a weakness for survival and sandbox games, especially rogue-like survival games, but I'm also very harsh on them. I have a lot of problems with games like Minecraft, Rust, Ark, Terraria, DayZ and more. NEO Scavenger has been the perfect survival experience for me though. It's not something to spend hundreds of hours on, no. Based on my playtime so far and the playtime of other reviewers, 70ish hours seems to be the cap before interest dives. That's when I felt like I had thoroughly learned how the game worked. What makes this an engaging experience is going from knowing nothing about the game to being able to take on any challenge it thows at you. Amazingly, it succeeds in being an experience both fantastic and realistic.

It's not perfect, of course. The story events and random events have some problems, but even though these choose-your-own-adventure style events can kill you, they're actually surprisingly lenient compared to the core mechanics of the game. You usually have to screw up pretty bad to get killed, and most frequently you just get a slap on the hand if you didn't choose exactly the right path through event. Since I died so much outside of the events, it was pretty fun to see how different paths and different character builds affected the outcome. Other than that, I personally couldn't care about the story and events very much. It's interesting, moderately good quality, and original. I normally love narrative and world-building in games, but in NEO Scavenger it took the backseat to the core gameplay. The only negative thing I can say about that is it could just use MORE. The art style, while flat, is exactly what it needs to be for the game, but everything definitely looks the same after only an hour or two. If there were a few more hex-types and some variation in textures, and especially if there was some physical depth, as in changes in elevation, to the terrain, it would be much more visually interesting. The item count is decent, but if there was just a bit more customization possible it would be awesome, and then every single npc wouldn't look identical. The map is actually quite large, and it can take a long time to get across it when you're looting everything that's even slightly lootable and fending off all manner of dangers along the way, but it could really use a few more unique locations with events tied to them, even though I said that's not what I'm here for. The character building is great: it really does feel like original Fallout and it totally determines what you can do and how you play, but for a system so deep it just feels so small. The world NEO Scavenger takes place in is very interesting, but outside of vague newspaper articles there's not actually all that much to explain it all. With a more cohesive and expansive lore, I could really get into this world. The story, like I said, is very short, and I frankly don't care that much about it; it's good enough for me. But it does have this interesting problem that unless you explore everything you can easily "complete" the story in just two "quests". It's pretty hard to tell what kind of story NEO Scavenger wants to tell, and how. I don't think it needs to be longer. With multiple paths and endings and the difficulty of the game it benefits from being short. But it does need a few more storytelling mechanics, and probably a better, more dense distribution of the story throughout the gameplay. As is, you play the core game and progress for a long while, and then you get a big chunk of wall-of-text story.

All in all, if you want a solid survival role-playing game, this is what you want. I think that for the type of people who enjoy this game you can expect as much as 70 hours of extremely engaging time with this game, which is definitely worth $15. Enjoy!

20409083.review:
Note: I bought and played mostly on the GOG version of the game, hence why I have less than 2 hours in Steam. I probably logged over 100 hours.

Anyways...


What this game does right is giving you lots of options when it comes to survival. Too often survival games feel limited, like things you should be able to do easily in a real life situation just aren't available in game. A couple examples that come to mind:

- Need to boil something but don't have a cooking pot? Use a tin can!
- Need to make fire but don't have a lighter? Rub two sticks together or use sunlight and a piece of glass!
- Need a container to carry items but don't have a backpack? Use a plastic shopping bag!
- Need bandages? Rip clothes, get rags. Need clean bandages? Boil rags.
- Need string? Rip rags.

Nice features include:
- 'Building' your camp: pick an abandoned building with the appliances you need, place traps, leave a sleeping bag... Not a whole lot of options but you do feel like you have your own personal secure spot you can come back to.
- An engaging storyline that makes you want to find out about what happened to the world and yourself. An interesting lore as well.
- Lots of crafting options to get the stuff you need to survive.
- Skills that give you special abilities
- Pretty good learning curve: you'll have to keep trying at first until you learn the basics. Then you'll manage to survive fairly well, and you'll still have many more things to learn and discover. There's lots of stuff you'll have to figure out on your own (or you can use the wiki).
- Overall, enough content to keep you engaged for many hours.
- Low hardware requirements. Will probably run on that $200 laptop you bought to take notes in class (check the specs to be sure though).


Cons:
- The game is text-based with a graphical interface. Nothing is animated, few things are drawn, most is just described through text. The combat system especially takes some getting used too as well. It's very playable and some people like that style, but for some people it's a deal-breaker. So be warned.
- Only one save/permadeath (although you can easily circumvent that).
- Not being able to pick all skills can make the game feel limited, forcing you to play again to explore other things (you can mod the game to get all skills though).
- The randomness can be harsh sometimes and force you to restart many times before you'll get lucky, have a good start and actually get somewhere.
- Many random encounters don't have a "good" resolution to them, sometimes making you feel like the game just ties your hands excessively and won't let you try hard enough, or making you feel like your skills are useless. Some encounters can actually punish you severely, with no way for you to predict that your decisions will lead to a really bad outcome. This is in deep contrast with the rest of the game where you have so many options to accomplish what you want to do.

Overall I recommend it to people who enjoy the survival genre, have the patience to fail, learn and try again repeatedly, and who can overlook the game sometimes throwing you in tough situations without you being able to do anything about it. People who aren't so hardcore can just mod the game a bit to make it easier and can circumvent the one save/permadeath feature.

I made it. I finally had made it big, and was loaded for bear. 

$1,000 in my pockets, with bullets to spare. I was making my way back to the DMC, happier than you could even think. I had made plans. I was going to sell these spare bullets, and buy a real gun and maybe some night vison goggles. I was going to be unstopable, moreso than I already was. Hell, already people were running as soon as I got in the same area as they were.

Like a fool, I traveled at night, with nothing out to help me see. Suddenly, I was attacked. I took cover and laughed. "Probably some Bad Mutha trying to kill me, I'll show him," I thought as I readied my new-found bow, and fired into the night mist. The arrows wizzed by, missing anything that could possibly be near. Suddenly, a fist slammed into my face, and in that second I was able to make out my attacker. I wasn't lucky enough to get a Ba Mutha or a random looter, but instead my attacker wore a hospital gown. A Blue Frog.

I wasn't able to ready my crowbar quick enough, and found myself on the recieving end of a beat down. I managed to crack my crowbar on the man's head a few times, which would normally kill anyone else. At one point, the man went down, and I had a choice. I could have run, and possibly gotten out fine, but I was a fool.

"I've gotten so far. This jerkoff won't be the end of me," I thought to myself, as I readied the crowbar, intending for it to pierce the man's skull. Instead, I found myself back on the ground, the crowbar and bow out of my reach. The man had somehow gotten the advantage again, and as I found myself slowly losing my wits, blood, and for that matter my life, I only had one thought.

"I was so close. Why did I have to die like this?"

20187043.review:
[b]Don't let the semi-clunky user interface and middle-of-the road pixel graphics sway you; [i]NEO Scavenger[/i] is an utterly addicting turn-based survival roguelike game that will steal your time.[/b]

---
[i]
So I have the wifey take this for a test drive, since I'm lazy and want to lay on the couch. I figure this run would end pretty quick, because I know death is apparently frequent in this game (aka roguelike). I turn around to eat a bag of chocolate, and before I know it the hobo main character is wearing six t-shirts, a hoodie, a hospital gown, a size 7 left shoe, and a size 9 right boot.

Wow. That escalated quickly. More like [/i][b]NEO Scavenger: Hobo Simulator 2015[/b][i]

Plastic baggies are [i]literally[/i] a currency in this world. We had one on our back, one in each hand, and about 6 spare ones stashed in the others. Nuts.

Not even to mention the inventory tetris that I just witnessed. Literally level 9,000 sh*t going on here. If you are OCD or have hoarding tendencies, be forewarned.
[/i]
---

[b]What was so fun about this game is that you really feel the excitement as you rise up and gather better and better gear.[/b] There is alot of strategy and exploration that keeps things fresh. The story elements are present, but are never bothersome.

[b]Pros:[/b]
+Quite addictive.
+Very deep and complex interactions. Lots of attention to detail with crafting and how items interact. How clothing functions, etc. Further, there are lots of ways to go about a situation.
+Feels fair. We actually got quite far on the first run or so.

[b]Cons:[/b]
-Interface feels clunky at first, but isn't that bad when you get past the learning curve.
-Music is almost non-existant. Fine enough with me because bad music is bad.
-The combat system leaves something to be desired. Thankfully the game is not centered around it.

[b]Yeah totally worth full price - lots of really fun replay value here.[/b]

20155007.review:
Hey smartass, if you think Fallout 4 is too easy, why not come and try your hand at some NEO Scavenger? After feral dogs jump up and rip your face off with their teeth for the fifth time, I bet you'll appreciate having a robot butler to care for you, you big cosseted ghost town lover!

Yeah, you think you're hot shit because you dunked a few Fat Mans into a Super Mutant's face? You're nothing. You have never been in a post-apocalyptic wasteland until you're running around, frantically searching for clothes in abandoned buildings to keep from freezing to death. You haven't lived because you haven't frantically searched for a soup pan to boil water with, because you know all the water laying around is an invitation to kill you. You haven't really survived because you know that the world knows about fifteen different ways to snuff your life out, and is cold and indifferent about everyone one of those ways because that's how hardcore and brutal planet Earth is. You haven't known the true terror of conflict as another one of your kind stalks you with a hunting rifle for all the batteries and water bottles you have.

You like being in constant danger? Good, because that's how the game masks its short length. From the very start, half of the game's goal is just living long enough to reach the Megacity of Detroit. It's a short walk, but it's a short walk fraught with danger that will kill people dead (especially if you decide you're too good for guns and try to go for a Melee-only character). It's an open world and there's all sorts of fun secrets to find. If you live long enough to get there, that is.
But if you do, you'll suddenly realize just how cramped it all seems. And yet, it feels a bit unreasonable to ask for more, because the journey to finding the secret is a bunch of little experiences in and of itself.

Also the random encounter roleplaying sequences do a great job illustrating how depressingly hostile the world is, but also rarely try to kill you outright. And I understand why they're there - even the hardest of motherfuckers in the wasteland will go down easy - but VERY SUDDENLY losing a character I've grown to love after playing for thirty hours carting shit back and forth to the DMC because I chose poorly really rubs me the wrong way. I'm not saying this is entirely a bad thing (I was choosing rather carelessly), but a little forewarning to sudden death is appreciated.

Anyway! If you want to play Super Hardcore mode in NEO Scavenger, take your dumb little talisman off and see how hard the game gets. Then you can complain about it to me in the comment section, you lily-livered aluminium can collector.

20021568.review:
- Highly original turn-based survival game.
- Think very carefully about your next move as biting off more than you can chew will end up with you being bitten off and chewed. 
- Very satisfying to scavenge and carefully arrange all of your loot, choose a good base, and take on the post-apocalyptic world. 
- Replayable due to different character builds, random map generation, and choice of approach
- In-depth, detailed crafting and injury system that is reminiscent of Dwarf Fortress' detail. 
- Unique combat with a heavy focus on strategy and avoiding injury rather than mindlessly hack and slashing. 
- Great writing and intriguing premise. 
- Interface looks intimidating but is suprisingly easy to learn. 
- Pick up and play for ten minutes, or get lost for hours. 
- Permadeath makes it all real.

**Story may contain Spoiler**

This is the story of my latest adventure

Day 1: I woke up in a strange facility, I have no clue who am I and why am I here.. Suddenly! Surprise Dogman appeared! I beat the living s**t out of it like there was no tomorrow until it stopped twitching.

It was a good work out I don't remember when was the last time I had a work out or if I even work out at all. My stomach made a rumbling noise so I went to search the place for food but only found a green bag with a white cross sign inside it was just a bunch of dumb pills.. I stared at the dead dog like creature feeling somewhat regretful for killing.. perhaps it was just trying to help me.. So I chopped his body into pieces and brought some wood from the nearby forest to make fire to cook it.

"This is what it would've wanted me to do" I thought to myself silently thanking it for becoming a meal and a coat but also silently hating it at the same time for not bringing any condiments with it.

After satisfying my stomach I went to stroll into the nearest town looking for any sign of civilization but nobody was here the streets were empty and ocassionally I'd see a few skeletons laying around, perhaps it's halloween and they're having a huge hide and seek event.. YES! that could only be the most logical reason!

I looked around inside buildings ocassionally taking items with me "I'm just gonna borrow this stuff I'm sure they wouldn't mind" I thought to myself as I grabbed as much stuff as I could carry.

It was starting to get dark and I was afraid if a stranger would walk up to me and offer me a sugar free candy, so I went back to the facility I woke up in and decided to call it home.

I saw a faint glow of light in the distance and I knew it.. they were hiding from me.. nobody hides from me.. nobo.. *falls asleep* zzzZZZzzzZZZzz...

Day 2: I had a good sleep last night but my stomach was beginning to complain again.. I went out and made myself a hardened spear before heading out any further.. just in case I encounter any stranger danger..

As I headed out toward where I last saw the glow of light I spotted more Town! as I sprinted toward the town I came across a friendly stranger.

He was carrying a revolver he must be dressing up as a cowboy and he was also wearing a pair of croc so I asked him to give me all of his stuff because my stuff sucks, but he refused and start to charge at me, The nerve of some people I tell you! So I poked him on the head with my sharp stick, he fell and was crawling away from me as he beg for mercy so I gave him what he wanted and kept poking him with my sharp stick until he was no longer in pain.

I was pretty happy that I could borrow his croc I saw that cool kids wear these kind of sho- err sandals..? what ever it is.. the cool kids on the old worn out poster wear it so I'm a cool kid now.

OH! and he also had an expired cracker and some ketchup! So I hack him and whack him and chop him since there's no point to let him go to waste no siree! he would've want me to eat him or else he would've told me stories about starving childrens in some distant foreign land! So being the civilized human being I am, I cooked him as best as I could with the few ingridients he had on him that I'm sure would've made Gordon Ramsay proud.

Today was a good day I said to myself as I went to sleep.

Day 3: A noise woke me up today.. it was a guy! He tried to take my precious empty bottle in the corner! “My Precious!!!” I shouted as I charge toward him and knocked some debris toward him, the debris made him vulnerable and as he tries to recover I stabbed him with my sharp pointy stick and carved a hole in his right arm.

I kept stabbing him with my pointy stick as I hissed at him aggressively, nobody touches my precious! Nobody but me!

I lacerated, gashed and carved him into pieces there was no mercy.. it was the sacrifice my precious neede- Oohh!! He had a crowbar! Now I can dress up as Gordon Freemsay the Angry crazy canibalistic chef with a Phd!

And so I ventured out as Gordon Freemsay! Suddenly 3 Dog appeared! I knew it.. I should’ve double tapped him when I last met him at Galaxy News Radio.. now he reappeared before me as an actual 3 Dog! 

So I demolished one of the closest dog’s head using my crowbar! That really got the attention of the other 2 Dog and again I demolished the other dog head, it seem that knocked some sense to the last dog as it tries to fall back from me but it knew.. it knew it was too late.. it knew that it had done f**ked up and “WHACK!!” that was the last thing it heard.. “nobody.. mess with Gordon Freemsay..” I said to it in a silent hiss.

As I went on my way I was again approached by more meanies.. they just don’t know when to quit..

After slaughtering about 2 more Dog and 2 Stranger with an angry mother issue, I went off to go shopping for a sauce pan and back pack and found a cool sled and since I’m not a thief I left my plastic shopping bag with some rotting left over cooked human meat as a trade in case the owner came back.

It was another great day, I cooked some water from a nearby lake so I can wash my boo-boo away and bottle some more in case I made some more boo-boo.

I also did an art and craft project by stringing small can with a handful of strings and pebbles it made music if people step or trip on them! It will be a great addition to my house!

Day 4: My art and craft project ringed in the middle of the night.. *sigh* I guess it’s time for a midnight snack, it was a dogie! “Chinese food it is then” I lured it into a trap but it still managed to scratch my coat before I stabbed a new nose into it’s lung and bled all over the floor.

Great.. now I’m gonna have to clean that up.. *sigh* why do they have to make things difficult I grumble to myself as I enjoy my midnight snack and went back to sleep but as soon as I closed my eyes another stranger ringed my welcome bell.. I got up and quickly took cover.. I couldn’t see where or who this stranger was so I lashed out and swinged my sharp pointy stick wildly to where I think he’s at but this stranger managed to shred my upper left leg, I fell to the ground and just then I knew.. I done goofed.. and all the horrible things I’ve done.. I’ve become a monster.. and I didn’t want to acknowledge that.. I was in denial all this time.. this is it.. my time has finally come.. I am ready.. do your worst Karma.. and just like that I passed out..

...

Everything was silent.. I woke up.. there was a bright light as if the sun was shining upon me..

...

Wait a minute.. it actually is the sun! And sure enough! there he was.. The f**ker that tried to kill me! Laying on the ground with a hole in his chest.. Boy~! I sure didn’t learn a single thing from that experience so I cut that f**ker up and ate him. It sure was a glorious day in this man army! And it was pretty nice of him to bring me a hunting rifle with a scope, strap and there's even a bullet in it aww that's so sweet of him.

I enjoyed the rest of the day munching on the left over while reading the outdated newspaper man.. I wish I had some fava beans and a nice chianti to go with this live- shh!! There were noises outside.. and sure it was another stranger waiting in the nearby outskirt of the forest.. and so Gordon Freemsay continues his rampage in this post-apocalyptic world..

19541115.review:
I've played this game for 14 hours, and I'm angry. Hear me roar.

I played for 14 hours, slaughtered COUNTLESS beasties, raiders and robbers. I killed something called a "melonhead" and I've slaughtered so many dogs I could wear their skins and pretend to be the wolf-man.
It was at that time - as I munched down another human steak, made on the desecrated remains of a man who had tried to steal my sled in the middle of the night, that I was assaulted. Well, it was actually while I slept after having eaten the corpse of the aformentioned adversary, seeing as time apparently stops when you eat things.

In any case, let me recount to you, the story of Philip the Doghide boy.
Philip, just as any man, awoke from cryogenic stasis in a secret lab, where he was quickly faced with a hideous creature screaming like the midnight wind 'cross a praire of bones so sharp as knives. And much like that praire of bones, the dogman was soon still and dead. You see, Philip was a total badass, and he vanquished this horrific beast with a few swift uppercuts and rock-hard right-left combos. The beast lay dead, and not satisfied with merely having sent this beast's soul to dogman-heaven, Philip decided that it's skin looked comfortable. He grabbed a shard of glass, cut it open and wore it's pelt - face and all, possibly while dancing to some trance-music and smearing cheap lipstick on himself. Naked. In front of a mirror.

After that psychadellic trip, Philip wandered out into the wilderness, wearing nothing but the skin of his dead adversary. He was messed with. Attacked by rabid dogs and feral.. Dogs. And more dogs. This game has a lot of dogs. If you don't like killing dogs, this is probably not the game for you.
Anyway, needless to say, dogs never really posed a problem for Philip. Philip had two good pairs of hands, and he had a shank made of glass in one of them. Philip was not to be fucked with.

Now, Philip was a hulking mass of death, even when armed with nothing but a shard of glass, so I'll assume you understand what happened when Philip found a crowbar and a loaded shotgun in a shed. That's right. Philip turned into a lean, mean, psychopathic killing machine. This brings us to a dark chapter of Philip's life. The killing. The killing never stopped.

Philip was a soulless husk of a man, and that crowbar whispered sweet things in his ears at night. It craved for blood. Lusted for it. Philip was renamed "Philip Mordake".
Philip tried to fight it, of course. Philip was no murderer.. Philip merely loved to kill dogs, but that didn't matter. For each person that crossed Philip's path, the crowbar screamed. It pleaded, begged and demanded of Philip.. Terrible things. Great things. But terrible things.
It drove him to insanity, the whispering. The screams. They all melded together as Philip gave in to the crowbar's crazed yelling. He'd separate flesh from bone, and smash until there was nothing left but something that barely resembeled a human. He'd eat the flesh. Why not? Cut it loose with a shard of glass, and eat chunk by chunk until he was no longer starving.

Philip's path on this strange earth was carved from the blood and bone of any that entered his path. Any that dared touch his sled. Philip was a cruel God on this earth, his fury tempestous and his retribution violent and brutal as it was swift. He cut many a foe from existance, and wore their remains as trophies.

This brings us to the end of Philip's journey. For Philip had been surprised to wake up in the middle of the night, at the sound of somebody stealing his sled! That could not happen - no not at all. And Philip's recourse to this - though predictable - was a thing to behold. He knocked down that poor thief, and whaled with his crowbar until there was naught left of his adversary. Philip hadn't even been injured at this. He was in perfect health, and continued to be so as he smeared himself with the blood of his enemy (note; you can't actually do this in the game. You'll wish you could, though.) and sat himself down again. He dozed off, and once more awoke. This time, to the face of the very first foe that he'd faced.

It was a Dogman, looming above him like a gaunt, shadowy behemoth. The crowbar awoke. It screamed. It begged for blood, and Philip didn't have to be asked twice. He leapt for the creature! He cut it down, and bit it's flesh with that accursed crowbar time and time again! A hailstorm of blows weakened the beast, and it desperately slashed out!
...
Philip was struck in the heart, and died immediately. And the crowbar fell from his hand, going silent.. It was just a normal crowbar.

Now, you might think that's an amusing story. Or maybe you hated that story, but let me tell you what.
I spent 14 HOURS. 14 BLOODY HOURS ON PHILIP.
Philip was a GODDAMNED MONSTER! He was the toughest thing since diamonds armed with shanks in a cuban jail.
He'd survived battles with up to three opponents at once, and though injured, he'd come out on top.
And now he just got killed instantly because of some fantastic stroke of good fortune for some psuedo-werewolf.

This game is interesting, but it's interesting for about 10 minutes. If you've discovered amazing loot in one house, you've basically found all there is in this game. Sure, there are random events and such, but very few of them actually lead anywhere. You're Philip, and you'll always be Philip. Not Philippa, or Sam, or James the Jive-ass Jukebox Jockey. Philip.
You'll pick your perks, disadvantages and roll out. You die because of silly reasons or because you had a bad start. And then you have to start all over, without any progress having been made.
After a while, it becomes tedious. It's not fun to micro-manage your campfire, clothes, hydration and hunger-levels, as well as spend the ENTIRE GAME TRYING TO FALL ASLEEP, I MEAN SHIT. JUST FALL ASLEEP, MAN! YOU JUST MASSACRED AN ENTIRE VILLAGE!

All in all, I'd refund this game if I hadn't hatefucked 14 hours of gameplay out of it. Do yourself a favour and look at a youtube-clip of somebody playing it without audio first. That will be your life in this game. Like what you see? Go for it.

19465576.review:
ORIGINAL REVIEW: Got so excited when I finally found a left shoe and a right shoe (even though one was a boot and the other a flip flop). Then my boot fell apart. Then I was mauled by a feral dog, and presumably eaten. Now I have to go back for more. 10/10

FINAL REVIEW: After playing more, my opinion of this game has come to change. I still recommend it, because it is enjoyable, but buy it on sale. Starts as a 10/10, finishes as a solid 7/10. 

The mechanics are fantastic. It has the right "feel" for a game that has Scavenger in its name. The storyline is intriguing, and well presented through random newspaper articles. Combat is a treat, taking a break from standard "X ability does Y damage" combat, instead simply treating combat as any other encounter, and allowing you to determine which skills to use each turn. But there is simply not enough to go around.

The beginning of the game feels like you're dipping your toe into a vast, deep, dark lake. But after a while, when you begin to figure things out, you realize that you aren't stepping into a deep dark lake filled with unknown dangers and treasures. No, you are simply looking at a puzzle, with pieces scattered, a system of parts that just need to be put together in the correct order. Don't get me wrong, puzzles can be fun. But they don't have the replayability that I seek from a roguelike. No matter how many times you dump the pieces out in a random order to start with, the end is always the same. 

Oh, and speaking of a lake...why no fishing? You can eat a squirrel. You can eat a dog. You can eat a person. But no fish?

19359754.review:
Probabilmente ci troviamo di fronte al RE dei survival-game roguelike.

Mai visto un tale livello di realismo finora e ho sulle spalle qualcosa come 30 anni di esperienza videoludica.

La prima cosa che farete è scegliere le abilità associate al personaggio. Ogni abilità ha determinati punti (in totale ne avrete 16). Sono presenti anche abilità negative in modo da farvi acquisire ulteriori abilità positive. Non è possibile scegliere il sesso del protagonista, il gioco è stato concepito con in mente un personaggio maschile e con un determinato nome. Ma vi assicuro che non è importante.

Ovviamente le abilità che sceglierete avranno dei vantaggi: se scegliete "Melee" sarete forti in corpo a corpo, ma è anche una delle abilità più costose perché vi fornisce un enorme vantaggio soprattutto ad inizio gioco quando la maggior parte degli incontri sono di tipo ravvicinato.

Vi risveglierete in un cryolab con indosso solo la classica camicetta leggera da ospedale e il braccialetto, vi guardate intorno e... no, non spoilero.

Lo spostamento sulla mappa, lo scavenging e persino il combattimento si svolgono a turni selezionando l'azione che il personaggio dovrà effettuare cercando di "prevedere" ciò che farà il nemico.

Quì niente è lasciato al caso: le condizioni fisiche, il crafting, tutto è stato studiato nei minimi particolari. Il livello di realismo è ESTREMO: per esempio se bevete dell'acqua senza prima averla fatta bollire, successivamente ne risentirete. Se trovate un carrello della spesa senza rotelle che potrete magari usare come "veicolo" (inteso come mezzo di trasporto per oggetti), lo dovete trascinare a forza, con la conseguenza che vi stancherete prima e avrete più sete/fame del normale.

Oppure: se non avete l'abilità "Botanica" tutto ciò che troverete nei boschi (funghi, blu berries, red berries ecc...) non saprete se sono commestibili o meno. Potete provarci, ma se sbagliate la pagherete molto cara.

Ed è fantastico, perché quando farete un errore (ho messo "quando" e non "se", non a caso...), imparerete qualcosa in più, quindi la prossima volta starete più attenti.

A proposito di "prossima volta"... le locations sono generate randomicamente, quindi ogni volta è un'esperienza diversa. Longevità assicurata.

Purtroppo anche in questo caso (come con Terraria) non c'è un tutorial, partirete sparati all'arrembaggio. La wiki sarà un ottimo punto di partenza (per esempio non sapevo che le ricette occorre metterle in mano per impararle): http://neoscavenger.wikia.com/wiki/NEO_Scavenger_Wiki

Conclusione: gioco eccezionale, già a prezzo pieno ne vale la pena, con gli sconti è da prendere assolutamente. Consigliatissimo a chi piacciono i giochi survival, quelli seri.

Voto: 9,0/10

19311269.review:
꽤 재밌는 게임입니다. 영어만 되신다면요.다만 텍스트량이 좀.. 읽다보면 소설읽는것 같아 재미를 더하긴 하지만, 영어가 모국어가 아닌 이들에게는 어느순간 피로감으로 스킵하게 됩니다.

영어문제만 제외하면 디테일한 생존게임입니다.

디테일한 생존방식! 그리고 폐허를 뒤질때 가방이나 쇼핑카트가 나올때의 그 쾌감!

간략한 게임설명 해드리겠습니다. 저는 맨땅에 헤딩하는 심정으로 게임을 해서 너무 오래걸렸지만...정보가 없는게 좋으신 분은 안읽으셔도 됩니다.

그 외에도
전투방식에 있어서의 거리개념, 무기의 리치개념도 있고특성에 따라 싸움방식이 달라지기도 합니다. 초반에 창을 만드시면 싸움에서 잘 이깁니다. 
물도 아무거나 주워먹으면 탈나구요, 버섯이나 열매도 독이 든게 있습니다.특성에 따라 한눈에 알아볼수도 있지만, 그게 아니라면 잘 골라먹어야 합니다.
온도개념도 있어 너무 덥거나 추우면 상태이상이 옵니다. 추우면 얼어죽기도 합니다...다치는곳도 디테일하고, 깨끗한 천을 들어 상처부위에 대면 붕대가 됩니다. 더러운천도 가능하지만 감염될 수 있습니다.

팁 몇개를 주자면, 베이스 기지의 전기나 히터 그런건 꼭 안고쳐도 됩니다.시작하면 베이스에 터를 잡고, 왼쪽위를 향해 갑시다.자신의 정보를 말하면 초기물품을 랜덤으로 주는것 같습니다. 그리고 작은 고기도 많이 줍니다. 어디서 난 고기인지는 이벤트를 보시면 아시겠지만..
 그 다음은 동쪽을 향해!! 그곳에 커다란 도시가 있습니다. 전기도 얻고, 물건도 살 수 있습니다.!!
 
초반에 등장하는 도그맨을 잡아서 라벨을 챙기시면 시티에 들어가는 패스를 쉽게 얻을 수 있습니다. 그렇지 않다면 시티에 들어가기 위해서 퀘스트를 해야합니다...간혹 왼쪽으로 진행하셔서 신비의 숲같은데서 시티패스를 얻으실수도 있습니다.하지만 이 패스는 영구추방당한 패스이므로 내다버리시길...한번 추방당한 패스로 인식당하면 뭔짓을 해도 시티에 못들어갑니다..

특정 지점들을 맵에서 찾는 재미가 있고 그 지점마다 이벤트와 스토리가 있습니다. 일단 주인공은 냉동상태에서 오랜만에 깨어난 상태라 자신이 누구인가에 대해 알기 위해 돌아다니는게 주 줄거리입니다.
깨어난 주인공은 목걸이 그리고 라벨에 써있는 자신의 이름정도가 전부인 상태..목걸이를 넘기라는 이벤트가 아래쪽 동굴에서 발생하는데, 넘기면 죽습니다.그건 보호부적이니까요.. 사신이 나타나요..지도 중간쯤에 있는 어떤 마을에서 목걸이를 살 수 있지만 그 전에는 넘기면 안됩니다. 

개인적으로 좀더 스토리추가나 DLC가 있으면 좋으련만요 ㅠ 할거 다해서 전 이제는 안합니다.. 하지만 무척 재밌는 게임입니다.지도 다밝히는걸 목적으로 게임을 해보세요.. ㅎㅎ주 줄거리는 내버려두고요..

19301558.review:
Extraordinarily difficult game. At no point has it ever become easy. You start with nothing, your choices literally mean an extended life until your next life threatening situation, a slow death because you effed up, a quick death because you effed up, or creating a neutral situation that still sets you back. 

Your goal is simple: Make it east to the city with lights. From there you basically get to trade for money and start to make a life. Apparently the game gets a little easier once you get there but I've never been there. I die before I get there.

That's the story of the game. You die.

19231963.review:
A friend of mine designs games and I wanted him to make a game where you were dropped into the desert and had to use what was around you to survive. He said he was too busy making aa tank game called shellshock skirmish, so im glad to have gotten round to finally purchasing neo scavenger. After being on my wishlist for a long time I picked it up on sale and its worth it and worth spending the time on. 

Using your brain to figure things out rather than being on a guided tour is a refreshing aspect not allowed in many games and theres plenty of small details and replayability to be had. Not a game for those who enjoy giving up as you will die many times, each time figuring things out more and more. On one of my plays through I had a good haul of equipment 7 days in and was progressing with the story (there is a story, you have to find it!) when I stupidly setup camp in a bad place and was murdered in my sleep, in another playthrough after just making it to the east coast i died from an infection from having drunk infected water on the trip!

All together this is worth your time and the turn based nature allowd you to relax and play alongside doing something else like checking your emails or cooking :)

19209861.review:
Musím se přiznat, že tohle jsem nečekal. Podle obrázků to vypadá jako ptákovinka. Posouváš se o políčka, čekáš na další tahy, taková ta hra pro ajťáky, řekneš si.
OBROVSKY jsem se mýlil. Možná to nemá nejúžasnější grafiku, ale po týhle hře mě čekalo vyšetření karpálního tunelu (nekecám), protože jsem u týhletý krásky strávil dlouhý večery. Nejhorší je, že tě zabije pokaždý něco jinýho. Pokaždý najdeš úplně jiný věci, který ti nějak pomůžou, nebo nepomůžou. Hra ti nevysvětlí nic, v podstatě všechno musíš nějak vymyslet sám.
Jakožto velkej fanda postapokalyptickýho světa mě bavilo objevovat a prozkoumávat okolí, bavil mě ten retro styl, jakým je hra udělána (ať už se to týká textovejch příběhů, způsobů boje, na kterej mi trvalo si zvyknout a vůbec přijít, jak funguje). Strašně mě bavilo, že hru můžu opakovat kolikrát chci a nikdy to neomrzí. NEO Scavenger jsem dostal jako součást bundlu, ale vědět, že mě to bude takhle bavit, určitě ji koupím.
Za mě 8/10.

Have you ever watched shows like Man vs Wild, Survivorman, Naked and Afriad (title is very similar to the early game, lol), and a host of other survival-based shows and thought, "I would like to know what that is like, but I don't want to die."

This is the answer.

There are many horrifing, diabolical, grusome ways you can expire which include, but not limited to:
-Starvation
-Hypothermia
-Sniped from 60 yards away by a UAV
-Sniped from 60 yards away by an angry canibal with a hunting rifle and a scope
-Blue Rot (like smallpox, but not)
-Cholera (*Painful flashbacks to Oregon Trail*)
-Gettind fried alive by an ADS (Area Denial System)
-Getting your intrails forceably removed by a Dogman
-Eating the wrong mushrooms
-Eating the right mushrooms, and drinking infected water
-Going to the house by the lake
-Taking off your Copper Talisman
-AND MANY MORE!!!!


In all seriousness, it may be a flash game, but it's better than the majority of Triple-A Games released in the past 2 years.

18958584.review:
Это пошаговый симулятор выживания в постапокалиптическом мире. Казалось бы, сколько их уже было, что тут можно придумать нового? Тем не менее, разработчикам это определённо удалось. Я пока наиграл не так уж много, но основные затягивающие моменты могу выделить.

Генерация персонажа незамысловата — выбираем скиллы на отпущенный бюджет очков, если хотим больше очков, придётся выбрать недостатки (близорукость, быстрый метаболизм, неуклюжесть и т.д.). Никаких поинтов ловкости, силы, интеллекта нет, только выбор из готовых умений. Это даёт некоторый реализм, ты либо умеешь что-то, либо нет. Скиллы применяются при крафте и в происшествиях/квестах (encounters), некоторые дают дополнительные возможности в бою.

Крафт оригинален: рецепты требуют лишь некоторое количество предметов и задают их характеристики, но не указывают на конкретные вещи. Например, для создания копья нужен «длинный жёсткий стержень» и «что-то острое», подойдёт большая палка и осколок стекла, но можно использовать и нож, тесак, топор или ещё что-то режущее. Для палатки нужны «куски плотного непромокаемого материала», «твёрдые стержни» и верёвки, опять же, под это могут подойти различные вещи. Для кипячения воды нужен источник тепла, негорючая ёмкость (подойдёт как банка из-под бобов, так и ковшик) и вода. У каждого предмета масса свойств, но они нигде не прописаны явно, так что надо применять здравый смысл, смекалку, а то и просто брутфорс, сваливая предметы в кучу и листая возможные результаты.

У самого персонажа также есть ряд нечисловых шкал типа голода, жажды, усталости, боли и т.п., при наличии скилла медика откроются ещё три специфичных параметра. Также, скилл медика позволяет определять назначение лекарств, а без него можно их кушать наудачу и надеяться, что повезёт.

Боёвка отличается массой возможных действий на каждом ходу. Можно прятаться в укрытие и передвигаться, не покидая его, можно бежать/идти/ползти к противнику или от него, перекатываться, заманивать в ловушку, кидаться мусором, добивать ногами, бросаться, сбивая с ног, бить головой в живот, а также использовать подручные предметы как оружие. Например, в ковше можно сварить чай, а можно взять его в руку и забить насмерть местных бандитов, равно как и в бутылку можно набрать воды, а можно разбить её об голову дикого пса. Ко многим вещам можно прикрутить ремешок и повесить на плечо или на шею, что неплохо освобождает инвентарь. Не всегда в бою виден противник, так что порой лучше незаметно покинуть поле боя и переждать, либо устроить засаду.

Левелапов и прочих условностей нет, крутизна персонажа целиком определяется экипировкой и самочувствием, о котором лучше всего судить по списку текущих эффектов, но т.к. классические хитпоинты тоже отсутствуют, надо быть всегда настороже. Умереть можно от различных причин: переохлаждение, отравление, болезнь, внутреннее кровотечение, пролом головы, что угодно. Как в бою, так и вне его. А умирать тут придётся часто, и лучше трезво оценивать свои возможности, прежде чем ввязываться в драку. Даже если ты без труда разбираешь одного бродягу с ломом, умереть от двух одновременно напавших собак проще простого.

Об инвентаре. Здесь нет большого невидимого мешка для найденного, в начале есть лишь две руки, поэтому одной из ценностей становятся пакеты, рюкзаки и т.п. Также, можно найти одежду с карманами или большую тележку, которая, впрочем, замедляет движение (осторожно, мелкие предметы проваливаются сквозь её ячейки!). В одежде, к слову, для большинства предметов обуви есть разница между правым и левым ботинком, если их надеть неправильно, ходить будет некомфортно, появятся мозоли со всеми вытекающими последствиями. Вплоть до того, что при очередном обыскивании дома вероятность быть погребённым под завалом окажется слишком высока.

Ещё есть лагерь, который стоит оборудовать спальником, гремящими ловушками, чтобы слышать приближение врагов, а иногда и костром (спать при горящем огне не рекомендуется — слишком высока заметность, придут, ограбят, а то и убьют). Лагерное место можно выбрать на любой клетке, но некоторые более предпочтительны, а другие опасны.

Ну и самое вкусное, у игры есть бесплатное демо, которое показывает основы. На самом деле, это довольно ранняя версия с плохим балансом (в полной версии крутые ребята с винтовками появляются очень не сразу, а тут буквально кишат), но понять из неё, нравится такое или нет, вполне можно.

Про минусы — в комментарии!

18920988.review:
A hardcore survivalist game. By hardcore, I'm talking perma death, just about everything can kill you easily, and you're kind of lady luck's bitch in regards to how well you can do sometimes. That said, this is a great game. It's a thinking man's title, borderline unfair (I mean that in a begrudging good way),  and it will take you a long time to really master the concept of it. Coupled with a gigantic procedurally generated world and you'll find yourself playing a new set of variables each time, particularly as you can pick a handful of your starting skills before stepping into the frying pan that is NEO Scavenger.

Story-wise, it's kind of an end of the world scenario, except more dealing with mutants, mad men, and bandits, rather than zombies. The plot is kind of backseated to the gameplay, however. I found almost all the NPCs to be universally hostile or locked into a constant fight/flight mentality. Don't expect dialogue or too much revealing information- your character wakes up as a corpsicle in a cryo vat and you're basically thrust into an unknown landscape. You have to gather what you need to survive and you need to do it FAST. Freezing to death is very easy and this game does not hold a newcomer's hand whatsoever. You will be hunted, attacked remorselessly, robbed, and yes, you can literally be killed in one round by the wrong person if you're unlucky. As such, this is about SURVIVAL. Not racking up xp and going nuts with a pea shooter.

While I like NEO Scavenger, there's some things that are a needless hassle about the gameplay. The interface is extremely clunky for your items, the crafting system is a bit vague (I have a sharp edge like the recipe says... I can't harvest this dog because...?), and the biggest issue to me, is the game saves via Flash cookies, not on Steam.

Imagine my disgust when I kept finding my save games erased after every play session. Hours and hours, gone. So I checked my Flash and found I had it enabled to allow cookies to be saved. So something else was deleting them. According to the developers, it could be one's antivirus or any of a number of things. With all due respect, I don't really care to go searching every minute infrastructural maintenance program I have to find out which program is deleting the cookies beyond Flash and what might need an exclusion to NEO- this should have been saved in the Steam Cloud or however many other games here do it without issue. I really REALLY wish the developers would have done something about this instead forcing the player to find a meta solution. Unfortunately, from what I've read, they're not really doing anymore updates and the game is considered completed. :/ Which is a shame, because I loved everything else about this.

I would heartily recommend NEO but the issue with saves is not something I can overlook after finding this out several hours in. If the developers would or could somehow make the game save within Steam and not through cookies, I will happily change this to a Recommendation. As of now, I reluctantly can't do that.

 По игре..  никаких сейвов, только хардкор! Каждый раз разное начало - вот вроде бы пошло, обзавёлся неплохим оружием, одеждой, еда вро де бы есть.. но зараза, нигде нет лекарств что бы поддержать имунную систему.. здоровье летит вниз ничего не поделать - конец!
 И вот взяли медицину, нашли аптечку с кучей лекарств, монтировку, на дворе холод собачий, и блин не одной собаки или тужурки в развалинах - бежим, но бег не помогает, всё холоднее и холоднее... замёрз - конец!
 Берём крепость организма, медицину, ближний бой - валим почти всех сходу, лут вроде не плохой, но чего-то не хватает, лазим по развалинам, получаем травму, перевязываемся чем есть.. идём дальше не скрываясь,. и вдруг стая собак разрывает нас на части - конец!

Это почти как шахматы, можно каждый раз начинать играть сначала и получать море кайфа - конечно если вы любитель небольшого садомазо))  Графика здесь не нужна, а вернее она такая, какая и  должна быть, остальное дофантазирует мозг. 
С опытом множества неудач придёт умение выживать в столь суровом мире, однако это не всегда спасает.

Очень рекомендую всем любителям олд-скулл рпг и хардкор режима, который раньше был очень популярен и вносил особый цимус в восприятие игрового процесса.

И да, я тоже играл в эту игру с торрентов вначале, но - автор вполне заслуживает награду за это творение, не поскупитесь - купите!  Тем более скоро энтузиасты полностью её переведут и можно будет более комфортно играть, если с английским не очень.

Спасибо за внимание!

18717891.review: I wanted to like this game. I really did. I'm a fan of roguelikes, but this game tried to be both roguelike and linear at the same time. You start in the same place every time, and while that wouldn't be an issue, it's always the same scenario. That's the issue I have - I don't play a roguelike to do the same tired story missions over and over. It has some pretty unique elements to it, but the things that aren't good really ruin the game for me. In most roguelikes, I accept the sense of permadeath and the inevitability of some unfair losses, but this game takes it to another level, stranding you with little to no resources and then giving you a disease that can only be survived through either extreme luck with the RNG or a very specific item. It'd be different if it was avoidable, but you can contract it simply by getting close to the enemies that carry it - and a nearly unavoidable game-ending feature like that doesn't make for a good roguelike.

18378417.review:
Neo Scavenger is a fantastic indie turn-based, survival, strategy, roguelike game played on a hex map. 

The game is very punishing and largely based apon RNG but also requires a lot of pre-planning strategy and skill to complete. Every playthrough randomizes many locations in the game and enemy spawns, allowing the game to be very replay-able. The learning curve may be steep at first but once you have the basic mechanics down it's just a matter of playing it safe, but the game can be very deep with a great skill system opening up many different ways of surviving the post apocolyptic wasteland. 

[h1]Pro's :[/h1] 
+ Fantastic survival mechanics ranging from your usual hunger/thirst to illness , fatigue and comfort.
+ Challenging turn based battle system based around your skills and condition. 
+ A large variaty of items.
+ Randomised loot, enemy and location spawns on every playthrough making it very fresh.
+ A good story with lots of hidden treasures and ways to complete.
+ Great stealth mechanics.
+ A hidden reputation system.

[h1]Cons :[/h1]
- The RNG can be absolutely infuriating sometimes, but that's the way of the roguelike.
- There are very limited animations, the game is mostly text based.
- At first the game is not very user friendly and the UI may be difficult to navigate. ( particularly campsites )
- Extremely difficult to complete on your first few runs, requiring you to playthrough once or twice to learn which options to avoid.
- Limited options for character creation.
- Very limited building options for shelter / bases.

All-in i would deffinitely recommend this game if you are into hardcore roguelikes, there is a lot of depth beneath the surface and the randomization and character skill system brings a variety of ways to play the game. If however, you are looking for an easy survival game to build up your own haven and sit back surviving the nights i would stay clear as NEO Scavenger can be very punishing at the worst of times.

17786880.review:
This is an awesome hex-based/turn-based post-apoc rpg that I added somewhat casually to my wishlist and found myself thoroughly hooked on once I played it. 

The game is VERY reminscent, genre aside, of Darklands, in that you have several text roleplay adventures that can be encountered either randomly or in permanent places whilst roaming a decently-sized over map (I actually wanna play that too now!). You can also encounter enemies (and you'll sure as hell encounter them), gather in forests, loot in buildings, and just overall scavenge your way to your next safe haven... or unknown!

The game is very fun and fufils that thrill/gamble factor with almost every action you take, as it is very luck-based with a few ways to bend it in your favor. It can be a little aggrivating on occasion (what game isn't?), but once you master what to look out for and keep in the early stages of the game, it seems pretty much clear sailing. Contrary to some of the frustrated negative reviews regarding permadeath, there is only a handful of situations where a player will die outside of usual combat, and most can be avoided by using your head and your wits. (spoiler example: [spoiler] choosing to label yourself "stock" at a warehouse club which clears caters for some sort of human trafficking, i mean really :P [/spoiler] )

All-in-all I would recommend this game to anyone who is comfortable with the genre tags; this gaming style is considered fairly dated by today's standards but it absolutely holds up, well and truly making up for it in storyline and gritty mortal desperation!

17772752.review: Deep and unforgiving. Replayable to infinity,  Only complaint is that it ends too soon.

17732999.review:
This game is brutal. It is unkind and unforgiving and sometimes it is straight up mean. Sometimes whatever God is left in the NEO Scavenger world decides that you looked at him funny, and so he introduces you to pain and anguish and misery. But in the event that God does not doom you to such a fate, you will find in this world amazing potential and unique adventures.

You will learn what fear is. Fear will guide you away from conflict. Away from that man, from those dogs, from that Dogman. You fancy yourself a proud fighter? Proud men die. Fear will keep you on your toes, will check any scrape and cut meticulously, will get you home by nightfall. 

You will learn what hunger is. You'll find yourself starving, losing energy, panicking. Maybe you'll trap a squirrel for a snack. Or beat a feral dog to death for some real meat. Maybe you'll take a step back and wonder how things got this way - huddled in some burnt out building, greedily eating packets of ketchup and saltines, washing them down with questionable river water. You might even find yourself in an unthinkable situation. You might manage to hold your own against a bandit. He came upon you while you were sleeping and tried to loot your camp. You woke, and he punched your head in a panic. You stand and brandish a crowbar. He turns to run, but he trips. You seize the opportunity. You strike. Again and again. Soon his blood rushes from his crushed head. And only then do you realize how hungry you are.

tl;dr buy it.

17715633.review:
NEO Scavenger is a very different game. I haven't played many like it, and certainly not any that I have enjoyed as much. It's a complicatedly simple game. It nearly masters survival against the elements, finding and cleaning water to drink, gathering plants for food or beating a deer to death with your bare hands for food.

It's style will put a lot of people off. It is a text game at it's descriptive and story core, something I am absolutely fine with, coupled with a hex based pixelated landscape. The controls are entirely mouse based or a combination of mouse and keyboard, and while it can seem strange and complex at first, a few playthroughs and you'll master them.

Another thing that will put people off is it's genre. It is that, no common, "rouge-like." When you die, you're kaput for good, and you start another play through. I liken it to Faster Than Light, in that aspect. Not just for it's art style and rouge-likeness, but for how you can upgrade your character, or ship/crew in FTL, and progress in the story only to die horrbily.

One great thing about NEO Scavenger is it's story. What is its story? I can tell you that you play as Philip Kindred who, after some odd years of cryo-stasis, wakes up in a world vastly different from what used to be. Kindred doesn't know that, of course, since he's conviently lost his memory. That's what you learn at the start, and that's where the story can end for you.

You can spend all of your time in NEO Scavenger simply getting better loot and surviving for as long as possible. The only way to advance the story is to seek it out activly. On the surface, it's a great survival rouge-like, but under the surface lies a vast and complex story filled with multiple branches, characters, challenges, and intrigue. There is an ending to the game. I didn't even know there was one, and I've been playing since early access. Honestly, I die or screw up before I make it far in the story.

The storytelling is all driven by you. You see a strange glow at night, follow it for a few days, and suddenly you find yourself surounded by life at the Detriot Mega City. What is this strange DMC? Ask some people, read some newpaper scraps you find while scavenging. Or don't. Go somewhere else, advance the story in a different way. I've found three ways you can "start" the story, and all of them require you to think and act proactivly.

The enemies and lore behind them is also great. I won't spoil what they are, but this game is supposed to be a realistic survival sim-like thing while also having deep roots in the supernatural. If you wonder to yourself," Oh my god, what the hell is that creature from the bowels of my worst nightmares," then google it and you'll likely find an real urban legend from Michigan that the enemy was based on.

NEO Scavenger is one of the best games in existence, in my opinion. Unlike a lot of other games, it has a demo! If you're on the fence, play the demo. If you think you like it, buy it without a doubt and get into it. I don't rate games, but for the sake of this review, I give it a 9.5/10. Why a 9.5, you ask. Because I'm super biased about this game, but I admit it's not perfect. 

So go play the demo, fall in love, and buy this game. Throw yourself full heartedly into the world and lore that surrounds NEO Scavenger. Explore the DMC, find awesome old-world loot, investigate strange amusement parks, derilect cities, and even face otherworldly horrors in the pursuit of Philip Kindred's epic story.

Or don't. It's up to you, but be warned: you'll likely freeze do death anyway. Seriously, Michigan is cold and it rains a lot. I'm talking ALL the time. Fuck rain.

Oh, and go ahead, take off that talisman. Seriously, it's no big deal.

Just don't lose it. Ever.
