17482824.review:
Am Anfang frustrierend aber mit den richtig gewählten Skills kann man doch lange über die Runden kommen.

Vor dem eigentlichen Spiel gibt es zunächst mal eine Auswahl von speziellen Skills die man auswählen kann um den Charakter zu verbessern (Beispielsweise verbessertes Wissen über z.B. Flora und Fauna oder auch Medizin, Nahkampf, Fernkampf usw) man hat 15 Punkte zur verfügung und kann dafür entsprechende Skills auswählen die alle unterschiedliche "kosten" haben. Man kann auch "Negative" (z.B. weniger Weitsicht, schneller Krank etc.)  Effekte wählen um über mehr als 15 Punkte für "Gute" Skills zu verfügen.

Danach beginnt das Spiel indem man aus einer Cryokapsel auf den Boden klatscht und man direkt auf eine nahende "Gefahr" trifft.

Je nach Auswahl der Skills gibt es jetzt bereits verschiedene "Lösungswege" um der Gefahr zu entkommen. Solche  Situationen sind allesamt Textbasiert und je nach Auswahl Positiv oder auch Negativ. 

Wenn die Gefahr gebannt ist beginnt nun das "richtige" Survival Erlebnis, mit nichts anderem bekleidet als einem Kittel und einer Armbinde mit Namen befindet man sich nun auf der Hauptmap und man hat verschiedene Leisten die den Zustand des Charakters anzeigen.

Man kann nun mehrere "Züge" machen um sich fortzubewegen die Anzahl ändert sich ja nachdem ob man schweres Gepäck trägt, man Schuhe an oder auch einen passenden Skill ausgewählt hat.

Man sollte sich also zunächst darauf konzentrieren kleine Städte, Dörfer etc. zu finden und dort die Häuser nach den verschiedensten Dingen abzusuchen. Je nach Skill und Austattung findet Ihr mal mehr und mal weniger Items Auch Skills sind davon abhänging.

Man findet zum Beispiel mehr Material wenn man mit einem Brecheisen, einem Feuerzeug oder dem Skill "Stark" nach Material sucht, lauft aber unterdessen Gefahr euch einfacher zu verletzen oder durch zu großen Lärm Feinde "anzulocken"

Gefundenes Material kann dann zu Waffen oder anderen Sachen hergestellt werden aber das verbraucht auch "Züge" wodurch Ihr euch dann weniger bewegen oder direkt rasten müsst.

Man irrt also zünächst komplett orientierungslos durch die Hauptmap dies ändert sich aber bereits wenn die Nacht anbricht oder man eine Karte findet denn dann "bekommt" man das erste wichtige Ziel (Mehr verrate ich nicht das könnt Ihr selbst herausfinden :P )

Währenddessen befinden sich allerlei gefahren auf der Map die nur darauf warten euch dahinzuraffen, denn Ihr könnt wenn ihr nicht aufpasst an so ziemlich allem sterben das es gibt. 

Vergiftungen, Blutverlust, starke Verletzungen, Monster, Fallen, andere Überlebende, Seuchen, Erfrierung und allerlei Erkrankungen und mehr warten auf euch.

Verletzungen werden mit Bandagen behandelt sollte man diese aber nicht vorher reinigen sprich abkochen dann lauft Ihr Gefahr euch eine Blutvergiftung zu holen und im späteren verlauf daran zu sterben falls Ihr keine Bluttransfusion bekommt.

Ähnlich verhält es sich mit Wasser welches Ihr in Bächen, Seen oder Flaschen findet. diese können Bakterienverseucht sein und müssen abgekocht werden um nicht an einer Bakterienvergiftung zu sterben.

Viele sachen können auch kaputt gehen wenn Sie zu oft benutzt werden da diese sich bei jeder Aktion abnutzen.

Auch Waffen können und sollten auch gefunden oder gebaut werden. Praktisch alles kann als Waffe verwendet werden von Steinen oder Ästen über kaputte Flaschen bis hin zu Schleudern, Taschenmessern oder Scharfschützengewehren ist alles dabei.

Ihr merkt schon das ganze wird relativ komplex und ich will auch garnicht weiter darauf eingehen das könnt Ihr selber rausfinden^^.


Wenn man über die "Grafik" hinwegsehen kann (da es einfach zu einem großen Teil ein Textadventure ist),
bekommt man dafür ein Top Survivalerlebnis welches Ich euch nur wärmstens empfehlen kann.

Kauft es euch wenn ihr auf diese Art Game oder auch auf Survivalgames im allgemeinen steht denn es ist einfach ein Top Game in dem Genre.

17479363.review:
NEO Scavenger was on my wishlist for a long time, $15 seemed steep for a graphics/text game, let alone a rogue-like. Well, I got drunk one night and impulsively hit 'buy'. So now I have it, and I like it enough to give a review, which I don't usually do.

NEO is brutal. This isn't the type of game where you play the ultra-altruistic "Hero" that saves everybody and looks good doing it. You'll live a lot longer if you take the attitude of "desperate homeless guy that doesn't want to get involved in your shit". 

When you die, it's over. No going back to a previous save. You just start over from scratch.

The learning curve is a little bit steep, but so rewarding once you get there. My first several hours I went through at least half a dozen deaths. I learned to avoid fights. To clean my wounds before bandaging them. I learned to not ever eat yellow berries. I rage quit twice. I came back twice.

Now, I've got a rifle (with ELEVEN bullets!), a warm coat and enough clean water to last me a week. I'm unstoppable, king of all there is in this wasteland. 

Except that I'm not. I still run away from everything that moves, I only camp in secluded buildings, diligently cover my tracks behind me and always keep an eye over my shoulder.

And that's how it should be. I survived for this long because I learned how to live in the wasteland. I didn't get a bunch of XP from slaughtering hundreds of enemies and then suddenly become immune to a bullet to the brainpan.

That's what I love about this game. The "XP" is your own damn brain. Learning how to craft the things you need. How to avoid those looters in the distance. Knowing that I've gotten as far as I have by not making mistakes. 

NEO has an outrageous amount of complexity that you would never know exists until you go looking for it. If you're on the fence, just buy it. Well worth the money spent.

One last tip: If you're new, take botany. Makes the game a little more forgiving since you won't really have to worry about food & drink.

17377187.review:
I revisit this game once in a while because I've yet to find anything like it. It's a turn-based post apocalyptic survival game with elements of sci-fi and fantasy. My favorite thing about this game is probably that the inventory system attempts to be realistic, which I find to be annoyingly rare in video games.

Criticisms?

I really like that there is permadeath, though I think I would enjoy the game more if I felt it was possible for a skilled gamer to beat it on their first try. There are important details I've only been able to learn by dying or visiting the wikia, and I feel that takes away from the immersion. I've yet to beat it despite around 20 attempts.

Why not have learned recipes carry over to future games?

I'd prefer more of the information found on the wikia to be displayed in game, such as item component properties and weapon damage/range.

Even the wikia doesn't have important details such as the degree to which things are affected by stat bars.

I've forgotten or otherwise left out other issues that frustrated me about this game at first, but I don't regret buying it. For new players I recommend the first attempt be done without the wikia, and the expectation to survive. After that you may find that use of the wikia adds a considerable amount of replayability.

17123749.review:
An amazing rogue-like that blends modern post-apocalyptic modern societal downfall with urban legend and the occult for a very unique setting.  While the game is not without its flaws, I still think it was very worth playing.

The problem with a review like this is that it is hard to recommend the game without exposing story or gameplay elements that are in a lot of ways crucial to the game experience.  As with many roguelikes, game knowledge is crucial to success.  Unlike many, NEO is on of the few roguelikes that uses fixed story and locations and events.  The random elements come in the form of items found from looting and NPC encounters.  The game does not require any combat to complete it, and much of the items lack the progression and semi-uniqueness found in fantasy roguelikes.  There are shotguns, but no +3 shotguns of ammo conservation.  Skills are chosen at the start of the game and do not improve, and you cannot level up.  Thus a large part of the experience is in exploring the unknown of the map, the story, and the game's mechanics rather than the depth of its progression mechanics.  This is both a unique appeal of the game and a flaw.  It fits the setting and feel of the game with the player as a normal person and lends to a stronger story, but further playthroughs are not so meaningful when you know where to go on the unrandomized map and what dialogue options to choose and what items to craft.  If you want a Binding of Isaac, Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup, or Tales of Maj'eyal, this is not the same game.

The story and setting deserve a special mention before I talk about the gameplay.  The content that is there is a good amount of content that allows for diverse approach, good for someone exploring the game for the first time.  However, by the end my feeling was there wasn't nearly enough of it.  The game map is large but a certain portion of the map is lacking in almost any of the game's unique elements.  While the game does indicate the location of a major world feature near the beginning, by chance a new player could decide to explore in the wrong cardinal direction and end up wandering around finding nothing but RNG encounters and generic locales for many many hours.   There are a few locales given extra detail in presentation but with no story attached to them nor reason to revisit, and given the fixed nature of the game's events at this locations it would have been nice for the developers to make more of them.  These and some various 'random' events are presented in a Choose Your Own Adventure book style with events presented in text with a few choices for action.  The fixed events are well written and choices can be very meaningful, but in the random events the choices dont reflect outcomes very well or nearly at all thus making those outcomes feel mostly arbitrary.  Compared to how good the fixed locale events are [spoiler]House at Seven Gables I'm looking at you[/spoiler], the random ones feel like low-effort filler at best and an excuse to abuse the player character at worst when things turn out badly for no good reason.

Additionally, it is bizarre to me that while the game is a permadeath one it doesn't delete your save after giving you a you a time-limited info dump at the end of the game.  When game knowledge is so crucial to the experience and the story, why freely let the player reload the game at his last save and ask different questions at the info dump?  I'm not against the info dump in principle, its just strange.  This ties into my discussion of game mechanics next as it is important to note here that once you finish the game it becomes apparent that the main thing preventing the player from progressing to the end of the game and rolling the credits is just not knowing where the location for that event is the first time they play.  As I said before, game knowledge and first time experiences are the meat of the game here.

Mechanics wise, the game is very solid when it comes to combat and health as well as how it treats item management.  Its a nice unique spin that doesn't just use HP and stat points like most, has some good surprises, and gives the player plenty of incentive to pick any of the skills at character creation.  Hunger, sleep, and weather are important more than just their immediate lethality from running out and triggering a game over.  Combat has a great mix of options and interactions as you play out whether you attack or wait for a good moment, or space yourself and try to run.  The only real disappointment I had with the game's item selection is that there wasn't MORE to pick from!  I wanted more cool things to find from poking around city ruins and by the time you finish the game you will very likely see every item the game has to offer with no +3 shotguns to spice up the mix.  Item crafting is slightly clunky but useful, but again only game knowledge prevents you from crafting one of the best melee weapons in the game two minutes in.  The game even has diseases but [spoiler] it is practically inevitable that during the normal course of the game the player character will become infected with a disease that for any non-wiki spoiled player will be almost unavoidably lethal[/spoiler], which makes for a very odd check of the player's skill.  

Lastly, the permadeath nature of the game is a strong contributor to the feeling of being a very mortal normal person that the game tries to present.  I clocked in 46 hours into the game, most of it in a fairly exploratory playthough where I spend a fairly good amount of time hording supplies and  preparing for unknowns with caution.   This felt appropriate, and I still died quite a few times despite my preparation.  I engaged in a fairly modest amount of savescumming for this one playthrough. and it is only apparent afterwards that the preparation wasn't so necessary and that the unique locales and events therein are not required to finish the game.  Again, the wonder of the game is in your first time experiencing what it has to offer.  Either I was supposed to learn to be more YOLO and careless and suicide rush to find new unexplored content, or I was expected to make an even larger time sink than I did from my cautious play.  46 hours is a lot, so seeing a sort of soft-death (such as saving only every 3 in game days or the like) might have been nicer than permadeath or savescumming.

All in all, I loved the game's mechanics and the genuinely emotion invoking experiences it provided.  Absolutely worth the full $15 in my mind.  I would highly reccomend it to those wanting a story and setting focused roguelike, less so to those not experienced with the genre.  If you play, don't feel too bad if you have to savescum a bit.

16871604.review:
Pretty much everything there is to say about this game has been said, though I'd like to throw in my two cents as well as address a couple issues I've seen people comment on in some of the reviews. First of all, the game is out of Early Access and is feature complete(to my knowledge), and does have an end-game scenario. It's just not that easy to do. 195 hours in the game and I have yet to "beat" it. Ususally for me the story comes second to the survival gameplay. The story is unique and interesting from what I've uncovered(and read about), though some things can take a long time to complete, and usually I'll die before I come close to completing my objective.

This brings me to my second point. The game is hard, yes, but it's not as impossible as some people make it out to be. Jumping right in to the game with no prior knowledge, like I did, will be tough. You'll die quite often until you start to make some sense of the mechanics and gameplay. You will also get unlucky at times and be woken from a dead sleep by a creature which can mess you up bad. But, like I said, it's not impossible. You just need to try new skill combinations and ways of going through the world. Taking the strong/tough perks will allow you to wreck NPCs that you come across, but when you're faced with a life or death story scenario, you may not be as well equipped to deal with dangers as you may have thought. At the time of writing this, I've been playing a no-combat-skills build. I've taken Hacking, Medic, Botany, Lockpicking, Eagle Eye, Tracking, Athletic and Electrician, along with Fragile and Insomniac for the extra points. I've been playing this character for three or four real life days now, and I've gone through at least thirty in-game days. Without dying. 

Playing like this forces you to reconsider everything you've been doing. Before, I'd walk right up to that feral dog and turn it in to a pin cushion with my bow. Now though, I'm fragile and unskilled at any combat. All I have for protection is a war club, which, in my hands, is about as deadly as a shoe. If I even see a feral dog, I'm headed in a new direction. I've also found out that running away [i] is fucking useful! [/i]. I may not be able to kill that guy and eat his body, but I'm alive for another day. And I didn't even need his man meat. I've got the botany skill and can just forage around some forests and fill up on berries. In this current game, I've also not used any noise traps when I sleep, because I don't have the room. I get burdened easy, and only carry a couple small backpacks. Still, I have yet to die. 

You just need to think a little before commiting to an action. Before I try to get some rest, I hide and wait for a few turns to see if anyone's in the area. If no one has wandered into my camp, I sleep. And since I have insomnia, I usually wake up before anything gets too close to me. I know there's a terrible and unfortunate death waiting for me in the future, but until then I'll keep scouring this wasteland, looking for the RFID spoofing software I need in order to advance a story encounter I have yet to complete.

This game isn't for everyone, but for me, it's definitely in my top 5. It's easy enough to pick up and play for 30 minutes of down time, or I can spend hours in the game, completely immersed and elated when I find a text file worth nearly $2000 in a laptop that's been sitting in a building for years, and which would have been useless to me were it not for the hacking trait. 

If you're undecided, just play the demo or watch some videos. There's quite a bit of content missing from the demo, but you'll get the gist of things and be able to make a more informed decision on whether or not this is your type of game. To anyone buying this game, I sincerely hope you like it, as it's like no other game I've played before, and absolutely one of my favorites. Thanks for the amazing game Daniel, and I am looking forward to your next endeavor.

16817601.review:
Despite its aged graphics and less than perfect UI this is a real gem of a post apocalyptic survival game. It can be truly unforgiving, but that to me was one of the things that drew me into the world of NEO Scavenger. The survival aspect is a lot more engaging to me than most other survival type games I've played, and you quickly learn to pick your battles very carefully. Just like in reality, a single wound can end up killing you if you're careless and don't have access to modern medicine, and nature itself can be equally lethal. This is something I've found to be missing from most other survival games. 


The story is fairly interesting as well, but some of the choice based encounters are a bit harsh. And losing a character that survived for a long time in one of those is rarely fun. Still, the game kept drawing me back in until I had beaten it, and I'm looking forward to what the developer has in store for us next.

If you want a challenge, love the roguelike aspect of dead is dead in a post apocalyptic setting and can look past the graphics then you can't really go wrong with this game.

16800834.review:
Probably one of the best if not best survival games I've ever played.
I played the demo for a few months on Blue Bottle Games site and I fell in love with it, I spent hours playing, crafting, getting as far as I could then starting all over again. Finally I begged my Mom for 10$ and purchased the full game. I play on my Macbook Pro and I am not dissapointed with the full version at all.

PROS:

- Randomly generated map with each new game (different potential situations and outcomes)
- Charming and beautiful graphics and sountrack
- Indepth and intruging storyline, very well written and executed
- Skills, crafting and survival elements are realistic and very satisfying for survival fans
- Easy interface/controls
- Hours of gameplay with hundreds of random encounters from enemies and items to find

CONS:

- Can't save a long running game and later continue it which sucks because I would really like to progress further in the story instead of dying repeatedly and needing to start over

OVERALL: 7/10

초반에는 오히려 사람들을 피해 다녀야 하는 상황이 많이 발생하고 나중에 어느 정도 파밍이 된 후 인간 백정도 가능하지만 굳이 그렇게 하지 않아도 진행에 큰 지장은 없다

이런류 게임에 흔히 있는 도덕성 관련 파라메터가 없는게 개인적으로는 속시원함

I am OBSESSED with this game right now. I definitely recommend it. The graphics aren't great, but I think the game makes up for it in content.

16633382.review:
a fantastic and thoroughly challenging adventure game/exploration RPG hybrid unlike any one thing you'll've experienced before. NEO Scavenger's mechanics are constantly intriguing, but more than anything, it shines with the world it presents and the judicious exposition thereof. while it certainly fits in the post-apocalyptic genre, it's a stranger catastrophe that's befallen this world than the usual nuclear or ecological disasters we see; the rules of the universe seem to be in drift. setting is dripped out in tantalizing paragraphs fished up out of scraps of newspapers from before and during whatever disaster it was that set things askew. the frustrations of a challenging narrative roguelike make things that much more intense: unlike a Stone Soup or a Binding of Isaac that can more or less be set aside at any point, NEO Scavenger demands the exploration of its mysteries, keeping the player coming back in the face of annihilation because of the raw power of the strangeness of the world that it depicts.

highly recommended.

16583661.review:
If you like Fallout and you like survival games, Neo Scavenger is the game for you. It's one of the best RPGs I've played in a long time, with tons of exploration, meaningful choices with actual consequences, and tons of different ways to approach any problem. Most challenges are easily overcome if you're prepared, but the same challenges can still easily kill you if you rush in, and in most cases you only get one chance. Enemy threats are easily distinguishable on the world map, with all NPCs shown wearing the equipment they're carrying, which lets you guess at their faction, disposition, and danger level. Also, you get to kick a dogman's ass with your bare hands.

Pros:
- Exploration
- Meaningful consequences to choices
- Lots of interactions and events
- Great art
- Traits used often and in useful ways

Cons:
- Somewhat limited variety crafting system
- Crafting slows down noticeably when carrying lots of items, and may break sometimes
- You -will- spend a lot of time playing inventory tetris
- Be warned, this is a permadeath game (for those who this is a con)

16568623.review:
InB4 Noob.

There's games, and then there's exercises in sadism.

This is an exercise in sadism.

The concept isn't bad, to be honest; and I don't mind the whole permadeath thing; but the difficulty curve is just above and beyond ridiculous. You can, and -usually will- die just from wandering around, because apparently your character is some sort of lizard who can't stand temperate climates. 

This is just one of the many flaws; but the most glaring. This game punishes new players hard. It's very, very difficult to get into. I've yet to survive a single day game time. Unless you're willing to die hundreds of times, just to get to a reasonable point, you're better off not bothering.

Immensely frustrating, seldom rewarding. And even then, you're going to die and lose all your cool stuff, so why even bother?

TL:DR.
If you're the sort of person who likes post apocalyptia; and enjoys inserting thumbtacks into their perineum; this is your game. 

If you enjoy post apocalyptia, but are sane, and don't feel like starting the same game ninety times just to get anywhere; look elsewhere for games.

Definitely not recommended.

16452479.review:
“How long can you survive the post-apocalyptic wastelands of NEO Scavenger?” Asks the developer.

To be more precise, It’s a game that will make you cherish plastic bags more than anything else.
At one time I did carry three plastic bags at once: One in each hand and one put on the shoulder. Inside these an assortment of the finest junk ever seen by man: Empty bottles, cigarette lighter, a t-shirt, twigs, a sauce pan and even more crumpled plastic bags, in case the current ones rip apart. Let me tell you, plastic bags are the superior container for almost anything you might want to carry at some point in the post-apocalypse.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_2K3mihtzrA

Oh and don’t drink unboiled water – I did and it was a mistake. A few days later while trying to sneak up to a sleeping stranger at night (To rob him, obviously; I needed a pair of new shoes), I got diarrhea. Uncontrollable stomach cramps made me fall down and curl up into a ball. The moaning woke up the stranger who’s been in a very bad mood. I started to bleed from my nose – probably from a virus like cholera I’ve ingested by drinking the water from a pond days earlier. I was indeed particularly thirsty the last few days.
The stranger sprinted towards me and a few moments later, without asking questions, he clubbed me to death with the butt of his rifle – not because of my pain, but to conserve ammo. I think it was for the best, I would have died from internal bleeding anyway. My life was over before I even knew it.

The interesting part here is that all of this did not feel “unfair”; I made a mistake hours before (drinking contaminated water) and could have prevented it (by boiling the water). Even after the fact, the symptoms of dehydration gave an indication that something was wrong: I could have ingested medicine immediately, but I didn’t.

It’s great that games like this are made.

16278862.review:
NEO Scavenger is a really intense survival game. You can make a character based off of different skills and survival tactics. Depending on what you chose, your experience with the game will change. If you take Medical Knowledge, you can tend your wounds faster, or if you take Melee, you will be able to fight better. 

It's a very brutal and unforgiving game. If you mess up, it could cost you your life. Perma-death is a thing so you really want to be careful.  The descriptions of what you do in combat is very descriptive and really helps with immersion.

Pros:
- It's very fun
- Rewarding if you come across some good gear
- Very realistic in the mechanics

Cons:
- no animations or visuals during combat
- Purely text based (could be a good thing if you like that, I do)
- near impossible on your first few lives.
- UI takes some time to get used to

Over all, it's a very brutal, but fun survival game, and I am really glad that I got it. If you enjoy wilderness survival games, this one will not dissapoint you.

16196028.review:
First of all: if you paid $15 for this game, you've underpaid. Sunk more than 90 hours in this game (online and offline) and I STILL can't see half of the content and this is just vanilla. I made the mistake of adding a mod to this game and holy crap...still can't see past 10% of the content without either dying, getting completely wrapped up in a spawn and exploration run and enjoy the hell out of simply trying to LIVE long enough!

NEO Scavenger's one of those games that no matter how much you die, live, fail, respawn, mix your talents up and roll again...you want to play some more. I've clocked almost 20 hours in the DEMO alone and when I bought the game, I bought copies for friends and sat many a night down in Teamspeak and we've compared survival times and setups and this game suceeds in making you declare "One...more...game..."

I turned this into a serious review just because I've joined the forums, added input and done a bit of bug submission as well and even the community is together despite it being a lone-dev game.

PROS:
-A very good "One more game..." setup.
-A lot of the in-game recipes are common sense based. Combine...and see what happens.
-The turn-based battle system with different movesets depending on your talents is functional and efficent. That feeling of satisfaction when you stab a feral dog to death with a wooden spear crafted by your own hands and sharpened with a glass shard.
-The storyline so far is intriguing and you get this sense of "Where am I? Who am I? What is going on?" constantly.
-Because of the game's setting and environment, finding so much as a shopping bag to hold your stuff feels like the greatest success. You'll know what I mean when you play.
-The idea of drinking water straight from a pond is hazardous at best.
-Eat berries, dog flesh, human flesh, cooked food, soup, scavenged snack cakes. The world is your buffet table!
-Josh Culler's submissions for the soundtrack of this game are short...but VERY, VERY suitable. 

CONS:
-The game is programmed for Flash. Depending on your PC and stats and some measure of bad luck-you ARE going to get some frustrate-level crashes. Save often and make sure the game doesn't bug out randomly because it pretty much means you're going to lose your progress. It doesn't happen often but when it does...damn. Hard luck. TIP: run the game in fullscreen and set your cache for Flash at 10MB to prevent random lockups.
-The game tilts itself against you unfairly sometimes, especially when you decide to settle down in an area for extended time and the enemy spawn rate tends to increase. Not exactly fair when you're someone who likes having a "base" to call home but the gameplay is meant to keep you mobile. Not stuck in one spot. Explore at will but know that if you hang around somewhere long enough, the game WILL start pushing you out to go do something else or go somewhere.
-The amount of enemies that can populate one tile per battle sometimes goes a little overboard. Nothing more rage inducing than getting strangled to death in your sleep by 4 enemies, 3 of whom took apart your noise traps and the other strangled you to death with a pounce. Not sure if this is intentional but it still is frustrating when it happens.
-Not all the recipes work seamlessly. Sometimes you HAVE to check your recipe book to see if you've learned it by accident and you need to click the RECIPE to craft said item in the first place.
-No way to repair items CURRENTLY at the time of this review without mod assistance. It's pretty annoying to have to play vanilla, find a backpack on 3% and lose it the next turn to decay, go play a mod and then come back to find out that there are still some minor frustrations.

The reason I approve this game is because the community contributes ideas, help, bug reports and helps design its own mods. So far there's 3 main stable ones that are available at the website forums and they add SO MUCH to the game already. You know you've succeeded with a game when people are climbing over themselves to add content and mods to your game, free of charge. 

VERDICT:
Buy this if you like roguelikes, turn based and making decisions via micromanagement of inventory and move turns. You'll spend a good few hours with this game and still find yourself coming back for more. The gods help you if you add a mod. Might as well quit your day job while you're ahead! :D

And now for your typical funny lines: 

Always use Botany.

Wounds infected?
Tannin Tea!

Thirsty?
Tannin Tea!

Pooping blood?
Tannin Tea!

Vomiting?
Tannin Tea!

Wanna make money?
Tannin Tea!

Infected and sick?
Tannin Tea!

Surrounded by 6 Dogmen and all you have is a rock?
Tannin Tea!

Tannin Tea! The best drink...for you and me! 

This advertisment brought to you by Zom Zom's.

16138534.review:
NEO SCAVENGER is a game driven by the stories you write. In one run you could be a survivor who runs around collecting berries and putting them into a bag of chips and in the other run you could be a medic who finds a sniping rifle which he uses to kill other survivors to claim their stuff. There are endless possibilities. Another great aspect is that everything is textbased and menu based, You are telling your own individual all in your head. If NEO SCAVENGER would've been a more visual dependent game then it wouldn't have been that great!

16043526.review:
Neo Scavenger is, in my opinion, one of the greatest survival games ever put to market.
I strongly advise you to play the demo before you decide if you want to purchase this, as how you feel about the inventory system will likely make or break the game for you.
It's brutal, at times tense, at times it may feel unfair, but there's genuinely no other game like it out there, especially in the survival subgenre.
The combat is rough, dirty and unforgiving. Get shot? I hope to god you know how to treat that because you're not walking away until you've got that under control.  The environment is dirty, broken down and makes finding food so difficult you're likely to consider cannibalism a few times.

If the price seems a bit high, play the demo a few times and see how you like it. I've already sunk 30+ hours into the game and I still haven't beaten it.

16031927.review:
NEO Scavenger is an incredibly in-depth survival game with a real throwback feel. It *LOOKS* rough on the edges but is actually incredibly well made. 

* TL;DR*
Well made game about making tough decisions to survive a wasteland in a rogue-like setting. Almost a Darksouls/Fallout child with survival and exploration focus. Prepare to die, pretty often, and have fun.
* *

The game is all about making those tough decisions. From the get go what traits you feel you'll need or use best, and what hindrances you're willing to cope with to take on all of those useful traits/skills. 
Fairly regular scenarios in which you make decisions based on the items you have, the skills you've acquired, and your environment, whether it be setting up camp in a crumbling building or out in the woods, to drink water of questionable origins, eating berries that may or may not be poisonous (a choice you can ignore with the botany skill), knowing eating said berries could stave your growing hunger a little longer, but also that it may end your game with you sweating and shitting your life away... unless you find the right medicines. Was that the red pill or the blue pill (should've taken the medic skill)? 

This game pulls no punches. It's hard, it's frustrating, and it can feel like your progressing very slowly... and you will. But you'll learn. You'll find what works for you. If that's a spear-wielding bandit, preying on others, chopping off their legs for a nice roast, go do it! If you want to hide in the forest, hunting game, living off berries and scattering sound and animal traps amidst your domain, go haunt those woods why don't you? 

The game's replay value is high. (Mostly) randomly generated, with no real reason to follow the story except personal interests. If you want to make a life for yourself in the wastes, there's nothing (but everything) to stop you. It cannot be recommended enough, and for the price, it's a steal!

15984588.review:
NEO Scavenger est un petit jeu flash sympa.
Vous devez parcourir des terres désolées hostiles tout en fouillant un maximum de ruines et batiments abandonnés à la recherche de "choses" et de "trucs" utiles. En bon clodo, il faudra déjà trouver une paire de chaussures et des sacs poubelles pour stocker à la main votre butin. Après quelques jours, et si le destin n'est pas contre vous, peut-être que vous pourrez avoir quelques fringues propres et un cadis pour trimballer vos mer*** jusqu'à la décheterie. Là-bas, vous pourrez les échanger contre des choses plus utiles ou voir même contre de l'argent !

Votre survie tient à de nombreux paramètres : soif, faim, fatigue, température du corps, système immunitaire, quantité de sang, etc.
Les moyens de mourrir sont encore plus nombreux : infection, pneumonie, peste, anémie, hypothermie, gastro, empoisement, malédiction surnaturelle, etc. La vie ne tient qu'à un fil et une bête égratignure aura vite fait de se transformer en une mortelle infection si elle n'est pas correctement nettoyée et bandée. En ce sens, NEO Scavenger est une très bonne simulation de vie sans domicile fixe post apocalyptique. 

On apprécie le choix, même modeste, de traits et défauts à la création du personnage. Ces aptitudes se révéleront extrêmement utiles et détermineront si votre personnage sera plutôt du genre à se cacher pour éviter la moindre rencontre ou tailler dans le tas même face aux dangereux drônes de combat de la Megalopole de Detroit (DMC). Ces compétences influencent aussi énormement vos capacités d'interraction avec l'environnement et de craft (se faire un manteau en peau de loup-garou avec la capacité Trappeur, ou un Fusil de Gauss avec électricien, c'est classe quand même !).

Le gameplay est bâtard avec un jeu bac-à-sable semi-scénarisé. Pour ma part, je pense que la prose est excellente (anglais) et les longues descriptions durant les rencontres sont de qualité. Je regrette que le scénario n'ait pas été étendu (il y a plusieurs fins possibles mais on reste clairement sur sa fin).

Finalement le jeu possède d'excellentes bases mais manque cruellement d'un liant. Avec quelques quêtes et quêtes annexes, un travail approfondi pour exploiter le background très intéressant déjà existant, on aurait pu avoir un classique. Je trouve dommage qu'on puisse développer des armes de guerre incroyables (Fusil de Gauss) sans jamais avoir le challenge adéquat face à nous... (j'ai fini le jeu avec une pauvre lance en bois).

Bref, pour une poignée d'euros, ce jeu vous transformera en clodo post-apo et ça, c'est la classe. 
13/20

[quote] Si l'avis vous a aidé, n'hésitez pas à mettre un pouce en l'air, sinon mettez un pouce en bas ou réagissez en commentaire (ça peut aider les autres lecteurs). Si d'autres de mes avis vous intéressent : [url=http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198032258674/recommended/] La liste de mes recommandations [/url]

Vous pouvez voir mon profil complet ici : [url=steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198032258674]Blaystro[/url] [i]désolé pour le moment, je n'accepte pas les demandes de connexion[/i] :'( [/quote]

15831606.review:
Although NEO Scavenger doesn't have the fancy graphics of titles with huge budgets and numerous developers, it manages to do a lot more with a lot less. Scraping by and surviving in a world in which almost everything and everyone would rather see you dead (and in which death is permanent) may not sound fun on paper, but the game manages to create that addictive just-one-more-turn quality that's a sign of a great game. Thanks to the excellent music and writing, the game also manages to pull off an impressive amount of immersion and atmosphere with the limitations of the isometric, hexagonal world.

Unlike a lot of early access games with more staff and so less of an excuse, the developer has been communicative and responsive throughout which I can only think has led to a better game.

NEO Scavenger is a testament to what one guy with vision and dedication can do.

I think this game is super unbalanced in terms of how much luck you need to get through it. It's really hard to survive combat without one of the combat traits but in taking combat traits you loose the survival traits that keep you alive over the long haul. It's not uncommon to spend a couple hours building yourself and your camp up up just to get wrecked by a dog you couldn't out run. Ultimately the scavenging and crafting are alright but the combat system is really what gets me. There is no consistant means of escape and no way to tell how much health your opponent has or has lost during the battle. 
On a side note I'm really interested in the story elements of the game. I want to see the robot facility and I want to find out whats in the middle of the swamp but I just feel like I'm spending all of my time dealing with malnutrition and water poisoning. This is again another luck based flaw. If you can't find a tin can or a pot to boil water in your as good as dead within the first day or so. In all honesty I think the best way to fix that would be to have more set, consistent points in the game. That way I"m not forraging through settlement after settlement just to have varying results of survival gear, weapons or neurishment which leave the players superunder capable of surviving.
Maybe I"m missing things that others figured out but there isn't even a tutorial system to introduce you to the interface.

15777878.review:
[h1]Review: NEO Scavenger[/h1]

[i][b]Neo[/b][/i]: [griech.: Neu...] Vorsilbe, die bedeutet, dass der im Stammwort angegebene Sachverhalt neu, erneuert, reformiert oder reformuliert ist.

[i][b]Scavenger[/b][/i]: [engl.: Plünderer] Person, die Sachen stiehlt/ sammelt und dabei nicht vor Gewalt zurückschreckt. 

Dies sollte keine Abhandlung über Wörter und deren Herkunft werden, sondern schlicht das gedankliche Bild formen, welches ich als Basis für mein Review nutze. Scavenger bedeutet unter anderem auch Aasfresser, also Tiere, deren hauptsächliche Nahrung aus Kadavern besteht. Das Bild eines Menschen, der ein altes Gebäude seiner letzten wertvollen Bestandteile, quasi seiner Innerein beraubt, hat durchaus etwas Hyänenhaftes. Darum sage ich: Herzlich willkommen in der Welt von Neo Scavenger, wo die Hyäne lacht und der Löwe stolpert - oder stirbt.

Alle Metaphern verdaut und noch dabei? Neo Scavenger bietet schwere rundenbasierte Kost im postapokalyptischen Michigan. Doch bevor unser Charakter mit dem Namensbändchen am Arm aus dem Kälteschlaf erwacht, dürfen wir Ihn mit einigen nützlichen Fähigkeiten ausstatten, die ihn ausserhalb seiner Kapsel am Leben erhalten. Dabei hat der Spieler eine mögliche Anzahl an Slots, die durch einzelne Skills belegt werden. Stärke klaut mehr Platz als Elektrik, Mechanik nutzt gesundes Mittelmaß. Genau hier wird festgelegt, was ihr später beherrscht. Die Starken können mehr tragen und sind geschickt im Nahkampf, Mechaniker reparieren Türen, Trapper bzw. Fallensteller sind gut im Verwischen von Spuren und wer Fernkampf wählt hat bessere Chancen darauf, mit seiner Schleuder auch mal zu treffen. Wer mehr Slots braucht, kann seinem Charakter z.B. Insomnia, sprich Schlaflosigkeit spendieren. Eure Spielfigur wird dann deutlich schlechter einschlafen und fühlt sich dadurch deutlich weniger ausgeruht, hat dann aber mehr Slots für weitere Skills. Dazu rate ich nur sehr erfahrenen Spielern.

In der Welt angekommen, wird man direkt mit der ersten Bedrohung konfrontiert, welche man als taktisches Tutorial betrachten sollte. Bei dieser wie auch vielen anderen Begegnungen hat man die Möglichkeit, vorhandene Skills oder Gegenstände einzusetzen um den Ausgang zu beeinflussen. Springe ich aus dem Fenster und verletze mich womöglich? Nutze ich den Elektriker in mir und verschließe einfach die Tür? Im weiteren Verlauf des Spiels werdet Ihr auf viele weitere Gegner treffen. Kommt es zum gewaltsamen Aufeinandertreffen, wechselt das Spiel in den Kampfmodus. Dabei sollte man weder tolle Zwischensequenzen noch animierte 3D-Modelle erwarten. Dieses Spiel arbeitet viel mit Text, dafür ausführlich und in einer Art und Weise, die es ermöglicht jeden Umstand im Geist zu visualisieren. Dazu passt dann auch die relativ schlichte 2D-Pixelgrafik, bei der trotzdem jeder Gegenstand klar und deutlich definiert wirkt. Der Kampf ist rundenbasiert und benötigt jede Runde eine ausgewählte Aktion. Die Bandbreite reicht von Weglaufen, In Deckung gehen bis hin zu Fallen stellen oder Kopfnüsse verteilen, geizt aber manchmal nicht mit unerwarteten und unschönen Zufällen. Wenn der Löwe stolpert..

Die Karte, auf der wir uns getreu dem Rundenmotto mit Bewegungspunkten von einem Hexaeder zum nächsten bewegen, ist isometrisch, schlicht aber aussagekräftig. Große Arien lauscht man hier vergeblich, erlebt aber zweckmäßige Musik, die ein glaubwürdiges Endzeitszenario erzeugt. Ist das Wetter schlecht, wird es Nacht, die Spielfigur Barfuss oder das Terrain unwegsam, stehen mir weniger Bewegungspunkte zur Verfügung. Nutze ich Sonderaktionen wie Spuren verwischen oder "Verstecken", steigt der Verbrauch der Bewegungspunkte pro Zug. Gezogen wird bis alle Punkte auf 0 sinken oder der Zug selbstständig beendet wird. Dabei ist wo und wann entscheidend für euer weiteres Dasein. Soll sich die Spielfigut ausruhen, betätigt man das Kommando Sleep und euer Alter Ego wird sich an Ort und Stelle niederlassen. Drei Balken werden euch dann darauf hinweisen, wie gut ihr vor Umwelteinflüssen geschützt seid, wie erholsam eurer Schlaf wird und wie schnell ihr auf ungewünschte Eindringlinge aufmerksam werden, sprich: aufwacht. Im Zweifelsfall kann man sich merken: Wer sich ungeschützt den Gezeiten aussetzt oder gut sichtbar auf einem Hügel schläft, wird zwangsläufig bald sterben.

Neo Scavenger ist nicht einfach nur ein Spiel ums Überleben, nein ich wage zu behaupten, es ist der Prototyp. Halbnackt werdet ihr mit allen Widrigkeiten konfrontiert, die das postapokalyptische Ödland zu bieten hat. Denn wer schon mit leichter Unterkühlung aufbricht, wird nicht lange unterwegs sein..
Kurzum: Wer nicht isst, stirbt.  Wer nicht trinkt, stirbt. Wer nicht schläft oder zuviel trägt ist zu erschöpft um weiterzulaufen - und stirbt. Und im Gegensatz zu anderen Survivals hat der Spieler kein vorgefertigtes Inventar. Er hat 2 Hände. Mit viel Glück findet ihr am Anfang eine Plastiktüte oder eine Jeans, in der ihr wenigstens ein Stück Fleisch lagern könnt. Erfrieren erwähnte ich bereits, bleibt also noch verbluten. Verletzungen können durch viele Umstände entstehen. Ursache Nr.1 bleibt zwar der Kampf gegen andere Ödlandbewohner, allerdings können auch Gebäude einstürzen während der Spieler plündert. Das ist mir zwar erst einmal passiert, war dann allerdings umso ärgerlicher als ich starb. Und Neo Scavenger kennt nur tot - oder lebendig. Gespeichert wird beim Verlassen des Spiels,  wer stirbt darf daraus lernen und von vorn beginnen. Zurück zur Ersten Hilfe. 

Verletzungen können unterschiedlich stark und gefährlich sein. Das geht von Kratzern über Schnitte bis hin zu Brüchen. Und wie alles in diesem Spiel, werden auch diese nicht wie von Geisterhand abheilen sondern benötigen zur Heilung eine realistische Vorgehensweise. Wunden sollte man auswaschen um eine Infektion zu vermeiden, alte Stofffetzen mit Alkohol desinfizieren und dann als Bandage nutzen. Äste können in Kombination mit Pelz zu einer behelfsmäßigen Schiene umfunktioniert werden. Erfindungsreichtum ist gefragt. Für viele im Spiel vorhanden Rezepte sind unterschiedliche Lösungen möglich. Eine Fackel muss nicht zwangsläufig aus Ast und Stoff bestehen, sofern ein Stab und etwas brennbares verbaut wird. Eine Plane, ein paar Stöcker und Bänder lassen sich zum wiederverwendbaren Zelt umbauen und und und..

Was ist nun eigentlich das Ziel eurer Entbehrungen, Schmerzen und Anstrengungen? Abseits von Hunger, Durst und Kampf wollt Ihr natürlich wissen: Wer bin Ich und was mache Ich hier? Wie der Spieler dem nachgeht bleibt ihm überlassen. Verfolgt die Story indem ihr Hinweisen nachgeht, euch mit Kultisten austauscht und Richtung Detroit aufbrecht oder verharrt im Ödland und erlebt, wie lange ihr durchhaltet. Dabei möchte ich nochmal kurz ins Tierreich abgleiten. Wer immer Löwe ist, in den Kampf rauscht und für sich das Recht des Stärkeren beansprucht, wird möglicherweise schneller sterben als ihm lieb ist. Zufälle sind allgegenwärtig im Spiel und ein kleines Straucheln kann der letzte Schritt für dieses Leben bedeuten. Manchmal ist Rückzug der Weg zum Erfolg. Wer als Hyäne zurückkehrt um die Reste zu plündern wird vielleicht keine Tapferkeitsmedaille erhalten, lebt aber spürbar länger.

[h1]Zusammenfassung:[/h1]

[b][u]Wertung:8/10[/u][/b]

Neo Scavenger ist unbarmherzig, zufallsbedingt und vielleicht auch unschön. Die Lernkurve scheint unendlich lang und steil. Die Grafik ist grau, der Sound stellenweise trist. Und doch: Dieses Spiel erzeugt durch Realismus, Text und Setting mehr, als polierte Spiele durch Präsentation je vorweisen werden. Ich empfehle es nur geduldigen Leuten. Wer mein Review bis hier gelesen hat, gehört zweifellos dazu.

15665089.review:
A devloper once told me, "UI (User Interface) is like a joke; If you have to explain it, then it isn't that good."
This game fits into that category with poor UI as only one of many design flaws. Don't waste your time and money.

* Unweildy Menu Navigation
The game plays in a window by default, which in and of itself isn't a bad thing. The problem comes when trying to back out of a menu just to end up closing the entire game instead (and losing any progress in the process). The menus themselves, such as inventory, crafting and the map are not very intuitve and require a lot of trial-and-error to figure them out. Saving a game is unweildy, too, because there is only one option; "Save & Quit" from the main menu. 

* Lack of Information and Direction
Very little information is given for each item beyond "condition" which is how well in a state of repair an item is. For example, when tying to compare weapons, stats such as range and damage are inaccesable to the player; You have to guess which weapons may or may not be better! Same goes for clothing; There are no stats beyond condtion that tell a player how well protected they are. Lack of stats and lack of other useful information leaves the player in the dark. Trial and error helps, but the game is so inconsitant that trial and error will only get you so far.

* Nearly Impossible Early Game
I like a challange, but this game has too many variables. The map, encounters and looting are all random, which could be a good thing. However, the game starts you out with next to nothing and already suffering from exposure to cold weather. When you need some basic supplies just to survive, and the only way to get those supplies is by a series of lucky random events, then the game becomes more about luck-of-the-draw and less about any real strategy.

* Bad Combat Encounters
On top of just trying to survive the elements, there are things out there that want to kill you, and you have next to nothing to fight back with! Your choices are fight with a poorly-designed combat mechanism or try to run and ineveitably get overrun anyway. Even if you win the fight, it's likely you will succumb to the injuries sustained in combat, because you don't have the supplies you need to properly treat yourself.

So on top on the bad, unhelpful UI design are a series of random events that will kill you rather quickly, because you never get a chance to get what you need to survive. This game is NOT fun, but rather frustrating, to have to start over and over again and get nowhere in the process. Don't waste your time - Go find a better game.

15596485.review:
You will freeze to death with one left boot on. This is the game in its entirety. I've played several survivor horror games in the past and I was looking forward to something different. Text/ turn based survival horror appealed to me.  At first, you kinda have to get used to the controls. Click this tab to do this, click this tab to do that. Click this button to turn off the text so you can do the only thing available to do. Speaking of, skills in this game are pretty much worthless. 
 Ya, some skills actually do stuff. Melee does help in combat, you can Hide while you explore the map, Botany gives you more loot to choose from in forest tiles, some cutscene you use tracking to reveal more text about something that happened when they just could have told you in the first place what happened. Other skills don't matter. Mechanical and Hide give you the ability to scavange buildings safely but reduce the probability of loot while scavenging.  Medic give you the ability to scavenge for medical supplies in the spawn point and gives you better healing but if you don't have any medicine ...who cares! 
 Your best bet is to hit the road and gather as much as you can to help you survive. The very first town you find will give you a cutscene and a little back story and that's usually it. Most times than not, this town is empty of stuff to take. So, you move out and explore the area around. And as you wander, in the cold and rain, you start suffering from hypothermia. You "could" build a fire but in the thirty five- fourty games straight that I played (because you almost always die within the first two in game days) I've found a lighter twice. 
 Now, as you reach near death due to freezing to death , you get a cutscene about an abondoned car. The car has a sleeping bag inside and if you use the Tracking skill, you will find one left boot. You can grab the sleeping bag and carry it to your camp, which camps always attract dogs, and if a dog or a soldier doesn't come into your camp and kill you, you can sleep for a few hours and warm up . But that just slows the inevitable. For the only out come for this game is..... you'll freeze to death with one left boot.

15581269.review:
Un juegazo increible. Muy buena mezcla de sandbox e historia que supera ampliamente a Project Zomboid (otro gran juego) en profundidad y en tener una historia (la de PZ la haces tú y a la larga se hace monótono) En ambientación se acerca mucho más a la saga Fallout, que mezcla destrucción y tecnología futurista.

La ambientación, con ese inicio en el que no sabes nada de nada. Y la desesperación de conseguir recursos está muy conseguida. Un Fallout en toda regla.

La profundidad de interacción con el mundo es muy elevada, aunque aún no he avanzado lo suficiente como para tener muchas charlas con los personajes. Mantenerse vivo es lo que más nos va a costar y divertir. Formas de morir hay muchas, incluso las básicas, como morir de frío, sed o hambre.

La música y el sonido, ni destacable ni pobre.

Los gráficos, son su punto débil, aunque son lo suficientemente buenos como para no causar repulsa. De vez en cuando tenemos alguna imagen de ambientación.

El juego está en inglés, y comprender los textos es importante. Tampoco hay prisa ya que se trata de un juego a turnos y podéis consultar un diccionario. Es importante que sepáis todo lo que leeis para disfrutar correctamente de la ambientación, debido a la falta de gráficos impactantes.

La fabricación de objetos es muy amplia aunque al principio, cuando no lo entendemos, nos pueda resultar frustrante. Asi que aconsejo empezar cogiendo alguna habilidad inicial de profesión (trampero por ejemplo) y ver las recetas que tenemos desbloqueadas desde el principio gracias a ella. Una vez que dominemos la ventana de crafting, podemos pasar si queremos a poner los objetos directamente. Aunque si os gusta descubrir recetas por vosotros mismos, adelante.

El mejor consejo es: no miréis una guía. El juego se disfruta mucho a base de morir y aprender. No hace falta tener unos conocimientos extremadamente amplios como en Dwarf Fortress.


PD Es posible que se os borren partidas si tenéis algo que borre cookies en vuestro ordenador. La mejor forma de no perderlas es copiando el arbol de directorios de las partidas guardadas justo cuando las habéis guardado. Y copiar encima justo cuando queráis cargarla (con el juego arrancado)

15564068.review:
So I really, really wanted to like this game, because the amount of potential in this game is absolutely tremendous. The interplay between different systems and the really neat environment and design decisions should have made a great game.

It didn't. There's not enough content for this game to shine, and because there's so little content the problems it has are made starkly apparent. Permadeath is not an inherently good or bad decision, but what it does in a game like NEO Scavenger is force the player through the same few bits of content over and over again. That content has an optimized solution, which means the first 5-10 minutes of every play-through are doing the exact same thing, every time, with no reason or reward from deviating from it. And then you end up at one of the pieces of game content that you _did_ play before, with functionally identical choices. And then you die, fairly or unfairly (and this game _loves_ unfair deaths; there are a number of places where you can die in a narrative scene because you didn't tag a skill!), and you get to do it again.

A simulation game has to hide its brain to be deeply rewarding. This doesn't, and the narrative and the neat bits do not carry it through. Buy it for a couple bucks and play it once or twice, but at list price it is emphatically not worth your money because it will not respect your time.

15509580.review:
This game drops you right into conflict: you wake up amnesiac, barefoot, naked, with a hungry wolf-thing in the adjacent room of a cryogenic facility.

The first second of the game is pretty much the last time you won't be desperately hungry, thirsty, hypothermic, exhausted, bleeding out, diseased, hunted down, or some gruesome mix of these things.

From there, the game revolves around challenging resource management as you explore a large hex-titled world looking for supplies and answers.

Do you leave behind the squirrel-trap or the cleaver?
Do you carry the sleeping bag or the rifle with 5 bullets?
Do you risk alerting the raiders nearby with a bonfire or do you let the cold weather grip you a bit tighter for another sleepless night?
Do you eat the rancid meat or do you risk a fist-fight with another looter to see if they have food?
Do you slowly drag their corpse to the woods to cook their flesh or do you press onwards into the fog of war?
Do you run to your next destination and get there in a day or do you silently sneak there and get there in three?

Until NEO Scavenger, I had no idea a turn-based hex-tiled game could compel such a convincing post-apocalyptic desperation.

My advice to you is to just jump in and hang in there until you've spent a couple hours. To be honest, I didn't even like the game at first until I'd suffered about ten deaths or so. Then I began to understand and get a glimpse of what the game had to offer. Like when I let a bandit limp away from a fight only for him to come back five turns later to kill me in my sleep with the cleaver I left behind at a salvage site a few tiles away.

It also sometimes feels like you aren't making any progress since it's so easy to die (permadeath), but soon you realize that you're surviving a little longer every attempt - 3 days, 5 days, 1 week, 2 weeks. And the game just gets better and better as you begin to master it. What used to seem like a basic combat system turns out to be a nuanced one. What used to seem like a pointless skill/ability becomes your favorite. etc.

My only complaint is that the UI is sometimes a bit tedious. For example, having to put down the sleeping bag every night and remember to pick it back up in the morning. Or doing the same 10-mouseclick dance with the crafting system to chop wood, light a fire, cook meat, and then eat the meat. But then again, you're usually so happy to find meat that 10 or so clicks is a small price to pay.

Also, due to the crafting system UI, it's tedious to answer the question: "What can I craft with the things I currently have in my inventory?" As I accumulate items, I often find myself flipping through my recipes to see if I can make anything useful, only to do it again in five turns to see if anything changed. The game would benefit from a quick-view of "Here are the items you can currently craft" with the ability to click those items to instantly make them.

However, the grid-based inventory management system is a fun minigame in itself. It really is addictive to answer questions like "Should I put the pistol with zero bullets in my pocket or should I fill my pocket with these gummy bears?" - Oh wait, your worn-out pants are going to disintegrate in about five turns, but you'll probably get hunted down by a mutant wolf before you have to deal with that.

Good luck!

15444615.review:
If you ever wanted to play a hobo simulator, this is it.  If you manage not to get RNG'd into the dirt some compelling storytelling awaits you, although you could always avoid it and just try to survive as long as possible.

PROS:
- Excellent atmosphere.
- Smart writing.  It's both verbose and short when it needs to be.
- Mod-friendly.
- Great for both short and long gameplay sessions.
- Visceral combat.  Ripping an arrow out of your arm ans stabbin a man to death with it has a certain appeal.
- Sensible crafting system and multiple skill combinations encourage different playstyles.

CONS:
- It's not winning any graphics awards.  Fortunately this doesn't draw away from the strength of the gameplay, but still...I could see someone not digging the look.
- The RNG God really holds power over this game.  It's hard not to feel like the whole world is against you when you can't find a pair of shoes and your shopping bag full of whiskey and twinkies rips open.  Which leads to my next point.
- The whole world is pretty much out to get you.  There are a couple of somehwat less hostile areas but for the most part everything in this game wants to kill you.  It's like Australia, except Michigan.
- Visceral combat.  It's pretty soul-crushing to finally find a backpack and a decent pair of shoes only to later discover that someone has beat your head in with a sauce pan while you were asleep.

15331317.review:
You wake up to the sound of freezing rain on makeshift tarp shelter. You take a quick look through your gear making sure nothing has been stolen in the night. Shoving the pieces of your shelter into your pack and throwing your hide cloak around your shoulders you take off through the pouring rain.

      You rummage through a few houses not finding much, these where the first places to get scavenger after everything went to ****. As you exit the last house on the street tearing an old tee shirt into rags, suddenly hearing a loud clatter you throw yourself to the ground and watch as a large figure resembling Werewolf from old story's lumbers past. It passes by and you release a breath you didn't know you where holding in. Unslinging the rifle from your shoulder you top off the magazine, fighting a dog man today is not something you wish to happen.
 
       A few days later you stand atop a hill scanning the area with half a binocular you keep slung around your neck searching for any movement while munching on a handful of berries. After several hours you see the flash a blue sash moving out of the tree line, a blue frog preacher not friendly and normally carrying somewhat valuable objects you will have no remorse from ending this ones life. Moving closer as to not waste your valuable ammunition you line up a shot from your rifle. With a loud accompanying crack the figure drops to the ground motionless. as you get close the man jumps to his feet and sprints back into the tree line, Swear under your breath you give chase into the dense forest.

       He couldnt have gotten far you think to yourself examining the blood trail. The trees seem to press closer on you and your draw a small revolver from your cargo pants pocket, your rifle would be ineffective at these close ranges. The blue sash makes it easy to find the lifeless body after a few minutes. Your so focous on looting the corpse you almost don't hear the rustle of foliage, you grab your pistol from where it lay beside the body and scan the woods searching for the source of the sound. A single shot whipes by your head and you throw yourself behind a log still searching for your attacker. You take a deep breath staying here is suicide, you lung forward from behind the log in a full on sprint. Stumbling over the overgrown roots of the trees you feel relieved as you see the light streaming for the edge of the forest. In all fairness you almost make it before the second shot rings out catching you in the leg. Gritting your teeth against the pain you fire blindly behind you as you break out into the field. You leap into the tall grass silently thanking what ever god stays about for the concealment. The third shot hits you in the back going through your lung, you cough blood flying from your mouth and then the fourth and final shot the only you don't hear finally ends your pain.

 Neo Scavenger is a post apocalyptic survival simulator. You must contend with food, water, the cold, the weight of your equipment, wild beasts and other people in your struggle to simply stay alive. Neo scavenger also adds in sides mission and a story although i must admit i have no lived long enough to complete any of them. Also random events can happen while moving about the hexagonal landscape ranging from slave auctions to abandon camps. Combat is turn based and visceral in its descriptions, enough to make you slightly uncomfortable with each killing blow. A skill is also in place allowing you to change your play style with each life keeping the game fresh. There can be quite a lot of reading in parts however its is done very very well, each line adds more to the atmosphere and does a good job of giving a visual of the surrounding area.

 This is a brutal unforgiving game Death comes quickly to the unknowing and the unprepared. Its not everyone's game by far taking up a niche role in giving a somewhat realistic survival game, probably the closest ive found to a proper simulator. 

 I give NeoScavenger an 8.5/10 
 Menus can be rather clunky at times and starting off as a new player can be rather brutal but once you grown acclimated to the environment it becomes a rather masochistic joy to play. Just be wary of purchasing and watch some footage and play to free demo to see if you think you would enjoy the game.

15135391.review:
The info:

In NEO Scavenger you will be fighting not only the vicious denizens of a post apocalyptic world; but nature itself.
Between the cold, hunger and baddies you will have a hard time surviving.

Finding something as simple as a potato chip bag seems like an accomplishment in this game as you will always be struggling to find ways to carry all the loot you find and and tools you need.
Every item in the game has a health and when that health runs out, it's gone forever and just like in real life if you find a old shopping bag it might have a hole or two in it so there is always the chance that loot you find will already be near useless. 
Having to decide whether to go on with a sword that has 1% use left in it verses the completely fine stick just laying there will become a easy choice. But figuring out if the small pocket knife is better to take with you because it takes up less space or if it's worth losing that extra storage to a base ball bat is a much harder to decide.

Every choice in NEO Scavenger could mean regret or death in the next few turns or happiness and success. 


 Some things to note before buying:
If you like not being able to save your progress then this game is fore you. The only option you have is to 'save' game; which acquaints to going back to the start screen or quitting the game and being able to pick up where you left off however you soon realize it's not really saving anything the first time you die your save is gone. When you die you have to start over again with nothing . . .from the beginning. For me I really get depressed when I worked really hard to get what I got only to die because it was cold or because I drank some bad water.


The good:

Challenging
Tons of content to see
high replay value



The bad:

The random nature of  encounters and item generation is very unforgiving at times and often ends with your character being killed after only a few turns.
A limited (small) set of starting skills to choose from.

15128921.review:
This is one of my favorite games of all time. If you liked Fallout 1 and 2, and you like survival and roguelike games, I think you'll love this. It's dark, creepy, atmospheric, insanely detailed and can be morbid beyond belief. Don't judge the screenshots - buy this game. Note: I played this off steam, that's why my game time is low. I probably hit triple digits in reality.

Had some of my most memorable gaming experiences with NEO Scavenger while it was in Alpha, and weirdly enough it wasn't even anything dramatic, just stalking deer and making jerky, exploring and braving the elements with my prized and carefully assembled "kit" of equipment, feeling like a badass survivor in a totally harsh and unforgiving world. In another playthrough, some truly weird shit went down in an abandoned insane assylum turned cultist haven: At the door, I gave up my prized kit in exchange for a hospital gown, got involved in some crazy masochistic, self-flagellating religious nonsense and cultist court intrigues, left on strange and uncertain terms, and then got shot outside the gates (left me absolutely speechless, like, WTF just happened?)

Quests go weird. Enemies can be unpredictable. Strange things can happen. Emergent gameplay up the whazoo.

This game offers so much all at once... The detail in it is enough to sattisfy your worst OCD compulsions, because this game has the most detailed inventory management of probably any game ever made (plastic bags that you can crumple up and put in pockets, pill boxes you can stock with individual pills, batteries that you can stock and charge with individual electric cells, etc.) It also has a really detailed and fairly simple to use crafting system, with absolutely tons of stuff. Just ridiculous amount of stuff, much more available through mods.

The atmosphere and tone is almost uniquely morbid. This is not necessary or recommended, but hypothetically you can kill someone with a sharpened stick, then carry their body to the woods, carve up the body into steaks and make canibal pemmican. That is outrageous, and disturbing, and just knowing the game lets you do that (though I think discourages it somehow), that in itself gives the game a uniquely dark tone (something about the graphic of the enemy's courpse, lying crumpled on its side, taking up your entire inventory and overburderning you, man that image got like burned in my mind I think). 

There are randomly generated scripted events and RPG/Adventure type of quests, choices, storylines. And the writing is actually good, I would even say excellent. These are optional though, so you can kind of "sandbox" it if you want. Anyway, I've sunk weeks into this game and enjoyed it tremendously, back when it wasn't even complete.

Cons: 
- None, really. 
- After countless hours, combat can get a little repetetive.
- Of course, the interface is pretty clunky and strange in some respects, so while on the one hand I absolutely adore this game just as it is, I also hope that one day it gets some kind of over-haul or redesign/relaunch.

TL;DR: The game developer is a genius and this is clearly a labor of love. I buy very few games, but this is one I was almost giddy to pay for.

Good lord is this game hard.

Trust me when I say this, this game holds no punches. Think pixelated turn-based STALKER. It's one of the best games I've played in a while. Turn-based combat is normally a huge hurdle for me, but this game does it really well. You WILL end up being so hungry you will resort to cannibalism (No, really, this game has cannibalism). 15069797.review:
Alright, look. I love the game. I do, really. It's awesome, it's fun, it's addictive, and honestly it could teach people a few things about surviving in such a situation that they can't depend on society anymore. Almost all the techniques in the game are solid survival techniques that could very well save your life in the real world. But after a series of deaths before I could even get enough supplies to make the journey east (which I understand is a roguelike feature, but bear with me.), I felt the need to write this review. 
One word, ladies and gentlemen: Yezinka. There's only one of them in the game world, and it wanders the map until it encounters your player. When it does, it hovers around in the hexes around you, and waits for you to inevitably have to sleep. You can't kill it by jumping it during the day because it can manage to sprint somewhere around 12 paces per move, while you can manage at best 4. It's also very difficult to hit with ranged weaponry (never got to try melee). Now here's the lemon in the wound: When you go to sleep, it immediately beelines for you, and steals your eyes. You can do NOTHING about it. You get around two turns, which is enough to stand up and start to look for it, and suddenly your eyes are gone. You can't do anything to recover them unless you've happened to encounter this late in the game and are near the city, and have been hoarding enough cash for cybersurgery. I say you need to be near the city because the condition "No Eyes" seems to flag you and every single enemy creature on the map drops what they're doing and attempts to kill you. I made a valiant effort and managed to kill two bandits and a dog before I was just overwhelmed with going into a new battle every turn (every other turn very VERY occasionally). Maybe if I were given a chance to pack up the things I had and try to luck my way to the city and sell everything I had for a single eye, I wouldn't have such a problem with this. Maybe if I were allowed to live for a bit and get a balancing attribute after a few turns that mitigated the fact that I can't see anymore, that'd be fine too. But as it is, if luck allows this broken monstrosity to seek you out without being killed by other wild animals or lucky NPCs, you are screwed, and there's no preparation at all that you can attempt to save yourself. I cannot in good conscience recommend any game that has a chance of giving the player such an enormous middle finger. But if you can get past that and you think it's not something that will bother you, then buy this game. The Yezinka is an enormous infected zit on the face of an otherwise outstanding game.
