14773667.review:
Wonderful idea, missing in execution. (Edits below thought)

It's slow to play and doesn't distinguish well in presentation (between turns, between degrees of injury, between how aggressive your opponent is acting) but it still doesn't allow saving.
Don't Starve for example plays fast and you can see how your opponent acts or why you can't run away. NEO is just being optuse and then when you inevitably die you have to go through the same very slow start once over.

Maybe fun to someone else, and I've hesitated to give a negative recommendation since I've come back to it several times - but then the same thing happens over and over again, and I'm back to the freezer.

[Edit: Ok, I came back again after a very long break, and found the mod support. You can make backups of your saves if you want a milestone. It's a pretty messy procedure, but the creator has explained it and some other modding tips as well as given good mod support. It's very hidden and hard to get to (like the rest of the game?) but it is there, so I can dismiss my previous biggest issue.

Thus I can add some time to say "this is a slow but very engrossing game with great worldbuilding" and change my recommendation to positive.

Further edits though: You'll still have to strike a balance between taking in more information about the gameworld (like the fact that your starting location will spawn extra amounts of rabid dogs to wear you down if you try to build a permanent base in that perfect locale) while not getting too many clues that'll spoil your amazement at the rest of the world. So it's a bit unsteady, like the game as a whole, but it remains, if just barely, a recommended game.]

14772429.review:
[b] TL;DR [/b]
Neo Scavenger is a brutal 2D survival game set in a supernatural apocalypse where you try survive the wasteland of everything that wants, can, and will kill you should they ever get their claws on you. Also permadeath is on. A shining example of gameplay over graphics.

[b] Game Detail [/b]
Name: Neo Scavenger
Genre: Survival, Strategic Inventory Management
Personal score: I never knew masochism and sadism was an art form till today. Fun.

[b] What is Neo Scavenger [/b]
Neo Scavenger is a 2D survival game set in a hex based world where a devastation has happened to the world and well, apocalypse thing happen and you are a survivor of it. In first glance the innocent looking graphic and the non threatening looking trailer may throw you off on how brutal this game is but as people often say, 'you don't know hell till you been there' read on. Permadeath is on btw.

[b] 1:Gameplay [/b]
The main gist of Neo scavenger gameplay is well, scavenging old ruins of buildings and forest  to follow the trail of barebone story. Each hex has a protection value from beeing seen, comfort and how alert you can be when something goes near you. Each of this stats can be improved by items, shelter and other craftable. A low protection from the enviromental will make your character slowly freezes during the night and if their body temperature is already low enough they will die. A low alert level will cause your character to not wake up when threats are nearby and bandits/looter/stuff can kill you in your sleep and you will die. A low comfort will cause your character to fight less efficiently and you might suddenly fall asleep and you will die.

Adding to that, the map is hex form and you have a limited numbers of move during the day and far less during the night to move around, scavenge or perform one of the many in game action before needing to end your turn for the AI to move. On each hex you can scavenge supplies with city tiles having more supplies but comes at the increase risk of being discovered by bandits and obtaining injuries. Scavenging is extremely important in this game because it is your only way of getting randomized loots early game. Pretty much everything you need can be obtain by scavenging. Which might leads to a fight should you encounter bandits while on the move.

Fighting in Neo Scavenger is a game of chances and luck. A fully kited out bandit can still be defeated by you wielding nothing more than a rock but such a thing would of course take extreme luck due to the hidden diceroll system. Based on the perks you have chosen special attacks may not be available to you and only to the perk wielder. A few way fights can be resolve is through killing your opponent, dominating them and causing them to surrender or simply point your gun at them and watch them flee. Even an empty gun works occasionally to fool the AI seeing as in real life you would of course not attack the man with a gun even though its empty but you don't know that.

Should you get wounded in Neo Scavenger you will have to treat them to prevent the blood loss from draining too much and yes it regenerates slowly. Wound treatment has their own special menu where you apply splints, bandages and meds to your character. Left unchecked a large wound has the potential to end your playthrough instantly. Also water and berries you collected are often time poisones because the game isn't hard enough. This might cause disease that has a similar effect to a tired status or in worse case scenario cause a total system failure which leads to your death.

From all the materials you gathered from the scavenging you can use the crafting menu to create items. A wood with a sharp object will yield a spear that you can use to attack. Container with strings and stones will yield a noisemaker to increase the alert level of your campsite. Many other options exist for the player to find themselves.

The player character will also experience hunger and thirst which can be reduce by eating and drinking, failure to do so will lead to death. But as mentioned earlier, most of the water and food you find in the forest where the risks are low are poisonous and consuming them will lead to death.

Inventory management in Neo scavenger are quite realistic in terms of real life, your character has only 2 hands and thus can only hold 1 item in each hands without a bag. With a bag this frees up 1 hand for combat and allows more item to be carried but a bag is not your only means of carrying. Side pockets in pants, shirt and even a sledge can be found and use to help you carry more items which is especially important during end game where you often have to make far away expedition. Any item being held or use will eventually degrade before completely break down into nothing and in fact most of the things found in the wild are actually used goods and so they already have lowered durability. To beat the coldness of the night without a good shelter multiple cloths can be worn on top of each other to increase heat levels during the night and prevent freezing to death.

The day and night system is also quite important. During the day enemies can spot you from further away and the same holds true for you and the during the night the decreased line of sight cause your action points to be less that during the day.

As you traverse the deadly world of Neo Scavenger you might come across strange landmarks or building that will lead you to a random event. Success of survival and loot gain depends on the players perks chosen and dialog choices.

And lastly the perks. During character creation you can choose several perks with perk points limiting the amount. The best perks are usually the most expensive but to help player with that negative perks can also be chosen that frees up point for more positive perks.

[b] 2:Sound [/b]
Utilizing more ambient noises instead of spoken dialogs the world of neo scavenger is truly brought to life, The forest shakes and the ruined city exhibit an eerie feeling as the player explores it. 

But well, good filler is better than no filler.

[b] 3:Graphics [/b]
Everything is sprite based no exception. The characters are sprites, the menu utilizes sprites and even the backgrounds are sprites but like other sprites these are well done enough to pass the inspection. You can clearly tell what an item is at a glance which should be the most important thing in a survival game like this.

At least they do look pretty.

[b] Conclusion [/b]
You will die a lot in this game. That is a fact and i hope i emphasized it enough. But the game definitely do not hold your hand at all from the moment you walk out of the facility till the next moment your guts spilled out from getting stabbed by an alcohol bottle. This game is intense. Fan of survival game should definitely get it.

FInal verdict: Yes.


[b] TIPS! [/b]
FIND A SHOE, SERIOUSLY.
FIND SOME CLOTHES TOO WHILE YOU'RE LOOKING FOR THAT SHOE.
YOU WILL DIE. AND IT'S PERMAD DEATH SO GET READY TO RESTART A LOT.
BUT THE MOST IMPORTANT THING IS....
don't eat those red berries.

14770564.review:
This game is very fun, and incredicly frustrating. I cannot stress how easily you will die.

Killed by a dogman, 3 hours into the game (no weapons aside from fists to fight with).
Brought a knife to a gunfight thinking the enemy didn't have bullets (a rare and extremely expensive commodity).
Didn't have Botany skill, died from posionous foods (berries and mushrooms).
Got infections from having dirty rags on wounds.
Drank bad water.
Tripped in combat.
Random encounters.
The list is unending.

But through it all, this game is a lot of fun. After the 5th or 6th try, you start to get the hang of it (as long as you choose the same skills in the beginning). Get used to living off the land, by the way. Hoarding is good, but make sure you don't keep everything on you, you only have so much room.

Some good advice, you ask?
Botany makes for eating on the run, as well as making tea that helps boost your immune system (very important).
Ranged skill allows you to make bows/arrows, as well as slings (early game weapons), as well as use pistols, rifles, and shotguns more efficiently (more late game (as far as late game exists) weapons).
Always equip better durability gear.
ATN members are naturally friendly, and won't starts fights. They are, however, pretty strong, and will end them if you aren't similarly equipped, or ambushing them. (eaiest way to tell them from others is they have white faces, and mohawks)
Members of the Blue Frogs should be avoided, especially in melee combat. Just being near them gives you a chance of getting sick.

But most importantly...
Don't take off the Bronze Talisman...

It looks so good! It sounded like the survival game I'd been wanting for YEARS! But after scavenging only 2 abandoned towns I was shot at and constantly stunned until I died. I was Tough and had clothes on, not sure if that improves my defense or not, and I was behind cover. Infact getting behind cover was the one single action I was able to pull off.

In my many playthroughs since I have never been able to find another frying pan or torch, and things were even harder. Finding a lighter is so damn hard that I usually starve to death. Or if I just try waiting it out and eating mushrooms in forests, I end up dying of sickness. This isn't a game about surviving, it's a game about taking a while to die. 2 days is my usual record.

This game relies so incredibly heavily on luck that it just isn't fun. But survival is all about strategy, so this works out horribly. I've tried building a great shelter, but died of sickness. Tried never staying in one spot, but got mauled. There are only ways to lose and no ways to win. Also with the very small amount of recipes available, you'd think the game would give you hints on when you need just 1 more item to make something. Dragging the skills into the crafting table is just really monotonous. It should be doing this itself! It's the Minecraft crafting table all over again, with no user-friendliness.

And the skills, they were a selling point for me, but now that I've gotten to play it I only pick the same skills each time. They are just not at all balanced. This is what I'd expect from a game still in beta. I thought I'd be avoiding these huge flaws in a finished game. Incredibly dissapointing. I've tried other survival roguelikes and they were pretty bad too in there own ways.

Starting to wonder if this genre combo simply can never work.

UPDATE: Same day I post this, a wonderful person tells me about a free game in beta called Cataclysm: Dark Days Ahead. It's got more content than I can handle! And despite it's wonky controls, it has a very clear crafting system, and loads of methods for getting materials. It's also far more immersive with you actually exploring the areas yourself. Just hope you don't need graphics, because that's the game's only flaw. To play it like Neo Scavenger, just turn zombies off and NPCs on. And finally, when you die in it, you learn from it. You play better next time. Something I sadly can't say about Neo Scavenger, where it's difficulty is based on a dice roll.

14703867.review:
[h1] Survival done right [/h1]

NEO Scavenger is another survival game set in a post-apocalyptic scenario where your mission is to, you guessed it, survive. Lately I've noticed that many games of this genre are, for the most part, shallow and very boring. Whether it's the oversaturation or my lack of interest, but I just haven't been able to find a good realistic survival game to spark my interest. But then comes Blue Bottle Games and gives us this fantastic, well-thought-out RPG that I just can't stop playing.

The gameplay is probably my favorite part about it, because it involves turn-based strategy, the best kind of strategy that fits these types of games so well. You will cautiously think about every next move you make. The style is similar to games such as Wasteland or S.T.A.L.K.E.R. but the difficulty resembles that of a Dark Souls game.

I think it speaks volumes when an indie game does a much better job at creating a world so dark and brutal that will make you dread every moment you explore it than most AAA titles with their overblown visuals and lack of originality. Just to make it clear, this one of the best survival simulations that you can experience, this game does not favor sloppiness, you will die until you learn how to survive the wasteland.

HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!

[b] 10 shoes/10 [/b]

14631810.review:
홈리스 시뮬레이터를 실행한다.

1. 연구소의 효율적인 탈출을 위해 특성에 Strong을 필수로 넣어준다.
2. 돌멩이를 멀리 던지며 넘어져도 개싸움이 가능한 Ranged를 선택해준다.
3. 본격 루팅 플레이를 위해서는 Hacking과 Lockpicking를 찍어준다.
4. 동물 가죽으로 은밀한 부위를 가리며 초반에 바로 비닐봉투를 얻고 싶다면 Trapping도 찍어준다.

연구소에서 도그맨을 끔살 시킨 후 x 버튼을 눌러 끔살한 도그맨의 시체와 Trapping, 유리조각으로 가죽을 얻어 입자. 중반부까지 홈리스 시뮬레이터에서 가장 큰 역할을 할 장비이다. 도그맨은 주기적으로 가죽을 공급해주기 때문에 매우 좋다. 가끔씩 고기도 가져오는 통에 홈리스 전용 쇼핑카트에는 물을 넉넉히 들고다녀야 한다.

5. 주변 건물에 들어가서 돋보기 모양을 확인 후 E 버튼을 누르자. 그럼 탐험 화면이 나타난다. 스트롱을 찍었다면 힘만으로 그나마 루팅이 가능하다. 한 번 루팅하면 리스폰이 되지 않지만 끊임없이 우리의 친구들이 각종 장비를 보급해준다.
6. 우선 비닐봉지를 들고 다니며 끈을 구하자. 가죽끈을 얻은 후 창을 만들자. 창은 유리조각과 끈 긴 나무를 조합하여 만드는데 이 게임의 근접무기 끝판왕이다. 3타일을 남기고 공격이 가능하다. 해보면 알겠지만..
7. 이 게임의 전투는 누가 먼저 찌르느냐의 전투이다. 안전하게 벽 뒤에 숨어 적이 다가오길 기다렸다가 3타일 남았을 때 힘껏 찌르자. 운이 좋아 상대방이 넘어지면 냅다 달려가서 배를 힘껏 차서 스턴에 빠뜨린 후 가볍게 창질을 하자. 홈리스의 흉포함을 다른 루터에게 푸는 것이다. 스트레스 관리는 이렇게 한다.

루팅을 하다보면 대망의 쇼핑카트가 나온다. 이 쇼핑카트는 단점이 있는데 전투중에 뛸 수가 없다. 걱정하지말자. 위험하면 쇼핑카트를 버리면 된다. 나중에 가보면 쇼핑카트가 버려져 있을 것이다. 다시 줏어서 쓰자.

시작하자마자 동쪽으로 뛰어가라. DMC라는 도시가 있는데 그곳에서 우리는 희망을 얻을 수 있다. 약 4개의 집단이 그 앞에서 치고받고 싸운다. 매일 아침 일어나 마당에 가 보면 각종 장비와 총기류가 널렸다. 총알을 분해하고 총만 수거해서 팔자. 총알은 후일을 위해 보관하자.

8. 운이 좋다면 가드의 장비를 통째로 얻을 수 있으며 군용 가방 역시 얻을 수 있다. 기분좋게 장비를 세팅하고 쇼핑카트를 끌고 템을 수거하자. 

준비가 되었으면 슬슬 메인퀘스트를 진행한다. 지금껏 모은 능력과 기술을 총집합해서 퀘스트를 하자. 경비병 옷을 풀로 입었다면 대부분의 적들은 당신의 눈을 피하려 할 것이다. 

그럼 즐거운 홈리스 시뮬레이터를 하시길!

14614135.review:
Imagine if wasteland, Fallout, and stalker all came together and had an orgy. This is their love child. Hands down one of the best survival games I've ever played.

Pretty much nails every aspect of survival as it should. Unlike most games you actually have to boil water, not eat every berry you find and not just place a cloth on a severe cut. The thing is if you have knowledge to survive in the wilderness in real life it makes this game a bit easier to play.

I say a bit easier because in reality this can be a very difficult game. Expect to die loads of times before getting the hang of things. However, the game is fun and different enough on each playthrough to keep you going. Lots of times you might run across events or other things that you haven't before.

Another reason I love this game is all the twists and turns you'll go through when you start uncovering the well hidden story in newspapers and when you first wake up.

The game doesn't look bad and definitely gives me nostalgia to those old post-apocalyptic video games. You can do pretty much whatever you want to. If you want to run at a guy wielding an ak-47 with a stick, you can. If you want to run around naked stealing other people's stuff, you can. If you want to make a suit of tinfoil and become a crazy hobo you can.

There is music in the game and it's pretty good, almost sounding like something that would be in the half life series. Sometimes the only sounds you'll hear is the various birds and critter chatter giving you a real sense of isolation. Although when you spot an event or something interesting one of the tracks might start up providing a cool atmosphere.

It's really hard to talk about this game without spoiling anything, but what I can say it's one of the best survival post-apocalyptic games out there. So while you can go running through the woods butt-naked, you can also try and discover who you are and what exactly happened to the world around you. The choice is yours.

14604597.review: The gameplay itself is simple and uncomplicated and the whole setting is equally involving; there's so much to explore, which is a big plus.  However, the game's mechanics can be set a little too high.  Deleting saved games when your character dies (which can be a little too easy at times) makes it extremely difficult to actually explore a world that's otherwise very interesting.  No amount of wit or cunning will help when you're ambushed by three to four feral dogs simultaneously while sleeping and ripped apart in a hopeless battle with no escape.  However, the fact that the game is extremely mod-friendly (with a whole section devoted to it on their website) redeems the game, enabling the player to customize their game to their own individual preferences.  The basic "out-of-the-box" game itself is hard, but the mods can make it as challenging as the player wishes.

14599292.review:
One of the mistakes people make when first playing this game is assuming it is unrelentingly hard just because you die a lot; it isn't. It just doesn't have a tutorial, and is very strict. You'll die, but those deaths are not random; they are because of some mistake you made. Learn from it. Don't die that way next time. And don't forget your skills; if you die of poisoning try to figure out why and not do it again. Maybe it had something to do with those mushrooms you ate? or that rancid swamp water you drank? Did you die of Sepsis? Then maybe try keeping your wounds clean instead of rubbing dirt in them.

Once you get into the swing of things, it isn't hard to survive, and luck starts to be a fairly minor factor. This can take a bit of learning; even poring over the wiki isn't going to totally familiarize yourself with the mechanics, but it is a good idea to use the wiki for craftables. Not necessary, but helpful.

One last bit of advice: there's no 100% completion for this game, so keep in mind you do not have to complete every challenge you come across. In fact, you shouldn't try; no character can handle all challenges. Pick your battles, and don't be afraid to run away, even if you are a full combat character. 

Most of all, the game is turn based. Take your time, think things through, and use your skills.

I was surviving for a week. Had a scoped rifle with some ammo hanging on my shoulder, a broad spear in my hand, I was in some army shoes, a nice pair of cargo pants, a hoodie with 3 layers of stuff underneath which was perfect for the weather. Had drinkable water for days, even more food, a full medkit, more stuff in my travois. Had an impressive kill-streak behind me.

I was walking towards a town when I heard a rumble of a car's engine from somewhere in the town. It was there for a brief moment and then it faded. I was not far from "Zom-Zom".

Feeling sleepy. I set up a camp with a fire in a small house, place some noise-traps around.
Just killed 2 dogs on my way here. Poor creatures. But they didnt die in vain. I skinned them. Roasted their meat.
Ate a chunk. Mmm... Wonder how it was before. I chuckled, ironically, because I can't remember a thing. But it doesn't matter now. Not here. The only things that matter here are skills and luck. And I had plenty. For now.
Tomorrow I am going to scavenge the area around "Zom-Zom" and finally deсide whether I want to go in or not.

It was late in the night. Had no watch to prove it to myself, but I had no need in that. I found a spot to lie down. Closed my eyes.
 I faded out quickly which is a rare thing to encounter being insomniac.

Then someone slit my throat with a glass shiv while I was sleeping.
10/10 Would die again.

NEO Scavenger is relentlessly brutal, surprisingly nuanced, and unapologetically old-school.

14534269.review:
This is one of the most interesting and engaging games that I have ever played. The game blends elements of the rougelike genre and the turn based strategy genre to make a very unique experience.

 Because of the permenant death feature, you can't just start from a previous save when you die, and you will die..... a lot, it is NOT an easy game. That being said, the permenant death system also allows for a lot of really tough decisions about how to use your resources. As hard as it is to decide if you should drink the water that may or may not be contaminated is, the game takes it a step further.

 You will encounter various, random scenarios where the game will go out of it's way to put you in the most difficult position that it possibly can. These situations rarely result in your immediate death (although it is possible), but choosing if you should pay bandits with fresh water to free a woman who's baby they have just cooked and eaten is not exactly an easy choice when you are suffering from cholera and your dehydrated.

 Even though there are a ton of tough decisions, at least you get to take all the time you need to make a decision. The turn based strategy format allows you to take all the time you need to carefully consider the decion you are about to make. This limitless time is often needed not just for scenarios like the one above, but also in combat. The combat system is surprisingly very deep. You are offered tons of options for what do do on a specific round in the combat. The game even goes as far as to allow you to attempt to tackle the other person, or in some cases leg trip them.

 Although it certainly isn't for a casual gamer, if you are a fan of rougelikes, enjoy a deep strategy game, or are interested in a new experience, this is certainly worth a try.

14527229.review:
Picked this up on a lark, as I am heavily into survival games lately. I was hesitant due to the low res, pixel graphics, but man am I glad I took a chance on this!

What stands out immediately is choice and consequence. You can't have it all. You have to build a character with weaknesses, and weaknesses can just be not having some of the skills you might like to have, or it can be actual weaknesses to give you points to get more benefits.

You might take Fragile for example, making you take more damage than normal if you get hit, and you might do this because you really want the points it gives you to take Trapping so you can make fire right away at the start of the game.

You might take Strong so you can carry more and Melee so you can close combat better, but this might mean you don't get Ranged skil and therefore cannot make arrows, and have limited range skill with guns and other range weapons.

Anyway, you make your choices and take your shot. Into the game you go and immediately your character choices effect your first encounter, in terms of whether you survive, escape, get hurt or kick the ass of the first opponent.

You survived the fight (maybe) and now you gotta get fire, you gotta get a weapon, you need clothing, you need shelter, you need a supply of food and water, and you need to get these things without attracting too much attention from the local wildlife. How you do this is up to you and there is little to no help from the game. You gotta figure it out, and fast, cause you are getting cold and soon you'll be needing somewhere to sleep.

RnG can help you or hurt you here, and at first I was like, well you need some good rolls to start, but later you learn it's more about playing smart, and persistently scavenging until you get what you want.

You have to be concerned about the noise you make, the tracks you leave, and even your scent, as you get through those nail biting first turns until you finally get to the point where you are not struggling and can start to carve your way through the world.

Now you start to get pleasantly surprised because you find there is depth in the game. Depth in the combat system, depth in the crafting system, and it's challenging because you are gonna die if you are not careful. You might kill that wolf, but you took a scratch that is gonna get infected because you didn't find or craft any clean bandages, and haven't managed to find something to act as a dis-infectant. Left untreated this may progress to septis, and ultimately death.

On the other hand, if you are not careful in combat, being tactical, the wolf just may kill you outright.

Items decay, so in the long game you need to be able to get a backup supply... and then you start to find that there is actually a story here... WHAT YOU SAY?!?!?!?! 

I thought I was just enjoying a really great survival game, and BAM... all of a sudden I ran into some story elements and again realize this modest little game is actually filled with depth and fun, and a reason to keep playing, try to live longer, try to figure out just why and how you came to be here, and what you can do to go beyond surviving.

There is a reputation system, and good versus evil behaviour. You can save the damsel in distress or throw in your lot with the bandits. It can be dark, really dark. You don't just kill stuff... you murder it... you rip people apart in scenarios where it's either you or them... fight or die... and sometimes you win just to find out later, you lost.

If you give Neo Scavanger half a chance, you'll find a real gem here. A game which has been clearly and cleverly thought out to provide many hours of entertainment. I'm about 168 hours in as I write this, and still haven't seen 60% of the map. Lots and lots of fun to be had for a bargain basement price! Seriously.. if you like survival, buy this!

14514306.review:
"Le survival game et le roguelike sont des genres ayant quelques liens. Il y a même des roguelike survival, l'un des meilleurs représentants de la chose étant UnReal World, un freeware sorti à l'origine en 1992 – et en ASCII même s'il a subit des mises à jour graphiques depuis – un roguelike méconnu devenu au fur et à mesure des années un survival hardcore vous emmenant dans des contrées nordiques et glaciales. Aujourd'hui le survival est à la mode, du FPS à la vue top-down, du temps réel au tour par tour, il y en a pour tous les goûts. Aussi, s’il existe des jeux accessibles comme Don't Starve qui reprennent beaucoup de mécaniques au roguelike, on était en droit d’attendre un réel roguelike survival. Voici Neo Scavenger, fruit du travail d'un seul homme : un ancien de Bioware ayant quitté le studio pour faire les jeux dont il rêvait, sans compromis. Et force est de constater qu'il a réussi.

Neo Scavenger – à l'instar de UnReal World – est un roguelike survival hardcore, simulationniste. S'il ne brille pas par sa création de personnage, il arrive à proposer un coté RPG un peu plus poussé que d'habitude grâce à un scénario, des dialogues, et autres événements, le tout sous forme de phases textuelles vous laissant le soin de prendre des décisions et qui ne sont pas sans rappeler les LDVELH. Ce n'est pas un jeu parfait et il abîmera les pupilles de certains d'entre vous. Son coté hardcore le réserve à un type de joueur masochiste dont je suis fière de faire partie. C'est un ovni du survival qui réussit, malgré un gameplay finalement classique, à être extrêmement complet, immersif et différent de la production récente. C'est un pauvre jeu codé sous Flash et créé – on ne peut en douter – avec amour et passion."

Si vous désirez en savoir plus, je vous invite à aller lire ce test : http://www.rpgfrance.com/test-10225-1-neo-scavenger 
Et je vous assure que Neo Scavenger mérite que l'on s'interesse à lui.

14511509.review:
While I really like the concept and everything:

1) The menus are clunky.  This whole game revolves around those menus, so the game is clunky.

2) Of the 10 tries or so, my character continually froze to death even if I had layered a shirt over a hoodie with pants and boots and slept in sheltered areas.

3) The combat is awkward and does not feel engaging.

4) Finding something to store my items was extremely difficult, so normally I'd only have a shiv or something.

5) Crafting is strange and it's not clear what you can/should build.  You learn more about what you can make the more you play, and sometimes you even find recipes, but finding those items again by the time you need them seems somewhat unlikely.

I feel like this could be spruced up and be far more exciting, but as it currently stands I cannot recommend it.

14383218.review:
Frustration does not even begin to sum up the experience of this game. Neither does satisfaction. This is a game where complacency costs you 12 hours of gameplay in a single stupid decision. 

Neo Scavenger pits you, an unarmed - clueless - protagonist against a motley crew of the worst of the worst. Thrown into a post-apocalyptic world with naught but a hospital gown, you must find clothing to stave off pneumonia. Shelter to rest in. A campsite to stash your laughable scavenged loot - there are no infinite backpacks in this game, you're limited to a realistic carrying amount. Want to pick up a shopping trolley to carry more stuff in? Fine, but it'll cost you; reduced speed, inability to run, being burdened, easier for enemies to pick you off. 

Neo Scavenger has a learning curve that is frustratingly high. You will not survive for more than a few hours on your first dozen runs. The first time you think you're playing well, you've maybe got a rifle, 3 or 4 rounds, a place to call home, and some futuristic technology - such as a water purity tester, but then you get cocky. You don't come back to your camp before it's dark, and suddenly you're pulling in a shopping cart 3 hours of work that you refuse to drop, and so you're caught by a group of looters or raiders, and you're dead in a matter of seconds - you're dead before you even realise it. 

This is an ultimate game of survival. You really need to think every decision you make out. There is a feel of grinding to it - you spend hours going from ruin to ruin looting nothing but trash, you stop to scavenge some berries for food and water, then you go back to camp, drop anything of value off, and restart again, slowly finding 1 bullet here, 1 course of antibiotics there, etc. There is a storyline to this game, and various amusing NPCs/Cities in the game for you to explore.

I also feel there really does need to be some sort of step back from the permadeath element. I'm not saying there should be an autosave feature every turn, but some sort of progress saving feature that compensates you from a death due to extreme randomness. For instance I died in the main city of the game due to an ingame mechanic that simply had my character hit by a car randomly while walking the streets, game over, start again from turn 1. That's just outright not fair, and impossible to avoid. 

Anyway, fantastic game for those out there who enjoy a challenge. You will hate this game for a very long time, but also love it.

14300663.review:
Never let it be said that you need a tripple A studio, an army of designers, developers and artists, and boundless resources to make a game that's challenging and fun.

Neo Scavenger is a breath of nostalgic air, harping games like Wasteland and Fallout, but with the new hardcore survival-style normally only found in modern titles like Rust. 

Just a dash of RPG elements, an elloquent crafting system and an intense focus on resource management (though "scrabbling" might be the better word) the world of NS is a brutal one.

Combat is surprisingly deep considering it takes place almost entirely through text, and often results in a desperate brawl. You'll never be too well equipped, as even the best gear can't save you from some of the nasties out there. 
Planning, tactics and luck will see you through though!

That being said, it's not perfect. There's a few terrible bugs, save games can be lost, and the nature of RNG can sometimes leave the player in unfortunate or outright unfair situations. Balance and tweaking post release will likely fix this.

But if you've missed games that punish you, or just have masochistic tendancies then this is the game for you.

14185275.review:
This is a wonderful game.  It is unforgivingly difficult, but very satisfying when you weather the storm and stabilize.

It allows many viable builds which will vary your play style significantly, although you will always play as a desperate scavenger.  Learning the survival systems and how to manage each is fun and engaging.  And it always feels wonderful when you discover the tools you need to make it another few days be it the means to make fire, clothes to stay warm, something to boil water in, or a large bag/sled to haul your stuff.

Although it seems unfair at times (such as when you are killed in your sleep without a chance to act) the real choice you made came earlier when you did (or were not able to) make a safe camp with noise traps.

I have one major gripe with the game is that the story elements, while immersive, tend to be too deadly, either ending your run prematurely, forcing you into a trial and error state to learn the proper choices, or spoiling the story by looking up the solution on the wiki.  While the rest of the game is fair but difficult, and revolves around the choices/play style of that run, these only involve foreknowledge of what is coming up and the time it took to prepare for it.

Even so, it remains one of the best indie games I've ever played.

14127261.review:
A "game" with no gameplay elements.

Every aspect of the game is completely random and simply beyond your control. No skill or tactics to employ, just plain old luck determines whether you'll live each day. Combine this with permadeath, and you find yourself stuck replaying the same day over and over again, having about as much fun as Bill Murray did when caught in the same loop.

I'm being serious, you can fall, cut yourself, and die of blood loss just from *walking* if that's how the dice roll (advancing in combat carries the chance to trip and fall). Whether or not you find shoes and clothes in time to keep warm and not die from hypothermia, pure luck. Whether you wake up in time to defend yourself before an enemy kills you in your sleep, pure luck. Whether you can actually get to sleep because it's random whether or not you'll find a sleeping bag and it rains constantly... again, luck. Whether your very first fire started in a burnt out office building because you are hiding from the rain with nothing but a hospital gown and a large stick attracts an entire pack of feral dogs who you literally have zero chance against... need I go on?

There's just no meaningful interaction. All of your equipment wears out shockingly fast and it's a crapshoot whether you'll find a replacement. At times it feels like a miracle during an encounter just to close the gap to an enemy without tripping over yourself and falling to the ground before you can poke 'em with your spear. Start a fire to keep warm and attract an enemy you aren't ready to deal with. Lay low and hide, die of hypothermia. Damned if you do and damned if you don't. Either option is viable based solely on luck. You're not playing a game so much as just watching the unluckiest man on Earth die over and over again.

There is no character progression. You know how to make everything right away. Just put all of your swag into the crafting table and whatever can be made is instantly available. However good you are at fighting and surviving from the moment you wake up is as good as you're ever gonna be. All of your equipment has a ridiculously short lifespan. So even if you find a really good anything, don't get attached. Even crowbars wear out... CROWBARS! Solid bars of pure steel... wear out.  Seriously?

There's just no feeling of accomplishment. None. If you manage to survive for a week, it's not because you did anything right, you just got lucky. A first playthrough can net you shoes, cargo pants, a hoodie, a multitool, and a saucepan after 12 hours of scavenging. A second playthrough can net you a cut arm, 200 pebbles, a handful of poison berries, and 3 shards of glass after 12 hours of scavenging. The player is reduced to the role of spectator of the very short and uninteresting life of some guy named Phillip.

Without engagement, without meaningful choices to make, without progression, there's just no game here.

14107879.review:
I don't normally recommend games that I have no intention of finishing, but this one has enough depth and originality that I'll make an exception for it.  If an unforgiving TBS game that features old-school second-person narration*, puts you in the role of an amnesiac cryonics patient who wakes up in a hostile post-apocalyptic world, and forces you to realistically manage every aspect of your well-being with meager supplies sounds like something you'd enjoy, I can safely say you won't be disappointed.  It exceeded my expectations, which were admittedly low, in part because of the uncreative title (but ultimately, it just wasn't my cup of tea).  The one thing I think needs an overhaul is the combat.  It feels tedious and, in contrast with the rest of the game, unrealistic.  It feels unrealistic when my adversaries are fellow human scavengers but never say anything before or while attacking me, and it feels unrealistic when, after beating a guy so badly that the game describes him as being in severe pain, coughing up blood, suffering from a concussion, and blacking out, he nonetheless refuses to surrender and continues trying to kill me.  Still, that's only a problem because this is a game that focuses on realistic survival simulation rather than combat, making it a relatively small complaint.

*It does not, however, stick to second-person, and instead frequently refers to the player literally as "player", which is annoying and breaks immersion, but now I'm just nitpicking.

14105922.review: If Omega (a very early massive PC roguelike), Wasteland (first PC post-apocalyptic roleplaying game), and Shadowrun had three-way that somehow resulted in a retro-graphic third-person isometric RPG with a vague but cool storyline, this would be it. The strongest parts of this game are not what is said, but rather what is left unsaid. It is terrifyingly addictive, and has a great deal of replay value. Personally, I am eagerly anticipating the mods to come, and would gladly pay money dollars for additional DLC. It's that good.

A small cut can turn into a life threatening infection to not having shoes to walk across the map.  It is a very brutal and unforgiving game, but rewards you greatly when you manage to survive long enough to reach a town or even establish a base.

14054199.review:
Get this game only if you like hardcore roguelike games that doesn't give you any slake. While I enjoyed the fact that this game seemed to be a love letter to Fallout 1/2 with it's turnstyle controls and combat, the luck factor in this game will often be against you if you are starting out. You will die a LOT in the first playthroughs, but if you retain your experiences from those playthroughs you'll be able to survive long enough to progress on the storyline.

It is a good survival game that is worth the price but my only complaints are that it feels a bit empty what with only a handful of locations to visit on a giant map. There are random encounters, but most of the time, they tend to be to your disadvantage unless you save beforehand. The major thing is that this game has permadeath ie. you lose EVERYTHING when you die...including your savefile. Unless you manage to make a backup of your savefile, you will have to start at the beginning everytime you die and that will be the breaking point for gamers interested in getting this.

Finally, my last grip is that there will be no new content added to the game by the creator. However, there is a growing Mod community for the game an the creator made the game itself to be moddable. Hell you can even play around with the xml file of the game itself to adjust the game to your liking, though you'll have to go to the game's forums to learn more on that.

All in all, if you enjoy survival turnbased games dealing with post-apocalypse and supernatural themes with good story, crafting and (more importanly) mods to extend the game , then buy this. If not, then Project Zomboid might be more your thing.

14032132.review:
Ugh.  Let me just sum up my buyer's remorse with two points on why I do not recommend this game:

1.) It plays as badly as it looks -- turns out this isn't one of those indy 'ugly duckling' games that have outdated graphics but excellent content and playability.  The graphics, story and gameplay are all sloppy.  Not to mention the previews are misleading.

2.) The game relies purely on difficulty to make this a survival game, lacking any of the richness I was expecting given the high praise among the Steam community.  One would expect that a game rated so highly would have sacrificed looks for content, and it certainly is lacking in both -- instead it's a series of instant-death by storyline misadventure or because the character is about as hardy and resiliant as wet one-ply toilet paper... despite being 'tough'.

I wanted to have some nice things to say about this game, but I really can't find anything worth the $15.  I would argue this should be considered no more than a $2 curiosity than a game worth the developer's asking price.

13974123.review: Neo Scavenger is like leaving school. You are thrust into the real world, with no idea what to do. Everything is strange, but you learn. You Survive. You thrive. Then you die of hypothermia.

13972795.review:
After hours of hard work and days of in-game hard-earned survival, I was well off: a cart to carry all of my heavy items that would bog me down in combat, two compound bows stocked with arrows (enough to take down pretty much anything before it even knew what hit it), enough provisions to last until judgement day, and my trusty spear should things get a little too close for comfort. I set up camp for the night in a dense bit of brush, threw together a lean-to using a tarp I took off the corpse of some raider who thought he'd take me for all I was worth, laid out my sleeping bag, and went down for the night. 
Around 2 AM I was awoken by a massive *crack* in the woods near my position. Suddenly I remembered forgetting to hide my tracks, that's how it found me: a savage creature the size of a truck with teeth and claws protruding like foot-long razors. It saw me before I saw it, and that was all it took. Its claws tore across my chest before I knew where the danger was coming from sending blood flying all over the campsite along with what focus my eyes had achieved in the 5 seconds since their rude awakening. I was able to bring up my spear before the next attack landed and sliced open the creature's powerful arm, interrupting its strike. Vision fading quickly, I lunged. The beast let loose a shriek as the spear found its mark and dove deeper, piercing the heart. I'm not sure what gave out first, my legs or the crumpled heap of what was once the hulking black monstrosity.
Somehow I dragged myself to my backpack and fished out some rags. I quickly bandaged the massive gash in my chest, ever mindful that giving in to the swirling blackness meant never waking up. I popped a couple of strong painkillers and some antibiotics to ward off the inevitable infection that comes with a reused bandage (like there was any other choice) and retreated back into the safety of my lean-to to rest and give my wounds time to heal.
I must have dozed off, I'm not sure, all I remember is the pain. The incredible pain that only follows a crowbar being slammed into your knee. 
Two thugs stood over me, wearing what appeared to be the mismatched hides of dozens of small animals. I didn't even have time to cry out in pain before the the bigger of the two brought his crowbar down again, silencing me permanently.
My vision churned and faded as I fell to the ground. Lying in an ever-growing pool of my own blood, my last sight was the assailants as they picked apart the life I had fought so hard for. As my sight turned to black, I had only one final thought:
I should have stayed in that cryotube...

Like an abusive relationship with a man who hates me, I keep coming back 
11/10

13951741.review:
Very fun game. Honestly, there isn't really much I would recommend that the developers change, they were very thorough in making this game. Certainly nothing game-breaking (so far). Bugs are non-existant as far as I can tell.* Lot's of fun for the file size. It has a sense of brutality without relying on gore to get the message across. 

I recommend when you play this game that you do *not* look anything up first. The game is intuitive, and a great deal  of fun can be had by messing up. This is a great game for just getting on and having fun. 

If I had to think of a downside, it would be difficult but I would say there are two. The first would be that it is simple, and those that want fancy 3d graphics or a complex game should look to a different genre altogether. Second would be replayability. It has a good story, but there is something disappointing about each part of the story fleshed out: that's one fewer mystery for later. Of course, you can say that about any story-oriented game. 

Again, I would say that the keyword here is intuitive. Easy to pick up the mechanics, more difficult to use them effectively, but overally the difficulty is anywhere from mild to moderate. This isn't an 'easy' game per-se, but it certainly isn't hard. It is a game where risk and reward are both quite high in most encounters. A small slip up can cost you dearly, a well timed strike can earn you incredibly useful loot, so long as you have the space to carry it all. By far the most scarce resource in the game is space. You can't carry everything you find in the beginning, so deciding what is most valuable can be a very tough decision.

All of the above serve to make it the ideal rogue-like game IMO.

*EDIT: About the bugs, I should mention that there is a minor graphics bug where items will appear partly off-screen, and cannot be selected from boxes. This is uncommon, however, and easily fixed by switching between fullscreen and minimized (you can end in whatever screen you prefer). Probably not worth mentioning except that I had said "Bugs are non-existant as far as I can tell."

EDIT 2: One other critisism: This game does not offer difficulty settings at this time. Initially, it seems difficult. After a few hours, it does seem slightly easy. Hopefully that will change in time, but with a sense of ease often comes recklessness (at least in my case), counteracting any potential for this game to become boring. It still remains a very fun game, and I look forward to updates.

RNG + Grindfest + Enforced micromanage = This. Making a meh-ish game is one thing, but watering it down with RNG poopfest is definitely over the line. Even the infamous Dungeon Crawl tries to make randomness controllable, and this... 'game' is just... too much.

At least in other roguelikes, you get to choose starting options. BALANCED AND MULTIPLE OPTIONS, IN DETAIL. Instead in this 'game', we get take-it-or-leave-it starter's kit with Tetris level freedom of choice. If you can't get to skin the Dogman at the start, you're likely to end up dead like 10 minutes after.

Say that you made the build, got the coat. Well, congratulations, you completed requirement for 30-minute survival. Enjoy so-oh-fucking-much-DayZ-like loot grindfest. Let's scavenge this! Duh, empty!  And this! Yes, we got completely useless shirts and jeans!

...While managing god-awful award-winning inventory. It's complete nightmare : tiny tiny single slot items, liquids being treated as individual items, all those junk items with no clear given use or whatsoever. Whatever you craft, it it's makeshift, expect them to be broken down like 10 minute later.

If the progression of game itself was fun, I'd bear it. But in this game... it's like kicking the same old ground. Scavenge, find shit, make shit, scavenge more, rinse and repeat.

But even with all these shits, I guess people will still play it, because of it being 'Unique'. Well tell you what, go play Unreal World instead. The game is older, with more contents and more things making sense, and less HARDCORE RNG SUHVIVORR bullshit.

A very unique gameplay experience. Here was my first time playing.

Day 1:
What is this place? Oh interesting. So we have cryo chambers. this game is pretty nic-
OH MY GOD WHAT IS THAT
*uses the power of nature to kill a lethal creature*
cool.
*climbs out window and doesnt bleed from chards for some reason*
Time to explore.
*time passes*
ooh, whats this? I'm...shivering?
Huh I better find clothes.
*time passes*
I'm thirsty? better drink this river water.
{PLAYER HAS DIAREHHA}
WHAT? WHEN DID THIS HAPPEN?
*time passes*
Oh god im freezing to death and now im hungry.
*night time*
I'll sleep in this abandoned office building.
{PLAYER HAS DIED FROM HYPOTHERMIA}

Wow.

Very tough and will take many tries to actually live long.

I think this game is a " [url=http://www.dontstarvegame.com/] Don't Starve [/url] " like game where you try to avoid dying as long as possible. It's going to happen. It's rogue-like and very tough. Whether you die from Hunger, Thirst, Hypothermia, or Diarrhea, this game will still be memorable.

PROS AND CONS:
----------------------------------------
+ Customizable stats. You can be very tough or an electrician, whatever floats your boat.
+ Very hard. This game shows no mercy and shoves you right in. (googling crafting tutorials might be smart)
+ Crafting. This game is full of unique crafting where you can craft anything from a fire to a wheelbarrow.
+ Interacting with others. It feels like it isnt just you out there. The world is bustling with Raiders, Looters, and nice people who you can kill, steal from, or just say hi to.
+ Strategical fighting. The first game I've ever seen with a "Threaten" option in the middle of combat.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
- Single Player only. This game would be boring with multiplayer, but I wanted to note this just in case you didnt know.
- Loot Spawning. Sometimes you'll find nothing in a locked shed. Sometimes in an empty field you'll find a loaded shotgun. The loot spawns sometimes are unrealistic.
- 2D artstyle. I personally am ok with the 2D, but it must be noted you are buying a 2D game.
- Unusual death. Sometimes you will be well fed, well quenched, and well slept, but die in your sleep from a monster.

I overall would give this game an 8/10.

13825448.review:
[u][b]ATMOSPHERE:[/b][/u]
You (a random guy) wake up from a cryogenic sleep chamber, and have no recollection of anything. Not even who you are. Your goal is to make it to "The Glow" or Detroit Mega City as you may learn to call it both. Your goal is to make it here, exploring along the way, better equipping yourself with the task of finding out who you are. 
This is how I would imagine a post-apocalyptic Detroit happening.
Constantly being bombarded by the ruthless Dogmen, and Bad Muthas, a Detroit street gang of brutal, thuggish cannibals who will NOT hesitate to attack you on sight. Also strangers and looters equipped with scoped hunting rifles, and Detroit Mega City Guards with rifles, shotguns, and full SWAT-type gear ready to exterminate you.
You will be excited as ever to just find a pair of old plastic shopping bags and a shard of glass or a broken bottle to arm yourself with. Every little space in your inventory counts, so space management is almost as important to your survival as dealing with combat scenarios with a cool, calm, level head.

[u][b]GAMEPLAY:[/b][/u]
You will need to scavenge for loot while maintaining low visibility, otherwise if you think you're tough enough you can brazenly move into an abandoned building, scavenge it loudly and roughly, and hope someone or something doesn't hear or see you. 
The choices you make for every little situation in this game need to be approached with clear thinking, and taking into account repercussions of your actions is seriously encouraged for this experience.

You will have random encounters within the story line and others along your travels.
You may succomb to diseases from exposure to sick people, bad weather (hypothermia and pneumonia), food poisoning, and even BREATHING toxic fumes over time.

You will wake up to people stealing your supplies and food or attempting to bash your skull in with a stone. Then be forced to make the decision to flee in complete terror, sneak up on the thief in the dark and take them by surprise, or just stand up from your sleep and attack them in a raging fury.

If you can get past the clunky UI and lack of animation or intimate graphical control, this game is a dirty gem just waiting to be appreciated by the next "arachaeologist" who finds it. I never pictured myself enjoying a game that's 60% text-based, but I quickly fell in love with this game. Here, you can learn quickly from past mistakes and keep pushing forward. If you ever thought it was hard to survive in other "survival" games, this is [i]FAR[/i] more unforgiving but also more rewarding to experience. True-to-life combat system that allows your simplest mistakes to be exploted by your enemy, possibly resulting in your death or serious injury.

[u][b]OVERALL RATING OUT OF 10:[/b][/u]
9.5/10
Even if you hate text-based games, or games with hexes (I certainly did), you may find yourself immersed and deeply invested into this game. I [b]highly[/b] recommend this for anyone who appreciates post-apocalyptic roleplaying games and/or heavy survival. Even at full retail price this is a worthwhile purchase. The game has a few flaws, but all are so minor and outweighed greatly by what [b]good[/b] there is in the game that you quickly forget they exist or have trouble noticing them to begin with. Very reminiscent of the first game of the Fallout series, more so than the second, but this game has its own unique flavour.

13823902.review:
This game is really, really good.  It's got an interesting story, but you can ignore it and carve out your own tale if you so choose.

However, I feel there are two problems with this game:

Firstly, the world seems pretty much dead.  Except for one story location, there doesn't seem to be anyone anywhere except hostile bandits and looters who are willing to not murder you on sight if you agree to not murder them on sight.  In my opinion, the world should feel just a little bit more alive.

Secondly, the game is TOO brutal.  I get that it's a roguelike and roguelikes are supposed to be tough, but there's a lot of things that, quite frankly, are full of shit.

I once stabbed a guy with a long, pointed tree branch made into a spear.  According to the game text, I viciously stabbed his upper stomach, and according to the in-game status text, he was bleeding heavily, in shock, and on the ground.  Somehow he managed to knock me out in one punch, steal my spear and backpack, and run away before I woke up, got an infection and died.

Several times I've started a brand new game just to not find any early game drops and freeze to death within a minute.  No hyperbole, I died within a single minute of starting a new game thanks to the RNG.  Other times I'll be walking around the game world and suddenly I've got diiarhea and I'm vomiting and my stomach hurts and I'm dead.


Don't get me wrong, this game is loads of fun to play and you should definitely give it a try if you like roguelikes and randomly-generated game worlds, but there's a lot of things that make me scream and swear at the game when I really shouldn't be.

Overall, I would indeed recommend this game.  7.8/10

13815917.review:
Bogata mechanika i losowy charakter rozgrywki gwarantują, że każde podejście to nowa, niepowatrzalna przygoda. Niech archaiczna grafika nikogo nie zwiedzie, lepiej zaprojektowanej i bardziej przemyślanej gry w 2014 roku nie było, a i na przestrzeni lat podobnego poziomu trudno się doszukać.

NIech za przykład posłuży fakt, że umrzeć tu można zarówno od ran odniesionych w walce, jak i od szeregu chorób czy przypadłości, jak zakażenie, sepsa, zapalenie płuc, grypa, wyziębienie, przegrzanie, odwodnienie, zawał serca, choroba popromienna i inne, a konkretna przyczyna zgonu najpewniej będzie spowodowana poczynaniami gracza - przykładowo trujące owoce spowodują biegunkę, ta doprowadzi do odwodnienia (którego da się uniknąć pijąc wodę - oczywiście przegotowaną, brudna woda tylko pogorszy sprawę), a odwodnienie do śmierci. By nie spożyć trujących owoców, musimy mieć umiejętność "Botanika" - bez niej nie poznamy się na leśnych owocach - lub pozyskać je z pewnego źródła (np. od handlarza). Zawsze możemy nie zjeść owoców i głodować. Wodę też zazwyczaj sami musimy sobie przygotować - pitna woda jest w tej grze rzadkim luksusem. Potrzebujemy do tego ogniska - sami je sobie rozpalamy, a jeśli nie mamy umiejętności "Łowiectwa" ("Trapping"), to potrzebujemy źródła ognia - oraz garnka, w którym brudną wodę umieścimy, a którego poszukiwanie może nam zająć dni, których możemy nie mieć, jeśli wcześniej nie znajdziemy sobie odpowiedniego odzienia, by uniknąć wyziębienia. Do tego trzeba zadbać o bezpieczny nocleg...

Z takimi dylematami musi sobie radzić gracz na początku każdej przygody, przynajmniej do czasu, gdy nie dotrze do siedliska cywilizacji - o ile oczywiście zamierza, bo rozgrywka jest otwarta i można równie dobrze założyć obóz w środku "nigdzie" i polować na grasujących po okolicy psoludzi ("dogmen"). Bez wględu na obraną drogę im dalej jesteśmy, tym większą mamy satysfakcję z tego, co osiągnęliśmy, ale i tym więcej mamy do stracenia, bo śmierć jest permanentna. To sprawia, że biorąc pod uwagę złożoną mechanikę gry, musimy zważać na każdy krok, bo zaniedbanie nawet małego, przypadkowego zadrapania może nas zaprowadzić do grobu.

W skrócie gorąco polecam wszystkim, a w szczególności tym, którzy poszukują złożonej, wymagajacej rozgrywki pełnej swobodnych wyborów, ale i twardych konsekwencji oraz wszelkim fanom survivalu, post-apo i podobnych klimatów. Dla mnie najlepsza gra roku 2014.

13805141.review:
[h1]Attack of the Barefoot Cannibalistic Showroom Dummies[/h1]

Two days into my first successful venture into NEO Scavneger, I've resorted to cannibalism. It's not like I really had to - I was taking a nap in a small city when a stranger woke me up. I was pissed. I took his soul away with a crowbar and noticed that I'm a bit hungry. Checked it - yes, not surprising - I can use a shard on the corpse and scavenge myself some tasty human meat. Two hexes later in the woods, I've made myself a nice BBQ and I'm feasting on that human.

As I chew on what was just two hexes ago my rival in an unfair fight, I am suddenly overcome with  disgust. I could have just left the corpse there, and move on to hunt a squirrel or pick some non-poisonous berries. Yet I chose to eat that person. And before doing that I looted him of his hoodie which was in a better condition.

But karma got to me quick. I was quickly poisoned in some mysterious way and then something wielding a 12-Gauge Shotgun blew me to bits, all my progress and looting down the drain.

NEO Scavenger can be really daunting at first; you'll die a lot. But once you pick it up - it's hard to put it down. It's a wonderful selfishness simulator that is fun and engaging, built on a fantastic crafting system which brings out the curious child in you. The "old" graphics do not deter from the enjoyment, quite the opposite – they only make it eerier and more atmospheric. The soundtrack is great too and generally it feels like a lot of thought was given to the game. 

I haven't delved into the lore of the game yet but there are newspapers lying around with bits of info and it seems that there's a bigger story which unfolds as you manage to survive and stay alive. Unfortunately that's not as easy as it sounds, not at all; you can also go great strides (even without turning into a cannibal) and then get blown away by a shotgun or catch a disease. This could hinder the experience for some players who focus on storylines and want to complete the game – take to heart that this will be [b]VERY HARD[/b]. This game is hardcore as it gets and it doesn't hold your hand at all.

The best advice is to watch let's plays etc and if you do pick up the game, try it for yourself before picking up a guide. You WILL pick up a guide ultimately but try to experience it without any aid at all. It'll produce unique experiences in which you'll end up dead (in your hospital gown usually). 

Overall this is worth much more than its price tag, a very refreshing entry to the world of roguelike which does it very very right - a sort of improved UnReal World with frightening creatures and a darker theme.

13798855.review:
It feels like I've still just scratched the surface but it has been a pretty unique survival roguelike experience that introduces a mix of new mechanics that work together quite well.  

+ character attributes: it's not like a typical roguelike where you have you basic generic stats and grind xp. You pick out traits to help define your character (melee, ranged, mechanic, athletic, strong etc) and can pick weaknesses as well which let you get more points on good traits as a tradeoff and allow you to try to balance unique builds. These attributes influence completely what sort of actions you'll have available to you, how you handle conflicts, crafting, trying to find shelter, heat, food and so on. They define and influence your decisions way beyond the normal str,int,con type character building.

+ crafting : there is quite a complex crafting system in place that is entirely based on resources available and the traits you picked. If you find just the right ingredients in the early game to make a decent weapon or clothes you'll have a much easier time, otherwise you'll want to avoid conflicts and scavange more. 

+(mostly) combat : deciding whether to fight, and how to fight is very important here.. not because you fight all the time but because the stakes are high and a few bad streaks could see you left bleeding in a field far from your shelter. I like this change to slightly more realistic combat. There's no visible health bar, it's all about waiting till you get a chance to strike, wounding your opponent, and then kicking while they are down. Not particularly heroic but if you make a mistake that leaves you vulnerable and they get a hit in, they'll do the same to you. It comes down primarily to trying to get in range for your weapon, stay out of range from theirs, and defend yourself until you have an opportunity. For example, if you have a melee weapon you can try to rush them but you risk falling on your butt at which point you'd be an open target, or you can advance normally but they'll be able to back away. 

- combat balance: My con with this is that your weapons make all the difference and with the random nature and limited weapon types, you can either be useless in combat or feel like there was no risk. In my first play through I believe I hit a guy with a pocket knife like 20 times until he ran away after punching me and then I bled to death. In my second playthrough I tied a knife to a stick to make a spear, with a range of 3 is the longest melee weapon. And then proceeded to kill everyone that didn't have a gun without a scratch because they couldn't get near me without getting stabbed. And those with guns I could sneak on fairly easy and then once I hit them they were too wounded to fight back. It went from combat being impossible to being 'meh'.

13764521.review:
Alright, so you wake up in some abandoned medical research facility, some sort of creature is pounding at the door ahead of you, using your affinity for mechanics, you lock the door and prevent it from getting in. Going outside, you notice its cold, so you scavenge a near by town for clothes, but its too late, you freeze to death.

So one more try. Again, you wake up an abandoned medical facility with a monster pounding at your door. This time, you chose to excell in strength, so you decide to fight this thing head on. You take a few scratches, but otherwise you beat. Using your trapping abilities, you managed to make a cloak out of its fur, keeping you warm for the forseeable future. Right on! so you start scavenging, you come across some food, a butchers knife, so shoes. You are doing pretty good! Buuuuut remember those scratches from before? You never treated them and they got infected, so you die. Again. 

Third times a charm, no? So you start again. You kill the monster, you make a cloak, this time you manage to find some clean rags to cover your wounds and carry on. You scavenge, find a nice ole' shotgun to keep you safe, but you come across a stranger, you don't know much about this person so you ease your way up, you threaten them and they try to run so you blow them away. They start crawling, and you decide to finish them off and loot whats left of the innocent guys corpse. You get a little tired, so you rest in the woods when something wakes you up in the middle of the night. Its a feral dog, and oh shit, youre out of ammo. You decide to stick to beating the thing with the but of your gun, but its no luck. One too many bites means its game over.

Incase you can't tell, you will die a lot in neoscavenger. Like...a lot a lot. The game makes no attempt to hold your hand, and that will inevitably turn some people off, while others will find this a refreshing change of pace. Neo is a tough game for sure, and the survival aspects are fantastic. Of course you have to eat, sleep, drink etc etc but you also have to make sure you don't freeze to death, make sure your wounds are tended to and don't get infected, make sure you have shoes so you don't get blisters on your feet, try and make some interesting moral choices along the way (Do you help the mother and her child escape from the cannibals? How about watching people fight to death in an arena for scraps of food?) 

All in all, I think Neo Scavenger is one of the gems of 2014. I didn't even know about it until searching through steams library. I think if you're a fan of the survival genre and want something that's tactical with a lot of options and a nice change of pace in terms of story other than your typical "Oh my god! Zombies!" schtick, I recommend you check it out.

13719064.review:
A surprisingly deep game about amnesia and survival in a harsh, apocalyptic themed world. Manage food, hunger, body temperature, and injuries and disease while you try to navigate the world avoiding fearsome monsters and people alike. Find the most secure campsite you can and hope that nothing gets the jump on you while you sleep (crafting can help alleviate this issue), encounter different events around the world which will make the world you're inhabiting seem strange, engage in a very deep combat system which has many types of injuries and conditions as well as ways to go about combat, and ultimately try and figure out who 'you' are.

In case barely surviving through the mass consumation of ketchup packets isn't your thing, it's the only game I've ever played where I got into combat wielding a bag of potato chips and pulling an orange toboggan behind me, or after the stars aligned punched somebody so hard in the chest that they died of acute bleeding after one hit.

13705757.review:
I like turn-based games.  I like survival games.  I like rogue-like games.  So a turn-based, rogue-like survival game?  Sign me up!  Except not for this turn-based, rogue-like survival game please.

IMHO rogue-like games like FTL and Don't Starve succeed because they're a streamlined experience, which makes "dying part of the fun".  Starting a new game is always exciting and you're confident you can learn from your past mistakes so you'll survive longer this time 'round.

This is where NEO falls short.  The dev had a vision and built the game to match that vision.  But if his vision of a post-apocalyptic wasteland does not align with your vision of a post-apocalyptic wasteland, prepare to encounter all sorts of frustratingly illogical, immersion-breaking events.

People call FTL brutally hard and overly random, but I "get it" - it makes sense to me when I play.  I can learn from past mistakes and play better.  NEO makes no sense to me.  The game design decisions are just weird, the interface is clunky, the graphics are grotesque.  Dying for no clear reason, when things seem to be going swimmingly right up until you die, *may* be realistic (?) in the dev's world, but not mine.

You get the same kind of all-of-a-sudden deaths in Don't Starve but it's always clear that "I shouldn't have attacked that Pig Man just for kicks" or "I shouldn't have tried to chop that last tree before lighting my campfire" or "I should have abandoned my hunt for gold and hunted berries instead, so I wouldn't starve".

Playing NEO is like being put in a straight-jacket designed by the dev.  "Play my way or not at all".  Okay dude - IF your way makes logical sense and there's a clear progression from A-to-B-to-C-to-You Died.   Going A-to-R-to-D-to-You Died does not help me live longer next time!  

So "I shouldn't scavenge that random house the way I've scavenged every other house so far, because I should have known the roof was going to cave in"?  or "I shouldn't have tried to run away from that particular encounter because I should have known I would trip, fall on my ass and not be able to stand up again even though I'm healthy, rested and well-fed"?  How do I avoid either of those situations next time around?  That's two of the dozens of deaths that will leave you scratching your head going "REALLY?!?".

Forumites will tell you, take this skill, that skill and the other skill and you'll never die.  Okay, but what if I *don't want* to take those three specific skills.  What if I want to build the character *I want to play*?  In that case, prepare for many, many, many frustrating deaths because you're not playing his game the way the Dev wants you to.

I don't get some of these other reviews:  "Dogman killed me while I slept despite the fact that I put down multiple noise traps, Thumb's Up 10/10."  WTF?  Is that a joke?  It's not helpful.  "Stabbed a guy three times then kicked him in the head when he was down.  He was hurt, bleeding out and on the edge of unconsciousness but he got up, landed one lucky punch and I was immediately unconscious, Thumb's Up 10/10".   

Troll reviews like that are turning this Reviews tab into a joke.

13698829.review:
Wow. This game is absolutely fantastic! I've played many games over the years, and I can safely say that this one is the best I've ever played. It ticks all the boxes for me:

1. It's challenging. A game without challenge is pointless. When you first start playing, you will get yourself killed multiple times, in a variety of different ways. This will keep happening unless you engage your brain, and use the tools available to survive. Permadeath means that you can't afford to make mistakes, which makes the game much more intense, and progression is much more fulfilling. I wouldn't have it any other way. 10/10

2. Gameplay. This game is a sandbox turn-based rogue-likeish RPG. Some may not like this sort of game, but I've played many games of this sort, and it's the best of the lot. Most of these sorts of games over-complicate everything, and gameplay suffers as a result. This is not the case for Neo-Scavanger! The sandbox element is the cherry on top - do whatever the hell you want to do. Perfect! :D 10/10

2. Focus is on gameplay and NOT on graphics etc. Too many games these days look nice, but in reality they have no replayability or depth. Neo-Scavanger is the opposite - the graphics and UI allow you to play the game, they are not there to be pretty . It's graphics and art are still great though, proper old-school stuff. Also, there is the added benefit that ANY computer will be able to run this game. It's built in flash, so if your PC can handle some random online flash game, it can handle Neo-Scavanger no problem. 10/10

3. Depth. This game is deep! I have been playing for a few days now, and I have barely scratched the surface. I've just about got the point where I can reliably survive in the wilds, and have yet to actually explore the world. The game is mysterious, it's hard to know what the game will throw at me as I continue to play, and I love that feeling in a game. 10/10

4.Lore and story. I like anything to do with post-apocalytic settings etc, who doesn't? I havn't really played enough to comment on this aspect of the game, but from what I've played so far the writing and story is top-notch. 10/10

5. Thoughtful developers who listen. Having read a few dev posts, it is obvious that they care about this game. They are very open to suggestions and discussion. 10/10

6. Mods. I haven't researched the mods much, but I know that they do indeed exist. Always great to have that option!

Summary: 11/10. Buy this game now! Even if you normally don't like this sort of game, give it a go! It's cheap ;)

13665577.review:
This game is an excellent example of post-apocolyptic, open world Survival games. It combines elements of survival, combat strategy, crafting, perma-death, inventory management, rpg, and a real sense of danger just lurking around every hex -- mostly in that order, I'd say. It's also turn-based rogue-like with the map changing slightly each time you begin a new journey. Do not let the modest graphics fool you -- they will be the least of your concerns, I assure you. 

The combat system is actually rather realistic! Based on the character ablities and flaws you choose from the beginning, the combat system allows you to pick from quite a few options such as Charging your opponent, Headbutting, Tackling them to the ground, franticly retreating, sneaking, taking cover, sneaking behind cover, Offer to Talk, Melee combat, kick while down, shooting a ranged weapon -- too many to name, here. Choose wisely, or face the consequenses. I really enjoy the combat aspect of this game, but I imagine there are lots of players who would perhaps prefer stealth over Strength, and trade-based ablilities such as Botanist or Hacking over Athletisism. You can choose from flaws (Examples: bad metabolism, fatiques faster) as well, which allow you pick another ability or two to boost your luck. And it is almost always luck. 

I'm currently playing a character with the traits Strong, Melee, Athletic, Botany, and for my flaw -Metabolism.

I have no idea who I am, but I appear to be a hulking, savage vegetarian. It's been 14 days, and I've killed at least 24 people -- I'm losing count, and can no longer remember any of their faces. I've been alerting many opportunists while  scavenging with a pickaxe and a lighter, but in turn, I've killed most all of those who couldn't escape. I'm hunting. Am I even human, anymore? At least I haven't resorted to cannibalism... yet.. and I'm sick with infection somehow. I found a couple of white pills, but without any knowledge of what they are, I fear the result. I've made a temporary home in a high-rise for at least 4 days now, only venturing outside to eat berries and mushrooms, and to gather water while I wait out whatever has me sick. Hopefully, I can make it through just one more night.....

I have yet to finish the RPG portion of this game, but so far the stories and context are both quite fun to read.

I played quite a bit before it was released, and it's also available in your browser! I only wish it was multiplayer compatable!!!
