13662598.review:
TLDR:  A good turn based survival game with neat setting and mechanics.

NEO Scavenger is a turn-based survival game whose difficulty I'd call 'tough but fair' once you get the  hang of the mechanics.  You play as Philip Kindred, a man who has lost most of his memories after being rudely awakened from his cryogenic-sleep pod in the near future.  The game is set in post-apocalyptic Michigan, with a mix of supernatural/horror and sci-fi elements.  Overall it reminds me of Fallout 1 and 2 in terms of tone and atmosphere.

Something you should definitely be aware of before buying: Permadeath!  There is only one save slot in NEO Scavenger and when you die the game deletes the savegame, forcing you to start over.  However you can get around this fairly simply by manually backing up your savegame files after you save, so even players who don't like permadeath should still be able to enjoy NEO Scavenger if they save often and remember to back up those save files.  (I believe there is also a mod that adds multiple save slots, or that automatically backs up your save game, or something like that.  I never tried it out myself, so I can't comment on it.)

NEO Scavenger is a text heavy game, and there is no narrator or voice acting.  Talking with friendly NPCs and fighting hostile ones both involve plenty of text.  Not that the game doesn't have a good UI too, but the lore and details of the game are all conveyed through text.

Speaking of which, the story of the game is told rather subtly, which I like but some people might not.  You'll have to search for clues to who you are and what's going on in the world.  Talking to NPCs, investigating strange locations, even simply finding and reading ancient newspaper article could tell you something important about the world of NEO Scavenger.  My point is you are going to have to really explore the game to uncover the plot.

There is an end to the story after which you cannot keep playing, but the game is pretty clear that going to that area is a fairly big deal and you are never forced to do so.

One of my favorite ways NEO Scavenger tells you about the world (and lets you tell the game what sort of person 'your' Philip Kindred is) is through random events.  These events will pop up occasionally as you explore the map, present you with a situation/problem, and a number of choices to deal with said situation/problem.  They're a bit like a single-page Choose-Your-Own-Adventure games.  Though sometimes a bad choice can get you eaten, so keep what I said about backing up your saves in mind if you dislike permadeath.  I've found several dozen of them so far and the choices and their outcomes are generally very satisfying.  There was one that actually let me ask for more information before deciding whether to help a slightly suspicious person, which is something I've often lamented a lack of in other games.

There's also a small modding scene, despite the lack of Steam Workshop support (flash and steam don't work well together apparently).  Check out the forums of the Blue Bottle Games website or Nexus mods for those.

Finally, I just want to mention that the actual total hours I've played this game are at least twice of what Steam says it is.  This is because I bought the game through the developers website and generally play the version I downloaded there.  Speaking of which. if you do decide you want to buy the full game, you can get NEO Scavenger DRM free on Good Old Games, or directly through the Blue Bottle Games website.

13660490.review:
EDIT 10.9.15:

I love this game. One time, I got shot by an arrow. I ducked under cover, then pulled the arrow out. Then I stabbed my assailant to death with it. 

One time, I was attacked by two dogs immediately after starting a game. I was naked (save for a thin hospital gown) and I had no weapons. As they charged me, I grabbed some shards of glass on the ground, and following a lengthy battle that I ultimately won, I used said shards to skin the dogs' carcasses and then made gloves out of them. Then I died of blood loss.

One time, I was attacked in the middle of a stormy night by two mutants trying to steal my shopping cart loaded with supplies. After I brained one of them, the other scattered. I gave chase, and dispatched it following a cross-tile pursuit. However, upon return to my camp, my cart was gone. The mutant corpse, mysteriously absent as well. Using my tracking ability, I followed the thief several tiles down, and discovered it was another mutant, slowly pushing my cart southwest, his deceased comrade most unceremoniously stuffed inside with the rest of the contents. I moved in and caved its skull in with one fell swoop. I felt no pity, no remorse. I really needed those 5 empty bottles.

10/10 excellent post apocalyptic hobo simulator

It's worth noting that there are a lot of mods available that greatly expand the game's potential.

13579889.review:
An awesome survival game.
Challenging to the newer players, and for myself, with about 60 hours in game, still a struggle to stay alive for long lengths of time.

It has multiple playstyles to suit however you'd like to play:
   -Want to be a survivalist who uses ranged weaponry to hunt wild animals? Go for it.
   -Want to use melee weapons, wreaking havoc upon any foe who walks in your path? Go for it.
   -Want to fight for justice, destroying any and all inhumane religious cults that have arisen? Go for it.
   -Feel a need to slaughter any human, animal, or whatever the hell you find in the wasteland? Go for it.
   -Want to knock people out, steal their shoes, and then leave them barefoot in the middle of a wasteland? Go for it.
   -Want to be insane, kill anyone you see, AND become a cannibalistic maniac? I think you know the answer.

With multiple in-game skills, the possibilities are endless.  You can be an overweight combat medic, a melee proficient electrician with a high metabolism, a weak and brittle botanist, an athlete with insomnia; There are many different combinations you can choose from.  You just need to find the right kit to suit yourself- with the ability to deal with freezing weather, wild dog attacks, and insane cultists.

An awesome game that is definitely worth the money.  The creator of the game is very willing to fix bugs, communicates with the players whenever the chance arises, and listens to any and all feedback.
In my book, a definite 10/10

13517884.review:
The main problem with NEO Scavenger is, sadly, the scavenging. While there's a decent bit of good writing to be found,  you'll probably never discover it unless you edit the game files or get incredibly lucky with your scavenging rewards, as health, weariness and thirst tick down with absurd speeds, areas get tapped out of resources in no-time(meaning that setting up a camp, which is necessary unless you get ridiculously lucky finding backpacks, etc. is useless) and all your items decay with ridiculous rapidity, too. 

You'll never really get to actually PLAY the game, is the thing, you'll be stuck doing nothing but grinding berries, cured meat and boiled water(which you can only get if you're lucky enough to find a saucepan), and then when you finally get enough of it to start moving somewhere... your backpack falls apart and you have to leave it all behind.

But, okay, let's say you're good at management and overcome that hurdle. Then you may find one of the twenty or so locations you can interact with beyond scavenging(in a map of thousands of hexes, and only a few of them look any different from the surrounding generic town hexes)... and whatever you do roughly has a 50% chance of instakilling you or losing you all your carried stuff.

So now, good luck, you can do all your grinding again! Hope you're lucky enough to find a saucepan early on this time around, too, or you may as well just restart.

The combat also boasts a lot of choices to make, but it boils down to either: Have a ranged weapon, keep distance, shoot shoot shoot, or have melee weapon, close distance, beat beat beat. A few of the other options might occasionally be tempting if the game gave any indication of how likely they were to succeed or not(say, percentages or odds or something) rather than just vaguely suggesting a "high" or "low" chance(what's high? 50+%? 75+%? 95+%?).

Long story short: Needs more obvious mechanics, needs less busywork to pad out playtime, needs to make consequences of choices more predictable/obvious OR it needs some sort of save function. It feels like someone played FTL and A Dark Room and wanted to copy them without understanding them.

13507394.review:
Possibly the best survival game I've ever played. I was very hesitant to purchase this particular game after my experience with Don't Starve. Although I did enjoy the gameply of Don't Starve, I feel no need to come back to that game, because even with it's rogue-like elements, it feels like the same experience every time. This is something I feel NEO Scavenger did much better. The skill system has so many good choices, that no particular set feels like the "best" way to play the game. It simply comes down to which way you actually want to play your current playthrough.

The other thing NEO Scavenger did particularly well is entry to the game itself. Without limiting the player's choices, the developers found a way to keep the game simple enough at the start that you wouldn't get lost in the incredibly complex mechanics until you actually need to use the particular rules of the game. By starting you with noting to survive the cold weather, you're forced to learn how to utilize the scavenge mechanic, which is the most important decision of the game. If more games that were this complex had openings like this one, I feel more people could explore the depths of these incredible games.

Even though it's clearly done on a budget, the art of the game is very well chosen. I found it easy to destinguish between the different items that I scavenged, and I rarely felt confused by the sprites that were on screen.

Even though the story itself isn't the big draw to the game itself, it's very well written. I found myself genuinely caring about my character and even being sympathetic to some of the people i encountered. These characters were made so well that I genuinely found myself thinking if I really needed to kill the people I came across. Even though it's clearly "every man for himself", the difficulty of recovering from fights and the chance of my having to drop my cart and run made each encounter a very difficult choice.

This is quickly becoming one of my favorite titles that I found on steam.

13489761.review:
This is quite possibly the most well-thought-out game I've ever had the pleasure of experiencing. I can't speak from experience as to how accurate this game nails the zombie apocalypse because personally I have not been in one, but from the fact that I'm a zombie fanatic I can say this game is quite realistic when it comes to living in a wasteland.

You wake up in a cryogenic facility with something (You later find out it's one of the game's meany creatures, a Dogman) trying to break in. You select your skills and use them to your advantage to defeat the beast, and then you are sent into the massive and unforgiving world that is NEO: Scavenger.

This game absolutely nails scavenging. You search around for ages finding useless, irrelevant items such as string and broken glass bottles but that feeling of pure, unadulterated satisfaction when you find some of the more useful items such as a backpack or especially a crowbar, is amazing. 

Don't get me wrong, this game is unforgiving. As you'll read down below, someone didn't feel like boiling the water they found, got cholera, and died. That's the kind of thing you have to expect on a daily basis from this game. I once forgot to set my noise trap and was murdered by a guy with a meat cleaver in my sleep. I had a shotgun and a noise trap, but it was in my backpack and I didn't feel like getting it out. Another time, I shot and killed a deer, took the meat, put it in my backpack and forgot to cure it, and proceeded to eat it a few hours later after it had spoiled. I got some sort of weird disease and died after hours of diahorrea and blood loss. 

And while it's unforgiving, it's ultimately very satisfying to play. You find youself getting killed, cursing the game out, and then coming back a few hours later for seconds. And that one rare playthrough where you don't die a horrible, painful death, you just feel awesome. I have tons of screenshots I've taken of the various times when I've had a surplus of stuff.

Also the developer, Daniel, is always reaching out to his fans. I'm personally friends with him here on Steam because I wanted to ask a question, so I shot him a friend request and he responded.

If you are thinking about getting this game, get this game.
If you are not thinking about getting this game, get this game.
If you hate this game with a passion, get this game.
If you're going to propose to your SO, buy them this game and put it in a virtual box.

13455441.review:
NEO scavenger is, without a doubt, the best surprise I've got through Humble Bundle. What at first seemed a little interesting survival game turned out to be a massive and addictive experience, with the most detailed survival mechanics you've ever seen (except maybe Project Zomboid).

In NEO Scavenger, death is considered a sure thing, the question is how long you will last for. Survive the cold, survive the wounds. Survive the infection, survive the unboiled water you were forced to drink because you had no way to make a fire. Survive the blisters you got because you hadn't found boots yet, while a dogman chases you. Survive the poisoning you got eating unidentified mushrooms. And worst of all, survive the people (NPCs) who want what you've managed to gather.

The world has unique lore, setting a post-apocalyptic world with paranormal phenomenons happening left and right, but extremely well presented, gradually giving you the information, which is spread through conversations, pieces of newspapers and others.

The atmosphere is similar(ly angsty) to those of Dark Souls, or EVE online, but more personal and centered around the desperate situation your character wakes up into, like Spec Ops: The Line.

The combat is quite simple and brutal: He who connects the first hit usually wins. This enforces a visceral and all-or-nothing mindset, with no place for holding resources back, and a "shoot first, ask questions later" policy that makes you question your own acts as a player.

Both combat and map gameplay are turn-based, and reward thinking carefully about your next move, since the game works with permanent iron man mode (dying deletes the save file) to ensure that you're adequately kept on your toes.

Overall, this is the best survival game I've ever played, and definitely the best one-man-made game out there: 
10/10

13453077.review: If Neo Scavenger were never updated again, I’d still revisit every once in a while. Where else can I feel the guilt of stripping the trousers from a dead man and then the delight of finding a cigarette lighter and a few twigs in the pockets? It’s a world of many mucky wonders.

way too hard, way too much luck involved. boring because permadeath makes you start over and over again - which means no chance to follow the story.
it feels like black jack... you try to minimize the chances against you but in the end you know the bank is going to win at some point.
of course you could start to hide a lot and to walk away from every fight and hide your tracks and stuff like that but then the game would become way too slow and it would take aeons to get through the story (and the rage factor after some really unlucky death would rise to infinity). i mean it is already slow because you have to deal with too much micromanagement and some really counter intuitive stuff. now add some permadeath and one really dumb encounter and everything starts again.
i made two posts on their forums about those issues but the die hard fanboys over there don't seem to get the point that everything they love about this game makes it a really crappy experience for the average player who has been lured in by phrases like "We serve the core role-playing game market by making role-playing games that focus on:

exploring worlds
customizing characters and equipment
creative problem solving
story".

sorry to bring it to you but in neo scavenger you neither explore worlds (because you die and start all over again due to unlucky circumstances) nor get something from the story (because permadeath + no luck). i played it now for 24 hours and all i've seen is the facility i wake up in and it's near surroundings. creative problem solving: well in a twisted way you have to solve some really creative problems like for example the shoe problem - your player character is too dumb to put his shoes on. no joke. so if you wonder why you wear a pair of the same shoes but still get that improper footwear message just check if the right shoe really is on the right foot and the left shoe really is on the left foot. (<- my favorite example because it really represents just how bad the game design gets at stages). at least you can customize your character and equipment.
it's a shame that you don't see anything of the world and story because what i really like about this game is that it somehow still manages to be immersive.

this game is for people who love micromanagement and boring repetitive stuff. definitely not a game for someone who's into story and exploration and adventure.

13441111.review:
Nicknamed ''Hobo Simulator'' by some, this is THE game you have to play if you enjoy survival games. An unforgiving roguelike where you start with nothing and everything you scavenge is randomized, NEO Scavenger is played from a top-down perspective in a turn-based fashion. There is a story to go along with your desperate search for food, clothing and materials, and from what I saw, it's alright. However, nothing keeps you from simply playing as a wandering vagrant murdering people for their belongings.

This game does not hold you by the hand. You will die repeatedly while learning the mechanics, but it's one of those games in which ''losing is fun''. For 10 bucks, it's a great deal.

Some cons to take into consideration:
- EVERYTHING is turn-based, including combat, which can get very tedious when you have to select the same option over and over again to run after a fleeing target, attack someone, etc.
- Since scavenging is entirely randomized, it is entirely possible that you will find nothing to help you survive your first days, and die from exposure to cold/sickness/a blow to the head without really having the time to get into the game. This can be a huge turn-off for some.
- A few bugs here and there.

13426059.review:
This is a truly excellent game, and I'm glad to see it's getting some press, although not as much as it deserves.

I knew nothing about this game going in. I got it as part of a Humble Bundle and figured it was worth a try. I think I played it for about 5 hours straight that first time. It's probably the greatest random find I've had.

You have various perks and handicaps that you select to build your character, so you can choose to have excellent vision and mechanical skill but be a weak, feeble insomniac. After you create your character, you wake up in a hospital, with no idea what's going on and why the world has gone to hell around you. Immediately, you have to deal with a dogman who's charging down the hallway towards you. Your traits will affect how you can deal with it. 

Afterwards, you venture into the outside world. It is bleak and largely empty. You'll set off, with nothing but the hospital gown on your back. You can forage for food and water, but you should really make sure that the food's fresh. Do you know what berries are poisonous? Can you trust that water? Explore a little further and you'll see some ruined buildings. Scavenge in them and you might find some actual clothes to keep you warm, maybe some preserved foodstuffs or a cell phone. Be careful, though, and try not to make too much noise.

You see someone on the horizon. You wonder whether they can explain what happened, but then you notice the rough spear that they're wielding. They charge at you, and you try to run. You can't get away fast enough, so you try to fight them off with a broken bottle you've picked up. You take the spear in the shoulder, and you stagger with the pain, but you get in an incredibly lucky thrust with the bottle and your opponent goes down. You shred some of your clothes and wrap the makeshift bandages around your wounds, but it's too late--infection has taken hold. In your last conscious moments you watch night fall, and you see a glow in the distance. It may be an illusion created by your feverish mind, but it almost looks like city lights...

Each playthrough is memorable in this game, even the ones where you freeze to death the first night. If you survive in this strange new world, you can find people and locations that will help you find out background about this world. There is a story here, but you have to go searching for it. Even if you don't find all the backstory, you still have a tale of desperate survival that's incredibly compelling. I heartily recommend the game to anyone who's interested in survival games.

13421815.review:
这是一款FLASH引擎的末世背景生存主题 Roguelike 游戏，于是很自然地就会拿来和另一款经典的末世生存 Roguelike 游戏 CDDA 比较，两者确实有很多相似的地方，但并不是所有喜欢 CDDA 的玩家都会喜欢本作，反之亦然

CDDA 通过抛弃图形化换来了海量的内容，自然在深度上完爆本作，开始创造人物时就会发现，本作的 Build 系统虽然也是用点数换取长处短处，但可选择的特性太少，加上特性的平衡性很糟糕（部分太优秀部分太鸡肋），导致人物创建的可塑性低下，玩家对游戏风格的选择自由度自然也就不大；同时本作的物品数量、怪物数量、场景丰富度、合成配方数量等等自然也是被 CDDA 甩开几条街，因为自由度和多样性而喜欢上 CDDA 的很可能对本作失望

不过本作在系统上其实也有不少亮点，主要归功于作者丧心病狂地对写实性的追求……需要注意的状态有：食物、水分、睡眠、负重、舒适度（气温）、生命——乍看上去和其它生存游戏没什么区别，但背后其实有一些出于写实考虑的相互作用，我给大家讲一些例子：
水分的消耗比对食物的消耗快，但吃水分含量高的食物可以补充体内水分，不过含水量高的食物变质也快；
虽说脱水或者饥饿而死会花很久，但忍耐口渴和饥饿对身体不好，人物没几小时就饿了、渴了，放任不管的话体力下降、负重降低、行动变慢；
剧烈运动会加大对睡眠/休息的需求，而剥夺休息体力低下也会增加对食物和水分的需求；
晚上天冷需要多穿点，中午穿太多会感觉太热，体温过低和过高都会造成疾病乃至死亡

游戏的生命条又可以细分为 供血、免疫力、疼痛忍耐 三个子系统，利器造成的伤口不包扎会失血较长时间，良好的水分补给会加快体内造血，不清洗伤口或者绷带没消毒很可能会导致感染，感染后病原体会同免疫系统抗争，在潜伏期不及时服用抗生素或草药的话会很危险……所有伤口愈合前都会造成疼痛，如果出现骨折或者肋骨断裂没有治疗则会持续很久，一些疾病比如食物中毒或者饮用生水中毒会造成腹痛和严重失水，剧烈的疼痛会让人行动困难乃至昏死过去……

其实，更加丧病的其实是背包系统的模拟，出门只有两只手可以拿东西，在没有背包的时候只能捡些塑料袋凑合：一只手拿武器，一只手提着塑料袋，最多肩上还可以再背一个塑料袋，不过塑料袋装不了太多东西，还要小心使用过度而损坏——事实上所有容器都不算大，而且都会折旧损坏，有口袋的衣服和裤子也就只能装些小东西，所以玩家通常会需要一个载具来运送物资——比如超市购物车，但带着载具就意味着看到敌人不能撒腿就跑，除非你打算把载具里的物资送给敌人……

游戏里的合成系统简单一部分也是因为写实——在那种情况下有限的时间和资源里玩家也就造些原始的弓啊矛啊，连把斧子都造出不来，某些生存游戏里的造枪造子弹什么的实在是太不科学了……另外钻木取火是个技术活，普通人没有打火机基本是升不起火的……所以游戏不鼓励建立基地，窝在一个地方是不可能自给自足的，还会因为折旧损失背包之类的重要道具，因此玩家必须不断探索、搜集

不过游戏的战斗和探索系统太过简单，基本就是拼脸，遭遇战连小地图也没有，根据距离、视野之类的状态选择一些行动选项，没太大的战术余地；而探索也很单一，看到废墟就进去无脑搜集，辅助道具/技能会改变搜集成功率、受伤概率、是否引起敌人的注意，但也仅此而已，有了一套装备/技能以后基本所有搜索都按同一模式来；角色（为了写实）没有成长余地，创建时是什么样子到死都是什么样子

虽然作者之前说会有剧情，但经历了一年的 EA 阶段，到了正式发行的今天还是半成品的状态（作者已经一个人独立开发了四年，遇到财政问题实在撑不下去了），底特律城只有寥寥几个可访问地点，显然没有完工，走完初期剧情到达底特律后主线就断了，玩家有兴趣可以自行探索地图上几个固定的特殊地点，剩下的就是四处瞎逛探索求生撞随机遭遇了，像我这样不喜欢沙盘的玩家很可能因此失去目标并感到无聊

另外在用户交互上虽然比 CDDA 那样的 ASCII 游戏要好，但依然有一些缺点，比如没有高效的容器内物品转移手段、缺乏游戏内的物品介绍、只有一个存档格等，游戏音乐也很没存在感，大部分时间都是无 BGM 的

我觉得这其实是受众针对性很强的一个游戏（不知道 Steam 为什么会有那么高的好评率），不易上手但上手后的乐趣也比较局限，步入中期确定一套获取饮用水和解决温饱问题的方法后，在复杂的写实系统下生存的日常就变得重复而琐碎——不是所有人都欣赏写实系统，而在沙盘式探索中能获得多少乐趣完全因人而异，还会因为糟糕的运气让人物永久死亡（比如在昏睡中遭到怪物夜袭、对于战斗过于自信），这显然并不适合所有玩家，购买前请先尝试 Demo！当然作者提供的这个系统确实很有邪典气息，也许在社区 Mod 的帮助下在未来可以挖掘出更多潜力，解决剧本腰斩以及多样性不足的问题

13406664.review:
Adeptes du RPG hardcore, ne cherchez pas plus loin!

Vous avez aimé Fallout? The Long Dark? The Forest? Tout ces jeux mêlant à la fois RPG et survival? Vous allez adorer NEO Scavenger.
Le monde tel que nous le connaissons a disparu. Vous vous reveillez, seul, dans un laboratoire, en ne sachant absolument pas ce que vous faites ici, mais apparement, vous sortez de cryogénisation. Du fond d'un couloir sombre, vous entendez quelque chose de monstrueux se ruer sur vous, vite , que faire? Usez de vos compétence en électronique pour fermer la porte? Sauter par la fenêtre pour vous échapper? Le choix est le vôtre, en tout cas, dès que vous aurez mis pied hors du laboratoire en ruine, une longue quête pénible et quasi impossible s'ouvrira à vous : .....survivre tout simplement.

Hé oui. Pas de ligne directrice, pas de tutoriels, pas d'Histoire clairement écrite, le message du jeu est clair: démmerdez vous. Vous devrez camper, chasser, fuir les nombreux ennemis qui vous guettent à travers ces terres désolées, combattre si nécessaire , bref, n'importe quoi qui vous permettra de vivre un jour de plus.
Autre message clair du jeu dont vous vous rendrez compte dès les première seconde: l'immersion. Vous n'êtes pas douée en électronique? De nombreux accès qu'il aurait fallu pirater vous seront refusés. Vous  êtes maladroit? Vous vous déplacerez moins vite avec plus de chance de vous blesser . Vous ne portez qu'un t-shirt?  Votre inventaire se résumera alors  QU' A VOS DEUX MAINS, rien de plus. 

Je pourrai écrire un livre avec ce que je pense du jeu, je vais donc conclure ici en invitant plus que fortement les fans de survival à acheter ce jeu,  vous n'aurez aucun regret, sauf celui de ne pas être tombé sur cette perle plus tôt.

13404823.review:
So I've played this a bit before release so you know... Playtime not entirely accurate.

I don't really have much to say or add but here goes:
It's a minimalist, roguelike, RPG that manages to be intruiging without any visual elements. 
Obviously there are visuals and not just text, but they serve more to simplify the UI. 
The UI is pretty great honestly and it's something a lot of these hardcore roguelikes just don't give a crap about, so it's a breath of fresh air to say the least.
I love the addition of the ambient soundeffects and the music. It livens up the experience quite a bit and makes it easier to immerse yourself.
To sum things up: it's immersive like a great text adventure. Lots of descriptive text and important decisions with the addition of much needed visuals and soundeffects.
It's just really solid and I recommend it if you like great text adventures and hardcore roguelikes. Just don't expect a flashy presentation.

13399588.review:
Extremely recommended. One of the best game I have recently played.
Keep reading, or download the Demo and try it for yourself. Yes, there is a [b]DEMO available[/b].

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You see stuff from above like, isometric map perspective: you navigate the lands from one hexagonal tile to another. [b]All the time[/b].
This costs points. When it's rainy or dark, it will cost more points.
When you reach a city hex, you can loot the location. This, also, will costs you points. Sometimes you will find amazing stuff, and sometimes only scraps of paper. But even those could be useful. Actually, when you start to know the game better, [b]every gôddåmn item is useful[/b]!
You will find more stuff if you use a crowbar, or have a light source with you. But beware as this will make more [b]noise and attract people towards your location[/b].
Looting can also just hurt yourself... like roof collapse. Shït happens right?
So you loot, equip yourself with what you find, and stroll around. Until some dude approaches and gets to your hex.

[h1]Combat[/h1]
The combat is [b]textual[/b]. You won't have the map view anymore. But instead, you'll be presented with an interface showing your dude's and opposition's status, and a list of actions you can execute. Everything you will do, like throwing a punch, will have a narrative text describing what's happening. So it's mostly [b]READING[/b] ya hear? No explosions there.
But don't be fooled... you can trip on the ground and fall. While on the ground you can try and grab the hostile down, you can crawl back and try to escape, drop your stuff and run like hell, etc. A lot of realistic possibilities here. It is extremely hard. [b]Your first encounter will probably be your last[/b].

[h1]Disease[/h1]
Getting hurt, bleeding, being cold, drinking shït water... these will have [b]consequences[/b]. Try to disinfect your wounds, patch'em up and don't let 'em getting infected. Be careful of what you eat too... could be [b]POISONOUS[/b] you never know muhahah.
Unless you are a doctor, in which case you will have a clear descriptions of your symptoms like, [i]"Cholera 3; final stage; certain death"[/i], you won't know what illness you just caught... you will have "[i]stomach cramps[/i]", you'll be like "[i]vomiting[/i]"...
So just act as in real life: grabs antibiotics, clean every wounds. [b]Don't take any chances[/b]. Ever. Why? Because the game has...

[h1]Permadeath[/h1]
Yep. Die and restart the whole game. [b]No save point[/b], and that is intended. You won't bring stuff with you from your last play. Nope, nothing. [b]It's up to YOU to level up[/b]. And this is where I disagree on the game mechanics. I am fine with dying and learning. But ya know the beginning of the game starts to be boring once you know it. And redoing the same stuff is just a waste of time. Hence I created a [url=http://tacticalfreak.blogspot.com/p/neon00b-save-scavenger.html]little tool[/url] to actually still save and, well, cheat. I advise players to die a lot first, and when you feel you are ready, just use my tool.
But even if you use it to reload an old save, it won't matter much, because...

[h1]It's random[/h1]
The map is randomly generated. But not when you first start the game, nope. It is randomly generated [b]as soon as you discover a tile[/b]. So saving the game and loading an old save will still yield something different :D
This is why I am a little "against" the permadeath. Loading an old save is not THAT bad. You will experience a whole different game. I would've liked just... ya know, an auto-save every night or something.
Anyway except for a few spots in the map that will never change, all the rest is random. [b]Random but fair[/b]. You won't like be in a desert without cities for miles ever. They are spawned correctly.
Even if you are a new player, you CAN make it. Yes because in the end, it's just logic.
Contrary to Faster Than Light (FTL) where there is NO WAY a new player will make it to the end because the randomization is too... random. In NEO Scavenger, [b]the RNG is just right[/b].

[h1]Crafting stuff[/h1]
As I said all the items there are useful. Somehow. Because you can craft and even "uncraft" stuff. If someone is giving you stuff, or if you finally found something of value... [b]maybe you can try to "reverse engineer"[/b] it and discover [b]HOW IT WAS BUILT[/b]. How awesome is that uh? Found a bow arrow? But you have no idea how to create one yourself? No problem!
There are also a lot of crafting recipes there. And many different combinations will work. Like you could use your crowbar to roast meat when you don't have a wood stick! Doesn't matter, both categorizes as a kinda "shaft." [b]So it's extremely smart and flexible[/b]. If you are lacking you favorite saucepan to boil water... just think a second... can't anything else, more common, be used as a saucepan? Eh, when I found that out, I literally doubled my lifespan. No shït. Think hard.

[h1]Narration[/h1]
It reminds me of Fallout 1 & 2. You had that little description box in the lower left which would describe what was going on. Here it's a bit the same. With random encounters or special places being very well described. There is a lot of [b]dark humor[/b] too. If you are not averse to reading you will like it and also find that it's well written.

[h1]Story[/h1]
There is a story. Your first goal will obviously be to survive, and so, to find something to cover your feet :) But after that painful initial phase, you will [b]meet strange people[/b]. You will find [b]places of interest[/b]. Or you will find new recipes that... use high tech items you had no idea were in the game.
The story is interesting and is closely related to the narrative part of the game: the only way to tell you stuff is through old newspapers and stuff. Those are funny as well...
[i]OX news reporting hoaxes[/i] ;)

[h1]Audio[/h1]
Every single one item has its own sound effect. Which is played when you grab the item from you inventory. That's it. But that's HUGE. There is a little music, but it gets a bit repetitive.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
If you like Fallout, post-apocalyptic worlds, a good narration, turn by turn mechanics and a pretty realistic game then don't hesitate. It's a [b]masterpiece[/b].
You still unsure? --> try the demo and make your own opinion.

13397569.review:
Прошло 4 года, и разработка игры завершена. Чем не повод сделать обзор?
Не буду особо вдаваться в детали и расписывать размах, отмечу только факты и кое-что поясню.

- Игра вертится на Flash. Что не мешает ей иметь поддержку модов, которая будет улучшаться в дальнейшем.
- Игру делал один человек, по обычному человеческому рабочему графику.
- Тут совершенно нет графона, но есть стиль. 
- Пошаговый режим. 
- И главное: микроменемджент тут возведён в абсолют. Трижды.

В последние годы были популярны песочницы, в которых весь сюжет зачастую сводился к нескольким надписям перед стартом игры, а то и вовсе отсутствовал. У NEO Scavenger есть сюжет. Есть мир, упорядоченный, последовательный и живущий по своим правилам. Персонаж игрока тоже часть этого мира, а не безликий и молчаливый болван, который должен со страданиями превозмогать и накручивать счётчик прожитых часов, только чтобы умереть. У персонажа есть своя история, в деталях которой и нужно разбираться на протяжении всего путешествия, и у этого путешествия тоже есть финал. Правда, пока до него получится добраться, пройдёт не один десяток рестартов из-за разных фатальных для персонажа событий. 

И тут есть своя изюминка: если играть внимательно и осторожно, то количество этих рестартов будет минимальным. Вы не захотите драться с какой-то волкоподобной дрянью, которая выглядит опасно, если на вас нет даже штанов, а из оружия - осколок стекла. Не стоит пить воду без очистки и кушать непонятные грибы. Не обязательно участвовать в бою и рисковать жизнью, чтобы заставить вашего оппонента отдать вам все свои вещи. Всё это возможно благодаря тому самому микроменеджменту, который тут во всём - от простого передвижения по миру, до еды, сна, медицины, создания вещей, взаимодействия с окружением, и боем.

Да, вы нигде больше не увидите такой детальный бой. В этом жанре просто больше нет игр (на данный момент), где был бы более проработанный бой, учитывающий не просто цифры в шкале "здоровье" или даже "выносливость", но и кучу мелочей, вроде тех же морали, окружающей обстановки, времени суток, погодных условий, и так далее. Расправьтесь с местным волкообразным существом, сдерите с него шкуру, сделайте из неё себе накидку - и вы не только решите проблему обогрева тела, но и сможете избежать треть всех стычек со всякими бомжами, которые будут в панике бежать при одном виде вашего персонажа, даже если на нём нет тех самых штанов. 

Помимо этого: бартерная торговля, псевдослучайная генерация мира (ключевые объекты, как правило, расположены всегда одинаково), история-паззл, элементы которой придётся собирать в несколько подходов, постапокалиптика в духе Кормака Маккарти и поддержка модов, если чего-то не хватает.

И всё это (лишь малая часть) всего за 10 долларов и без туманных обещаний "в следующем патче".

13382776.review:
With the launch of Neo Scavenger I figured I would share my thoughts on this title.

The good:

* Great atmosphere.
* Punishingly hard gameplay. One mistake and you die and have to start over.
* Combat is best visceral and brutal. It's all text based but very well done.
* Mostly well written story.

The bad:

* Pacing is really off. Feeding yourself off rabbits can take several in-game hours.
* You sometimes feel like you're playing a hobo.
* Sometimes too hard.
* Lack of real character development options.
* Unguided gameplay. You really have to dig deep to find the story and main quest.

That said, I still think this is a superb title.

13372941.review:
This game is one of those low-tech gems that you find yourself immersed in despite it's obvious difficulty and it's lack of flashy presentation. You experience the life of someone in a strange, while still somewhat familiar world and you are left to what you can find to survive among a population that is more aggressive than passive. Friends are in a short supply, as are the means to adequately defend yourself from both the enemies of the world and the elements of it, two threats the game pits against you that are only outweighed by the threat you pose to yourself and your body's basic needs for survival.

Can it look better? Probably. Does it need to look better? Absolutely not. Throw away what you think a game should look like and remember instead what a game should be, because that's what you'll find here. Certainly a selection for the determined as you will suffer inexplicable loss time and time again, but the constant struggle for survival make all of the moments of success you encounter, however many or few that you may find they be, all the more rewarding.

13356765.review:
(Disclaimer: English is not my native language, expect some typos and grammar errors.)

Oh my.... Where do I start?

I came to find this game thanks to ''James Recommends'' from Extra Credits. So I knew that, based on his review, this game was going to be good. 

But... when I played it, I realized that my expectatives of ''Good'' were an utter underestimation. The game wasn't ''Good'', it was ''DAMN EPIC!!''.

For a game with less than 100MB of size, this game stands WAAAAAY HIGHER than many Million Dollars AAA titles when it comes to survival; not even Fallout:New Vegas or State of Decay can hold a candle to NS when it comes to TRUE SURVIVAL. Which, when combined with Rogue-like makes for a WHOLE NEW GAME every time you play it; one in which you can never know if you'll succeed or fail until either of them shows up (Like when I found the Crowbar, some Binoculars and a Sauce Pan on the first town and I thought I was winning, only to freeze to death because I never found any shoes or clothes).

Unlike in those games where you charge into a group of enemies with just a knife and an angry roar, knowing that if you die, you can just hit the Load Save button, in this game, you gotta think out real carefully each of your moves. Just as you would do if you were in the player's shoes (or bare feet). This makes the game feel extremely real and complex. 

''Do you sneak up on that scavenger to kill him while he's asleep to steal his shoes and his gun? You already know that almost every gun you see lacks ammo, but what if this one's loaded? What if you trip on something and wake him up? You could end up losing all you've gathered so far, and there's a high chance you won't encounter most of that stuff again.''

That's the feeling you get. And that's not something I've been able to feel with any AAA titles.

Just a warning, tho; be prepared to die a thousand times, even right after the start. More than once I stepped into the first area just to be torn to shreds by a Feral Dog.


My only critics to this game are the following:


-Crafting Instructions are just too vague.

The crafting system's utterly complex, but the instructions and recipes are even worse. You can't just figure out what do they say or what do they require until you go read the wiki. Perhaps if the items had some sort of Status Screen that told you what properties do they have, it'd be much easier to do this, as just figuring it out can take THOUSANDS of tries.


-The Full Map is too hard to understand.

At simple glance it looks just like a 300% Zoom on a SNES-era Sprite. You can't even tell what's what and even those places that are marked, it's hard to make out WHERE is the mark, as all you see is a big word. (Dunno if the iSlab or Smarphone's GPS Apps make it look better. Never gotten any of those.). I know this must be hard to do with a randomized map, but right now, there's just no real purpose to use the Full Map other than locating the Glow.


-The Full Bottles' colors are confusing.

Whiskey are orange-colored when full of whiskey, but also when full of water. Same goes for the Corn-a-Colas which are yellow. This can lead to a lot of confusion at the time of picking up stuff or even drinking. More than once I've been carrying around whiskey bottles filled with both water and whiskey and I've accidentaly drank Whiskey because I thought it was water and got drunk, which often led to death. This issue can be easily fixed with a couple palette swaps, so I hope it's fixed by the time the game leaves Early Access.


-MOAR STUFF!

No, seriously, this game needs more stuff, it's already cool enough as it is, but it could be even cooler. The current Item Pool is just too small for such a neigh-infinite world of random possiblities, so it's a bit sad that, once you manage to get some clothes and shoes to stay alive, they're almost always THE SAME. (Your shoes, the Hoodie, three shirts, some Cargo Pants and a Backpack if you're lucky are what you always end up wearing.). A game this big should have at least twelve variants of every piece of cloth or shoes.


Aside from those, I have no other complains. This game has the markings of an Indie Masterpiece, and so far, it hasn't let me down. So I hope it has become even more of a Masterpiece by the time it leaves Early Access.

Umiejętności do wyboru jest niewiele, ale każda z nich zmienia oblicze gry. Zupełnie inaczej gra się silnym traperem umiejącym walczyć, a do tego znającym się na mechanice, a inaczej skrytym tropicielem - łucznikiem. 
Jeżeli mógłbym zarzucić coś tej grze to fakt, że w różnych lokacjach specjalnych bardzo łatwo jest zginąć przez przypadek - wybierając jedną z niczym nie wyróżniających się opcji do wyboru, nie dostając przy tym żadnych wskazówek do czego może jej wybór prowadzić. 
W obliczu tego że nie ma tutaj możliwość zapisania gry "na zaś" (ok, jest, ale trzeba trochę pogrzebać w systemie plików ;) ), a śmierć  jest równoznacza z zaczynaniem wszystkiego od początku, takie przypadkowe zgony bolą. 
W zasadzie każda rozgrywa to materiałna osobne opowiadanie. Za każdym razem opowieść jest pełna wydarzeń, niepowtarzalna i ciekawa. 
Gracz w zasadzie nidy nie może czuć się pewnie - przykładem niech będzie jedna z moich gier, gdzie moja nieźle już dopakowana postać, która już odwarznie przemierzała postapokaliptyczny świat (bo to przed nią inni uciekali) zginęła od... pojedyńczego ciosu garnkiem w głowę od jakiegoś przypadkowego grabierzcy, którego zresztą sam napadłem. 
Naprawdę gorąco polecam

13312583.review:
I've sunk at least 50 hours into this game (I used to play the demo a lot...I was broke!) and I can honestly say that this is one of the best work-in-progress games I have ever played. 
That's not to say that this game is flawless. The games combat system is designed to be extremely punishing. Therefore adding a risk vs. reward element into most things you can do. However, even when equipped with the best gear, it often comes down to random luck. I've flat out shot people in the head, had them survive, stay concious and then shoot through my helmet and kill me. Other times, I've shot people in the leg and had them die. It honestly feels like I'm playing turn-based Call Of Duty when using guns. The melee system is even worse. It doesn't really matter what weapon you have or what armor you're wearing if you face a dogman (or any other creature for that matter) and attempt to melee it you're screwed.
Also, this game being in a post-apocalyptic setting, you have to scavenge for resources (food, water, clothing, armor, etc.). While normally I would be all for this type of mechanic, especially considering the setting, the speed you run through your resources is ridiculous and, at times, can make the game extremely boring as you get stuck in an endless cycle of, find city, scavenge city, use resources found in city, repeat. While this isn't always true, it is for a large majority of the time. 
However, the story elements that are slowly being implemented are making this game much more dynamic and the resource system is becoming less and less of an issue.
Where this game shines and puts it head and shoulders about the competition is its realism. Most games shy away from the possibilities of what a post-apocalyptic society could become, but not NEO Scavenger. From the arena, to the gated city of Detroit, this game feels extremely realistic in its setting, something many other games can't claim.
If this game was released today, I'd give it a 6/10. But for an early access game, easily a 8/10.

13309337.review:
NEO Scavenger is a rather simple, yet in-depth post-apocalyptic strategy RPG game(woah lots of adjectives). You start off in a Cryo Facility and find yourself roaming a world ravaged by an unknown apocalpyse. The game is turn-based so you have enough time to carefully plan your next move, or end up perishing. The game offers lots of choices as to how you're going to proceed. Fight or Flight? Eat or not? Explore or abandon? The RPG elements are great and there is a lot of detail in the overall health system(pain, blood, temperature...), lots of possible customization, all of it affecting your player(having a rough air filter just might save you from an allergic reaction, or the inhalation of toxic spores). The game takes time to master and lots of luck as well, even after 10 hours I still find new things around the game(randomly generated map, but still unable to scavenge all of it), and still find the dumbest ways to die.

10/10, slipped and fell, died whilst unconscious. (jk) PROTIP: Start with Medic and Botanist Perks.

>I'd give it a 10/10
>Pros: Leaves you to imagine most of it, great customization, detailed health and inventory system, replayability, hard and challenging, lots of points of interest, many more great things!
>Cons: Sometimes you won't be able to really understand something until it kills you.

13291037.review:
This game is utterly amazing.  Don't be put off by the mildly ugly graphics.  You will forget them in no time.  What makes this game mind blowing is that it is a rogue-ish game with permadeath, yet it doesn't feel like it.  Sure, the first few times you play you are going to measure your lifespan in hours, but once you get the hang of it you realize that survival is all up to you and completely possible for very long periods of time.  I am writting this after burning a solid 6 hours on this game in a single sitting.  In that entire time I had thrills, upsets, and close calls, but never died.  This is a rougalike game to be sure, but don't let that cause you to run screaming.

The survival aspects of this game are absolutely awesome.  You find yourself searching for food and water, planning ahead, and deciding when it is worth a risky encounter.  There is no "I am a bad guy" badge on people.  See a fellow stranger in the distance?  It is up to you if you want to use surprise to take out a possible threat, or wave and see if he is friendly and wants to talk.  Do you risk a fire to boil water, knowing it might attract a threat?  When it gets dark, do you stumble blindly looking for a good camp, or take a risky spot in the open and hope for the best?  What do you do when you wake up to find a melon head stolen your weapon and backpack; grab a stick and give chase, stalk them, what?  There are always so many options, and that doesn't even get into the tactical turn based combat!

The combat, while simple on its face is complex and interesting.  Planning is rewarded, but so is on the spot craftiness.   The the game never demands a split second decision, so you have time to ponder your move and roll the dice.  It lets you do so many crafty things and it tends to behave as you would expect.  For instance, imagine you come accross some scary looking person who looks like they want to eat you, and have a host of options.  Do you sneak in close and try and stab him with your trust spear, hoping that this game awesome wound system will let you stun and cripple the guy before he realizes you are there?  Do you try and slip away before he sees  you?  Maybe you decide to bluff and at a distance try pointing your rifle (with no bullets in it) at him, trying to scare him off, if he charges anyways, flip that rifle around and show him the butt of it.  You can jump out of concleament and egg him on, hoping in the rush to get  to you he gives you a solid opening to land the first blow.  Perhaps you get out your old butchers cleaver and start the fight by charging him over onto the ground, and hacking him apart before he can get up.  Hey, he might not even a bad guy, you can always just wave from a distance offering friendly chat and see what he does.

This game is so unassuming, but it is solildly on my top 5 for 2014, and for the value for the price, it is easily #1.  It says "early access", but as far as I can tell, this is a full game.  This game is an absolute gem.  The worst thing about this game is that there are so many things that might scare people off from what is an awesome experience; perm death, ugly graphics, early access, a slightly obscure interface (until you get the hang of it), and a strange theme.  Don't let any of these things scare you off.  This game is amazing!  I can't even imagine what it will be once it is out of early access.  Don't wait for a sale, buy it now.

13275890.review:
A brutally hard survival game. If you are feeling a masochist, pick this.

Jokes aside, although the only control you have on you caracter is on the inventory management and choosing which actions to perform, I can assure you that this is one of the most complex survival games available in Steam. Due to it's level of difficulty, I suggest you play this on short bursts (as on the first playthroughts you won't last that long anyway :P )

PROS:
-Excellent atmosphere that absorves you into it's post-apocaliptyc setting.
-The sound is great, from the realistic effects to the music.
-Every choice has a consequence, even a choice as deceptevly simple as drinking a bottle of water that you just found
-I would dare to say that the depth of the game's survival mechanics are unparalelled.
-There is an actual main storyline to this game shall you choose to follow it.

CONS:
-It is a very difficult game. I have 6+ hours on this game by the time I am writing this, and I still take a beating every time. I tottaly understand if many people are put off by it.

-The learning curve: I will be honest. This game has TONS of trial and error. Only after the first 5 playthroughs(about 2 hours of playing), you will be able to understand why you have died. From there, the game gets more satisfying, but adding to the complex interface and the fact that the game almost begs you to seek vital information (such as important crafting recipes) to the game's wiki page.

Having said that, if you are looking for a challenge, you certainly have one here. If I were to call this game by other name, it would be Bear Grylls Simulator.

13201718.review:
This game is an awesome mix of survival, scavenger, skyrim, and a turn based combat game. The map is huge, consisting of hexagons which may or may not have item already on the ground, indicated by a box. The looking glass indicated scavenging. The tent indicates your camp sites, and finally the red feet indicate whether someone or you have been there recently.

This game is not for the faint of heart. In the beginning, you die frequently and most often by things you wouldn't normally expect. There are NPC who are homicidal and roaming the wilds looking to 'scavenge' off your newly dead body. At first I could only last a few hours, and then I quickly learned the skills necessary to survive longer. My average now is 3 to 5 days. The skill/flaw system can be a little frustrating, and there aren't many of either. It could definitely use more of both to allow a better customization of the characters skills and flaws.

On top of that, there is not a way to customize the characters name, gender, or gender-based clothing, at least none that I have discovered. This is truly a survive or die game. Weather, injuries, cold, hunger, thirst, disease, poison, and combat can all kill you. There are also random hex's that have NPC run stores in which you can trade things for money or for other items. The only city I have found as of yet is Detroit.

The one resounding issue I have with this game is once you are dead... you are dead. There is no way to save unless you want to dink around in your computers files to rig up some kind save system. While the character is still alive, you can save and come back to your one save, but after death it disappears and you have to start over. I don't see a point in that system, but then again.. I didn't make the game. 

I think this game has some real potential. It can be frustrating, and seem difficult but failing has helped me learn how to survive longer and pick the skills necessary to survive. There are little things that I think could be corrected like in-game items, or the way in which skills are used. 

My favorite skills to use would be Trapping, Botany, Medic, Hiding, Tracking, Electrician, Mechanic, and a few others. I'd like to see a sewing skill and possibly the ability to take/train an animal companion. I know if I were trying to survive, I would try to find a dog to help protect my stuff, and me while sleeping.

I am concerned though that the developers are making the game significantly harder, so I think the option to choose a skill level from safe - ultimate survivor could be used to allow many different people with varied experiences with games like this could play casually or have a challenge. I like being able to play through a game and then go back through it collecting all of the little dodads and whatnot. 

In conclusion, I love the basis of this game. I think a few things that need to be changed are the save games, a few additional items in game, a few additional skills and a few changes to how the skills work, a better skill/flaw menu, addition of companions, as well as a difficulty setting.

A bug that I think I have found would be while wearing different shoes, or a single shoe still gives the negative effects of being barefoot. However if the two shoes are the same, the effect goes away.

Great game, my fiance and I are addicted to it. Keep up the good work!

13110831.review:
NEO Scavenger is a turn-based, roguelike scavenging game. I like it a lot, because it's gritty, fairly in-depth and more realistic than almost every other survival game.

NEO Scavenger first asks you to choose your perks/flaws: Botanist, Strong, Myopia, etc. There are no XP and levels, so, mostly, what you see is what you get. After selecting your starting skills, you are thrown into the game barefoot and with only a hospital gown.

Your first order of business is finding the basics of survival: shoes (one left and one right!), warm clothes, a lighter, a crowbar for scavenging, a sleeping bag, tools to obtain clean food and water and something to carry all this stuff around. In fact, the very first treasures you'll scavenge are probably disposable plastic grocery bags. They're very fragile, but they're tiny, weigh nothing and will serve as your first backpack. Those bad boys are little life savers, you have to love them! We should probably produce and dump more plastic bags all over the place for fututre survivors, right now. What do you think of that, environmentalists?

From then on, you'll also need to find all the other things you need to survive: clean rags for wounds, alcohol for disinfection, antibiotics, painkillers, a firearm with ammo, gloves, a gasmask for polluted areas, crafting tools, binoculars, noisemakers to warn you of intruders during the night, etc. One of the game's main qualities is that the list of things needed to survive effectively is very, very long, but you can also make do with just the essentials.

Contemporary technology is surprisingly useless. A found computer might have no battery, then a found battery might have no charge in it, then a charged battery will reveal the computer is password-locked, then you'll hack it (if you picked that skill)... only to discover the computer only contains pictures of cats. On the other hand, a cheap plastic bottle filled with safe drinking water is always a useful commodity. Is that social commentary or what?

Weapons are also imporant, but not nearly as much as in most survival games. It's possible to completely avoid all combat with a peace-loving build.

Speaking of which, combat is a strange numberless affair, where you choose broad actions (run forward/back, take cover, trip enemy, threaten). The only numeric value is range, which is enormously important depending on your fighting style. What you do get are surprisingly graphic descriptions of your situation: "You have passed out from unbearable pain" or "You have died from acute bleeding to the lungs". Ouch. As in real life, he who strikes first usually wins. It's also possible to win a fight and die from your injuries not long afterwards. All in all, fights are terrying (as they should be), the results are sometimes unpredictable and fighting fair is always a stupid idea. Did I mention you can be killed in your sleep (and vice-versa)?

There's also crafting, there's always crafting. Except here it's realistic. You're not going to craft an assault rifle with rocks in NEO Scavenger. In fact, a good ol'fire is probably the number one recipe. Sorry, no fire by friction if you haven't chosen the Trapper skill at character creation. Making fire without an external source is really not that easy without training. Another essential crafting recipe is: Fire + Water + Receptacle = Boiled (sterile) Water. Don't tell me it's boring until, weakened by diarrhea from drinking dodgy water, you are punched to death by a hobo. By the way, the game doesn't tell you what makes you sick: you only know you messed up somewhere when symptoms start showing up.

The game leaves the player with three general survival strategies: use nature's gifts to provide for your needs, scavenge cities for pre-apocalypse technology or... murder every survivor in sight for the contents of their shopping bags, RAWR!

The game has a main storyline, but as of right now it's pretty short. And did I tell you THIS GAME HAS NO ZOMBIES? Yay!

The game has two main flaws. First, the game could do a better job helping you find points of interest. The map is very large and it's not obvious where the important areas are. The second is almost a praise: I want more of it! I want more items, more weapons, more unique areas, more special encounters, more animals. MOAR! The possibilites of common household items having ingenious survival uses is almost endless. Variety in this game is good, but not great, but things are still being added to the game (and there are mods).

I wrote the initial review while the game was still in Early Access. While I still recommend NEO Scavenger, it turns out the final amount of areas in the game is quite small. I highly recommend some of the more popular mods, which increase the amount of improvised items without changing the dynamic of the game and add some new events/areas.

In conclusion, I'll quote Rock, Paper, Shotgun's Graham Smith which sums up the game's worth pretty well:
"NEO Scavenger is the only survival game that feels like it has anything to do with survival."

13110101.review: old school, hard ass quality gaming - I freaking love it!

13081675.review:
This game is *almost* good, but like many roguelikes I've seen come around, the devs ultimately seemed more concerned with making the game hard than making the game fun. Most interactions with this game are like this:

Player: Oh boy, I found a gun!

NEO Scavenger: But you didn't find any clothes in the first two turns, so I'm going to have to kill you.

or:

Player: Oh boy, clothes *and* guns!

NEO Scavenger: Guess what? Disease time! Have fun dying from something completely out of your control!

I understand the need for realism, but there's a point where that has to bow to gameplay and NEO Scavenger just often kills the player out of nowhere and pisses away a few hours of progress. Oh yeah, this game is permadeath-only, which already alienates everyone who actually likes not losing hours of progress due to unfair BS. 

There should be challenges, yes, but the player should never be put in a unwinnable situation if they themselves weren't the ones who put themselves in it. I'd be a bit more forgiving if this game HAD A PROPER SAVE SYSTEM, but since it doesn't, I can't forgive it for destroying several playthroughs simply because I rolled a bad number.

13061365.review:
This game is a bit of a hard sell at first. The user interface is not exactly intuitive, and the graphics are nice but a bit retro.

If you overcome these initial scepticisms though, what you'll find is a game that is a mixture of "A dark room" (minus the initial set-up phase), "Minecraft" (minus the blocky 3d graphics) and any Rougelike (so expect to die frequently).

The basic setup is always the same: you wake up in some kind of cryo-lab, and the world outside has turned into a post-apocalyptic dystopia similar to "The Walking Dead" or "28 Days Later".

You have to find out about your own past and uncover the secret of what happened to the world.

You walk around the landscape on hex-grids, scavenging the woods or the remains of long-gone cities for clothes, food, water and weapons, while avoiding (at least initially) other NPCs or animals, most of which want to see you dead. You can craft things together with recipes you find scattered around randomly, and from time to time you find pieces of newspapers which tell you a bit about what has happened.

The environment is highly dynamic, you have different weather patterns which impact your sight (when you find a scope or binoculars, you can even increase your visible range), and many other scavengers are roaming the area on their own (one nice example: I once found a corpse, looted it and moved his stuff into my hideout, just to find him chopped to bits of meat when I came back the next day... and of course the killer was not far off and killed me a few minutes later...)

The story unfolds bit by bit (you have to survive the first night to even get an idea on where you should be moving), and even though I not yet come very far in the story yet (did I mention it is very easy to die in this game?) it is a game I will keep on coming back for "just one more try..."

The only downside (IMHO) is that there is no way of saving the game (except for the "save&quit" function), so every death is permanent. And since it's written in Flash there's no easy way of getting the save data out for bakup purposes. But that just shows that it's a real Roguelike at heart...

12993408.review:
Well well well.  Now this is something quite good and interesting.

This game has pleasently took me by surprise and I'm enjoying whats on offer so far.  

Best way I can sort of explain this, is basically a Tactics style game with Text Adventure Role Playing elements set in an apocolyptic environment, coupled with...I guess Day Z/Rust style scavenging.

I'm only just starting to understand the basics of the game, however it is quite enjoyable.  

Basically you are person thats escaped from a facility and you must try and uncover who you are.  To do this you must survive going through the world and scavenging stuff that you need.  To do this, you enter locations and you must decide if its worth it to scavenge there or not.  You may find nothing or the mother load!...or a trap and a jackass waiting to cave your skull in with a crowbar.

I like how my first OMG YES!! moment was when I found a backpack so I could carry more stuff.  I guess thats the best part of it.  The thrill of finding those essential bits and pieces that you need and surviving those moments where you are attacked.

The combat requires you to be thoughtful and tactical, until someone gives in or dies.  So you have to read the text box to see what is going on in that fight and do what you can accordingly.  One mess up and you are done.

I like whats been done with this game.  You get the feel that everything is your enemy, from the human, the creatures and the world itself.  Hell you are just as likely to freeze to death as you are to be bludgeoned to death.  It will keep you on your toes.

Give this a game a try, it will keep you engrossed for a long time and for what...a 60-70MB download?  I'm behind that all the way.

12971004.review: Se você curte o tema sobrevivência, esse jogo é um DEVE TER!NEO Scavenger consegue ser brilhante e nos entrega uma experiência nova a cada partida, uma pena que ainda não possui uma tradução para o português e os jogadores menos conhecedores do inglês vão penar muito, afinal o jogo é baseado em textos e interpretações.Os gráficos contribuem para o charme do jogo, com detalhes legais e criativos, claro que nada comparado com jogos AAA ou outros indies que se destacam por esse quesito, mas mesmo assim não nos decepciona nem um pouco.A jogabilidade é baseada no mouse e fazemos praticamente tudo com ele no jogo(menos girar objetos,isso fazemos com teclas) e os menus são bem intuitivos e muito fáceis de usar, contribuindo para deixar o jogo mais imersivo,afinal é imprescindível ter conhecimento dos controles para se dar bem no jogo.O áudio é muito bom, com sons de selva e calmaria enquanto percorremos o mapa e cada objeto no jogo possui um som próprio, deixa a desejar em batalhas, pois nem se quer os inimigos e NPC's falam ou gritam, animais selvagens e criaturas também entram nisso.A chave mestra do jogo está em sua dificuldade, você vai cansar de morrer e existem inúmeras formas de isso acontecer,verás quando jogar.Todos os objetos possuem durabilidade e se deterioram com certa facilidade, uma vez que difícilmente você vai achar algo com mais de 80% de durablidade, o que contribui para  que sempre estejamos a procura de equipamentos e ferramentas;os alimentos são muito escassos também, a água é relativamente abundante, mas basta você tomar do lugar errado para pegar uma doença e por fim a sua vida.As batalhas são legais e intuitivas, mas devemos ter muito cuidado pois existem muitos fatores que podem nos prejudicar nas batalhas, como por exemplo:Tipo de terreno, nossas condições físicas, clima, fome, sede, claridade, durabilidade de nossa arma (que se for branca, é muito danificada chegando até a quebrar muitas vezes),  os inimigos na maioria das vezes vão ao menos conseguir te machucar um pouco, o que é ruim, pois é difícil encontrar antibióticos, álcool ou bandagens limpas para limpar os ferimentos.O sistema de crafting é muito fácil de usar, você apenas arrasta os itens para a janela e ver se a combinação de ambos resulta em algo.O jogo é baseado em turnos e você terá que escolher sabiamente o que fazer em cada um deles, pois um turno jogado errado e isso pode significar sua morte.A visibilidade a nossa volta no mapa também é importante e a noite ela diminui drasticamente, tornando assim nossa vida mais difícil e nos aproxima muito mais de encontros indesejados.Resumindo...é um jogo IMPERDÍVEL, e é barato também, com certeza vale o investimento e olha que o jogo está em acesso antecipado!Promete demais ainda!10/10

12966878.review:
A nice premise - old style hex adventure, but with the usual apocalyse scenario.

Its far from easy, for example anyone thinking of rushing headlong against mobs the moment you start should think again or you will die, and it will happen often. Sneak around scavenging for clothing, weapons... craft those bits of junk into something useable. Then go out again - you'll still get killed, but perhaps less often. This is a game of learning and trial & error. You will learn as you die. And you will learn as you survive. Its something of a slow burner. You WILL come back to it after a period of frustration. It'll sit there somewhere in your mind, suggesting you have another go - maybe this time...

Permadeath has to be in the game or would essentially ruin the story, and essentially this is the driving force - this game can be replayed with different information based on your skillset - perhaps some things that would be hidden would be revealed.

I feel some things that need improving - crafting for example is good, but would be best if it remembered every combination you'd come up with from previous games (rather like the old son of in the old rogue type games. This has some previous recipes but not many, and trying to remember them all yourself is absurd.

Also something that (I think) needs changing to a degree is the way loot is calculated - many times you can obtain a hoard from scavenging with almost no chance to gain anything, but then you can repeatedly find nothing when you have a good chance. Certain skills improve or reduce this, but I think too much in some cases.

Basically here is a potentially good game, which needs many more refinements before it can really be considered complete.

I enjoy this sort of game, but I really wonder if I'm actually anything better than totally rubbish at them. The fact is that despite any faults - any time you have what you deem to be a completely unfair death or when you were just starting to do well for once then along comes... a big nasty monster... at least you have the knowledge of what doesnt work next time, or a different skill to pick - maybe you'll endure the early multitude of deaths and finish the game - perhaps I really am rubbish at it, maybe it (the game) needs balancing, or maybe it always will be just a tad too hard.

In conclusion:
I'd play it more if I didnt die as often, if I got to see slightly more of the story.

All too often you go through the initial stages then die in a low level battle. Perhaps if you were just left sometimes with your stuff robbed - at least you had a little chance...

7/10 (with potential to be 9/10)

**SPOILER ALERT**
Leave the talisman alone.

12818434.review:
NEO Scavenger is an excellent example of survival RPG, bringing to mind other isometric games like UnReal World and Haven and Hearth.  This game masters the eerie, abandoned quality present in Fallout, and is as challenging to navigate.  You will realize the painful cost of each difficult decision.

That said, the game features nothing by way of world building.  You can craft your own ramshackle gear from the broken remnants of the pre-war world and the often hazardous wilderness, but you cannot cultivate, construct defenses, or harvest natural resources apart from sticks, branches, water, and a few edibles.  Everything in the game is slowly decaying, and ultimately, so are you.  If you want a sense that your character has a future other than ending up the corpse someone else scavenges, this is not the game for you.

I can honestly say I feel I've had my money's worth, but I don't think I'll finish the main story line.  This game may well leave you feeling like a murderous hobo, starving, infected, insane, who would gleefully pop out of nowhere and bludgeon some random stranger to death with a tree branch for a shoddy left boot and a plastic shopping bag.  But some people who enjoy the survival genre are looking for just that.

Happy hunting, you psychopath.

That will get you killed fast in this game. Take what you need, set priorities, and for survival's sake, stop picking up every bloody rock and twig!  This is a no nonsense survival game with a quaint, homebrew feel and a ruthless approach to killing off your next character in some new and intresting way.

12768790.review:
I want to love this game, I really really do. I still would suggest it to people who like rogue-like(lite) games, and enjoy the survival because the survival is incredibly well done. I’m akso sure I will play more hours of this as time goes. With that said, my main issue is, unlike a lot of other permadeath games, this one has a story to tell, which might take you a long time to figure out when first playing, and it seems really interesting. 

The problem is, very few will ever get to experience that story as no matter how you gear up or character build, your character has the staying power of a lit candle in a hurricane. Little to nothing can stop a low or average enemy from getting in a lucky shot that will knock you out or kill you in one blow, costing you hours of game time. You will lose anything and everything you were working on. Having to re-create a character and starting again with the repetitive cryo facility wake-up scene. I understand this is the concept of this genre, but to have nothing left after working so hard to build up a character and losing 3-5 hours, for me, is frustrating. There are some who may love that, though. Once again, it’s not the permadeath for me, as much as it is the lucky cheap-shot.

There are several mods for it already, though most just give more items and such. There are no saving mods as of yet, and the only way that truly seems to provide a means to see the story is some kind of invulnerability mod. Though removing the challenge entirely isn’t any fun at all. There is also a great mod out there that gives limited repair features that help shift the gameplay.

With that said, the scavenging and survival system is absolutely incredible. Sometimes it can be a little over-complicated when you first play, but as a general rule most recipes make logical sense. Found a shard of glass? Use it as a cutting tool, wrap it with a piece of paper for a makeshift shiv, or use it as a weapon in dire need at the risk of cutting yourself. Found a glass bottle? Smash it and use it to threaten off an enemy. Use clean water or whiskey to sterilize your wounds before using those rags you sterilized in boiled water to stem the bleeding.

The survival is the strongest aspect of this game and it shines over everything. From having to keep warm, to managing your health. Accidentally drank some bad water? Got sepsis from that wound you forgot to clean? You better find a place to hunker down and heal up with that bottle of anti-biotics you found in the locked shed with your makeshift lockpicks. Forage some wood and keep that fire going to stay warm and keep your immune system up, but make sure you set up some noise traps because people and…things can see it burning.

The in-depth survival system makes this an amazing game to enjoy overcoming what I have said above, which is why I still suggest it. To see an indie dev put together a system that a AAA company could never have the creativity to pull off is a breath of fresh air. A game that will make you piss your pants in excitement just for finding a shopping cart.

12689939.review:
I don't normally write serious reviews. I'm one of those undesirable pricks that uploads the "11/10 uninstall function works great" review, but [i]NEO Scavenger[/i] will be my exception. You have no idea how hard it will be for me to not write "I murdered a naked guy while wearing a clown mask", but I will get through it, for this amazing game.

Let's start with the basics; you're some random guy (avoiding spoilers) that has just woken from cryogenic sleep during the apocalypse somewhere around the city of Detroit. After a friendly interaction with a lovely creature known as a "Dogman", you step outside to  experience the outside world of Michigan... and dang, it's cold. Like, "Oh my God I can't feel my feet and I'm feeling really sleepy" cold. After a few deaths and several hours of learning the basics (don't eat random berries or mushrooms you find unless  you know they aren't poisonous, that guy with the broken bottle really wants to eat your leg, and yes, it's cold, put some pants on) you really get into this game. 

As others have said, however, an ungodly amount of time can be spent on this game, and it can never be taken back. In a sense, it's like [i]DayZ[/i]. You spend 3 hours finding a weapon, finding your friends wherever they are on the map, and end up faffing around until some gruesome death by either a glitching zombie or a player that only speaks Russian. [b]This, I believe, is another selling point of NEO Scavenger.[/b] In the beginning, you get used to dying. After a while, however, you end up living longer and longer, until one life lasts you hours of real life time. Everything is peachy until that one night you decide to sleep in a forest and forget to set up a noise trap or hide, and you're stabbed to death by some plague-ridden nutcase in your sleep. After a day or two of angry avoidance of the game, you decide to give it a second chance, innocently, you pour more hours into it, only to die in a similar manner. It's a beautiful circle of life (death)!

With such extensive content already and more updates to come, NEO Scavenger is one of my favorite games of all time. I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys hardcore survival games, and/or murdering innocents with his/her bare hands whilst wearing nothing but a Ronald McDonald lookalike mask and a hospital gown. (Damn, I said I wouldn't write that.)

12676152.review:
Okay, Take the classic Fallout games and Combine them with Dungeons and Dragons.
Now you have NEO Scavenger.

NEO Scavenger is an overall fantastic game.
If you enjoyed the classic Fallout games or if you enjoy playing tabletop RPGs such as DnD this game may appeal to you.

NOTE: This review is based solely on my opinion, Do not be angry with me if you do not agree with my opinions.

Pros
- Retro Graphics to deliver a sense of Nostalgia. (Some people love em others hate em.) 
- Advanced Character Creation (Very similar to Project Zomboid) 
Traits and Flaws system makes endless character potential
Traits can help you survive, Such as using a skill to make fires from scratch
- Complete Open World
Move Spaces much like a tabletop RPG
- Entriguing Lore
- Awesome Choice-Based Turn Combat
- Choices in Encounters allow for Interesting Outcomes
- Good Inventory System, As well as Injury.
- Fresh Scavenging System
Use Skills + Items to increase items found, Random events while scavenging (Roof Collapse)
Cons
- Cruel Learning Curve (Not Necessarialy bad, Personally I like it.)
- Relatively Short Storyline (Still in Progress)
- Somewhat Linear Start
Would be nice to be able to create your own character and spawn at a random location
- Esscentials are difficult to find


Overall I would say this game is a solid 9/10,

This game is worth buying if you are
A: A fan of older Fallout games
B: A fan of Tabletop RPGs
C: Both
D: A Bad Mutha
