9274815.review:
You can look around the review pages for this game and see a sea of "recommend" posts, thats for good reason, and I will get to that. First however, I would like to try and define what NEO Scavenger is, though that may be difficult. 

     NEO Scav is a survival game in its simplest form but the title of "Survival" doesn't do it justice. I would like to define it as a "Turn based RPG", but that too doesn't quite fit the bill. "Sandbox"? no, not that either . Now I'm not saying that all of these traits and aspects are not included in NEO Scav, but each one does not define it well alone. The only thing I can think to do is paste all of them together (using medium string and a sharp edge) making it a Sandbox Survival Turn Based Role Playing Game (a SSTBRPG), now all we have to do is throw a H in front of that acronym for "Hardcore" and its shaping up to be a decent genre description, a bit of a mouthful though. 

     Not that (H)SSTBRPG's really exist (that I know of aside from a few indie titles scattered about the web) as a gaming norm, just kind of an acronym I made up on the spot, but the idea isn't a norm. Why is that? The only answer I could think of was that it is too much of a risk for large companies to make a game like that, one that would truly test a person's ability to survive in the wilderness  and deal with day to day threats like hunger, thirst, sleep, and warmth. I don't know if that's true or not, and looking at the amount of people who play games like NEO Scav, I can't see how that theory could hold together. 

I'm getting off track. 

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

     NEO Scavenger is created (to my knowledge) by one person, Daniel Fedor. That alone when looking at the game is an amazing feat, especially considering how in depth NEO Scav truly is. Whether its crafting or just scavenging there is plenty of things for you to make or find. 

     The first day is the hardest, you wake up in an odd place with something scratching at the door (I won't go into detail as, well... Spoilers) , but you immediately have to escape. Using skills to selected at the start, a set of four with the ability to add more at the cost of negative traits, you venture out into the world. 

     You walk out into the sunlight of the world, its dawn,  its cold, and you don't have much in the way of clothing save a hospital gown. Immediately you're struck with a problem, find clothing or die of hypothermia. This is what kills most new survivors, and it took me a while (and a few protagonist deaths) to find my rhythm. This first day is brutal, but once it's over, a whole new day begins. 
 
     Now you're warm-ish, but the previous days exertions have caused you to grow quite thirsty. You see that there's a water source nearby, a river, but you don't know if the water is safe to drink. You have no method of checking if its "infected" or if its "sterile" but  you don't have the luxury of waiting. This is something that kills off a lot of the players that make it past day one. Let's say you were lucky, and now you're no longer thirsty, and you didn't manage to acquire some form of disease or infection, now what. 

     By this time you're starting to feel a little hungry, while scavenging you manage to find a couple of mushrooms and some berries, but without the proper skill (which you can choose at the start of the game, it's called "Botany") you can't tell if these are poisonous or not.  You pick them up all the same, if it comes to it, you might have to take the chance. 

     But whats that on the horizon, it looks like another scavenger is none too pleased with you stealing his supplies (or for any myriad of other reasons), and now he wants you dead. You can't escape, you have to fight. You pick up a large nearby stick and prepare to defend yourself. 

     The fight is frantic, messy, and results in both parties getting pretty bruised up, but eventually the other scavenger retreats from battle, leaving you to treat your wounds...

     The point is that NEO Scavenger is relentless in its urge to kill you, but it's not like you can't combat this. You can cover you're tracks so that enemies have a harder time following you, you can hide in urban areas and ambush scavengers to steal their stuff, you can apply bandages to your wounds and take pain pills to deal with blood loss and manage the amount of pain your character is in. All the while traveling for some far off goal. 

And there is SO much more, and even more to be added I'm sure. 

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

     In short try the demo, it's a pretty accurate but  slimmed down version of how the game plays out, if you like it, buy it... you can't go wrong. The creator is pretty active in the forums, discussing current game bugs and ideas with the community, both here on steam, as well as on his site at Blue Bottle Games.  

Take care, good luck surviving, and hopefully this was helpful. 

P.Kindred XIII

Der Einstieg war etwas umständlich und die Steuerung, bzw. die Oberfläche und die Dialogfelder sind zunächst gewöhnungsbedürftig. Aber schon nach ein paar Minuten Spielzeit wird klar, wie der Hase läuft und dann kann das Spiel richtig süchtig machen. Es befindet sich zwar noch in der Entwicklung, was man vor allem an der bisher recht rar gesäten Story, bzw den vielen fehlenden Quests sieht, aber die Atmosphäre und die Spielmechanik begeistern trotzdem. Besonders das umfassende Gesundheitssystem ist hier hervorzuheben, denn selten stirbt man bei Spielen auf so vielfältige Arten. Dank PermaDeath-System lernt man recht schnell aus seinen Fehlern, denn wer einmal an einer Sepsis gestorben ist, weil er vergessen hat, seine Wunden zu verbinden, oder wer an einer Vergiftung durch verseuchtes Wasser dahingeschieden ist, schenkt der Gesundheit seines Charakters in der nächsten Runde doppelt soviel Aufmerksamkeit. Selten hab ich so ein "realistisches" Survival-Game gespielt, bei dem es eben nicht nur darum geht eine gute Waffe und ab und zu was zu Futtern zu finden. Zahlreiche Lebensparameter wollen stabil gehalten werden und eine Vielzahl von Krankheiten oder möglichen Verletzungen sorgen dafür, dass es nie langweilig wird.

Ein dickes Minus gibt es aber: Das ganze ist ein Flash-Spiel und auch wenn es nur Perma-Death gibt, könnte man rein theoretisch seinen Spielstand speichern, wenn man das Spiel vorzeitig beendet. Allerdings vernichten z.B. Tools wie der CCleaner oder ein Browser, der beim Schließen automatisch die Cookies entfernt diese Spielstände gnadenlos!
Aber, hey: So oft kommt man eh nicht zu speichern, denn wie es schon in einem anderen Review zu dem Spiel hieß: "Be prepared to die...a LOT!"
Wer sich unverbindlich ein genaueres Bild vom Spiel machen möchte, kann auf der Seite des Entwicklers die Demo sowohl komplett im Browser spielen, als auch downloaden. Bis auf einige Gegner, Waffen und Items unterscheidet sich die Demo bis zum Erreichen der ersten, verhältnismäßig weit entfernt liegenden Stadt, nicht vom Original.

Prepare yourself for a brutal game. This is a detailed, post apocolyptic survival game. I've only got 6 hours in it, but I plan to play, and inevitably die, a lot more. There is a goal to work towards, and combined with various encounters, you'll be busy with more than just surviving. 

Long story short, this is the toughest survival game you'll play in quite some time. I was struck with pangs of remorse as I wailed on a downed bandit, made all the worse by the other feeling... deep within my gut... the joy of finally killing the bastard and looting his corpse!

9229928.review:
NEO Scavenger has to be one of my all time favorite games. Even when it was back in early access. The first time I tried it out, I played for six hours straight. That's a long time for me. I was just so in love with it.

There is a storyline to follow, but you don't have to watch the story unfold with each playthrough, because NEO Scavenger doesn't hold your hand...at all. Whether you want to find more information about your life and what has happened to the world is up to you. Personally, I just like to see how long I can survive in this messed up wasteland.

This game does have a steep learning curve, but once you figure things out, you'll be set to survive for weeks. And while some say the graphics are too unbearable to live with, I don't mind them. I think they are part of the charm that sucked me into the game in the first place.

To be sure that this game is for you, check out the demo before you spend your fifteen bucks. That's what it's there for, right?

いわゆる「終末もの」。今のところ主な目的は生き延びることらしく、ヘックスで構成された森や川や廃墟が並ぶマップを、化け物や他の生存者を避けたり追いかけたりしながらタイトル通りにひたすらアイテムをかき集め続けることになる。

オススメしないというか、オススメし辛い理由はあまりに意地の悪い難易度設定。
開始直後からまともな防寒着か寝袋（と、その使い方）が見つからなければ一晩持たずに凍死。
探索も対応したスキルかアイテムがないと成果が小さく、失敗どころか怪我をして動きを制限されれば瞬く間に泥沼に嵌る。
運よく揃った装備品も寝ている隙に奪われたりついでに殺されたり。

要するにゲームの知識があってようやく運ゲーが出来るレベル。
手ごわいゲームが欲しいのなら御あつらえ向きかも知れないけれど、ストーリーが完成してないβバージョンの現状ではデモ版で済ましても十分かな。

[h1]2015/01/05追記[/h1]
βテストが終了していたので久しぶりにプレイ。
相変わらず無慈悲な難易度です。探索やイベントはまだ経験で何とかなりますが、戦闘が完全に神頼みです。

こちらは一度死んだら終わりにもかかわらず、ライフルを持った敵さんは超レア＆高価な弾薬を容赦なく浴びせてきます。
血だらけの瀕死にさせてもスキルでこちらを転倒させた後、手に持った矢でプレイヤーを刺し殺してきます。
とてもNPCとは思えません。DayZで他のプレイヤーに遭遇するのと同じ位危険です。相手が死んでくれないと安心できないのです。

スキルの組み合わせや攻略手順を（数分に1回死にながら）いろいろ試してみるのは楽しいといえば楽しいです。
ですが、ストーリーを読み込んだり、ロールプレイする要素も余裕もほとんどありません。
自分の中ではそれなりにプレイ時間が累積されてますが、やっぱり人にはオススメしづらいです。

9225477.review:
First and foremost, do not take my above playtime as my experience, I've bought it on Desura and the Website, and I wanted a third save and to give an additional amount of money to the devs. (Why can't I just give you money?!) Anyhow, this is Neo Scavenger in a nutshell:
    
     Cold. How long has it been since I've been warm. A day? Ten? I don't know any more, time seems so eternal out here, and I've lost track of it. I don't know anything but pain, fear, and cold these days... and hunger. I tried building a campfire a while back, and that damned Bandit left me bleeding and scarred. I went looking for some medical equipment later that night, an an apartment collapsed on me. I'm weak and tired, but I'm too afraid to sleep... But I can afford to close my eyes a bit, right?...
     "Give up all your f***ing gear if you want to live!" Before I'm even fully aware, I'm staring into the muzzle of a revolver. I panic and begin to scream, and he whacks me across the face with the revolver's butt.
     "What? You f***ing deaf? Hand it all over!" I'm not deaf, but I'm not stupid either. If I hand over all this gear, I might live a while longer, but I'd still die. Slower and even more painfully than if he shot me. Besides, he might even be bluffing? Before he knows what's happening, I slam a heavy punch into his chest, knocking the wind out of his lungs and freezing him for a moment. Not one to waste, I use that moment. I grab a heavy-looking stone on the ground and begin to pummel him. In the dark, I see nothing but a vague grey shape. I slam the stone into his stomach, and he screams in pain. I pummel him even further, and further... Long after he dies, I'm still hitting him with the stone. My arms are aching and my head is pulsing, but I keep hitting the battered corpse. Finally, I relent. More out of exhaustion and pain rather than any sense of logic.
     Then, I sleep. Fitfully and weakly at first, but soon enough, my fatigue catches up to me, and I rest. When I wake up, the full realization of what I'd done caught up to me. The "bandit" was a starving emaciated skeletal husk, and his revolver was a rusted abomination that was more likely to explode rather than fire. I begin to suck in a hitching, weak breath as I sob. That could have been me, and it probably would be before long...
     It's been a while since I killed that man, but the heavy black weight of it hangs heavily on my shoulders. I hate my own existence, and have long considered suicide... If this isn't hell, then what is it? Just as I begin to slip the bottle of sedatives out of my pocket, I see a man approaching me. I haven't seen another sould in so long... and I feel genuine joy and excitement at the prospect of talking to someone... Maybe even make a friend? I begin to rush towards him, hands in the air to signify my friendliness. Before I know what happens, I am knocked aside the head, and looted.
     This is Neo Scavenger, and though your adventure may not last as long, or be as miserly, you will experience the highs and lows of survival. You will wonder: "Why? Why did it have to end this way?" And you will face many hard choices.
     Do both your practical intellect and your inner masochist a favour, and buy this game. It's well worth it's price.

9202328.review:
I heard about this game from a friend and decided to play the demo to see how I felt. About two hours passed and I purchased the actual game, to spend another two or three hours playing the balls off of it.

At first a first look I was unsure about the action events (fights, encounters etc.) seeing as it was primarily text and seemed like it would be a little dull. I was very wrong, while yes the action events are just text along with some other info (character portraits, conditions and so on), it doesn't detract from the intensity at all. If anything imagining what is happening as it's described to you makes the whole fight even more tense.

I think the most appealing thing about this game is how realistic it is. You can (and will) die in so many different ways, it's fantastic! You can be beaten to death, bleed out, get poisoned, mauled, shot, etc. But what I love is how indirect it is. You can go into a forest and eat some berries, a few turns later you get some pop up text informing you that your character is vomiting. What caused that? Was it the berries? The dirty bandage giving you an infection? The water from the lake? Along with hunger, thrist, sleep deprivation, temperature and the horde of melonheads closing in the game becomes very stressful. But in the best possible way.

Besides the many ways to die, the scavenging is top notch. Far better than say Fallout for the sake of argument, where you gather stuff for a while and then you're good till end game. In NEO Scavenger you need to keep scavenging to survive and you will not find guns in every house, or food in every cabin. Chances are you'll die before ever using a gun, but when you have one with the right ammo, you feel worried about using it in case it's wasted. This combined with the crafting and character skills to open up new options, makes each playthrough very different.  

The best part is the game isn't even done yet, so new features are being added to make this experience even better. So if you're reading this right now and you're still unsure I really reccommend you at least try the demo. I think this game is fantastic and would really sing it's praises to anyone who's looking for a challenging and realistic survival game.  

I'd give it a solid 8/10 so far, would be swarmed by melonheads again.

9200020.review:
NEO Scavenger is a title that offers multiple ways to play, many places to go, and innumerable ways to die. Adopting only traits like melee, strong and tough can get you far, getting a semi-serious injury or two almost definitely spells death. Playing it safe with tracking, hiding, athletic and trapping will keep you alive. At least until you stumble across another survivor that deems you weak. Of course, electrician mechanic and hacking skills can lead you to some pretty sweet gadgets, but good luck getting the supplies needed to construct them. Neo Scavenger is a game that requires careful decision making, good foresight, and a cool head. This game, even in early access, promises heaps of discovery opportunities, and discovering something new is pretty common, even after 10 hours of gameplay, and each time adds a new sense of excitement and motivation to branch out an try a different method of survival.

 Props to Blue Bottle Games for all of the planning of where this game is going and showing it to the community, it's a great comfort to have a good idea of where this title is going. If you are on the edge of buying this game, or just can't decide, the demo might change your mind. The demo is free (duh!) and since the game is 2D, it takes very little time to download. This game is awesome, inexpensive, and I can't wait to see more of it.

9166077.review:
First - try the demo. The game style is somewhat of a niche, so it may not be for you. After that... well if you're still reading, perhaps a review is in order.

Perhaps the best way to explain why NEO is worth a shot is the fact that I've introduced three players to it, with each having exactly the same responses (almost stages of grief style). First is the inevitable freezing to death ("What? What did I do wrong? This game is stupid!"). Next is figuring out how to survive that part ("Ah, I can use that sleeping bag until I find clothes, or possibly light a fire"), normally followed by having your head bashed in by someone ("What? What did I do wrong? This game is stupid!").

Next run through you figure out how to make weapons ("Now I can go take on those damn bandits!"). And, after killing a couple, you WILL get cocky and drown on your own blood ("What? What did I do wrong? This game is stupid!"). 

By about the fourth serious run (normally with a half-dozen freezing to deaths in there) you're surviving, and doing it well. You start analysing the risks of combat (he has a machete, I have a bow... how close do I let him get?). From there your deaths are almost always due to errors on your part - surviving can be time consuming but is generally not hard, unless you want to deliberately handicap yourself by not taking the easy way (no trapping skills, no botany skills) for a difficulty boost - and all three players were hooked. At each stage you could see them figuring out what to do next, how to avoid the mistake they made last time.

Despite what some reviews have said you do not need to find the recipe papers to make anything - they tell you how to, but if you put the ingredients in the crafting screen it will let you know what you can make. Generally it's pretty intuitive too - large stick plus knife equals sharpened stick, for example, but you soon learn the crucial recipes by heart.

Yes, it's unpolished. Yes, it's flash. Yes, the story and interface leave a lot to be desired. But it's still well worth the time.

A pretty outstanding game.

It's a hexagonbase survival strategy game, that stresses on finding equipment to endure the elements, finding food, water, and medicine to survive. In a post apocalyptic world, it's you and you alone that must brave the outside world where anything could be your enemy.

It's a scavanger game, you loot anything you are able to and keep anything useful, anything from nuts and bolts to nightvision goggles and assault rifles. Eventually you will have a character that you have put a bit of time and effort into creating, this is where the game gets fun.

I really enjoy this game. It just recently came out a few months ago, I believe, and the dev is already coming out with patches, and helpful fixes towards the game. So, there's always new stuff to look forward to.

If you play scavanging games, and you enjoy the satisfaction of trying to survive as long as you can.
Then, I suggest you give this title a try.
It even has a demo; if you are still unsure.

NEO Scavenger is a fun little indie title by Blue Bottle Games, if your vision of fun is watching your character slowly dehydrate to death after you develop diarrhea from a diet composed of berries and swamp water. Despite being incredibly unforgiving the permadeath mechanic makes it an excellent game to play in short bursts, and death itself is not that much of a frustration.

In its early access state it has a great crafting system and survival mechanics that can only get better, but it suffers from a combat system that needs a lot of work and a big lack of NPC interactions.

If you enjoy the survival genre or even turn-based games this little gem is a nice title.

Игра имеет немного приятного, статичный графен и довольно богатые описания местности, что есть очегодное сочетание.
Turn-based перемещения по карте, совершение действий и бои заставляют вас продумывать всё наперёд совместно с элементами сюрвайвала, ведь если сделать что-то не так - окочуритесь от голода, холода и вообще вас сожрут. Однако не умом нашим единым - вы должны быть удачливы, ведь это rouge-like отчасти. Так что выживать тут сложно, поверьте мне наслово.
Кстати, название игры тонко намекает на то, что эта игра - рай для клептоманов типо меня, ведь можно обшаривать всякие разрушенные здания, леса и прочее говно в поисках всякого стафа, можно даже увеличивать себе переносимое место, находя рюкзаки и делая себе всякий транспорт для вещей.
Есть неписи, враждебные и неочь, и на каждого можно напасть, убить и обшманать, иль наобарот, пройти мимо, зашкериться и вообще. Есть особые места типо города Детроита, фактически единственного целового и работающего, есть лес с духом душителем, а за вами будет гнаться НЁХ в виде духа, что боится одной вещи на вас.
А ещё можно себя немного аугментировать.
Можно заболеть чем-либо, пожирая необработанную еду, иль ядовитую.
Вообще, игра очень продумана уже сейчас, в ней куча всяких деталей.
Она неимоверно затягивает, в ней можно потерять счёт времени. 
Пойду наработаю в ней ешо несколько суток.

9045330.review:
Que bela surpresa tive ao jogar NEO Scavenger. Em muitos aspectos ele é bem parecido com Wasteland e Fallout, mas apresenta uma boa dose de originalidade em suas mecânicas. É uma mistura de RPG antigo, TBS estilo Civilization e jogo de tabuleiro com uso constante de textos para passar ao jogador cada detalhe do mundo desolado a ser explorado. Sobre a história, o melhor é experimentar e não falar muito para evitar spoilers. 

Basicamente você assume o papel do sobrevivente de um holocausto sem saber quase nada sobre o passado ou o que fazer em seguida. Logo no começo é possível escolher as habilidades do seu personagem e com isso mudar radicalmente o tipo de experiência ao longo do jogo. Por exemplo, pode criar um sobrevivente especializado em combate que mata e pilha outros sobreviventes. Um hacker com conhecimentos de mecânica e eletrônica que pode fazer um bom uso dos aparelhos eletrônicos ainda existentes no mundo desolado. Pode ainda criar um personagem do tipo caçador furtivo que evita contato com outros NPCs e faz uso dos recursos naturais para sobreviver, entre outros. 

O jogo não segura a sua mão com tutoriais nem tampouco faz por você o que você deve descobrir experimentando. E esse processo de aprendizagem é bem brutal, pois envolve incontáveis mortes por hipotermia, fome, sede, exaustão, ferimentos, etc. No entanto, a partir do momento que você começa a dominar as estratégias de sobrevivência, o jogo se torna extremamente recompensante e viciante, pois cada hexágono a ser explorado pode trazer um grande perigo ou descoberta que faz você ficar naquela apreensão e vontade de experimentar só mais um turno, semelhante ao que só a série Civilization sabe como fazer. Sem falar na sensação muito boa de estar vencendo o jogo simplesmente por estar vivo lutando contra bandidos, mutantes, doenças, fome, frio e sede, esses quatro últimos sendo os principais adversários de NEO Scavenger.

Os gráficos são bem simples, no estilo FTL de simplicidade, o que em momento algum impede você de ficar envolvido com os eventos do jogo. O combate é todo por turnos bem parecido com os Fallouts 1 e 2. Você escolhe qual arma usar e vai clicando em ações baseadas no que você espera do seu adversário. Na tela você vê informações que descrevem o tipo de inimigo, arma utlizada, estado de saúde atual etc. O combate pode ser rude e simples, mas é incrível como você fica tenso aguardando o desfecho dele. E não há sensação mais legal do que ler que aquele golpe com um pé de cabra acertou em cheio a cabeça do bandido e agora ele está jogado no chão inconsciente e aguardando que você dê o golpe final ou apenas pilhe o corpo agonizante e caia fora dali antes que outros bandidos ou animais apareceçam.

Mesmo estando em beta, NEO Scavenger está quase pronto e com muito conteúdo a ser explorado e zero de bugs até onde pude jogar. (quase dez horas de jogo).
É mais um indie que entrega uma experiência única e inovadora e um dos melhores RPGs por turno que já joguei. Baixem a demo, não custa nada.

9039549.review:
This game is a welcome throwback to the old style, where creating an atmosphere was more important than the pixel count of the cutscenes. Running a minimal gui and text-based descriptions of most events, the game manages to create a sense of urgency and intensity right from the first moments.

This urgency stems from a sense of realism, not in the sense of arbitrary damage values or photo-realistic animations, but in the sense of hand-to-hand combat being a bloody and exhausting affair. I engaged my first human unfriendly (not to give too much away, beginning or no,) with a multi-tool knife thinking that my "weapon" easily beat his "basic attack" only to be surprised by tackles, ground fighting, and a desperate struggle that left me frantically kicking him to death rather than celebrating with some level-up mechanic. I realized that even though I thought myself armed, in reality a multitool is a terrible damn weapon. The realistic aspect here is simple and effective, and more than just the number crunching.

At present build it seems like a few things could use tweaking or adding on to, but that's to be expected at this point and gives me hope that player input will keep this easily-overlooked gem on track. If the game were free, I would gladly still have donated just to see this game continue.

8977932.review:
NEO Scavenger is a turn-based, post-apocalyptic, survival roguelike with perma-death. I also now sometimes fondly call it a Procedural Death Michigan. It's mean, immersive, annoyingly addictive and seems to strongly dislike players wearing right boots (left boots are fine).

Basically, you scavenge around (and die after the building crumbles on you), fight other people scavenging around (and die valiantly with monkey wrench in hand) or try to talk to them (and die a turn later by drinking a celebratory made-it-through-the-turn sip of poisoned water), try to kill creatures that would like to eat you almost as much as you'd like to eat them (and die hungry), craft items to help you survive (and die warm because your fire alerted every deadly thing around), keep track of your hunger, thirst, diseases and injuries (and die very informed) or try to get to the seemingly last big hub of civilization (and die trying to get there; or trying to get in; or after you get in; or on your way back out).

In short this is a game where you try to make it through the day while figuring out what has happened to your hero and the world - and die trying. I really don't want to spoil this too much for you, but rest assured, whether you prefer dying by traumatic brain injury, blood loss, cholera, dehydration or an angry mob, there are enough options there to suit everyone's tastes. And if that doesn't sound fun to you, go away, I don't like you.


-----
[h1]And here's some actual analysis[/h1]

NEO Scavenger is the chess of survival games, if chess came without an instruction manual and forced you to scramble to understand its rules. It's all about making tactically sound moves, about the constant weighing of risk-reward decisions, but without ever feeling certain you made the right choice. Very much like real life in that way. The gameplay mechanics, while seemingly unforgiving, are actually there to remind you that you are not a badass superhero, just an average person thrown into a huge mess. Combined with the deliberate obfuscation of the player stats, this feeling of vulnerability makes the game surprisingly immersive. It's an exercise in role playing and player driven choices based on gut feeling rather than number crunching.

Quite realistically for an average Joe, going in situations guns-a-blazing will rarely be rewarded, running away and hiding your tracks from a bunch of stray dogs may. The combat is a constant dirty struggle of trying to get the upper hand while dancing around your opponent, surprisingly complex and rewarding for something delivered with a few buttons and a bit of text. But even with great equipment and a character with decent combat skills, every fight you survive will leave you weakened, hurt, tired and more vulnerable to the next threat that comes along. In that way, the combat, as well as the deeply simulated survival and sickness mechanics, enhance the constant feeling of being exposed and alone, afraid and uncertain in the middle of a hostile world. You are never allowed to feel safe. You are never allowed to hunker down, build a huge base, put fences around it and kill everything that dares come through. Throughout the game, the mechanics drive you to keep moving on, keep surviving day to day, keep doing mundane inventory management, and keep trying not to die. And almost always failing.

But dying here isn't always a bad thing. Since you can't really improve your skills, (though you can add to them in a limited way) you need to die to improve, to learn, to realize how to make better choices next time. You even need to die to learn more of the world, simply because you can never uncover everything in one playthrough. Which brings us to the story.

Behind the immersive atmosphere and the fun, unforgiving gameplay mechanics, hides an interesting, complex, well-written story and huge amounts of lore and flavour text delivered both in long screens and in tiny bites literally everywhere you look. The story will never beat you over the head with what you should do next (and it's fair to say you should remain doubtful when it seems to do that), so it is perfectly ignorable if you just enjoy the sandbox game. But it's worth getting into, and it's also worth remembering that every time you think you know all the possible answers to a question, there's likely more there to discover, if only you do things slightly differently next time (by having a different build, carrying different items, making different choices, going down a different path, uncovering different information). The mystery of the story is a sprawling, complicated puzzle, one you will not solve easily, even by finishing the game the first few times.

If it looks as if I'm ignoring the game's flaws, it's because to be honest I enjoy the game too much to notice them most of the time. That said, the UI could be friendlier to newcomers (which is a polite way to say it's pretty unintuitive); thankfully it's perfectly serviceable once you get used to it. Also, while obfuscating stats is an interesting and perfectly valid design choice, obfuscating some of the less intuitive game mechanics is simply an annoying hurdle to climb over when you first start out. In more technical matters, the cookie-based save system (one of the few elements there to constantly remind you that this is still a flash game) can be a real pain, the game doesn't play well with many commonly used modern resolutions and the process of adding mods is a bit too archaic and involved for most players these days. Even more importantly, there is a very valid argument to be made about how well a perma-death roguelike game with unforgiving mechanics can still make for a deep story-based experience that is more enjoyable than frustrating.

But even with all its problems, as you may have gathered I think this is a great game: the perfect flawed little gem, and in my head already a cult classic.

8954027.review:
Não é um jogo para todos, mas, aqueles que se interessarem por uma espécie de simulador de sobrevivência num universo pós apocalíptico (com toques de cyberpunk) e que não tenham problemas em enfrentar um curva de aprendizado bem brusca (ou seja, prepare-se para morrer MUITO) irão deleitar-se com um jogo que pega elementos de Fallout (os dois primeiros, vide o cenário), Civilization (mais pelo esquema de turnos e mapa com hexagramas), roguelikes (como Nethack, Rogue, Dungeons of Dredmor, etc.), simuladores de sobrevivência com elementos de crafting (Minecraft, Stranded II, Schiffenbruch, etc) e mistura tudo isso num conceito novo. Jogadores mais hardcore que gostem das séries Jagged Alliance, X-COM e Heroes of Might Magic também poderão achar aspectos interessantes nesse jogo, guardadas as devidas proporções.
É um jogo difícil, de gráficos simples, ainda em fase de desenvolvimento, e como já disse, não é algo para todos, mas, aqueles que persistirem e aprenderem a apreciar os detalhes do jogo verão que as suas sucessivas mortes são geralmente resultado de suas escolhas, e não da sorte. A cada novo jogo, um jogador perseverante irá aprender novas táticas. estratégias e cada vez mais entenderá como funciona o universo de NEO Scavenger.
Você basicamente começa semi-nu, sem saber de nada, num mundo devastado e cheio de horrores, sem aliados, sem ferramentas (salvo certa seleção de habilidades), enfrentando um clima impiedoso (maldita hipotermia!!!), outros pobres diabos tentando sobreviver como você e criaturas mutantes. O clima de paranóia é constante, o desespero em achar o segundo par de sapato é palpável, aquele momento em que você está morrendo de sede e tem que decidir tentar a sorte com um ambiente hostil ou beber aquela água de procedência duvidosa parece durar horas...
Grande jogo, mas, jogadores que não gostem de títulos modestos (e por isso sem amarras de contentar a todos), estranhos (e por isso mesmo cheios de personalidade) e difíceis (pois não te pegam pela mão), evitem. Fazendo uma comparação cinematográfica, está muito mais para "A estrada/The Road" do que para Mad Max.

The game is still very raw, but awesome already. If you are into survival stuff or/and a big Fallout fan, you must try this game out. Combat system is just awesome leaving you with a dire impressions of a martial combat to death, I can't think of anything exciting like that in recent turn-based games. You will feel the force of each crowbar punch landing on your enemies' breaking their limbs. I'm not being sadistic here, but that's what you expect from a post apocalyptic role play survival game. Lack of sex is a big disappointing here though, it would give the game a perfect touch.

NEO Scavenger's mechanic is purely brilliant, but the main hardcorish problem to me is that story line is rather linear (though it gives you options to complete quests depending on your perks from time to time), once you've made "a wrong" decision you'll be punished with no option to progress at all, making you literally start the game over from the very beginning. It forces you to constantly peak into forums and wiki, leaving you with no free will options at all.

I strongly recommend to buy this game to support its developer.

8907304.review:
NEO Scavenger

NEO Scavenger is a game that wants you to die. Even more than that, it is a game that wants to kill you. Brutally and rapidly if possible, but slowly will work just as well. From hypothermia to bandit attacks to starving to death, it pulls no punches in the “you’re going to die” department. It is an unforgiving game and makes no apologies about it. Quite frankly, that’s one of the reasons it succeeds so well. Before you go running off without reading further, allow me a moment to elaborate. A single paragraph is all I’m asking.

You see, NEO Scavenger also wants you to succeed. It does supply you with the tools and skills you need in order to survive. It simply doesn’t hold your hand or coddle you along the way. You begin simply enough. You start the game by picking your few basic skills and you wake up on the floor of a cryogenic freezing lab with something mean heading your way. Your journey has just begun in earnest. You may use your chosen skills to assist with the incoming creature, via feeding it another survivor or simply locking the door. The skills you have chosen to outfit yourself often change the game in this way, leading to all kinds of different outcomes to little problems like this. It’s undeniably gratifying to halt an enemy attack by using your hacking skill to drop a cryogenic tank and feeding the creature a reality television star. Let’s be honest; who hasn’t wanted to do that at one point or another?

Are you still with me? I thought that might get your attention. The aim of the game is fairly simple; find out who you are and what happened to the world. Things take place in a post-apocalyptic environment, and you have no memory of any of it. It’s fairly standard, but it plays out relatively well nonetheless. Hints are revealed through old newspapers you find scattered about and obvious visual cues. Your hand is never held at any point, there is no tutorial, and there are no retries. When you die, it is game over and you start again from the beginning. NEO Scavenger is a harsh, unforgiving piece of work. But you also get a little better each time, get a little further, and learn a little more. It’s tough, often seems unfair, and is always exciting.

Technically, it is a pretty solid game. It’s still in development, so it does have its share of bugs and incomplete features, but what is currently present does work well and you shouldn’t be deterred from giving it a shot if you find yourself at all interested. Over the course of the next few months it will be fleshed out and cleaned up, and it’s looking like it will become a great little game. I would recommend it easily enough, especially considering the $10 price tag attached to it. If you think you might be interested, and don’t mind a rough edge or two, give it a shot. If you think you can take the abuse, that is.

8826263.review:
Ah NEO Scavenger, I've seen you grow from a tiny early access game to now a fully fledged game.

I'm a sucker for these kinda games, turn-based and almost entierly text based. I wish I could re-live my first expierence with this game, it started with me waking up in the Cryochamber pouring over every line of text. I read that an entity was coming for me and I had to think fast, so first thing I did was jump out of the window, wouldn't anyone want to get away as fast as possible? Well that wasn't exactly a great idea, as I jumped out in my reckless haste I had mangled myself up real bad on the broken glass, not good. Not only am I now bleed profusely from everywhere, I have a hospital gown on, a weird necklace, a hospital band saying "Philip Kindred," and a hulking werewolf following me. I took my first steps out into the world, only to die later that night from hypothermia and blood loss.

NEO-Scavenger puts you in a post-apocalpytic Michigan with a slew of crazy characters and horrifiyng monsters. It's brutal and unforgiving when you start out, and your first (and many) deaths will come from hypothermia. The scavenging and loot system for this game is completly random but not unfair and makes finding that one piece of equipment feel so good. Finding a gun is a hell of a lot harder then finding a jacket or some food. You're more likely to find clothing in an apartment than a storage shed. It's satisfying seeing your character grow and aquire new gear and become a true badass of the Michigan area, that is until a random thug comes up to you hits you in the head once with a rock and kills you instantly. Then he's the new badass Michigan. Did I mention this game is hard? Well at least the first few hours are. This game kicks your ass when you first start out, once you get your berrings and figure out what works best (Strong+Melee+Trapping+Broad Spear = OP) then the game really does get a lot easier and a lot of the challenge goes away. As other review's have stated once you hit end-game and beat it you really have seen and done everything there is to see and do. "Quests" are not random, story events are not random, and the ending is not random. What happens happens, but, getting there is where all the fun is at. Looting everything you can while staving off hunger, thirst, and keeping your own wellbeing while fending off Bad Motha's, Blue Frog's, and Dogmen are what truely make this game entertaining. I've seen this game grow up and it is still as fun when I first started playing it. Open the Wiki and just go at it, every death is a learning expierence!

If you are looking for a unique game that kicks your ass in the beginning and makes you feel like a badass later, with a killer story and fun gameplay then look no further than NEO-Scavenger!

8818465.review: This is THEY survival title. It is absolutely unforgiving, its brutally realistic... it makes you learn from your mistakes and adapt to the tools given to you. Its only in beta... and its a masterpiece. This is not a game for the weak hearted, it will crush you, you WILL die... over and over. But the satisfaction of perserverance is well worth the price of admission. From crafting to combat, survial through scavenging - this is perfection. Buy it.

8807018.review:
Right now, it is a promising start for a Roguelike-like. The game offers an interesting spin on the survival genre, by almost singlemindedly focusing on resource gathering. Every mechanic of the game is geared toward that. You'll spend most of the time looking at a grid-based inventory screen, playing Tetris with items. This is no Diablo, though, and what you bring with you might make the difference between life and death.
Food-clocks are a pretty common mechanic in traditional Roguelikes and many offshoots (Think of the advancing rebel army in FTL). Time and resource based constraints are a good way to keep the player on its toes, forcing him to push forward instead of farming lower level content to gain advantage. 
NEO Scavenger doesn't joke with time constraints. Get some clothing fast or it's unlikely you'll make past the first night. 
There are some balancing issue though, mostly due to the random world generation. Sometimes jeans are harder to find than sleds for some reason. Sometime, there are miles between your initial spawning location and any useful city hex tile.
While dying like this might be realistic in a post-apocalyptic setting, it's kinda frustrating to experience more than a couple times.
Also, there's a story going on; and by that, I mean a real story, not an emergent one - with quests, characters and dialogues. Not something you see everyday in these type of games. I'm not particularly bothered by it, but I wish I could opt out of it altogether and strike out on my own, handling my own business. The main issue I have with it is that, due to the nature of the game, you're going to see the same text-adventure inserts and lore pieces again and again. 

With all its quirks and unfinished or unpolished mechanics - combat is especially dull and clunky at the moment - it's shaping to be an interesting and unique game.

8802511.review:
(This review has changed for the third time on 6/31/17)

Being the first game I ever bought on Steam all those years ago, I feel like I should recommend this game. I already had written two seperate reviews in favor of it. So why do I feel like flipping that  big thumb upside down? Well, I've realized that this just isn't a good game. My issues with it just pile up when you actually look at it objectively. (Skip to the list now if you just want a brief overview without too much reading.)

For starters, the RNG is ridiculous sometimes. I've had some playthroughs were I magically managed to kill one of the most powerful things in the game with nothing more than a hoodie and a stick. Other times, I take about three steps away from the start and a thing called a Mega Wraith comes by and slaughters me. Both of these things have happened at least twice.

OK, lets say that RNGeezus is on your side and you managed to become an absolute tank. Now what? To be honest, I'm still not sure. I've got to the lengths of cheating the game and there's nothing else to it. You can go and do the story for a bit. A really small bit. I mean, [b] you don't do anything in the story! [/b] No really, I've tried every dialogue choice and item combination allowed in the first "encounter" of the story. They all end with you being given a task -- a fetch-quest to get the "Vase of McGuffin" or something equally ridiculous -- that will either kill you if you're not a tank and bore you to tears if you can survive. Oh, did I forget to mention that it never tells you were the dang thing even is?! This is where my playthroughs tend to end.

Last thing before I let the bulletpoints take over. Did I forget to mention this is as polished as a rusty machete? It's running in godforsaken, [b]2005 Newgrounds,[/b] Adobe Flash for crying out loud! It also barely understands what a 1080p screen even is. I never noticed this for a long time but I used to play this exclusively on my laptop from... huh... it was from 2005 as well.

[h1]PROS...[/h1]
- More in-depth than any other post-apocalyptic survival games I have ever played.
- Kinda funny predicaments like getting your head LITTERALLY CRUSHED by something called a "Mega Wraith"
- Story is not necessary. Really, you can just jump in, not read anything and still have a good time. Great for when you don't have a lot of time to spend
- Addicting. Beacuse you die so much, you constantly have that Flappy-Bird-ish, "Just one more turn" mentality (see CONS)

[h1]CONS...[/h1]
- More expensive than I would like. Maybe thats just me but it just doesn't feel all that polished. In fact, it's still running in Adobe Flash!
- Really hard. Since it's randomly generated, it takes a whole lot of luck to not die before you can even have a fighting chance.
- Too much cussing in the main story. This might be my personal taste but some of the cursing in the game feels forced and unnecessary.
- Ultimately pathetic story. If you do choose to play the main story, you'll eventually feel either A) disappointed with how it's handled or B) be completely and hopelessly lost. After the first meaningful encounter with the story, they pretty much give you the boot out of anything you might find helpful and pretty much tell you to do a fetch quest. A quest, mind you, that never once tells you how to complete it.


I'm disappointed to have to turn my back on this game but I feel like it's just not good enough to recommend. Play the demo and leave it there. You've already played all the fun bits.

8697459.review: I for one am a very big fanatic of hardcore survival games such as this one, but had been surprised when I first started playing. I have been playing "hardcore" games for years, now. This game brings on a new definition for the word. This game is immerciful, harsh, and unforgiving. One wrong move and you could have your entire life come crashing down. You should never expect to live longer than past the night when playing this game. At first, you'll likely only live about a few hours, if not a day or two. After a while, you'll start discovering recipes, finding equipment, and even special places that do/don't have much to do with the story, such as Zom Zom's. Along the paths you take, you will have opportunities to help people, scavenge for resources, and even get in a fight or two. The entire game is ectremely difficult and is not something to be played leisurely. I do have one problem with the game, though, and that's the constant dying by "Acute bleeding in the lungs." It's almost become the new "Arrow in the knee", which can also happen, making your experience feel somewhat ironic at times. But, back to the "Acute bleeding in the lungs", I find that it happens much too often, making the game feel somewhat less serious. Sure, it only happens after getting whacked in the chest and stomach repeatedly, but you could imagine how annoying it would be to see that it's the only reason you die, half of the time. I would reccomend this game to any person interested in a new type of survival game. A word of warning, though; don't take off your talisman!

8694750.review:
Very much enjoyed this game and will likely play it some more. I haven't even gotten very far so far, just under 5 days of survival I believe. Much like FTL (Faster Than Light) you will find this game gives the player a number of significant choices in a world that is generated differently each time with events equally varied and random. The game has it's flaws, to be sure. And without using much of a guide thus far I still occasionally get confused or am unsure as to how some mechanic works. It has occurred once that I was in a fight I believed I was winning when all of a sudden my equipment had disappeared and I was out of battle finding myself thinking to the game "I'm sure you're right, but why?". 

All in all, the game has many possibilities to make it immersive, there are a few things to be improved on, a few minor bugs and a learning curve if you want to make your way far. But all in all, I would say this is great for a player looking for a good survival game. Much like FTL, this game isn't made for you to be the hero, or in your favor like other games where you are central to the plot. You exist on it's terms, you can't run around being all-mighty.

I would also like to add that this game has static graphics to accommodate the text/UI based game so don't expect anything aesthetically amazing. The graphics accomplish what they need to accomplish, they will make the world feel complete, but not 'beautiful', and to be frank that's fine. It suits what the game is. With that said, I would also like to add that the text portions are very well written in my opinion and the events I have encountered thus far have been incredibly interesting.

This game isn't for everyone. If you aren't interested in survival games I wouldn't recommend it, nor if you are looking for a beautiful game. If you believe you have the imagination however or desire to see how you'd fare in a survival game I would definitely suggest looking into the game a bit further and possibly throwing out the $10 to buy into the game.

8648730.developer_response:
Hi jarballo490,

Sorry to hear that the game disappointed you! Regarding the save system, it shouldn't be broken, though there are some things that will cause conflicts with it.

NEO Scavenger was built on Flash technology, which uses SharedObjects to store data on the user's machine. SharedObjects are like cookies, and therefore, often get swept away by software that clears cookies. Some examples include web browsers and browser plugins, CCleaner, and some antivirus software.

If you're interested in finding a solution, the following link should help:
http://steamcommunity.com/app/248860/discussions/2/648811852284474523/

I agree that this isn't ideal, but it's unfortunately a consequence of my technology choice.

Again, sorry for the inconvenience, and hopefully you'll give NEO Scavenger another try!

Best,
Daniel Fedor

8593097.review:
This Ultra Realistic Survival game takes place in some kind of apocalypse, were mutiant animals and creatures, as well as the desprite people who were luckly enough to survive this long, roam the vast world. You wake up not knowing whats going on or who you are and how to survive, with nothing but a hospital robe, your forced to wonder this vast, cold, dangerous world, in hopes that you might find some food or clothe, before you become to hypothermia, fall to a disease, poison, lack of water or food, or simply bleed to death from a cut, or an attack from unforgiving bandits. How realistic this game is will just blow you away. The combat is great, unforgiving, ruthless, but realistic all the same. With hundreds of diseases to watch for, and injuries to avoid. In this game, it actually matters were you get hit, punched, cut, or shot. If you were to get punched in the arm, you simply recieve a bruise, minor pain, and a small inpack to what you can carry with it. However, if you got punched in the throat, you will be seriously injured. It will become hard to breathe, drinking water or eating food becomes unbearable, and if the hit was hard and precise, you will probably die or choke on your own blood. Anykind of injury, sickness, including physical or mental, that you can think of, is present in this game. 

In this game, you will die, die, and die again. It takes a little while to get used to the game play and how to fight, but once you do, you will play for hours and hours. The story telling is great, and it will make you feel like your playing fallout all over again. Despite all the injuries and sickness you come across, there is always something you can find that can protect you against it. I recommend that you get this game so friggin much.

I encountered a bandit and we traded blows, eventually he wounded me pretty good but i was getting the better of him and he surrendered.  Getting injured is a problem in this game and can mean a death sentence if you can't get healed.  Outraged that he had injured me I beat him to death even after he had surrendered.

 Easily one of the most impressive survival games I've played to date. A lot of people might say something along the lines of ".. but the graphics aren't great at all.." and thats okay. But what this game lacks in graphics, it more than makes up for in the mechanics and detail.

8533463.developer_response:
Hey immotus,

Sorry the game fell short of your expectations! Pricing is a highly debatable topic, so I don't think you're necessarily wrong or right. Each person has to make their own determination about value, and I hope the demo helped in your decision!

Regarding some of your points:
-You mention that the randomization is basic/simplistic. What are some of the things you were hoping to see to make it more complex? I feel there's actually quite a complex system at work, with a large amount of data, but perhaps the game is doing a poor job of showing this?
-Regarding the lack of ways to prosper beyond basic survival, it's true that there isn't much beyond surviving, exploring, and following clues. The game is largely focused on nomadic play style, since adding more permanent lifestyles is a layer I'm unprepared to tackle. (E.g. farming, fortification, followers, etc.) I do hope to have some satisfying encounters to find and clues to uncover while exploring, though!
-The cart/sled issue you mention is actually addressed in an upcoming build. There is now a dedicated move to "emergency ditch" one's cart/sled without needing to access the inventory screen, granting a dodge bonus for that turn.
-As for crafting, the recipes tend to be fairly rigorous, so even small ingredients matter. As BoxCatGamer points out, there are a few ways to make a fire, but you'll need certain skills (like Trapping) if you don't have the right tools (e.g. lighter, torch, or other flame source).
  
Thanks for your feedback, and hopefully you'll give NEO Scavenger another shot in the future!
  
Best,
Dan

It's a demanding turn based survival game placed in post-apocalyptic world.

Although it lacks great graphics or sound, it manages to have good depth of the gameplay. There's a dozen of conditions your character can suffer from, needs to take care of, and there's a crafting system that's interesting.

The combat is very rudimentary, but still quite interesting with its choice of actions. Nothing beats the feeling of succesfully scaring off bandits with an empty rifle.

In comparison to other survival games, is is what Dwarf Fortress is to Sims.

8473709.review:
One of the most beautifully crafted games, up there with AI War, and it's [i]not even finished yet.[/i] The developer is incredibly active, pushing out [u]quality[/u] updates often of content and bug fixes. Also pays heavy attention to the community and is well receiving of criticism and ideas alike.

The game itself contains hundreds of recipes, items, and ways to die. The survival system is realistic. You need to eat, drink, stay warm, have vision, scavenge, hunt, trade, and try to keep healthy while doing it. Starving? Those mushrooms look mighty tasty. BAM! They're poisonous. Should have been a botanist, eh?

Oh, you're tired? Cold? Campfire in the woods sounds nice, and man am I so glad I found that sleeping bag. BAM! Robbed in your sleep. Bam! Dogman fight! Oh god, you're bleeding out! Slap rags and a makeshift splint on your torn and broken arm. Ouch, you didn't boil them, now you have an infection.

I've never really been one to enjoy hardcore games. Infact I usually stay away from roguelikes. This one's demo alone kept me in it for [i]two weeks[/i] before buying it. Definitely a good pickup for survival and roguelike veterans and newbies alike.

A fresh take on the old rouge-like with great new game play systems that integrate seamlessly into the genre we know and love.

The exploratory gameplay is engaging and nerve-wracking at the same time, and the unpredictable nature of events in the game means you'll spend much of your time simply trying to plan ahead for every contingency. This coupled with the constant threat of permanent death creates a very engaging experience.

It truly defines survival, a lot of times on fresh starts I'd freeze to death on the first night since I couldn't find proper clothing, now that's realistic. There's a lot of potential here and I can't wait to see what the devs do with it.

Well, if you're into games like FTL, or df in the way you pretty much lose no matter what, this is your game!

There are wolfdogs(kind of like a warewolf but dog instead....first encouter creature) and melonheads(science experiments gone wrong?), then you have good old raiders and looters. 8360015.review:
Half roguelike, half text adventure RPG/adventure game, NEO Scavenger is definitely something new.  I picked it up after watching a couple of YouTube videos, planned on playing for a few minutes, and found myself trying to beat a bandit to death with a rock while I coughed up blood.  Limping away from the fight, I died moments later from acute blood loss.

It's a brutal but phenomenal game.  It relies heavily on your own imagination which, in my opinion, makes it that much more powerful.  It is one of the only games that captures the bleakness and terror of the situation.  One moment you're strutting along with a shotgun in hand, a smile on your face, and the next, you're panicking because you drank contaminated water.  You're sick, coughing, vomiting, and it's all over.  

Phenomental, wonderful game and a great replayable experience.  Just be prepared to lose because it is a *difficult* game.

If you use melee skill, large branch, shard of glass and a shirt or cloth you'll get a broad spear that smacks guys around!)

Anyway the only thing I wish this had was weapon skills, so I can get more deadly and have a better chance to kill with a bow or gun. I understand that will NOT be part of the final build and although I want it I am fine with not having it. Items degrade pretty quickly, and there arent many stores to buy stuff so you have to make due with what you find. 

Another thing thats awesome is cooking. Lets just say I killed a raider, was starving, had no luck with my animal traps and had to make a "life" decision, do I die or do I cut up mr raider and cook him? 

Overall very impressed with the game and I'm enjoying every minute!

8144818.review:
This game is unlike any I have played in the last two decades. I recommend it to anyone who wants a turn-based hex RPG. Set in a post-apocolyptic Lovecraftian Michigan, your character emerges from a crygenic vat to step into a race against time. You can die from dehydration, starvation, disease  and hypothermia, in addition to wounds inflicted by the various denizens surrounding the Motor City's wastelands. 

This hard setting is further amplified by the decision not to include a leveling system. Each time you play, you learn more about the game mechanics and possibilities. You can augment your character with four of a dozen advantages, as well as about six disadvantages. Thes combination of these influence your play style, as some opportunities only present themselves to those with a given trait. 

For those who love to play first-person shooter "RPG" as murder hobos, this is not the game for you. It is more reminiscent of games from the late 1980s and early 1990s in that it tells its story in a piecemeal fashion with only one Rouge-like save option. While you can engage in combat, you will frequently die. Stealth, scavanging and crafting reveal much more of the story, and further contribute to the desperation as you try to unravel not only how you came to be cycled out of the cryogenics tank, but also what happened to create this near-future landscape. 

Expect to die a lot. And enjoy it.

8139661.review:
I think you have to be a little bit careful putting a blanket 'recommend' or not on a title like this. 

This is most defninitely not for everyone. 

If you are willing to 'do your homework', i.e., read the wiki, watch a few youtube vids, read the forums, ask a few questions there, then you are certainly in a position to find what I did. 

What I found was the most addictive, delightfully absorbing, strategic and tactical role-playing, survival game. It reminded me of my favourite gaming experience of all time, that of Fallout 2. 

However, the user interface, is not friendly nor intuitive. This is one step up from Dwarf Fortress. There's a lot of inventory micromanagement, and that involves a lot of clicks. 

There is a demo, which minus some items, is very similar to the main game, so I see no need for a long review. 

Just ask 'am I willing to put some effort in here?'. If you do a bit of homework, you will be very much rewarded. 

More of this sort of thing.

8030969.review:
One of the best survival games I have played; where it's a dog eats dog world. Hunger sets in if you don't consume food, you can die from dehydration, freeze to death, bleed to death, die from infection and poison; the odds are stacked against you. However, the same goes for everyone else in Neo Scavenger, as well. It isn't like other games, where they severly penalize you but the conditions does not effect the enemy. Far from it, scavengers you find along the way can bleed to their demise and freeze and perish in the cold if they have no clothing, just like the way you can in the given conditions.


If you pick this game up, be prepared to scream at times, and die countless more. Each death comes with learning to play better, and the learning curve is extremely steep. This game is literally based on Marxism, and it truly is a brutal, unforgiving atmosphere. Do not underestimate the enemy, and if you encounter two or more at once, do not be frugal. It's better to use that ammunition and live another day, than die and start over. Gear up and learn how to survive; and good luck.

7986971.review: If you ever wanted a game that blends Oregon Trail and Fallout but with total emphasis on player response-ability (yes I mean response-ability) then go try the demo of this game right now. Although brutal from the start (I survived 3 hours my first playthrough), the more you play this game and the more time you devote to figuring out what skills/items/reactions will help you survive depending on the given situation (Hint: run) the more satisfying it is when you reach the point of gun-toting, berry-eating, sleeping-bag-sleeping, Dogman slaying badass, ONLY to die of diarrhea (RIP colon). And in the total stupor of "how did... that... why?" begin another playthrough and start the whole brutal endeavor all over again- BUT this time ready to defeat the mutated Detroit Diarrhea of the future with the knowledge gleaned from your frothy death (Hint #2: boil your damn water). Excellent! Fine! Stupendous! Here we go again! Thanks to procedurally generated environments, the game feels fresh every time you restart it. New buildings to scavenge, new bandits to hoot and holler at, and the realization that the best weapon of all in this game isn't your .308 rifle with 2 bullets, but simply the knowhow to just run the hell away and live another night. I will recommend this game to anyone I give a damn about and use it as a litmus to test to see if I'll get a hold of them when the world goes to shit. Thanks for making this and keep making great games!

NEO Scavenger is the best roguelike to grace steam in some time. It's not about grinding, leveling up or anything like that. It's far more of a roguelike survival simulation. Only unlike Waywards island sim this game is more akin to the movie The Road or th S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. 

It's desperateand meaningful combat involves you sneaking around, pulling people down, parrying, stabbing, swinging and doing everything you can to win. While a win feels great, the person you're facing is often in the same shoes as you. 

As for graphics everything is nicely drawn. Icons are easy to see and understand, the world is big but easy to navigate, the hand drawn figures range from average to awesome. It's not the best looking game but it's got a gritty atmosphere about it and it works great with the music.

As for the sim part, this game just shines. Plastic bags will rip and you'll lose items, certain items can't be put into shopping carts because of the wholes in the frame, you'll be dumping pills out of small pill containers and putting them into larger ones so you can carry more. 

For a turn based game played on a hex grid, this is game can really get to you. I definitely suggest picking it up.

7961943.review:
Be prepared to die...a LOT!  And with "permadeath" that means you will be met with a black screen unceremoniously alerting you to your demise, manner of death and hours you managed to keep this poor guy alive.  Now, don't assume that this is put forth as a criticism because that is the appeal to this survival game.  After succumbing to the countless manners of death you begin to appreciate the fragility of humanity in this post-apocalyptic world.  Every decision begins to weigh on the player as you try to balance all the needs of survival.  I suppose there IS a way to "win" the game, though I've never seen it.  For me the appeal is simply the test to see how long you can stay alive while dodging the raiders, bandits, the elements, wild beasts, disease, dehydration, famine - I'm sure you get the point.  Go ahead and eat that rancid hunk of meat you found because the immediate fear of famine out-weighs the ramifications of food poisoning you will have to deal with tomorrow.  

This is an early access game so there will be problems.  The only bug I encountered was a turn bug that caused the time to keep clicking by until he just died.  Only happened to me once, but it was frustrating just the same.  The developer is aware of the issue and promises a fix.  There may also need to be a few play-balance adjustments because as I said it is really difficult to get deep into the game.  There are lots of interesting traits to choose when beginning the game, but honestly "toughness," "melee," and "strength" are the main ones you have to have or you will not survive the first night to even begin to utilize the other abilities.  Combat is unique and interesting once you figure out the order the text reads out, and how the interface deals with multiple enemies.  

This is a flash game with tons of depth.

7959906.review:
I went into this game hesitantly after doing some research on it and I haven't regretted it.  I'm a huge fan of survival/apocalypse type games and, although I'm not too keen on permadeaths and rogue-likes, in this game, it doesn't bother me as much.  NEO Scavenger is challenging and requires a lot of conservative thought if you hope to survive as every decision, every chioce and every action you make, matters.

As of writing this, the game is still in Early Access but it is definitely playable.  My only gripe is that combat is extremely stressful (well, for me it is) and I can't help but feel that the AI cheats.  Even when I do my utmost best to hide and cover my tracks to try and avoid combat it's almost as if the enemies are psychic and always find me regardless.

In my opinion it feels more like a simulation than a game, in that, sometimes I'm not having fun.  Situations will arise where I second and third-guess every move I make and wonder if the next turn will be my last.  Sometimes I'm under so much duress I need to take a break to let my adrenaline subside.  Not that this is a bad thing, mind you.  I suppose I just get too immersed. 

NEO Scavenger is a great game and I recommend it to anyone who enjoys the hardcore survival genre.

7947395.review: I got this game AGES ago when it was MUCH less complete than it is now, and even then it was great. Since then, the game has grown by leaps and bounds, and with every new build it gets better. A post apocalyptic setting that isnt just an irradiated desert makes for an interesting environment with a lot more options. The crafting system has so much depth its rediculous. Countless items, weapons, ingredients, great resource management elements, weather systems, and a story that will slowly but surely draw you in. Permadeath is a bummer, but you can always reload a previous save. However, chosing to start again with new traits and skills is just as rewarding, with a new experience with each new game. Even the opening moments of the game will change depending on your chosen traits. I can not reccomend this game highly enough.

7947256.review: Amazing. Can't wait for it to be fully done.

7939486.review:
This is my first experience with a 'serious' roguelike, and I have to say that I'm extremely impressed.  The exploratory gameplay is exciting and nerve-wracking at the same time, and the unpredictable nature of events in the game means you'll spend much of your time simply trying to plan ahead for every contingency.  This coupled with the constant threat of permanent death creates a very engaging experience.

If I had to point out a flaw, it would be that the interfaces are generally not very streamlined, which can slow down your gameplay a little bit, depending on what you're doing.

7934038.review:
I've been playing this game throughout it's development and it quickly became one of my favorite PC games. The game presents you with near limitless ways to approach and handle situations. Food, water, energy, and the environment are all factors that will determine your survival in-game. The combat is slow-paced and challenging, yet rewarding when you manage to win a fight. I can't recommend this game enough. Also, if this game looks interesting to you, try the demo!
-Full Release Update: It only got better. Fixes, improvements, more content. Everything you could ask for from a small developer and a shining beacon of what Early Access games should be like.

7933945.review: I've played this game on and off for nearly two years. I've followed it's development since it was first announced, and every time I come back I fall in love again. This game combines the brutality of dwarf fortress, the atmosphere of fallout, and world layout of civ to create a true masterpiece. This game is in a class of it's own.
